Awesome stout. Strong alcohol nose with hops chocolate cherry and coffee, complex. Taste is chocolate covered cherries some hops toasty coffee and faint alcohol. Gets better as it warms up 60 degrees f or a little warmer is best to bring out the cherry and chocolate flavors to balance the bitterness and tastings of the malts.
From a bottle. Pours very dark brown with a very thin tan head. Smells like dry ash and roasted coffee. Tastes very dry and earthy, lightly roasted. Light body and low/medium carbonation.
Bottle. Pours dark opaque brown with toffee colored head. Aroma of smoke and coffee. Taste of fresh roasted coffee.
bottle with a newer label has a deep black pour, thin tan head. black coffee, faint dark chocolate. mild astringency.light body.

Rating 1,000! Pours a deep black/brown with a dark tan head. Aroma of roasted coffee and cocoa with a smokey note mixed in. Mouthfeel is thick. Taste is smoked throughout. Extremely so. ItÂ’s almost like sitting next to a live fire while drinking a stout. A pronounced hop finish blends with the smokiness to remove any of the sour notes typical at the end of dark stouts. Finish is also very dry. It could use a little bit of sweetness to counterbalance the smoke and bitterness, but itÂ’s definitely distinctive.

Bottle. Pours black with medium almost fluffy tan to ruby colored head, good lacing. Smell is piney hops, roasted...almost burnt coffee, chocolate, oatmeal, and vanilla extract. Taste is dark bitter chocolate, cocoa, roasted coffee, oats, hint of smoke, and hop bitterness in the background giving a bit of grapefruit and orange notes. Carbonation medium to low, oily texture. Balance seems a bit off, but not bad.

Poured from bottle into tulip glass. Jet black pour, almost no head. Coffee aroma and not much else. Flavor is more bitter and less sweet than I was expecting (especially compared to BGBW). Roasted coffee and bitter chocolate. Moderate smoke undertone that is layered through the entire brew. It's there, but never center stage or overpowering. Surprisingly drinkable. Very good. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast. 7,5% kÃ¸bt mikkeller.com pris 40 kr. Duft: kaffe,Kaffe,kaffe, sÃ¸dme, ristetbrÃ¸d, chokolade, Fylde: stor fylde. Smag: kaffe ristet malt, noget bitter i smagen
Mejor birra del estilo stout que ya probÃ©. En la casa de Martun, donada por el Flaco. Nota 10!

Bottle: super deep & black, inky & oily pour with a mocha, slightly gray-tinted head that settles quite nicely. Aroma contains sweet smoke, coffee beans, roasted malt, & a light finish of caramel-y sweetness. Faint cocoa & dry oats, but the smokiness is fairly dominant. Taste is similar with a strong smoke-y flavor, lightly sweet, all the way through, Underneath lies some faint, roasted coffee beans, roasted malt, & a finish of bitter cocoa. Light undercurrent of sweetness, leading into a cocoa & smoky finish. Very nice brew, even though I wasnÂ’t expecting all of the smoke. Luckily I like smoked beers.

Bottle thanks to Nick! Black thick pour with a small dark brown head. Smell is muted coffee, roasted malts, and slight bitter chocolate. Taste is straight black coffee... Wow I donÂ’t think I have ever had a coffee stout like this. I might not be able to sleep tonight. Other than coffee, I get some nice roasted character, bitter cocoa, and hop bitterness. Nice thick mouth feel, good carbonation.
Poured from a bottle itbis an almost black beer with s large foamy tan head. The atoma is of coffee and the taste is delightfully coffee with a very strong roast finish ejivh lingers on the palate.

From a 33 cl bottle shared at home. Pours black with a thick tan head. Aroma of coffee. Flavors of coffee, licorice and chicory. Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, bitter finish (but not as bitter as the Beer Hop Breakfast version),

Bottle 330ml.
Pours jet black with low brown head. Nice lacing. Aroma is of chocolate, roasted malt, coffee (beads), slight vegetal stuff. Taste is of chocolate, coffee, bitterness, alcohol (not too well hidden). Palate: Full bodied. Thick. Somewhat sticky. Overall: Pretty good. Lots of coffee. Pretty bitter. Not cloying.

Truly fantastic stout. Rich and luxurious. Black body with thick mid-brown head. Aroma as expected with coffee, cocoa, toffee and flavour follows this but with the alcohol warmth and a good hop bitterness to finish off. Up there with the De Molen Rusian stout series and that is praise indeed.

330ml bottle. Pours black with a brown foam head and aroma of malt, oats, chocolate, coffee, roasty. Taste is similar, sweet malty, with oats, chocolate and roast coffee notes plus some hop bitterness. Smooth mouthfeel, full bodied, soft carbonation, roasted dry bitter finish. Well balanced and very drinkable.

Bottle from Brewdog shop. Black color, white head. Bitter taste with coffee, chocolate, licorice, roasted malts, oats, nuts and a bit of vanilla. Bitter finish with coffee, oats and roasted malts. Excellent stout.

Bottle 0,33l. Pours a dark brown with a tan head that settles quickly. Aroma is heavy on malts with chocolate and coffee in the end. Flavor is very roasty with mocha, and a mildly bitter finish. Palate is lighter than expected but very creamy.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a Deep black with a dark brown head. Aromas of coffe, roast. Taste is coffee bitter, malty. Decent bittering hops as well. Finishes pretty dry for what it is. Very good.

FROM NOTES: June 29, Â’12
Served in cellar temerature from a 22 ounce bottle into brandy snifter. 

A: Espresso, roasted malt, dark chocolate notes and a little bit of yeast and alcohol. 
A: Pours pitch black with a big creamy, foamy light-brown head. 
T: Strong roasted malt with notes of chocolate. Strong coffee taste but blended well with other tastes. This goes down dangerously well. Very robust flavors. 
P: Thick and full bodied, yet so smooth. Velvety smooth and absolute delight! 
O: This is the best coffee stout IÂ’ve had in a very long time, maybe ever. While it is, in fact, an imperial oatmeal stout, the intricate mix of malts lends itself to an excellent mouth-feel and velvety smooth taste. I have to say that Mikkeller succeeded in creating a truly smooth and delicious beer.
Very thick and mouthfilling beer, gets better and better when warming. Well balanced and unique.

330ml bottle from the Drink Shop, Tallinn. Black colour, small brown head. Very roasty aroma of lots of coffee with notes of smoke, chocolate, nuts, leather and oatmeal, bitter burnt taste. Extremely full body and oily mouthfeel, light carbonation, roasty bitter finish. Quite a tasty and peculiar creation with an awesome body.

330 ml bottle. Pours black with a short lived beige-brown head. Aroma is coffee, vanilla, hazelnut. Flavor is tons of coffee, black licorice, dark chocolate. Very dry. Finish is very bitter coffee. Dry as heck. Medium to strong body, weak to absent carbonation. Good.

Pours deep black revealing a bitter, fizzante stout full of coffee that no doubt goes well with breakfast. An espresso shot for alcoholics!

Rated by BrewTom

Pitch black beer with cinnamon coloured and quite big head. Very dark aroma, lots of coffee, dark chocolate and salty licorice. After the first sip, you can taste sweet dark chocolate and then lots of roasted malts and coffee. Roasted flavors dry your mouth and the after taste is pretty long. Really full body, it was like drinking oil. Totally awesome coffee stout!

Bottle. Pours a thick dark black color with a small java head, Nose is oatmeal and chocolate. Taste is rich oatmeal, coffee and chocolate, and thick on the palate. Finish is dry and full of flavor, with a somewhat tart chocolate vanilla finish. Another great brew from Mikkeller. Quaff Score 8 / 10

Pours pitch black with a brown head and aroma of oatmeal and chocolate. Taste is roasty and sweet, tons of chocolate, oatmeal, coffee, light vanilla, and smokey, roasty tones with a chocolatly finish. Delicious, very drinkable stout

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2014 Bottle 330ml @ home from polet. 

Pours black with small head. Aroma of dark coffee, chocolate and roasted barley. Tastes plenty dark coffee, a little chocolate and then some more coffee! Just a little bitter in the end. Pretty thick stuff, with little carbonation. Maybe to much coffee for me in this one, but still an excellent beer.

side by side tasting with the beer hop breakfast. poured pitch black with a creamy brown-ish head. espresso coffee, malts, verry creamy mouthfeel. dark chocolate. no bitterness at all compared to the hop breakfast. for me this one was best of the 2
PiÄ™kna brÄ…zowa piana, zapach mocnej kawy z lekkimi cytrusami, w smaku kawowa goryczka przechodzÄ…ca w kawowÄ… kwaÅ›noÅ›Ä‡.
Bottle - Chocolate and dark coffee roast. Jet black with a great brown head. Tons of coffee and dark roast malts. Nice body and good finish. A good coffee beer.

Feb. 2012 vintage 500 ml bottle from nabbirra, served in a Teku glass. Pitch black with no light passing through, ligh brown-ish head that leaves wonderful lacing. Huge coffee aroma with some herbal/grassy hoppy notes, light liquorice, leather, some burnt wood and bitter chocolate. Taste is obviosuly powerful and bitter coffee, rich dark chocolate and roasted malts. It has a creamy and lightly chewy texture but itÂ’s still extremely drinkable, even though the alchool isnÂ’t exacty well hidden. Nice coating sensation on the lips after a sip. Overall, a fantastic oatmeal stout.

Bottle from Belmont Station. Pours black with a thin light brown head. Aroma of molasses, coffee, and licorice. Taste is incredible! Toasty grains, coffee, molasses, and a bitter finish. Full smooth body. This one knocked my socks off!
Immediately smell the coffee. This beer is fairly bitter, a strong stout but not overly thick and not particularly creamy.
Unmistakable classic. Incredible coffee flavour in a nice thick stout. Not too creamy, just roasted and coffee notes.

Bottle. Dark brown with a tan head that settles quickly. Aroma is heavy on malts with coffee in the background. Flavor is very roasty with mocha and a mildly bitter finish. Palate is lighter than expected but very creamy.

12 oz bottle poured into a snifter. Big roasty nose of burnt malt, coffee & bitter dark chocolate. Thick & chewy mouthfeel. Bitter flavor of coffee and dark chocolate. Oatmeal present. Big hops throughout. Not the smoothest, but what I expected.

Has a subtle chocolate aroma and pours a lovely dark chocolate. With a nice creamy brown head. Goes down smooth with a nice chocolate and oat finish.
Sweet chocolate and coffee aroma. Black as hitlers soul in color with a darken brown thin head. Very balanced coffee and vanilla with a creamy finish.

Bottle from Cave a Bulles in Paris. Bottled in February 2012.

Aroma: Initial classic porter roastiness (freshly baked brown bread and roasted coriander) gives the stage to a strong, yet pleasant alcohol presence. True to the info provided by the guys in the shop, coffee aroma is very subdued and barely audible. 

Taste: Much less sweet than expected. Alcohol, so prominent in the aroma, is nowhere to be found. Coffee note, on the other hand, is quite accented, but doesnÂ’t overpower the mouth feel and contributes well to the overall roasty profile. 
In addition, here we are dealing with a strong, black and well-roasted coffee.Flaws? Well, the body feels a bit thin, wouldÂ’ve loved it to be a thicker and chewier brew.

A very good brew, the least complex and, for the lack of better word, the most laid back of the Mikkeller RIS offerings I had thus far. And this is a good thing, if you ask me.
I would really like to try a more fresh bottle, to see how it compares.

Hmm, for a rich breakfast, roast coffe, little caramel and dark as night. Batch 766c. Why drink coffee?

Black colour, tan dissipating head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, caramel, mocha, light hops. Malty flavour, lots of coffee, bitter coffee and roasted malts. Bitter coffee finish, roasted malts. Nice.

Nice toasty aroma of roasted peanuts. Almost peanut brittle like. Pours black in the glass. Straight up coffee flavor with some cocoa. Overall, A tasty complex brew. Thanks to BarZigKin for his generosity!
Pours black, fantastick brown lasting head. Aroma is roasted hoppy coffe, with spices. Roasted coffe, spicy leathery tast with oily, smooth texture. Medium long bitter finish. I like..

Bottle. Pours with a thick brown head. Aroma has rich coffee notes on top molasses and pine. The flavor is strongly of coffee; pine and herbal bitter; not very sweet at all. The feel is thick and lively with a slightly pine astringent end. Really good, especially as it warms.

This pours black with a creamy, brown head. There is a mild aroma of coffee. The taste is slightly bitter with a creamy, coffee mixture. I was expecting a little thicker texture as this was thinner than I imagined. Finished slightly bitter.
Mild coffee beer. Good aftertaste that makes this beer enjoyable. Not too dry. Follow me @ Kung av Ã¶l @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2014 Black with very small tan head. Aroma is coffee and oatmeal smell. Taste is big mouthfeel, caramel then strong roasted bitterness; lots going on here. Palate is bitterness - maybe too much for me. Overall a great stout here but maybe a little too astringent for me.

A very dark brown beer, with a disapointing light brown head. It is hard to create and disapears quickly. 0,33L bottle. Black cofee color with nice cappuccino hat. Dirty, old coffee bean aroma. Taste is good fatty. Old coffee grain is so nice and tastless and what pleasurable bitter center and end. Good!

Pours an opaque, very dark brown, with just some hints of cola brown where light can pass through the bottom edge of the glass. A gigantic, sudsy, mocha-tan head forms, but dissipates relatively quickly, given itÂ’s size. Large aroma of both brewed coffee and fresh coffee grounds. Some chocolate liqueur in there as well. Smokiness emerges early. Some burnt flavors intermittently appear. The smoky after taste really lingers. Surprising that this is only 7.5%. It drinks like an big imperial.

Bottle from Ã¶llepood tartu. Dark almost black thick stuff with Not much head. Roasted and bitter. Long aftertaste. Hint of coffee. I barely notice.

Great coffee stout. Lives up to the hype, in my opinion. Roasted malt and coffee aromas. Very dark with a small head as this had some age on it and a good deal of sediment at the bottom. Smooth texture but not heavy. Somewhat dry finish, which I attribute to the coffee. Strong roasted flavor with a hint of oat and coffee with maybe a touch of chocolate but not too much to make this a dessert beer. IÂ’ll have another.

Bottle, brewed in 2012. Pours a pitch black, opaque beer with a big, beige head on top. Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, caramel and some oak. Flavour is nicely bitter, some sweet caramel touches in there as well. Long lasting, sharp bitter aftertaste with a sweet finish. Low carbonation, oily mouthfeel. Full bodied. Awesome beer.
Lukt av karamell. mild rÃ¸kt lukt. Svart i farge med flott beige skum. Smak av kaffe og brent mokka. Mektig Ã¸l med mye smak.
Sort med lys brunt skum som ligger godt. Lukter brendt sjokolade og karamell. Bitter sjokolade, ettersmak som sitter lenge.

4 euros from Drink Shop. Mikkeller Brewed At Lervig Aktiebryggeri, Norway. 7.5% thick viscous motor oil pour with a deep tan head with great lacing. The aroma is roast coffee beans all over the place. Nice thick creamy mouthfeel. The taste is very dark bitter coffee. As I am not a coffee drinker this isnÂ’t really my thing. Nicely made though. For those who like their coffee black.

Tap @ fairbar, 15/8 2013. Pitch black, small tan head, okay lacing. Aroma, roasted malts, lots of chocolate and coffee, slight notes of hops. Taste, roasted malts, coffee and lots of it, bitter chocolate, licorice, . Bitter dry aftertaste of cold coffee and licorice. Just a great well balanced coffee stout.

Bottle at home. Pours black with a small dark brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Taste is of roasted malt, hops, coffee, chocolate and smoke. Body is a bit above medium. Long bitter aftertaste of coffee and smoke. Not bad but not fantastic either, but I would happily drink again.

Bottle @home, from Mikkeller & Friends Bottle shop. Pours pitch black with a nice creamy tan head. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, vanilla, slight peat, bacon fat, brown sugar. Taste is chocolate, coffee, bacon fat, peat. Mouthfeel is dry yet creamy at the same time. Very good!

Bottle. Poured black with a creamy tan head that settled to a ring and left good lace. Big roast coffee aroma. The flavor found lots of roasted malt and coffee with a backing of hops. Med to full body and a bitter coffee aftertaste.

Black with a brown head. Aroma: Coffee, chocolate, dark fruits, slightly hoppy, leather, earthy and roasty. Taste: Much more intense on the coffee! Very bitter coffee and hop flavours, bit of a soy taste as well. Licorice and salt. Thick texture, fizzy carbonation and a bitter finish. Amazing. Understandable that this beer helped put Mikkeller on the map, I could imagine it being a tad too bitter for some peoples tastes, but IÂ’m loving it.

Bottle. Smokey oat, coffee aroma. Black body with tan head, medium lasting body, nice lacing. Flavor begins sweet, with notes of chocolate, coffee and oats. Followed by a nice hint of hops. Sweet, bitter finish.

Black colour with a large dark head. Aroma of roasted malt with chocolate and coffee and a strong flavour of dried berries and milk chocolate. Taste of roasted malt with coffee beans, dark chocolate and berries. Thick and dry palate and a full body. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours dark black with minimal head. Aroma of smoke, chocolate, and hops. Taste is smoky peat, chocolate and funk. Deliciouso.
Bottle..Pour is dark with a tan ..Nose is chocolate, spice, coffee, spice..Taste is coffee, chocolate, Spice, dry, nice boldness..

Bottle, new 12oz bottle, 08/03/2013. Pours dark brown, dense frothy dark tan head, thick lacing. Aroma is thick coffee, wet grounds and dark bakerÂ’s chocolate, lighter chocolate malts and oatmeal. Taste is dark roasted grounds, acidic, dark chocolate and char, intensely bitter, almost smoky aftertaste. Medium thick body. Coffee taste is a bit strange here, not as enjoyable as those original batches. Still decent nonetheless.
Bottle poured into a snifter, thin black pour with a small tan head. Nose is a bit odd, some coffee, oats, maybe a little funk. Not bad but Founders BS is a better choice.

Bottle (500 ml). 1+ years old. From Kevin, thanks! Black with a medium mostly lasting brown head and some lacing. Aroma is of roasted malt, coffee, caramel, grassy notes, dark chocolate and light sweetness notes. Taste is slightly to moderately sweet with coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, light herbal notes and light bitterness. Medium body. Smooth and silky mouthfeel. Moderate carbonation. Good coffee Stout, well balanced. It would probably be very different fresher, but probably no better (or at least not much better). Coffee is still very present.
Pours black with yellow head. Smooth creamy chocolate with woody finish. Slight bitter taste. Great beer

Admittedly, this beer was drank a bit later on the evening, but, given that this is the top rated stout, I expected a touch more. Pours black with a head that is whiter than expected. Scent is coffee and cocoa. THICK. In my opinion the finish seemed overly bitter. Going to have to give this beer the opportunity to be the first beer of the evening, as opposed to the last. Bottle - Grassroots Natural Market - Jacksonville, FL

Bottle.
Pitch black, not thin nor oil type thickness. Adequate mocha head.
Rich malts, fresh coffee, no burnt characteristics. Clean coffee up front, mellow co2 feel comes alive, finish of rich dark chocolate as if just biting into a candy bar. Coffee harmoniously blends with malts for a match made in heaven. Hops shine in linger taste of citrus/floral. First brew from Mikkeller; highly impressed.

Smells like walking into a cafe at breakfast time, strong coffee aroma. Jet black with a thin creamy head. Light chocolate, bitter coffee and oats. Light carbonation and smooth mouthfeel. Favourite beer and oatmeal stout IÂ’ve had so far. Bottle from Mikkeller Bar Copenhagen.
Black with dark tan head, aroma was almost all coffee, lots of coffee flavor with some chocolate roasty flavor in there, fairly bitter. Mouthfeel was a bit thin for me.

Poured in a medium size wineglass.
Stong aroma of cofee with burned nots. Black color with a small brown head. Taste is a potent dark chocolate, smokey, cofee and oat. Finish is long... really long... Overall very good :-)
11.2 oz bottle. Black color and coffee aroma. Very strong coffee taste that lingers. The strong coffee taste was a little too much for me.

Bottle pour into pint..black color with dark tan head..nose of good coffee..chocolate and licorice..light mouthfeel..taste is like slightly bitter cold press coffee with slight spice..creamy almost and could pass for straight coffee..chunks appear on bottom of glass that are rather large..good tasting but a bit thinner than anticipated..
UPDATED: AUG 7, 2013 Pours black with nice brown head, aroma and taste are rich roasted coffee and light bitter, finish is a bit thin and sweet, nice beer

Pours black with a foamy brown head. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, leather - a very rich, semi-sweet stout aroma. Flavor is bitter chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, with a somewhat dry, bitter finish. Coffee really comes through as it warms. Smooth, moderately oily on palate. Comes together beautifully.

500ml at my place with Taylor Thomas Scott and Erin. Aroma of coffee and burnt malt. Taste of coffee, light chocolate. Lasting rich coffee chocolaty finish. Medium heavy mouthfeel. Great beer, much better warmer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Hearty espresso, dark roast on the coffee aroma. Smells nice. Bitter coffee and baker's chocolate on the palate. Body needs work though: too much carb and too thin. Solid stuff.

Bottle. Pitch, pitch black with a small light brown head. Aroma is dominated by chocolate and coffee. A nice balance of bitterness and sweetness. Dark malts, almost some smokey notes.
Taste is fantastic. Coffee, chocolate, dark, dark licorice, roasted and burned characteristics. Mouthfeel is lower side of full, but nicely creamy from the oats. The aftertaste is definitely a bitter coffee taste thatÂ’s simply lasts forever. ThatÂ’s how it should be! An extremely nice example of how a coffee stout should be like. Loads of dark, roasted impressions, no hints of the alcohol. One of MikkellerÂ’s best! If there was a bigger sweet component from some dark fruits perhaps, this would be close to perfect

Bottle

Appearance: Oily black

Aroma: Fresh coffee, hint of smoke, chocolate

Taste: Very well orchestrated blend of coffee, chocolate, dark malts. No single component stands out other than the coffee, which is not overly dominant

Palate: Extremely smooth mouthfeel. Minimal carbonation. Mouth coating goodness

Overall: Excellent coffee stout. WnB is comparable, but this seems to end up more integrated, and with no acidity.
Aroma Dark chocolate malts, chili, coffee,bacon, nutty and smokey. The pallete is wonderful thick and buttery bitter. Over all a wonderful beer.

Bottle @ Home. Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, light vanilla. Flavor is rich roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, cocoa, vanilla. Full body, creamy mouthfeel, soft carbonation. 170810

coffee coloured head that disappears quite fast with some lacing. coffee colour. viscous pour. aroma is earth, hop and coffee. taste is coffee with a long bitterness. quite dense mouthfeel, soft carbonation and medium body. does get a bit boring after a while.  2013 version / bottle 33 cl

Bottle poured into a snifter. Thin black pour with a foamy tan head. Coffee, chocolate, malt smells when you crack open the bottle. medium bodied and thin. Very roasty taste to like a strong black coffee. Bitter finish hangs around it. Not as much chocolate. Good, not great
Bottle at Bishop Arms, SkÃ¶vde. Black beer with a big brown head. Coffee, chocolate aroma with smokey notes. Coffee, chocolate and smoked flavour.

Thanks for the share, Jordan. This beer had a very dark body to it along with some great tan head retention. Aromas revealed coffee and a porter-like earthiness. Flavors were all coffee and bold stout with a smooth chocolate finish. Straight-forward delicious and easy on the palate.

Bottle from Grapevine Wine and Spirits. Check them out!! Nose is big, full roasted coffee, light molasses, a touch of soy/oxidation, chocolate malts, dry cocoa. Dark black, oily pour. Oily palate. Thick roasted coffee flavors and dry cocoa notes behind burnt sugars and light hops. Nice brew.

Bottle @ ElfoÂ’s Pub, Perugia, Italy. Pours with a pitch black colour; short lasting minimal brown head. Aroma has strong notes of coffee and licorice, dark chocolate, cocoa and roasted malt; quite hoppy, with notes of herbs and grass. taste is light to moderate sweet, moderately bitter, a bit salty. Medium body, very smooth and oily texture, average to lively carbonation, long lasting bitter finish.

11.2 oz bottle to oversized snifter. Looks good; black with thin tan head that dissipates into lacing fairly quickly. Smells of dark malt, roasty coffee, and chocolate with oat notes. Tastes like it smells, only roastier, to the point that itÂ’s not as smooth IÂ’d prefer. Good, not great.
Bottle from Rehills, Newcastle. An inky black beer with a bright brown coloured head. Very rich coffee flavours are followed by chocolate and roasted notes with a dry coffee finish. Excellent!
Black body, brown head. Aroma has roasted malts and really nice Intensive coffee aroma. some Medicinal hops. Flavour is bit sweet which is surprising. really thick and oily. excellent beer.

500 ml bottle not sure if i should be cracking this at night...all well. Big dark pour, lots of tan head smells fantastic, bits of hops, coffee, roasted malts and some sweetness. Ah man what a great beer, combines a lot of different flavours effortlessly without any one overtaking the beer. Up front there is a bit of sweetness, has a very smooth texture, rounds out with some roasted malts and a hit of nice but not overpowering coffe flavour. Now I need to try a weasel. Stat.

New 12 oz bottle. Pours an opaque black with thick mocha head and beautiful blanket lace. Nose is dark roasted coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, peat, spice. Full bodied and creamy, tons of roast. If you like roasty stouts this is top notch.

On tap @ Animal. Black colour with a tan head, with a medium lasting and nice lacework. Aroma is black chocolate, mainly coffee, light hoppy. Flavor is strong black coffee with a good duration, chocolate, licorice and roasted malts. The final is very compensated between alcohol and coffee notes. Smooth, rounded and creamy on palate.

Pours a deep black with a tan head. The aroma is filled with roasted coffee and nuts. A very light body puts the flavor up front. Bitter, but not overly so, with a little chocolate up front and then gobs of delicious coffee at the end.

Purchased at Discount Liquors in Milwaukee, WI; enjoyed at home the day after the Blackhawks won the cup. Fantastic oatmeal stout, probably the best IÂ’ve had yet. Appearance is a thick pitch black with a rich tan head that rims around the glass. Aroma is robust in roasted chocolate, oat, rich dark roast coffee / espresso, very subtle hop spiciness, smell is fantastic. Taste is even better. The coffee flavor is exceptional, and mixes well with the chocolate to offer something more dry than sweet, very easy to drink but is definitely more of a dessert brew. Awesome awesome stuff!

Pours black with a frothy, tan head that lingers and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is roasted malts, oats, dark chocolate and coffee. Taste starts with sweet toasted malts, chocolate, oats and ends with hops and coffee. Mouthfeel is medium thickness and creamy. Well rounded. Great flavor. Thanks for Sharing JB. Held up great for being cellared over 3 years.

Pours pitch black(opaque) with an initial large creamy head then settles to a thick ring around the glass and leaves moderate lace. Aroma consists of gourmet coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate, and licorice. Flavour is coffee, cocoa, roasted malts, licorice, mildly bitter I assume from some hops and the roasted malts. Nice velvety mouth feel with a great coffee flavour. This beer is everything they say about it, it is great with breakfast and likely the best beer IÂ’ve had to date with coffee in it.

Pours an opaque black with a frothy brown head that leaves lots of sticky lace. Aroma coffee, cream and sweet oatmeal. Taste is coffee, cream, bitter cocoa. Mouth feel has moderate carbonation and oatmeal give a nice slick mouthfeel that makes like drinking a creamy coffee.
Had this one after a rough night... Good replacement for my usual morning coffee. Loads of coffee flavor, a little oatmeal and chocolate.. really good.

Black color, small brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate and licorice. Taste is dry sweet with bitter finish and long coffee aftertaste. Full body, soft carbonation. Nice full-flavored stout.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2013 Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours thick and black with a centimeter of bronze head. Smooth and full-bodied without being overly carbonated. Heavy chocolate and coffee notes on the nose with an added sweetness of caramel. Silky smooth - drinks almost like a milkshake, and hides the booze very well. Finishes with a nice, lingering bitterness. A hulking, ebony monstrosity of an oatmeal coffee stout that without a doubt stands shoulder to shoulder with some of the best.

Pours black with a thick brown head. Aroma is wicker basket with chocolate in the background. Taste is smooth burnt malts with a chocolatey background. A lot of stuff going on in this one. Picking up fig, tamarindo, but no coffee. This is an example of a truly complex stout. Dark bitter finish.

They say that Pope Paul III fell on his knees when Michelangelo finally unveiled the completed Last Judgment at the Sistine Chapel. Before trying this much hyped beer, I was very sceptical of its artsy-fartsiness, especilly by those coffee grains figured on the appalling label. Ready to snigger with despise, I had to concede that the appearance was perfect, and the aroma was only above average. But when I finally drank it, I fell on my knees and cried, asking for forgiveness and most thanking all the Gods for this opportunity. The new ones and the old ones.

Pours thick black with a thin tan head. Aroma is weird and off, but the taste is crazy roasted coffee with a dry bitterness aftertaste and some kind of mossy peat notes.that isnÂ’t too pleasant.. I see the great ratings on this, maybe I got a bad bottle? Not that great but decent.
Medium brown head. Black as the night. Cocoa and coffee on the nose. Taste of burned coffee and cocoa. Mouthfeel is amazing for this one, almost milky. Really nice stout.
UPDATED: APR 1, 2015 Pours opaque black colour with tan head, almost brown. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, roasted. Taste is the same, also bitter. Full body, soft carbonation.
Bottle.Pours  black with a little head.  Tons of. coffee,  chocolate and peat on the no se and it dominates the taste.  smooth,  thick beer,  just awesome mouthfeel.

330ml bottle - pours deep brown with nutty brown head and great lacing  Nose is milk chocolate, coffee and nuts.  Flavor enhances the coffee notes giving it a more roasted character.  I wouldnÂ’t have this for breakfast because I like my morning coffee to be hot.  Fairly gritty like coffee is when the filter is of pour quality.  Hides the 7.5% very well.  bitter like black coffee.  Makes me think of what Turkish coffee would be like, if served cold.  Becomes a little sweeter as it warms.

Pours deep and dark with a big brown frothy head. Aroma of chocolate, big roast, dried fruits, and a big hop presence. Not a lot of coffee on the nose. Coffe and hops come up front, with a HUGE blast of roasted bittersweet chocolate. Lingering cocoa and sweet fruit left on the palate. Relatively high carbonation for the style, bur still retains a nice silkiness. Bitter really lasts. Nice stout that sits somewhere on the flavor profile scale between Plead the 5th and Darkness, with focus on the bitter cocoa and with less chewiness.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours black with 2cm of creamy mocha head. Aroma is espresso, chocolate, soy and roasty malts. Taste is rich, lots of espresso and chocolate dance across the palate with an extremely smooth carbonation and full body.  Nice lingering bitterness. Does what it says it does, but it was definitely an unforgettable stout.

Bottle at Mikkeler Bar. Pours beautifully black with a dark brown head. Aroma of coffee, malts, very smooth. Little carbonation, medium body. Perfect stout, lots of coffee, little chocolate, long aftertaste.

Bottle at Sybarite Pig in Boca Raton. Tulip. Very black, thick pour with mocha two finger head. Waited to warm it some. Aroma is Pete, coffee, chocolate and roasted malts. Taste was complex, yet simply delightful. Coffee, Pete, chocolate nibs, roasted malts, and hops to match. Very well balanced. The oatmeal adds a creaminess. Very very good.

500ml served into a 22oz. snifter.

A - Blacker than black body with 1.5 fingers of espresso frappe than produces layers of lacing around the glass.

S - Rich chocolates-milk and dark, roasted/smoked malts, fresh coffee with cream, earthy wood, alcohol vapors.

T - Roasted chocolate malts, espresso oils, spicy hops surround the flavors adding good bitterness. Hints of unknown fruit seem to be lurking. Woody undertones create a semi-rough and earthy layer. Has a dry and acidic roasty finish.

M - Full body with creamy carbonation. Smooth and oily feel with a dry roasted finish.

Very focused flavor profile. The coffee and chocolate sing together while the roast adds great balance. Woody undertones and light fruit add character as well.
A very well crafted stout.
I would love to swap this for my morning coffee.

Serving type: bottle

04-06-2012
Black pour with a dark tan head. Oats and coffe in the aroma. Flavor is loaded with coffee and roasted malts, some chocolate comes through as well.
Tap at Kaisla, Helsinki. Colour is deep black with medium brownish white head. Aromas and flavours: Massive coffee, dark chocolate, some sweetness, hops, bread and roasted malts. Fabulous beer.

New 11.2oz bottle. 

A: Pours in an oil-like manner. ThereÂ’s plenty of bubbles cascading through this, and itÂ’s got a 1/2" of separating mocha head. Dark mahogany - looks good.

N: Oatmeal, hop leafs, roasted malt, and coffee. Dark chocolate and espresso. Well rounded on the nose here.

T: Very bitter with lots of roasted malt/smoke. Has a fair amount of bakerÂ’s chocolate but thereÂ’s only a very moderate sweetness. Which works for the beer as itÂ’s definitely meant to emulate the coffee side of things. Has a little rye spice in here.

M: Medium-heavy body with a good amount of carbonation. The oats add an excellent roundness to this. Seems about right for the style.

O: Ended up really enjoying this. I donÂ’t remember the previous batches being quite as good, so IÂ’ve shied away from this, but IÂ’ll be more tempted to buy it in the future.
lot of coffee aroma, toast,   hops.    clear black color with a heavy brown head.  a long bitter taste.

22oz bomber. Pours pitch black, with a huge thick mocha head. Aroma is big on the coffee, roasted malts and a hint of chocolate. Tastes of bitter coffee, deep roasted malts, char, with slight notes of oatmeal and dark fruit. Really rich and silky.

Pretty epic beer. Strong roasted coffee notes on the nose with a strong tang of bitterness. Continues in the mouth with a deep coffee richness and an oily mouth feel. Deep flavour that has a very long finish. Excellent and complex.

Bottle. This beer is fantastic! Pours a slick and oily black body, thing brown/white head, a really overpowering but enjoyable espresso-like aroma, slick and heavy to tongue, tastes sweet syrupy with a very complex chocolate/coffee taste which starts really smooth and sweet and seeps down the back of your throat into a dark and crisp finish. Again, this beer is just fantastic, its full bodied flavour is really really lovely, this is one which stout fiends like myself will adore!

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2013 Bottle fom Lervig. Coffee aroma. Dark black color and thick head. Tastes coffee and a little bit of chocolate. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

15 month old bottle poured into snifter. Nogne version.  Beige head.  Viscous black.  Slightly floral smell - smells good for a stout.  Taste - Big roasted barley, some coffee, slightly floral finish with some whisky notes.  Becomes very smooth and chocolately if itÂ’s given a bit of time to breathe.

Very nice coffee aroma.  Dark black color, nice thick head.  Frothy head, but watery texture to the beer.  The taste is mostly coffee, with some grains, vegetable and dark chocolate all chipping in.    A nice beer, but I think too much coffee for my taste.

2012 1 PT .9 fl oz bottle poured into tulip.  Pours a nice deep black with a 1/4" thick head.  Aroma is mainly coffee and dark chocolate, with, of course, roasted malts.  Taste is light-medium bitter coming from the roasted aspect with a slightly sour finish (again coming from the roast).  Body is rather medium with a slick texture.  Carbo is soft with tiny bubbles.  And come to think of it, thereÂ’s some very slight astringency in the finish too.  Overall, well, this is my second Mikkeller and I have to say that I canÂ’t deny the craftsmanship that goes into the guyÂ’s brews...thatÂ’s for sure!  I liked the Beer Hop Breakfast a tad more though, but thatÂ’s purely out of preference.  This is a classic, and something I would buy regularly...if only it was available in Quebec.  Very, very well done.  Oh, and f you SAQ (liquor board/state monopoly in Quebec, Canada)

Pours a black brown with a tannish head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. Slightly smokey in the taste. Extremely smooth. Nice better smokey finish. Just like coffee with breakfast.

Bottle, rated from backlog. Roasty bitter chocolate aroma, with lots of coffee bitterness/astringency. Taste with a fair amount of chocolate malty flavors, and coffee is present but not overwhelming. Good balance. Very nice beer.

The color of the beer is an opaque dark brown with both a medium tan head and large pieces of sediment in the bottom of the glass once poured. The aroma is reminiscent of coffee, toasted oatmeal, roasted malts, with a touch of vanilla. The taste is mildly umami, slightly bitter, and slightly sweet; furthermore, the palate complements the taste due to the fusion of the medium body, soft carbonation, sticky texture, and a bitter finish.

Creamy brown head. Black colour. Aroma is malty with earthy, coffee, dark chocolate and licorice notes with a light fruity accent. Flavor is malty with milk and dark chocolate tomes, slightly earthy, ending in a gently roasty finish. Full bodied.

2012 bottle. I actually drank this with breakfast (maybe I have a problem). The mouthfeel and body were absolutely perfect on this one. Velvety, creamy, heavy, rich. Tons of coffee, but itÂ’s smooth and sweet and lacks the characteristic sour/acid notes that many coffee stouts have lurking in them. You get some wonderful chocolatey flavors as well. The only bitterness is in the finish, and it is perfect.
tap @ Nordic. pours black with a medium beige head. coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malts  in the aroma. roasted malts licorice, chocolate, coffee, in the flavor. smooth, full body.

Pours a black beer, hazy liquid with a brown head.
Smelled like coffee, chocolate, burnt and roasty.
It tasted like coffee, hoppy, nice bitter.
Full body, thick sticky and dry texture. An average carbo and a long bitter finish

Botle.  Jet black pour with smaller dark khaki head.  Aroma is strong roasted malts and bitter strong coffee, hint of hop bit.  Flavor is bitter coffee (some of the bitterness is probably from the noticeably strong hops), piney hop, roasted sweet malts.  Great mouthfeel.  Overall, this was a good beer, but perhaps I had too high of expectations.  The hop/coffee balance was just a tad off for my palate.

The aroma is subtle. Dark fruit, and hints of cereal. Pours a blackish brown with a lasting foamy khaki head and spotty lacing. The taste is roasted meaty malts, roasted coffee, bitterness with a grainy finish. Full body with medium carbonation. Overall, a very enjoyable robust stout. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
March 2010. 22 oz. bottle. Pours black with a beige head. Aroma is coffee, oatmeal, roasted malts. Great structure and balance. One of the best stouts out there.

I have heard a lot about this beer and finally I had the chance to taste it.

Walked on down after work. Full nonic pint of this bad-boy. A nice finger width creamy beige head on top. Excellent retention. Leaves perfect sip rings clinging to the glass, reminding me of what was. Nice potent chocolate aroma, melds well with coffee grounds, vanilla extract, and a slight earthy scent. I can tell this one is going to be rich. 

Creamy body. This is similar to a nitro-draft. Really mellow smooth mouthfeel. Good viscosity. Coffee flavors abound and really start this one off. I can see where the "Breakfast" comes from. This characteristic doesnÂ’t overpower though, as it fades into a milk chocolate sweetness with touches of vanilla and almond. Slight roasted aftertaste gives it a subtle smoky taste that I dig. 

This is a really well-made beer, and I can totally see how it gets the marks that it does. I never felt like pulling the trigger on the slightly expensive bottle whenever I see it, but IÂ’m glad I got it now.

Black as night in a tulip glass with a tan 2 finger head which did not last long. Aroma was smoke, coffee, and bitter chocolate. A nice new leather aroma was present after swirled. On the palate you get cocoa up front followed by mild coffee and finishing off with a nice hint of smoke and some lingering bitterness. Mouthfeel was medium with soft carbonation after being in the glass for about 30 minutes.

A very well done oatmeal stout, Pours very dark with little or no head. 
Aroma - My Shnaz is busted but what I do smell is very appealing.

Palate - I love the aftertaste keeps you wanting more.
Overall - Definitely would buy this again.

This is a beautifully smooth oatmeal stout. But, and this is a big butt, it cost me $18 for a 1pint 9 oz bottle! Wow! Is it any better than Samuel Smiths? Maybe a touch smoother, but man we really need to question the cost/benefit ratio here. I give it a 19 instead of a 20 just on the price point alone, plus the fact that i do not like adding coffee to beer. Good Oatmeal stout does not need coffee flavors added.

Pours nice and oily - medium bodied.  Very small carbonation and brown head.  Rich aroma - chocolate, molasses, coffee, and barley.  Flavor starts out starchy and sharp, then bold, dark roasted coffee with a smooth but slightly biting finish.

Pours a beautiful pitch black with a gorgeous frothy biege foam. Aroma is not as strong as I expected. Taste is absolutely dive body is the right thickness and the coffee adds a nice bitter finish. Almost perfect beer!

My first rb review; what would be more fitting than the beer geekÂ’s breakfast?

Undated eurodeuce.  Based on aroma, this bottle isnÂ’t fresh, but certainly not past itÂ’s prime.   

Spectacular flavor.  One of the smoothest flavors in an oatmeal stout IÂ’ve ever had.  Coffee adds to the very dry bitterness, but provides no overwhelming coffee flavors.  (Presumably the product of coffee notes fading as the bottle has aged.)

Summarily, the mouthfeel provides a dry, flat bitterness that maintains gently but consistently. 

Overall, a standard of beer.  A standard of oatmeal stouts foremost, in my opinion, but also of beers with coffee in the bill.  The balance of this beer is unsurpassed within the style.

500ml bottle @Cimmeria, Oviedo. Nice smoky aromas, dominating, along with coffee, nuts and cacao ones. Full body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. Taste is quite bitter, intense coffee and dark cacao, with very well integrated smoked notes. Alcohol well hidden. Long warm and bittter aftertaste, with lingering smoky notes. Really nice and enjoyable.
Botella de 500ml @Cimmeria, Oviedo. Aromas ahumados dominantes, junto con cafÃ©, chocolate amargo y nueces. Gran cuerpo, textura cremosa y carbonataciÃ³n baja. Sabor bastante amargo, notas de cafÃ© y cacao, con sabores ahumados dominantes, pero que no resultan apubullantes, bien integrados. Alcohol no percibido. Retrogusto largo, ahumado, amargo y "calentador". Muy "disfrutable".

Yea... having this RIGHT before I have the brunch weasel, and yummmm... very good. Wonderful mouthfeel and a great coffee stout. Getting a bit too drunkity drunk to give it a literate rating, but quite good! Worth the great reviews it gets!

2010 at 2 years 55Â° into snifter

Yes sir! This has aged beautifully. Plenty of coffee left to spice up the oats, chocolate, and berries. Big tightly structured cookie head on a black body. Smooth luxurious mouthfeel with soft coffee roast to close. Everything has come together so well in this one. Complex and integrated. Very, very good.

2013/02/08 - Pours black with a frothy, tan head that lingers and leaves a nice lacing. Aroma is roasted malts, oats, dark chocolate and coffee. Taste starts with sweet toasted malts, chocolate, oats and ends with hops and coffee. Mouthfeel is medium thickness and creamy. Well rounded.

Great beer, brilliant black color, beige head, almost brown. Looks like a classic stout, dominated by the coffee both in nose and the mouthfeel. Texture between watery and creamy, medium bodied. Very great beer.

500ml bottle. Darkest brown colour with small to average, creamy, fairly lasting, lacing, tan head. Intense dark malty aroma with a roasty touch, notes of coffee and dark chocolate. Taste is slightly roasty dark malty, coffee notes, some chocolate, decent tartness, lasting coffee finish smooth, harmonical, well balanced, round.

Pours daaaark brown, big brown head. Strong coffee aroma! Soy, milk chocolate, some roasted notes. Taste is a lot of black coffee again, dark bitter chocolate and aftertaste is even more coffee. A lot of sediment at the bottom of the bottle.

Â£7.85 for 500ml from Vino Wines (Edinbrugh):
Black with a large, three centimetre tall head that is part bubbly/part creamy looking and seems quite thick on first appearance. The colour of the head is a tan brown colour and the retention is okay with only a slight reduction.

Roasted malts, some cocoa and a nice helping of coffee. There is a lingering smokey aroma that I hadnÂ’t been expecting and some dark chocolate too.

Strong roasted malts and a nice helping of cocoa along with the coffee and darker, rich malts from the nose. There is a boozy alcohol taste somewhere around the middle and some darker chocolate & some dark fruits at the end.

Smooth with a medium to full body and stronger than expected carbonation although nothing to lively. The beer had quite a rich and creamy feel to it and it went down well with a nice, boozy alcohol finish.

A strong tasting Imperial Stout, it seems slightly stronger than the 7.5% abv. would suggest but it goes down well with a nice kick to it and is packed with both aroma and flavour in abundance. Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2013 Growler. Black with small dark brown head. Aroma is coffee, smoked malt, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, lots of liquorice. Taste is medium sweet, texture is creamy, medium/full body, soft carbonation. Finish is lightly roasted, liquorice and mild bitter with discreet smoke. Smooth and dangerously easy to drink.

Milk chocolate and coffee aroma, more coffee and smoky aromas as it warms. Beautiful aroma. Dark and thick, coffee-crema head. Dark chocolate predominating, coffee on the finish and long hop bitter aftertaste. Extremely well balanced and coffee is not overwhelming, something I usually dislike quite a bit in coffee stouts. Medium carbonation and medium-thick body. Great beer.
Deep brown black, nice creamy tan head. Coffee nose. Robust mouthfeel. Coffee in the flavour, with some spice and hops. Slick and creamy on the palette. Long roasted finish. Lovely.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2014 Very deep dark brown almost black with reddish notes. Medium beige head. Lacing nicely.
Aroma.. deep roasted malts, quite intense coffee with some chocolate tones, bit hoppy - perfect for not loosing balance.
Very smooth milkish. Not pushy malty sweetness with  bitter smooth finish.
Great example of stout. Must repeat. I was kinda bored of coffee aroma, thou this one changed my mind back =]

Pours black with very little head.  Aroma is oats, coffee, bitter chocolate.  Taste follows suit with the coffee and oat flavors blending nicely.  Palate is moderately thick and sticky.  What is left on the palate is beautiful with a little smokey flavor sneaking in there as well.  Excellent.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2013 Aroma - dominant and pleasant burned malt, tones of cocoa, chocolate. Pours deep dark with brown-creamy top, semi sweet with proper bitter, creamy texture, chocolate type bitter aftertaste.  Palate is most amazing - it comes through you and to you like mild touch, like whisper through coffee plantations. This example has more "voice" than more carbonated samples cause speaks not loud but with proper balance, well matured, conditioned palette. Although beer is heavy champ - is very drinkable. Cause believe that there is some examples of beer after which my hand will jump after glass of water, I put only 4 in palete - otherwise - it is amazing.

Aroma is roast and chocolate malts, fresh brewed coffee, light caramel, earthy hops, faint plums and raisins, and a touch of oak. Pours JET BLACK with a dark khaki 2 Â½ finger head.   Nice tight small bubbles reinforced with excellent carbonation.  Nose is of used coffee grounds or mellow coffee.  Slight hint of a bittersweet chocolate, raisin type dark fruits, maybe a hint of alcohol.  Taste is very similar to the nose except for the alcohol.  Mouthfeel is very velvety although there are oats in this stout, so that is to be expected.  Nice alcohol legs, but hardly any notice of alcohol in the taste.  I paired this beer with a chocolate cupcake.  The sugar in the frosting and cupcake is massively intensified by the slight bitterness of the coffee in the beer.  As the beer warms, the coffee gets slightly less muted and tastes more robust.  Overall a decent stout, I donÂ’t know if it meets the hype that comes with it, but a very good oatmeal coffee stout.

A little smoky  Taste: Coffee forward, but not overpowering. Nicely balanced with some sweetness. Just the right amount of bitterness to pull it all together. palate: medium-full body. Moderate carbonation. Nice lingering finish that isn't overpowering. 
Overall: I don't get anything to really set this so far apart from other tasty coffee stouts to warrant me going to lengths to seek it out and spending this much for a bottle. An oily black with a creamy tan head. Lots of coffee aroma with some fruitiness too. Smooth and creamy beer with some nice coffee, vanilla and molasses. Pretty excellent.

Left for Father Christmas by my 21 month old. She rules, like actually. I saw Leif on Xmas day, she was a little bemused. Drank while being a little inapprpriate, which is ironically approprite. No, I donÂ’t know what IÂ’m talking about either.
gosh this is seriously smooth albeit on the bitter side with plenty of coffee and chocolate maltiness. complex with a kick in the middle and a boozy afterglow.
Pours pitch black with a black/brown head. Nose of sweet chocolate and coffee. Nice sweet aromas of coffee, some chocolate, and smooth roast. Nice thick mouthfeel. This is great beer!

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2013 Bottled. Black as sin. Coffee and chocolate in abundance. Coffee and chocolate but without the bitterness or throat catching finish. Thick. Good for breakfast, maybe dessert, but lacks the sweetness.
Bottle.  This is my favorite coffee beer.  Not overly bitter - with a nice smooth coffee finish.
Bottle shared with jndubbs..black pour with brown head..nutty aroma...taste is expresso with a creamy back end... freaking awesome
Wow. Nutty aroma. Pours thick and dark with minimal head. Perfect blend of nutty coffee flavor. tastes like a mocha shake almost.Easily one of my favorite stouts.

Very dark pour with terrific head and lacing.  Beautiful aroma primarily of licorice along with some cocoa.  Deep roasty flavors with licorice, cocoa, and bready malt.  Rich, yet silky, mouthfeel - not over-bodied at all - simply outstanding palate.  Flavors linger.  Splendid stout - best IÂ’ve had yet!  Has more flavor than most impies IÂ’ve tried.
Bottle. Black with thin tan head. Aroma is oat, chocolate,and coffee. Aroma is the same. Very solid stout.

Pours inky black with a thick, lasting, slightly clumpy red-brown head.  Nose is oatmeal, coffee, charcoal, olives, faint cherries in the background. A little cream.  Alcohol comes through as it warms. Nothing off at all. Flavor is bitter with some early maltiness.  Has that rounded oatmealy mouthfeel.  Not oily at all.  Long bitter aftertaste.  Very heavy, in fact is heavy in the glass to pick up.  Bloody brilliant.

Bomber from the lake beer fridge.  Pours black with thin tan head.  Nose is coffee / expresso and bitter chocolate. Taste is similar with hints of black licorice.  This is a great beer for my # 400!  Very very tasty and robust.

Bomber---->tulip.  Pours super black with a pretty thin tan head.  Aroma is full of coffee and licorice.  Tastes of full on coffee and creamy roasted malt.  Palate is a tad thin and flat.  Breakfast is certainly a good term to use for this beer.

Bottle at home. Black color, medium light brown head, looking delicious. Deep aroma of coffee and licorice, roasted malts. Full bodied smooth taste, chocolate, coffee in balance. Medium lasting taste, hops on the back. Very nice.

Bottle.  Pours black with a smallish dark brown head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate, and caramel.  Taste is coffee, dark chocolate, dark fruits, caramel, and a bit of smoke.  Not too heavy.  Very, very good.

high expectations of this one, yet afraid of opening it (for dissapointement since iÂ’m not a coffe fan) so double feelings ! 
finaly opened at home, pours very dark clear brown, as good as black ! kinda like the hel en verdoemenis ! brown-white foam witch fades fast.
smell is just incredible. coffe, yeah, but in a good way. smells like a delicious stout, complex heavy,..soft on the carbo, heavy on the taste ! SO much a reminder of hel en verdoemenis / some of the black damnations, in other words , my favourite beers ! more on the coffee-side, but again, the good side of cofee. aftertaste is on the bitter side. i LOVE this beer and i think i just discovered something iÂ’ll try to have constantly from now on ! .
Yum. Pours opaque black with tan head. Choco and coffee aroma, toastiness. Sweet, dark fruit. Nice smokiness in the background. Smooth roasty finish.
Toasted, coffee and cocoa aroma. Very dark colour. Coffe and toasted flavour with curious notes. Almost perfect.

Pours a thick, inky black with nice cocoa head...hangs around for quite awhile. Awesome. Aromas of strong coffee, smoke, and a bit of soy. Thick and rich mouthfeel. Bittersweet chocolate and coffee flavours. So nice...fully, thick, creamy, soft. Beautiful balance, and great tasting. Excellent.

Good woodsy sweet aroma.  Dark brown with no head.  I do not typically like stouts, but this one had a very good flavor.  Licorice, tobacco and a slight coffee flavor.  Good, but I would probably not order a whole pint of it again.

Det hÃ¤r var en nattsvart sak, men ack sÃ¥ vilken trevlig Ã¶l-upplevelse. Smaken Ã¤r kansken lite spretig med inslag av kaffe, kaffe och choklad, dessutom Ã¤r kroppen pÃ¥ Ã¶len alldeles, alldeles stadig och hÃ¤rlig.

Wow. My favorite stout! Pours thick and black with a latte coloured head. Tastes of coffee, dark chocolate, licorice, smoke and roast malts. A very nice mouth feel, perfect bitterness and a good body. A great beer!

Black pour with a frothy brown head. Intense roasted malts, powdered chocolate, syrup, caramel, toffee, espresso bean, and a hint of vanilla. Really has all the good aroma traits. Taste is sweeter but light, for a stout. Smooth with average carbonation. Wish it was of a higher abv.

From a 50cl bottle, pour a deep black color with a thick dark beige head.  Aroma of roasted malts, hops, coffee and dark chocolates.  Flavors of coffee, dark chocolates, malts, hops, grass, herbs.  Soft carbonation, Light bitterness and light sweetness, but good strong coffee, chocolate and hops tastes present.  Long lasting taste in mouth.  Very tasty and enjoyable.  Nice to finish the evening with, like a dessert beer.

Pours a near black color with very little head.  Aroma is roasted malt, smoke, chocolate, coffee, bacon, and some very light fruitiness.  Taste is mixture of dark malts.  All the aromas balance nicely until the finish which is a bit too smokey for me.  This really is a breakfast beer.  Mouthfeel is medium body and silky texture.  I like this beer but nothing really makes this stand out.

Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; pours dark brown with a frothy tan head, rich coffee aroma, this beer has a glorious really silky mouth feel slips down a dream. The taste is initially coffee with roasted malt a slight hint liquorice, this is an awesome stout.

Bottle, traded with Cunningham. Lovely looks - like Irish coffee, black with a dense, creamy head. Lovely nose - a good dose of coffee intertwined with a rich dark maltiness, with notes of dusty, dark chocolate, and also dusty roasted grain, plus more subtle notes of licorice, wood and tobacco. Rich and deep aroma, while the coffee is not dominating. The mouthfeel is nothing short of excellent, almost more creamy than cream itself. Robust, thick body, smooth and oily palate. The taste is equally deep as the aroma, bitter with a somewhat dryish finish. Tons of dark maltiness - roasty and chocolatey - in the flavour. The coffee notes stand out in the aftertaste that carries with it the aroma of roast, wood and earth, plus more subtle hints of piney hops. What I miss here is at least some small hint of balancing sweetness that would draw this beer even closer to perfection.

Aroma eccezionale e sapore superbo. definire questa stout non Ã© semplice Ã© una birra importante con una punta penetrante di una ro e la sensazione di bere una spremuta di chicchi di caffÃ¨ che sovrasta su tutto senza perÃ² risultare sgradevole. una stout solida senza eccessi che Ã© la prova che non sempre gli eccessi sono quello che serve per rimanere impressi nel bagaglio gustativo delle persone.

From trade with Umich03jm. Black pour, low brown head, light aroma of roasted grain. Taste is also of roasted grain, with hints of chocolate and subtle fruit notes. Moderate bitterness that lingers in the finish. Not thick, balanced, nice overall, but would like some more layers of flavor it this.

(From notes 1 Nov, 2012) Bottle. The head is beige and not large. Color of the beer is a very dark brown (black at a quick glance). The aroma is great: perfumy, sweet hops, smoke, vanilla and chocolate. An interesting combination. Flavor is bitter, hoppy, some sourness. Mouthfeel is very smooth. Finish is a dry bitter.This is the second time I had the Beer Geek Breakfast. Again I am thinking, perhaps the #1 Ratebeer Stout ranking for this one affects my judgment. Overall, a complex enjoyable beer. A bit challenging for me, as it is on the dry and bitter side of stouts, as opposed to sweeter and/or hoppier imperial stouts I usually enjoy. I drank this one slowly and at quite a warm temperature. A good choice IÂ’m sure.

smooth and creamy liquid, very nice.... coffee and chocolat in both nose mouth and finish, very intense... nuts, some bread, espresso... really great beer, escpecially considering itÂ’s alcohol percentage... soooo thick and smooth! thatÂ’s its greatest quality!
Tasting tray at a beer festival in Dublin. Roasted coffee, mellow, full mouthfeel, no head at all, dark brown, slightly oily texture. Really nice, I recommend.

A - pours deep pitch black brown with high tight bubbled espresso head. Some clumpy lacing. S - nice rich oatmeal stout aromas. Rich burned malts, vegetal malts, dark chocolate and espresso notes. A little simplistic. M - medium heavy beer. The oatmeal stout part thickens it a bit. Simplistic. Lingering bitter espresso. T - very simplistic. Burned malts, vegetal malts on the nose, very much a coffee stout, espresso to be precise. Grassy tangy espresso. Raw cacao. Lingering espresso and vegetal malts. O - pretty good coffee heavy stout. 7+

Pours a solid black with a thin tan head and lacing. It has a rich aroma of chocolate, coffee, dark malt, and some smoke and alcohol. The flavor is strong dark chocolate up front with a dark roast coffee and malt middle leading to a semi bitter aftertaste, all over a velvety-smooth mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours thick and oily. Huge aromas of coffee, cream, hops and chocolate. Mouthfeel is full and creamy. Taste is chocolate and coffee.
Puts a huge smile on my face from start to finish.

Powerful oats, nuts, raisins and deep cocoa come out on the aroma. Black in appearance with almost no foam. Creamy vanilla, chocolate, soft molasses and some nuts upfront settling down into a mellow coffee finish. Thick and creamy without being too overbearing of a texture. Overall, The Beer Geek Breakfast is not as good as it had been made out to be. Nevertheless, it is a very solid brew with some nice balanced flavors. IÂ’d give this an A rating.

Definitely worthy of the top stout spot.  It's like Guinness but with coffee and more ABV.  One of the best coffee stouts I've tasted.  Loved the strong coffee flavor.

- check out more at www.beeriam.com

Pours very dark brown/black, oily, viscous, tan head which dissipates. Aroma is all coffee and bitter chocolate. The taste is more of the same, massive coffee notes, amazing bitterness and chocolatey goodness. This really is quite a spectacular beer. Amazing.
As an Irishmam and stout lover, I can only say that this is what stout should taste like, full and full
191012. Bottle at oconnels, tampere. Pours black with a low head. Aroma coffee, chocolate, burnt malts. Nice burnt malty taste. Full bodied. Not Bad.
Normal stout. Nothing too special. Would not necessarily recommend. Dark and chocolaty.
Sublime, on the mark, roasted coffee, mellow, full mouthfeel, no head at all, dark brown, slightly oily texture.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet, Lillehammer, Norway. Pours what at least appears to be pitch black, with a delightful brownish head. The head dissipates rather quickly though. Never mind that, the aroma is wonderful, rich coffee and dark chocolate in abundance. Mouthfeel is great, thick and almost creamy. Flavour is roasted malts, and of course the coffee/dark chocolate is abundant. There is a mild bitterness in the aftertaste reminiscent of coffee again. A superb stout, and IÂ’d love to try their imperial variation.
Pours deep brown with beautiful head.  Smells of chocolate, malt, and coffee.  Tastes like chocolate with a hint of coffee.  Very tingly.  Bitterness on the finish, with a dry mouthfeel.

Bit disappointed in this one. I like Founders Breakfast Stout much more. I was expecting more of a coffee aroma and taste, but only got a bit in the aftertaste. I kept trying to determine the aroma, and to me, the aroma is what you get when you walk into a tire store, strange rubbery smell. Taste is quite bitter with a French roast coffee aftertaste. Glad I tried it, but probably won't buy again. There are better ones out there.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Randolph Beer Room. Beautiful dark black with a bold tan head. Really nice lace. Thick sticky texture from the oats. Aroma of roast and coffee. Some alcohol and vanilla. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Black as black,short thin head with scattered lacing.
 Aroma:  Roasty chocolate,roasty mocha, ash,dark chocolate,liquorice,maybe some  hop pineyness mostly muted from the choc/roast. Cherry.Tobacco smoke.  Nutty-dusty-Leather.Some earthy/herbal upon warming also.
 The complex flavors really unfold in this upon warming.This is super roasty,dark chocolate-mocha based,but malty with smooth oat creamy/slickness/smoothness. There is a malty base with a slick mild nuttyness with carmelized  mild liqorice.chocoalty,with a piney hop,and piney maybe rhindy bittering.Tobacco ash roast with tart cherrie continue to linger on with a numbing peppery menthol or mintish bittering.Good stuff!

Pours black with small head. Aroma is dark chocolate, some smoke, roasted malts. Coffee.
Flavor is ash, light chocolate, coffee beans and some hops. A bit lighter taste that I expected...

0,5 l bottle @ VihreÃ¤ Haltiatar. Pours black with a low tan head. Aroma is roasted malts and coffee. Could be stronger. Flavor is roasted malts plenty of coffee and a hoppy finish. Really nice and soft mouthfeel. Quite nice.
Bottle. Dark brown color, near black. Beige head. Strong aroma of chocolate, coffee and roasted malt with some hops. Thick taste of roasted malt and some lemon. Full body.

This is one of my top five beers to drink. Amazing aroma and taste. One of these and a fireplace on a rainy winter night is amazing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a silky, slightly viscous black with a cola like tan lid. Bursting with aromas of roasted malt, chocolate, oatmeal, coffee, oak, peat, leather, hint of vanilla. Massive array of smells. Taste and mouthfeel: medium carbonation and full bodied. Massive flavour profile. Absolutely delicious. Malt, chocolate, coffee and hop bitter. Earthy and full bodied. Flecks of vanilla.

Bravo!

---Rated via Beer Buddy

500ml bottle, brewed 20/02/12, best before 20/02/2016. Pours like dark syrup, pitch black with a nice, one finger tall, thick and bubbly fudge colored head. On the nose thereÂ’s lots of chocolate, coffee and hints of toffee and smoke. Taste is intense coffee, roastiness and cocoa, nicely balanced by a slight hop bitterness in the end. Loads of longering coffee in the finish aswell. The mouthfeel is incredibly creamy and smooth, a real pleasure to drink. One of the better coffee stouts out there. Would love to try the bourbon version.

IÂ’m frankly torn on this one.  Initially I was under the impression that this was an imperial stout, so I maybe was expecting more.  I got in in the mail so perhaps that was the reason it was so flat, but when I found out it was a stout, I realized that maybe it actually was supposed to be that flat?  Taste was good, but frankly an extremely unenjoyable drink.

on tap at reservoir, waterbury. black pour with a nice beige head, good retention and lacing. dark roasted malts, peaty bacon, ground coffee, woodiness. hint of sweetness. soft carbonation - creamy, full body, very nice smoked coffee and resinous hops - medium hopping. excellent mouthfeel. very nice!
Bottle slightly expired.  Nice head. The aroma chocolate, coffee. Taste an feel is Drinkable with nice stout velvet appearance and flow yet thin . Chocolate!

Bottle.  Pours black with a brownish film on top.. some bubbles in the film.  The aroma has bitter chocolate, coffee, roast, mocha, cappucino.  Taste is sweet mocha up front with a sweet coffee (with cream) finish.  The palate is smooth and drinkable but the texture is very full and velvety. Probably the best non-imperial stout iÂ’ve had.

On tap at The Fred. Pours pitch black with a medium, persistent, brown head. The aroma is coffee, milk chocolate, butterscotch, and burnt toast. The flavor is very sweet, with a little bitterness. The palate is medium to heavy, chalky and syrupy. Overall, this is a good, balanced, and tasty stout.

Lovely black colour with sexy caramel head, good smell of coffee with hints of chocolate. Amazing smooth texture with light refreshing carbonation, taste of roasted malts and coffee/chocolate, one of the best stouts ive tryed in awhile beside dungarvans coffee and oatmeal stout

Pours pitch black with a small dark brown head. Smells of coffee and subtle chocolate. taste is coffee and bitterness, with subtle hints of roasted sweetness. Full-bodied with a smooth, creamy texture and soft mouth-carbonation, Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast finishes with a mild coffee bitterness.

On tap at StubbyÂ’s.  Dark brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, peat, chocolate and mild sweeter malts.  Taste of dark roasted malts, chocolate, earthy/peaty notes, black patent malts and some coffee.

Motor oil black with a solid tan head and nice spotty lace. Chocolate, roasted coffee, and dark fruit aromas. Rich bittersweet dark chocolate flavors dominate with lots of roasted malts, some dark berries, oak and alcohol. Full body, silky smoothness on the palate, minimal carbonation and a lovely espresso aftertaste. Pretty much the quintessential stout - just awesome.

Pours black as night with a minimal dark tan head. Very nice lacing. Smells of dark chocolate, coffee, some carmel, lots of roasted flavors, sweet, and no alcohol on the nose. Taste starts with some roasted chocolate, leather, lots of coffee, and some dark fruit like plum. Finishes with intense roasted goodness. Bitterness from the hops and coffee. Just like beer hop breakfast, it is pretty much a full body and thatÂ’s impressive for only a 7.5% beer. Pretty much beer hop breakfast without the hoppy qualities. After having the hoppy version, this just doesnÂ’t do it for me. DonÂ’t get me wrong, itÂ’s good, but I just had high expectations for this. Still a solid stout.

Bottle. Pours pitch black color with nice brown head. Aroma is coffee, roast, wood. Taste is roast, dark chocolate, licorice, coffee, hops. Tingling licorice and alcohol in the aftertaste. Has a strong flavor and very oily texture, yet is surprisingly light and drinkable.
UPDATED: DEC 5, 2012 ! Dark brown with nice head. taste of chocolate and lots of coffee. long aftertaste.

(500ml bottle from Voldby KÃ¸bmandsgaard, Hammel) Easily one of the best Stouts I have tasted. Pours black with nice tan head and lacing. The dark roasted malt/chocolate/oat/coffee taste combo really hits the spot. Lovely stuff.
IÂ’d drink this for breakfast....wonderful coffee and chocolate flavors. I would definitely suggest.this to stout lovers. Great color, Carmel brown head on the pour. Great Flavor!
500 ml bottle. A pretty solid beer, with its heavyness and different sweet flavours, it matches desserts and coffee perfectly.

Bitter sweet aroma is medium strong: salty licorice, medical herbs, suryp. Black with thin head. Taste is really roasted, dry and bitter with strong finish, lots of dark chocolate. Full body, medium feel, low carbonation. Strongly flavored, highly aromatic beer.

Nice dark head that lingers around rim for duration. Nice dark roast coffee smell with some alcohol. Dark as night and coffee and chocolate hit you in the taste and a pretty decent bitter aftertaste. Overall pretty good coffee stout. Would try again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured from bottle into glass very dark with light brown head. Aroma of chocolate and vanilla. Taste has oatmeal up front with coffee finish. Nice smooth finish.

Dark brown, almost black pour with medium sized dark tan head. Aroma is amazing coffee, espresso and chocolate. Taste of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, cocoa and a hint of caramel. Low carbonation and creamy mouthfeel. Delicious!!
Pours thick and black with a dark brown head. Sweet aroma with coffee and some chocolate. Soft mouthfeel with very little carbonation. Bitter but not stingy taste. An interesting stout.

Dark, opaque, in fact, with basically no head.  The aroma is a blast of bitter chocolate and thereÂ’s also a lot of that in the taste along with smooth malt and coffee thatÂ’s more of a presence in the nose than on the tongue.  Overall itÂ’s milder than I expected and a little flat.  Not all that IÂ’d hoped for.
Bouteille 500 ml Ã  lÂ’Autre Oeil. Couleur noire, mousse brune. ArÃ´me de cafÃ© espresso, de torrÃ©faction. Notes de cafÃ©, herbes, chocolat noir. Finale en houblon amer, cafÃ© et cacao. Excellente.

Bottle at home.
Dark brown colour, little carbonation. Bitter, sweet. Chocolat and coffee, full of taste. Nice brew.

500ml bottle pours a thick black with a tight mocha head but not much lacing. Aroma is full of chocolate, oatmeal, roasted malts, and coffee.  Mouthfeel is creamy and oily, with a fully body.  Coffee comes out in a pleasant bitter finish, although the taste is sweet. Overall one of the best stouts anywhere.

Pours extremely dark in the glass with a light brown head. It has an aroma of chocolate and vanilla. Taste has oatmeal up front with some coffee in the finish. There is a mild chocolate taste throughout. Smooth finish.

Bottle at home. Pours a black colour with a medium light brown head. Fantastic roasted aroma of coffee, dark chocolate and smoke. Wonderful roasted flavous with espresso, burnes wood and leather. Has a slick mouth feel with a lasting medium bitterness. A delicious and tasteful stout.
UPDATED: AUG 14, 2013 Dark brown/black colour, little carbonation. Bitter and a bit sweet. Chocolate, hops and a lot of coffee, full of taste. Very good!

Bottle. Pours jet black with dense light brown coloured head. Aromas a quite sweet and fruity. Light chocolate and a little roasted grain in support. Flavours show plenty of roasted grain bitterness, some sticky sweetness and a decent alcohol burn. Medium mouthfeel. NIce stout.

Pours an opaque, sooty black with a thick brown head and good retention. Lots of malty and dark roast coffee in the nose. Thick, oily mouth with a lingering bitterness. Overall pretty smooth drinking and hearty.

Pours black with a nice tan head. Not a lot of retention or lacing.  Tastes of coffee, chocolate, and oatmeal and it is delicious.  A really good breakfast stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black with a beautiful dark brown, tight bubbled head.
Scent is coffee and chocolate...roast.
Flavour is silky sweet, creamy oatmeal, chocolate, coffee....very good coffee.
Incredibly smooth.
Absolutely wonderful beer.

500mL to tulip
Strong chocolate and coffee and alcohol aroma. Dark brown with a tan head. Coffee and chocolate come through with the taste along with toasted malt.
Had a bottle from Madness. This is so creamy and sweet, The taste is cereal, sweet chocolate and coffee, like a fresh mocha. Breakfast for a king, indeed!

Exactly what you would expect of a oatmeal stout brewed with coffee. Roasted malt, black coffee, coffee grounds, ash and chocolate... What is impressive to me is the beautiful balance and texture achieved. Rich, creamy and full bodied, without being heavy or thick. This beer has a wonderfully balanced weight on palate, and a long finish, echoing the initial flavors, without being overly sweet or bitter. A darn good breakfast in my opinion. Would drink again if in the mood.

--- tasted while on a long journey to understand the world around me...
This is exactly what a breakfast stout should taste like. Strong coffee notes resulting from a blend of malts instead of the usual coffee pot flavor. Can not wait to find another!

Aroma: The smell is toast, ash tray and sausages.Appearance: The beer is black, with a brown rather modest head, leaving little lacing. But good curtains.Taste: The beer is sweet, brown bread, strong coffee and chocolate, as well as a coffee liqueur nuance.Palate: Medium low carbonation, sticky, oily a big body, a light dry finish.Overall: A really good iconic beer.Note: Bottle, big at De Klomp tasting. Reviewed 2012-08-11.

Dark brown with a creamy tan foam. Nice lacing. Aroma is mostly coffee and roasted malt. Taste is well balanced coffee & dark toasty malt. A bit of sweetness in the front. Lightly carbed, works well. Excellent coffee stout. Easy drinking, very enjoyable. 

More beer please...
Pours black with an off-white head.  Roasty and coffee aroma. Tastes has some coffee and cocoa with some minor hop character.  Lovely beer!

Keg.
Black, tan head.
Big coffee aroma.
Taste is big espresso but you definitely get the hops and some sweet chocolate.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar. Near black with small tan head, plenty of lacing - looks seriously viscous - amazing. Aroma is beautifully complex coffee (of the seriously robust, dark roast, freshly ground type), roasted malt, dark chocolate, oats, some slight dark fruit notes. Taste is a wonderful balance between the rich roasted maltiness and the coffee complexity, plenty of dark chocolate with a touch of almost-citric hop bitterness thrown in. Mouthfeel is silky smooth - velvety. Lasting coffee and roasted malt aftertaste. Great stout, not many better ones out there in my mind.

Bottle from HÃ¶keren.
Pours pitch black with a small brown head. The carbonation bubbles are so small, really nice to look at.
Loads of coffee and chocolate hits the nose, some grains and hints of smoke and alcohol.
Smouth mouth feel as one usually finds in oatmeal stouts.
Taste has a lot of coffee, nicely roasted malts, hints of cherry and a punch of bitterness in the end. 
After taste has a nice coffee bitterness. Well balanced and very drinkable, apart from the aroma the alcohol is well hidden.

Tap at the Euston Tap, served in a small snifter glass, shared with Muggins. Looks excellent, jet black with a small brown head. It may be me but dark beers definitely get an advantage on appearance marks! Aroma is strong, roast malt, coffee, hint of booze. Palate is lovely and smooth, oatmeal really kicking in here. Very flavoursome, bit of coffee although I wouldnÂ’t have necessarily got that there was some coffee in here, roastiness, dry bitter finish. I thought this was a truly excellent stout, silky mouthfeel, good booze backing but not in any way dominant, maybe not the most intense beer ever but one of the best balanced. Crazy Scandis think this is appropriate for breakfast...?

500ml bottle. Dark black with a nice brown head. Was expecting coffee to jump out in the aroma but itÂ’s actually pretty subdued; it might have faded over time as this bottle is a year old. Some additional dark chocolate and oatmeal cookies in the aroma, along with unexpected citrus hops in the background. Taste combines all of those elements with little sweetness and lots of bitterness. Palate is mostly smooth and thick but shows some thinness at times. A well put together beer in general, but it failed to really grab me.

Aroma imponente y penertante, a la vez, sumamente agradable, y que permite esperar mucho de esta cerveza. Destacan sus notas a cafe, maltas tostadas y ligeramente a Avena.

Su apariencia es la de una excelente Stout. Color totalmente negro, nula carbonataciÃ³n. Corona de espuma abundante y color marrÃ³n al servir, la cual se diluye lentamente permitiendo la creaciÃ³n de una capa de burbujas color crema. Cuerpo medio.

En boca cremosa, elegante y densa. Sumamente sabrosa.

Al paladar, una vez degustado el liquido, es de sensaciones placenteras, las cuales solo pueden emerger de una cerveza de gran calidad.
