Ligeramente amarga,  suavidad aterciopelada al recorrer la garganta, misma que deja Ãºnicamente una verdadera Sweet Stout, dejando un prounciado sabor a cafÃ©, de final largo.

En terminos generales una excelente cerveza mÃ¡s de Mikkeller, la cual da origen a variedades diferentes de esta Geek Breakfast, y que una vez mÃ¡s, no decepciona......

Bottle sample at a tasting at DaganÂ’s place. Thanks avrashi. Pours black with an off-white head. Great roast and a little coffee aroma. Tastes dry and roasty, bitter with just a little cherry. Medium-bodied, roasty finish, carbonated. Great beer.

UPDATED: AUG 15, 2012 On tap. Looks, smells, and tastes like a cold espresso. The bitterness on the back end has a nice blend of hops and coffee bitterness. Would have liked a little more sweetness, but still phenomenal.

Poured from a 16.9 ounce bottle into a Cigar City snifter. No freshness info on bottle.

Appearance: Pours an extremely dark brown, almost black with a 1-2 finger finely bubbled foamy mocha brown head. Nice head retention and lacing.

Smell: Dark roasted malt, coffee and a touch of chocolate.

Taste: Dull roasted coffee and a touch of mineral notes up front followed by a muted coffee flavor and a bit of burnt toast in the middle before ending with more dark roasted coffee and a touch of hoppy bitterness. Aftertaste is roasted and mildly bitter. To be honest, the flavor was a bit of a letdown after the aroma. ItÂ’s definitely not bad, but disappointing nonetheless.

Mouthfeel: Light-to-medium-bodied with a surprisingly high amount of prickly carbonation. ItÂ’s a bit watered down compared to what I want in an Imperial Stout.

Drinkability: Good drinkability. The alcohol is well masked so you could easily finish a pint or two without much difficulty.

Overall: Pretty good beer overall. The flavor leaves a little to be desired and the mouthfeel is subpar. The aroma and appearance are right where you want them. While it doesnÂ’t compare well with many of the higher rated Imperial stouts or coffee stouts on the market, IÂ’d still say this one is worth trying.
Helsvart Ã¶l med ett ljusbrunt skum som ligger kvar lÃ¤nge. Doftar frÃ¤mst av rostade kaffebÃ¶nor. Smaken mer komplex med det rostade kaffet, lÃ¤tt rÃ¶kighet, choklad och en avslutande humlebeska.
Tap at bar sf, bcn. Black colour. Heavy coffee aroma and taste. Delicious.

Bottle shared at drowlandÂ’s going away tasting. Pours a dark brownish black with dissipating brown head and light lacing. Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, and alcohol. Taste is all the coffee and malt, and the only hint of the alcohol is a slight burn on the way down. I can see how it would be good with breakfast, a slight maple sweetness on the back end.

At Gourmet Haus. Aroma of coffee and slight semi-sweet chocolate. Black with a muddy head that rings the glass with large bubbles. Dusting of head across top. Taste of roasted coffee beans. Very dry finish. Some nice spicy bittering finish. Mouthfeel surprisingly thinnish. Really expected more from this one.

Poured from bottle. Dark brown, almost black, with as tan head. Aroma is roasted coffee/malt. Its not very strong. First taste is smooth, maybe coffee taste, but quickly gives away to a smoke/roasted taste. Not one of my favorites. Needed more coffee and smoothness.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

IÂ’m really not that high on this one. ItÂ’s good, but itÂ’s not that exciting. Tastes like other run-of-the-mill oatmeal stouts, with some added coffee bitterness. Very bitter, with a little bit of a soft sweetness in the mid-palate. Roasty flavor. Really not spectacular. Was hoping for a lot more.

0,5l bottle. Pitch black color with nice big brown creamy head. Aroma is quite intensive and yet mellow at the same time. Roasted malts, coffee beans, cocoa, very faint sweet honey in aroma. Creamy texture. Sweet, honey, coffee, roasted, dark chocolate, liquorice in flavor. Aftertaste is nice coffee bitterness and mild salty. Very nice beer.
Pours a black color with aroma of roasted malt mixed with dry coffee beans.  Taste is very rich and full mouthful, lasting aftertaste of coffee and malt.  A hint of oatmeal lingers after the swallow.

A quite NÃ¸gne Ã˜ish beer geek breakfast. It has a great grassy and spicey quality which I find quite often in NÃ¸gne Ã˜ beers  with dark malts. Very well balanced after my own preferences. Lovely coffe and roasted notes. A bit creamy palate with a  dry coffe and roasted malt aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours dark opaque black with a medium dark brown creamy head that lasts a long time and leaves nice lacing. Aroma is roasted malt and coffee, not strong. Rich, thick and creamy in the mouth. Taste is quite complex, with roasted malt, chocolate and coffee dominating, plus a bit of grass. Finish is medium bitter, with chocolate and coffee notes lasting till the far finish. This is a damn nice beer.

Paired side by side with Beer Geek Brunch Weasel.

A: Black with a big beige head and decent lacing.

S: Very enticing aromas of coffee and roasted malts.

T: A really great beer. The coffee and roasted malt are blended so well together, itÂ’s like they are dancing. The aromas and flavors are not as bold as many other coffee stouts, including Mikkeller Beer Geek Brunch Weasel. That being said, this is a tasty offering, and pleasant to drink.

M: Crisp carbonation with a sticky aftertaste and a slight alcoholic finish.

D: A nice brew, and not too hard to find. A good one to have in the cellar.

Bottle. Dark body, tall tan head. Aroma has coffee and milk chocolate. Smooth and dense palate. Rich chocolatey taste with lots of coffee. Nice hoppiness follows to balance all the sweetness. Very tasty and ridiculously drinkable. The name makes me wonder how it might taste when poured on breakfast muesli.

woho! my 100th rating, so iÂ’ll rate one of my favs! 
Black pour with a small tan head, looks creamy and nice.
Nose is filled with coffee and roasted malts, hints of tar and leather and bitter hops.
Taste is bitter with tonnes of the coffee from the aroma, roasty and with some hints of dark chocolate and caramel. The smoked malts blend well with the rest and just makes for a hint of dried meats.
Body is close to full and softly carbonated.
This is a great stout!

500ml bottle. Dark, close to black with brown head. Aroma has coffe with notes of pine and camphor. Taste black roasted coffe, mocha and caramel with notes of vanilla and spices. Long bitter and refreshing aftertaste. Delicious beer!

At just on cool and into a snifter. Took a rough pour to get some life but settles out with a persistent, looming 1" head of brown foam. Black as midnight in body, opaque, with well conditioned, fine carbonation. Very rough and piercing, charred and burnt grains, and heavily roasted coffee beans on the nose with a considerably tainting note of paint stripper reaching through. There is just  the slightest nuances of vanilla-choc icecream, peppery hops and dark chocolate. Woody, tannic, puckering, harsh and bitter burnt malt and heavily roasted coffee bean flavours grip the palate. I could stop writing, as that is it. One dimensional and shed a tear sad! Overly dry, oily in feel; there is a limited peppery hop bite. Bonfire, scorched grains, caffeine kicks in - ugh! A disappointment. Harsh for no reason!!! ( 50cL, Batch 659, Cellarbrations Carlisle)

On-tap at Northdown Cafe.  Pours black, mocha head, thin collar.  Nose is coffee-forward, chocolate, roast, toasted malts.  Tastes is coffee and chocolate, like dessert for breakfast.  Mouth is medium to full body, rich and smooth, creamy finish.  Really nice beer and one of the best from Mikkeller.

Black, small brown head. Nose is toasted malt, flowery hops, coffee, chocolate. Taste is malts, dark chocolate, bitter espresso, oatmeal notes, ever-so-slight sweetness, hops. Aftertaste is smooth dark chocolate and fairly intense espresso.  Mouthfeel is creamy, silky. Discreet carbonation. Delicious.

Pours black with dark tan head. Smells of smoky deep roasted grain and coffee. The taste is very rich and full, lots of oat. A bit of a sweet sugary carbonation hits light with a robust lingering coffee that is close to drinking a great cold cup of Joe. This is highly drinkable and is lighter bodied than some even with the full grainy mouth feel.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2013 Fra flaske pÃ¥ Mikkellertreffet pÃ¥ Cardinal: M. laget denne for fÃ¸rste gang pÃ¥ sitt kjÃ¸kken i 2005, men som en havrestout uten kaffe. Den ble kjedelig sÃ¥ han tilsatte en kanne stempelkaffe. Inspirert av Alesmith Speedway Stout. Viktig med lav bitterhet i kaffen (urÃ¸stet?), bitterheten mÃ¥ komme fra humlen. En moderne klassiker. Flaske fra batch 396 (brygget 130808, bf 130813), hjemme mars-13: kaffesjokolade bÃ¥de i skum, aroma og smak. Lav bitterhet men stor smaksrikdom. Dette burde alle produsenter av kaffemaskiner strebe mot! Men mÃ¥ aldri oppbevares sÃ¥ lenge,  der var et stort bunnfall av geleaktige klumper.
Pours a nice tar black with a chocolate milk head.  Serious lacing.  Great head retention.  Aromas of chocolate and coffee.  Bitter chocolate and coffee on the palate.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2016 Aroma: Dark roasted malt, coffee and berries. 
Flavour: Very dark roasted malt with coffe, slight chocolate, some fruity sweetness. Aftertaste is roasted malt and dry bitter. Mouthfeel is creamy and alcoholic warm. 
Colour: pitch black with a tan head. 
From: Bottle @ Salling Super Sept. 2016. 
(2012: 8,5,8,5,18) A very good beer. Roasted flavors of coffee with nice bitterness. Very dark in color, almost black with a creamy brown head.

22 oz. bottle purchased at JulioÂ’s Liquors in February I canÂ’t find the receipt however, I know I paid a high price. On this stout; the price was worth it. No date on bottle anywhere. Complexity in nose and flavor. Coffee with cream, vanilla and rich roasted malt noseÂ… yum! The aspect of the flavor I like most is the lingering espresso bean bitterness. Lots of flavors mingling together. Medium body with oats being known yetÂ… bottle seems like it may have sat too long. On the brink of being past its prime. Without a date itÂ’s hard to known. Anyhow, I still loved it!

UPDATED: JUL 9, 2012 Wow, I understand why he called it breakfast stout. Aroma of dark coffee, pine, roast and some chocolate. Quite dry palate, but that suits the beer excellent. Very rich on flavours, and you can find a new flavour from each taste. ThatÂ’s a quality that only the best beers got!

Beautiful black pour with mid-brown tight half-inch head.  Aroma is...unbelievable.  Coffee, chocolate, fruit.  Oh tasty.  Perfect balance, rich flavours, smooth, smooth mouthfeel, alcohol hidden.  Yum.

Poured into a ccb glass. No head, dark black, thin ring around the glass. Light coffee aroma, some malts and a small hop aroma. Taste follows the nose, really smooth finishes with a smokey coffee aroma. Medium body, high carbonation. Not the best coffee stout but not bad.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2014 Dark brown with brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate. Taste is coffee and chocolate. A great beer.
Re-rate: cellared beer from 2012. Upped the appearance rating to 5. Perfecetion, nice head and lacing, chocolate milk head.
Roasted coffee with slight cream aroma. Looks exactly like I want a stout to look, deep opaque black with a two finger pillowy tan head. taste is creamy roasted coffee with velvety mouthfeel.
Bottle from Ale Yeah! in Decatur, GA. Thick black with roasty aroma. Big, strong bitter coffee flavor.

Aroma, coffee, malt, chocolate. Pours pitch black good tan head dissipates quick leaving persistent tight head with lotÂ’s of lace. Taste, coffee, malts chocolate slight bitterness great body slightly dry good coffee and chocolate finish. exceptional stout

Pour pitch black, with a small brown fizzy head, that quickly diminishes.
Aroma of coffee, chocolate, oatmeal. The aftertaste, is where it really comes to power. Everything just seems so clear. definitely some hops in here as well.
Taste is quite bitter, from all of the coffee and bitter chocolate, with just faint hints of vanilla and brown surgery - sweetness.
Medium bodied, with a slight fizzy carb.
Tap at Bishop Arms, Copenhagen. Black with a beige head. Aroma and flavour of roasted malt, licorice, coffee, dark dried fruit and chocolate.

Poured into a goblet. Pitch black with an awesome half finger of tan head.
Wow. Huge, rich smell. Molasses in my nose, less black coffee and burnt malt.
In order: cafe con leche, dark chocolate, bitter coffee and burnt malt at the end that bites the edges of the tongue.
Super smooth, but it still has lots of carbonation. Creamy and milky in the end.
Easy drinking and smooth at the beginning and moves to a more aggressive bitter coffee type of profile. It is well balanced and the best coffee stout I have had.

Great hearty aroma with hints of coffee and maybe a touch of chocolate; pours black with a small light brown head that quickly diminishes to a ring with slight lacing. Good flavor thatÂ’s not overpowering with a long pleasant finish.  Lightly carbonated with a full creamy body.  Eminently drinkable!

Inky black pour with a nice foamy rocky dark khaki head.  Deep nutty aroma with tones of toasted pecan, gourmet cold coffee, light chocolate tones, and a faint tone of leather.  I know its 25% oatmeal, but it has more of a nutty aroma.  Taste is rich and deep, though not terribly astringent.  Flavors of cocoa powder, roasted coffee, some oat-iness, some light nuttiness, and light roastiness finishing with some cocoa and light coffee tones.  Bodyfull, though not overtly powerful. Great, but not mind-blowing.

Pours pitch black with a med tan/brown head. Smells like coffee and cocoa. Taste rich with coffee, dark chocolate, dark fruits, and a little grapefruit. Full bodied. Texture smooth but then chalky. After taste is rich, dark with a nice bitterness. Great balanced coffee stout.

This might be the closest I have come to finding my perfect beer. I am a coffee nerd as much as a beer nerd and this satisfies both. Big fresh coffee aroma, pours black with a slight tan head that mimics the crema on an espresso. The taste is dark toasted coffee, chocolate, caramel with a slight bitterness that helps balance the sweetness of the caramel. I will definitely be stocking up.
From bottle. Pours black with minimal tan head. Roasty coffee aroma with licorice. Very bitter taste. Full body, thick texture.

On tap at mikkeller bar - best place to have it, isnt it?
Pours black with no to low head. Served a bit too cold...
Aromas of coffee, alcohol, chocolates...
Intense coffee and bitterness. Stays looong. Very nice mouthfeel. Starts with a kick in the mouth and moves into a bitter end. Wow!
UPDATED: APR 29, 2012 Draught at Mikkeller Bar. .A pitch black, beige head, good lace. Licorice, roasted malts, fruity, deep dark coffee. Complex, smooth mouthfeel. Long bitter lingering finish.

50 cL bottle at Stone. Black pour with 1 finger mahogany head. Roasty aroma of nuts, coffee, and campfire. Very smooth mouthfeel with burnt tones of coffee, chocolate, and smoke. Way too drinkable. I finished 2 bottles back to back.

Average stout. Not as good as the cult-status rep of Mikkeller would have you believe. Leaves a dry nauseating aftertaste. Tastes like burnt ashtray.  There are many better stouts at a more reasonable price point.
Gedronken met dutchdrebus, zwart/donkerbruin, niet echt mijn biersmaak. Koffie, caramel en mokka smaak.
Pours a dark black with reddish brown head. Medium carbonation. Nose is coffee, smoke, dark chocolate.  Tastes the same, lots of roasted coffee. A well bale DD stout a 7.5%  Paid $7.25.

Picked this up at Hunger Mountain Co-Op. Poured into a tulip at fridge temp.

A - 3-Finger dark coffee coloured head, big and creamy bubbles. Fantastic head lacing and very slow dissipation. Dark brown to black. A little lights goes through but barely enough to count.

S - Mild roasted coffee scent, smoked malts, vanilla and espresso acidics. 

T - Very bright oatmeal taste with a lovely coffee finish. Roasted malts.

M - 60/40 caronbation, oily taste and an intense espresso aftertaste

O - This is a beer for guys who LOVE espresso. If you love cream and sugary lattes with vanilla, you wonÂ’t like this beer. The one critique is the oatmeal is a bit subdued as if this beer has sat around for way too long.

Nice orangey head with notes of chocolate and mild latte.  Not too much on the hops, but also not needed.not to thick and only mildly sweet with a good shot of hop bitterness at the end.  Excellent beer.

500mL bottle into a duvel glass, Pours think and black like motor oil with a big chocolate head and a massive aroma that has so much going on. Has a big esspresso taste as well as creamy chocolate and warming down the throat. I dont drink alot of stouts although this one surprised me with its complex flavours, very enjoyable on a cold rainy day.
UPDATED: MAY 17, 2012 Pours very dark brown with lots of caramel head. Smells of roasted malts and espresso. Tastes the same a bit of alcohol on the finish
Lovely beer. Big roasty aroma with big coffee nose. Hints of chocolate as well. Flavor is espresso, smoke, dark chocolate. Very nicely balanced stout.
Bottle. Hard to overstate how nice this was. Big coffee punch with some dark chocolate and roasted goodness in there as well. Pours black. Medium  carbonation and a good full body in the mouth.

Bottle poured into imperial pint.  Dark, dark brown in color, looks to be opaque.  Big, frothy dark tan head.  Heaps of lacing.  Aroma is full of dark roasted malt with nice supporting notes of coffee, leather, and a touch of oak, licorice, and vanilla.  Nicely complex but not a punch in the face.  Taste is on-point!  Beautifully balanced; this starts out simple with a touch of milky sweetness before flipping the switch over to a big, bold roasty bitter middle and very dry finish with coffee lingering on the tongue.  Hint of chocolate as well.  Full bodied, creamy, and just damn good.  Slightly metallic also but not a big detriment.  Mikkeller is the man!

This was a really cool beer.  I actually had it FOR breakfast with a beer friend of mine.  Oatmeal and coffee pretty much sums it up.  They should add a bunch of sulfur to get kind of an egg smell to it.  Just kidding.

Pours quite black. Decent head, not overly impressed with the staying power or lacing, but decent. Lots of roast in the nose, alcohol notes, coffee. Flavor is off the charts. IÂ’ve been away from big stouts for a while, I got a bit burnt out on them. What a great way to get back into them.

Pours really dark brown with brown head.  Malt, coffee, cocoa, and some alcohol in the aroma.  Taste is bitter and acidic, with coffee, roast, and a little tinniness.    Thin mouthfeel.  Good, but I was disappointed based other beers IÂ’ve had from Mikkeller, as well as the ratings I saw for this one.

This pours jet black, blocks out the sun with a dark tan dense head.    Nose is sweet, roasty with notes of cocoa and actually smells Â’creamyÂ’. Flavor is a bit more roasty than the nose, a bit more burnt.  Not a big bite on the tongue, but the flavor does linger.  Very hearty.  Not sure IÂ’d go this direction for a breakfast brew but if the caffeine keeps me up tonight, who knows, maybe IÂ’ll wish I did save it till morning.  Palate is full and and a bit astringent.  I think the coffee overwhelms the creaminess of the oats here.

From 750ml to pint glass. Pours a dark brown almost black with a three finger mocha head. Smells of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and oats. Tastes of black coffee with the roasted malts and oats present, slightly acidic like bitter coffee. MF is on the thinner side but still nice with soft carbonation. Overall I really enjoyed this beer.

Bottle. Pours pitch black with a tan head. Complex aroma of dark chocolate and roasted coffee. Dominate taste of coffee but not overdone, chocolate and oatmeal, great mouth feel, the duration of the finish goes on forever, Fantastic beer!

Dark pour that looks like syrup.  Espresso head with nice lacing.  Aroma of grain, roast & coffee.  Some sugar in there too.  Mouth is heavy.  Taste is roasty coffee with some chocolate and a hint of smokiness.  Chewy mouth feel.  Slight tobacco taste too.  This is one delicious stout.

bottle. Pours deep black, with a brown pillowy head. Aroma is strong coffee, roast, chocolate. What a mouthfeel! Great texture from the oatmeal. The taste is smooth and rich without being jolting or abrupt. Lots of earthy coffee and sweet roasted malt. No hint of the alcohol. Enjoyed this with a dinner of pancakes bacon and eggs. A really fantastic brew.
thik black pour with great one finger chocolate colored head. Coffee and oat aroma. Strong coffee flavors that linger from start to finish, which are nicely complimented by oatmeal texture.
Pours black, nice brown foam. Smell of chocolate, coffee.  Had for breakfast, perfect for this occasion. Dark and filling, without being too heavy.

Pours like black syrup. Smells like coffee, has mocha foam with mad staying power.  A hard, crisp  bitter taste and strong coffee bean and roast malt to it.  All bitter, no sweetness from this one.  some bitter chocolate maybe, but I mean bitter. ItÂ’s pretty good but a little overrated for me. Bottle at Rhino
Great beer.  Noice strong stout taste with lots of coffe and a substantial amount of bitterness.

I literally had this for breakfast. Pours pitch black with a frothy brown head. Delicious aromas of chocolate and coffee. Taste is a perfect, crisp balance of sweet and bitter. It's on the lighter end for a stout, which isn't a bad thing. Overall: awesome!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

500ml bottle. This is a beer IÂ’ve enjoyed many times, but forgot to actually rate. ItÂ’s a great and solid oatmeal stout. Black as night with a nice small brown head. Powerful aromas of roasted malts, coffee and licorice. Full flavors of roasted goodies, coffee, some caramel. The large amount of oats in the mash gives a great full body for the beer. Nicely hopped with a great bitterness. Long aftertaste that lasts. Recommended!
DonÂ’t even think about drinking this beer if its cold.  Let it warm up and enjoy the magical transformation.  Coffee coffee coffee.

500ml bottle.  Poured a deep black color with a large dark brown foarmy head that left nice lacing as it slowly subsided. A rich aroma of malt, coffee, chocolate, and some ligthly smokey woodiness. The flavor was malt, coffee, chocolate, anise and a touch of pepper. It has a medium body and a smooth bittersweet finish.

Poured from the bottle for breakfast. Pours dark, with a dark tan thin head. Lots of lacing. Aroma is chocolate and coffee. The flavor is where this gets good! Starts chocolatey, then I get coffee notes, some smokiness and, the oatmeal is quite noticeable.... More so in the palate. The palate is velvety smooth from the oatmeal, just delicious! Thick and chewy and finishes a bit sticky. Very balance and very good with my scrambled eggs! What a great way to start a day. Will try to enjoy this on days off of work, like today!
centimeter sized dark tan head. Dark black body. Good solid coffee flavor smoothed out with the oatmeal. Good body. Not too thick.
UPDATED: MAR 19, 2013 Negra de giste amplio y cremoso. Aroma a chocolate, cafÃ© y caramelo todo intensidad. Sabor intenso a malta tostada, chocolate y cafÃ©.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2012 I?m not a beer geek, but even I know that oatmeal and coffee is a great breakfast.  Don?t give me those stinking eggs, or toast, or bacon (well, ok, I?ll have the bacon later).  But then there is convenience.  Oatmeal takes forever to boil, and coffee, if you want it right, takes forever to clean up after.  Or you can just grab one of these, the perfect, get-out-of-bed and start your afternoon drink.

Smells like sweet soy sauce. More carbonation that I expected but not that much. Tastes like it smells plus a butnt leaf note that I donÂ’t like. Their is a chocolateky finish which makes this thing salvageable. I canÂ’t understand why this beer has such high ratings. Not having it again. Disappointing

Pours a dark used motor oil black with a nice khaki head that sits around the edge of the glass. Aromas of cocoa, dark chocolate, dark cherries, coffee, espresso and a nice grain aroma. First taste is smooth and creamy, filled with cocoa, coffee and roasted malt. There?s a slight alcohol bite and a nice roasted/hoppy bitterness. Dark chocolate finishes it off. The oat character really comes out as the beer warms up. Quite delicious. Mouthfeel is oily and sticky and the bitterness kinda lingers. This is an amazing beer. Get it if you can.

12oz bottle shared with the friends. Let me start be saying this this beer is  brewed with Civet Coffee, which as we all know, is coffee that is pooped out of a cat-weasel thing. Luckily, my buddy MADE me try it, as I couldnÂ’t get over the poop-in-my-beer aspect up to that point. And It was great! Complex, rich, huge nose. Coffee notes with hints of cocoa, butterscotch, and whiskey barrels. Taste follows the nose with a big creamy texture, coffee and smoke, cocoa and booze. I definitely realized instantly that I was drinking something special. Amazingly contemplative beer. We must have talked about it for 45min. Only reason I didnÂ’t give it a 5 was because it was brewed with poop.

Poured from a bottle into a snifter. Appearance is a dense black with a respectable brown head of foam. Aroma emits a resinous dark chocolate and black coffee presence reminiscent of a nice french roast coffee. Roasty. Hints of smokiness waft up from the glass as well. Finally the first sip makes its way to my lips. At first I find a bitter cup of black coffee with a side of super dark chocolate. The bitterness slowly fades to a drying, less bitter espresso taste. Notes of toasted bread come through with a hints of somewhat burnt edges. Full and chewy body with just the right amount of coffee and chocolate aftertaste. I could drink/contemplate this beer all day. Fantastic!

A nice dark brown body with a nice brown head that faded away a little too quickly.  Aroma had good roasted malt notes, I could really get the coffee.  Some sweetness from chocolate malts and oats.  There was a faint hint of smoke in the background.  Flavor was velvety smooth.  There was great roasted coffee notes upfront,  a sweetness from the chocolate really complemented the coffee notes.  Finish had a mix of mild smoke  and some hops.  It did have a nice sweetness to it, probably from the oats. A well balanced beer.

500ml bottle pours black in color with a 3 finger beige head that has excellent retention and leaves some lovely lacing on the glass.  Aroma is dark roasted malts and hints of coffee and hops.  Taste is roasted malt and coffee bitterness balanced with a chocolate malty sweetness with a hoppy bitter finish.  Medium to full body with decent carbonation.  This is a truly outstanding stout and is highly recommended.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Dark brown/black body, medium thickness khaki cap, spotty lacing.

S: Rich roasted coffee, oatmeal, a little smoke.

T: Like the nose, Beer Geek is dominated by a nice coffee presence and is backed by a nice semi-sweet oatmeal base.  Mild bitterness and a trace of smoke.

M: Medium-full bodied.  Nice creamy thickness.  

O: A very nice stout that fits in well with the others in the series.

Beer Geek pours black.  Pitch black.  A huge tan crater filled head is poured.  Great retention and lacing.  Now for some reason I thought I was going to be blasted with coffee in the nose but I didnÂ’t not that I was disappointed by that I didnÂ’t but I would of figured since it was called Beer Geek Breakfast that more coffee would be in there.  Usually my kind of breakfast is a nice latte from Starbucks =)  Instead I think the star of the aroma is another breakfast treat. Oats.  Nice oatmeal like aroma.  Backed up by espresso, roasted malt, and a tiny bit of a grassy hop aroma.

Taste is basically the same but things seem a bit more balanced.  The coffee and roasted malt notes I got from the smell definitely match up nice with the oats.  ItÂ’s more 50/50.  The taste is slightly bitter from the coffee and slightly dry from the hops.  I could drink this stuff everyday for breakfast =)  Mouthfeel is medium bodied, silky, and goes down smooth.

Bottle from Stirchley Wines, Birmingham. Opaque black, brown head. Smells very roasty, mocha-like. Mouthfeel is unbelievably smooth, oily, rich and thick. The flavour of rich coffee is powerful, controlled and consistent from front of tongue to back of throat. CanÂ’t tell itÂ’s 7.5%. Really extremely good.
Poured a nice black color with a tan frothy head that laced the glass. Has a nice smooth roasted flavor as well as hints of coffee.

1 pint .9 fl oz  bottle in Guinness pint glass.  Pours as dark as an ex-spouseÂ’s soul.  Moderately active reddish head dissipates quickly, some lacing remains.  Aroma is as expected for style.  Taste is very good and smooth.  Little carbonation or alcohol evident.  Pretty yummy, one of the few oatmeal stouts I have tried that can rival Samuel Smith.

20/05/2011 Brasserie 4:20 (tap). Nera densa, impenetrabile, lieve schiuma color cappuccino, poco persistente. Al naso Ã¨ caffettosa con luppolo ben in evidenza, note di cioccolato e vaniglia. In bocca Ã¨ principalmente amara, caffettosa, solo appena dolciastra. Al palato Ã¨ vellutata, cremosa, con corpo pieno, restituisce sensazioni simili alla Imperial Stout di NÃ¸gne Ã˜. Non eccessivamente carbonata. Una stout di primissimo livello, davvero notevole.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2012 Pours black with caramel thin head.   aroma is striking. This is what a stout should smell like , smokey, coffee, and hops.  flavor is spot on    smokey  chocolate roasty clean and refreshing for a stout  wow   this is amazing    best stout ever

From bottle. Colours is black, fantastic brown/tan 2-3 fingerbreadth head which lasts long. Aroma is coffee, mokka and malt. Taste: Sweet malty, dark chocolate, roasted tones and coffee. Smooth and easy to drink, but with a bitter aftertaste. Medium-full bodied. Great beer!

Poured close to black with a pinky thick mocha/Carmel color head.  Aroma is sweet and malty with a hint of sweet oatmeal.  Flavor earthy, roasted coffee is very prevalent, in a good way.  Toasted malts and chocolate undertones, this one is close to the top of my list.

Bottle. Black coloured beer with a huge dark brown head. Complex roasted coffee aroma with some grainy chocolat hint. Full creamy almost thick palate. Finish is light alcoholic roasted with hints of coffee and dark bitter chocolate. Longer roasted taste. Complete.

Bottle from El IrlandÃ©s. Batch #582. This one appears in the glass with an impenetrable black color with a big rocky brown head that diminishes very slowly and laces well. Aroma is malty, deep, showing especially toasted coffee grains, bitter chocolate, oat, truffles and vanilla. Solid and elegant but as it warms you start getting slight hoppy notes of lemongrass that counterbalance in a heavenly way. Taste is roasted but finely supported by the malty sweetness. Generous strong coffee notes dominate everything else and persist even several minutes after the last sip. Under that there is a second layer with hints of chocolate, caramel malt, cereal, vanilla and a very soft trace of hop bitterness. I perceive this as a classic, prototypical oatmeal stout but with added complexity of hops. This stout showcases an oily texture, low carbonation and a tremendously smooth full body. In the end, a long and fine roasted finish leaves an intense aftertaste. A breakfast beer but you could still pair it with oysters, bacon and smoked ham. A perfectly made Danish stout that I would love to have for breakfast every day.

Bottle/500ml - Pours a very dark, oily black/brown in color with a medium dark tan head that eventually settles to a creamy eighth inch covering over the top of the beer.  No lacing, but a nice cohesive head.  Aroma is big of darkly roasted malts, some chocolate and coffee/espresso along with some smaller amounts of dark fruits and just a hint of alcohol bite.  Flavor is also strong of the dark malts, chocolate malts and a fairly intense amount of hop bitterness.  Better than average palate, but not quite what I expected from the oatmeal.  Some of the fruitiness is also not present, as expected.  Lingering flavor of dark malts, hop bitterness, coffee/espresso and medium hop bitterness. Really good...
(Bottle 30/12-2011) Low dark brown head, black color, roasted coffee aroma, smooth balance roasted coffee taste, soft co2. Batch # 659, brew date 13.07.11, BB date 13.07.16.
650 ml bottle shared at the Bayou. Coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, caramel, fruity, dark stone fruits. Finish is dry, very well balanced.
I find this beer a bit overrated. MikkellerÂ’s Beer Hop Breakfast is better. This beer is a nice oatmeal stout with a dry/roasted body. The burnt flavor lingers a bit without much other character

Poured from a bomber into an English pint glass.  Color is dark brown with a thick, dense light brown head and some sediment floating throughout.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee, and alcohol.  Flavor is complex with coffee and chocolate at the start, some alcohol and a touch of smoke through the middle, and nice hop flavors present at the finish.  Palate is creamy with slight astringency from the coffee and hops.  Overall an extremely well balanced and tasty stout.  Too expensive to drink regularly, but definitely worth a try!

Bottle. Dark brown with a huge, thick, tan head. Aroma of fresh roasted coffee, cocoa, caramel, and some vanilla. Flavor is bitter coffee and roasted malt with some light chocolate sweetness. Full body with average carbonation and a dry dusty mouth feel. Really nice coffee stout, lots of roasted coffee aroma and taste yet still very drinkable.

Tap. Very dark body with a small brownish head. The nose is a lovely combination of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee. The taste is pleasingly dry and smooth. Bitterness abounds, but not overwhelming. The palateÂ’s nicely stable, full and oily. Overall, a really great beer.

Yes, this is a chocolate coffee oatmeal stout from a highly praised Euro brewer.  Well balanced and refined.  Light smoke.  Medium bitterness with a short sustain.  Nice coffee aftertaste.  Not quite as robust as I prefer for a coffee stout. More delicate, than I imagined.  IÂ’d consider it a "light coffee stout".  Perhaps thatÂ’s why they market it as a breakfast beverage.  Founders Breakfast Stout is much better and it doesnÂ’t cost anywhere near $10 a pint.
Keg at BD. Pours black/darkbrown eith resilient tan head. Great coffee and mild chocolate roast flavour. Velvety and sharp. A fantastic beer.

Tap. Nice dark colour with a chocolate coloured head. Nice deep coffee aroma. Taste of coffee and bitter chocolate. Bitterness of coffee really apparent. Long finish. Definitely a good choice for breakfast. But just one!

Bottle.  Black with a thick dark brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, and some burnt sugar.  Taste is mild sweet, mild bitter, roasted with lots of coffee.  Dry roasted finish.  Medium bodied and very smooth, maybe a little watery.  Quite good.
Tap at brewdog. Black with tan head. Coffee and chocolate aroma. Morenof the same on the taste. Perfectly balanced, good body. Delicious

500ml bottle. Black pour with a big mocha head that lasts and leaves a nice lace. Huge nose of chocolate and coffee. A little more lively on the palate with some noticeable fruit character. Finishes with a good coffee vibe.

Tan head. frothy. big beer. coffee, grains, cereal, burnt toast, chocolate.

Taste: wow. hops amongsy the toast, very nice.
Great. chocolate.

500 ml bottle bought @ Ã˜lbutikken and consumed on November 29. Pours oily black with a creamy chocolate brown head that dissipates very slowly while leaving some trace on the glass. Smell is slightly sweet with roasted malts, some liquorice and lots of coffee. Taste is sweet with heavily roasted malts, tons of coffee, some liquorice, some soy and a good amount of bitter chocolate. Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth. Finish lasts a fortnight and is bitter with coffee. Very nice!
500ml bottle.  Pours pitch black with a large head.  Aroma is black coffee, some tar.  Taste is bready to start.  Coffee finish with a little tar on the lasting finish.
Great taste... Chocolate, coffee... a little bitter taste afterward. Not so impressive at nose but a very good beer generally. I think it could largely improve with 5 or 10 years of age.

Pitch black ale with a large, creamy, tan head. Excellent retention. The aroma is of chocolate, espresso and caramel... everything deeply roasted and rich. Lightly sweet flavor balanced by light bitterness. Charcoal, mocha, ash and vanilla. Full-bodied and milky with soft carbonation. Finishes dry, burnt and softly bitter.

From bottle.
Colours is black, fantastic brown/tan 2-3 fingerbreadth head which lasts long.
Aroma is coffee, mokka and malt.
Taste: Sweet malty, dark chocolate, roasted tones and coffee. Smooth and  easy to drink, but with a bitter aftertaste. Medium-full bodied. Great beer!

Smells of malt and coffee, pretty typical of a stout -- as is the appearance.  Palate on this was somewhat thinner than I expected and surprisingly, very bitter.  A bit of a let down, but still honorable.

Poured 22oz into a pint glass. It had a black ink appearance with a long lasting roasted espresso head. This is a perfect oatmeal stout, good with any meal. Well balanced roasted malt favors with strong coffee notes that jolt out of nowhere.

Bottle. Pours black with a big brown head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate Dark roasted malts, sweet malts. Taste is sweet, roasted, coffee and chocolate. Velvet fullbodied mouthfeel and a long sweet roasted aftertaste
Thick black-brown pour with thin beige head. Roasted chocolate nose. Full bodied, light carbonation with bitter coffee finish.

From the bottle. Poured black with a large tan head. Malts, caramels, and chocolate hit my nose. I remember thinking that not even in my wildest dreams could Mikkeller do wrong. Tastes rich, finishes bitter, and has such a balanced body. I could see myself starting my day with this one and moving on to Brunch...

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2013 This is clearly the best sout in the world, pours pitch black with brown head with reagular retencion. It has an intense aroma with notes of heavilu roasted malts, chocolate, caramel. The body is medium to robust, the flavor is excelent, it has the same notes as the aroma but with the adition of citrusy hop notes, it starts bittersweet and ends bitter

fine light brown head, pitch black. nice almost fat nose with rye, peat, lightly bitter chocolate, sugar. it just evolves and evolves. allmost fullbody and quite long. soft and very pleasant with a light bitter finish. notes of coffe, dark chocolate, and a litgh spicey finish. Very good, but maybe to heavy for breakfast at working days...

16.9oz bottle from Sendiks Brookfield (what is that, half liter?).  Pours super dark black with large foamy brown head. So dark I cannot tell in tipping if carbonated or not. Aroma is chocolate, coffee, oatmeal. Mostly rich chocolate. Quite sweet smelling.  Taste is smooooooth bittersweet chocolate, some coffee, soy, some vinious fruit. Did I mention super smooth ....  Very drinkable. Finishes somewhat long and bittersweet with some alcohol presence.  Lovely!

Black with tan head. Pours like motor oil. Strong chocolate nose with some dark roast coffee and vanilla. Thick and velvety with good carbonation. Somewhat astringent bitter dark coffee with chocolate and some smoke. A bit too bitter, but mouth-feel is terrific, and still a very good beer.
oily feel, slick feel, soft carbonation, long finish, full body, cough drop, raisin, smoke, vanilla, smoke, earthy,

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2012 Keg at BrewDog, Edinburgh. Pours a thick dark black, small light brown head. Aroma of oatmeal, chocolate, coffee, a little burnt toast. Taste is outstanding, one of my absolute favourite tasting beers. Fundamentally bitter, with coffee, chocolate and a definite oatmeal taste as well, with burnt toasty notes as well. Silky mouthfeel, taste lingers for a while. In terms of complexity, quality etc, this could almost pass for an Imperial Stout (even though it isnÂ’t), in my opinion. And it doesnÂ’t get any less rewarding as you drink on - it keeps on going. Utterly wonderful. EDIT: Had it in bottle, and itÂ’s not nearly as good as keg. Took a couple of points off to equal it out.

50 cl bottle. Batch #412, BBE 17.03.2011.
Originally rated on 20091114.
Pours pitch black colour with a beautiful large, foamy and beige head. Aroma is lots of dark roasted malts, ashy chocolate, licorice, notes of smoke and coffee. Flavour of roasted and smoky malts, dry dark chocolate, coffee, oat, mocha and cacao. Full-bodied and smooth palate with a mouth-dying finish. Very delicious.
5327

I poured a 500ml bottle into a tulip glass.Appearance: Pitch black body without any traces of red. A very dark, brown, whipped cream-like head which retains and laces extremely well.Smell: Light dairy-aisle aroma with minor notes of iced coffee. The nose is surprisingly tame, although it indicates it will be more sweet than bitter.Taste: Beer Geek Breakfast is one of those beers that starts off with a bang, but then seems to fall victim to the law of diminishing returns. The first few sips are incredible, actually. Strong flavors of a robust, imperial oatmeal stout. A light sweetness throughout the first half, very cream-like. Then suddenly the roasted malts appear out of nowhere for a big, bitter taste. Bitter dark chocolate also emerges between the two flavors and again as the roasty flavor transitions to a light iced coffee sweetness. This is a very impressive and tasty palate.As I drink on, the laws of entropy affect the palate. The sweetness mellows out, and the coffee bitterness fades a little. It certainly remains a quality oatmeal stout through and through, but the overall palate seems better when itÂ’s not homogenized. I was also a little disappointed by the lack of real coffee flavor per se, although the coffee bitterness is plenty prominent. Mouthfeel: Soft, comfortable, and less thick than youÂ’d expect.Drinkability: This beer psyches you out. It looks, smells, and tastes a little like an imperial stout, but itÂ’s not since itÂ’s only 7.5% ABV. ItÂ’s surprising just how easy it is to gulp down and just how velvety smooth the texture is. This is a good beer to have as a liquid dessert.Overall, Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast is a perfect example of a higher end oatmeal stout, although I donÂ’t think it justifies its higher end price point of $13 a bottle.
a very approachable Stout. Nothing crazy here at 7.5% ABV. If you enjoy coffee and stouts, this is a good beer to try. I would be a good beer to serve with scrambled eggs and bacon!

Beautiful black body with medium, light brown head. Caramel, coffee, roasty and resin. Rich and balanced. Taste is smooth and spot on; but not as impressive as I expected. Not sure why this is so much higher rated than other tasty stouts. Have to agree itÂ’s a great quality brew though with no faults. Especially good long aftertaste.

Aged this one about a year and a half which in hindsight was probably a little long given the abv...very tasty though, and I like the drinkability.  Strong oatmeal flavor and a ton of coffee I like the balance in it and the overall flavor...a little more intensity from a fresh one would be a good experiement.

pours black with a lasting tan head and some moderate lacing.  very pleasing, semi-sweet aroma of chocolate and coffee.  soft carbonation and a medium heavy body make for a very sultry and rich texture.  taste is primarily coffee with a fairly strong hop character that balances well against the chocolate malt sweetness.  each sip leaves a syrupy residue on the lips.  finish is bitter-sweet chocolate and coffee beans.  quite warming.  I canÂ’t imagine a more lovely, well-balanced coffee stout.

65 cl bottle from Kulminator. 2007 vintage in 2011. Dark brown/black liquid with big brown head. Aroma is malty with notes of coffee, oats, dark chocolate, port wine, roasted malt. A bit oxidized from the ageing. Taste is also very much coffee, medium bitterness and a bit of roastiness. Medium bodied with smooth mouthfeel. Served it a bit too cold, but got great as it warmed up. Really nice, love the coffee.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2015 16.9 fl oz bottle, purchased from DutchÂ’s for $10. Pitch black color, 2-finger thick brown head. Great lace. Active carbonation visible from the sides of the glass. Roasty, oat, chocolate, complex coffee aroma. Great coffee aftertaste that lasts and lasts. Great bitterness, with some sweet permeating all throughout. Wonderful full body and texture. The carbonation is stronger than I was expecting. A delicious and effective brew. Fantastic to enjoy outside in my backyard with my cat on this beautiful morning (IÂ’m supposed to drink this in the morning, right?). Quite large chunks at the very bottom of the glass. Looks kind of strange, but I swallowed most of them in my effort to finish every last drop of this brew. 8/5/9/4/17 Re-rate 6/11/15, on tap at DutchÂ’s: This is a batch brewed at Lervig in Norway in December 2014. Up front, I can quickly tell that I definitely donÂ’t like it as much as I recall liking the Nogne O version. Bit more metallic, kind of toasty and spicy, more of an astringent sort of coffee flavor. Moderate bitter taste, light to mdoerate sweet. Medium to bigger body. Smooth, kind of crisp light carbonation. Very dark brown color, near-black. Slightly translucent around the edges. Thin bubbly tan head, leaving decent bits of lace. A solid euro stout, but nowhere near as good as I remember. CanÂ’t tell if thatÂ’s my frame of reference expanding, or the quality of the beer dropping. Probably the former. 7/3/4/7/15 UPDATE 6/21/15: This has been growing on me more and more as I return to the taps to take more sips. Nice heavier roast malt, satisfying bit of coffee, mild dark fruit, pleasant earthiness. Enjoyable. Roasty. Assertive. Pleasantly chewy.
Very nice beer, Great smooth body with flavors of oats, coffee, tobacco, and chocolate. Not as good as the Brunch Weasel, but very good.

Strong aroma of roasted coffee beans, dark chocolate, mocha, and soya sauce. The mouthfeel is quite unique with its smooth creamy feeling. Despite having a pitch black body this stout strikes me as surpisingly easy to drink. This beer truly creates a pleasant drinking session, the head even looks like caramel! The aftertaste is dominated by dark coffee (espresso beans) and lasts forever. What a great stout!
Black with brown head - aroma is of roasted malts - taste is olso of roasted malt along with some coffee and chocolate - long lingering finish of roasted malts - this was very good
Bottle. Black. Medium nougat brown foam. Strong coffee toast roasted barley aromas. Tannin like smoke dry finish. Great beer from my idol in brewing.

Geruch malzschokoladig mit rÃ¶stigen Kaffeenoten, minimaler Fruchteinschlag. Malziger Antrunk mit leicht sÃ¤uerlicher Komponente, die eher bereichert als stÃ¶rend wirkt. AnschlieÃŸend sehr starke und dichte Kaffeearomen. Zum Abgang hin wird das Bier rÃ¶stiger, schokoladiger und erst jetzt macht sich eine ausgeglichene Bitterkeit bemerkbar. Zweifellos ein ziemlich gutes Bier, dem es, um meinen Geschmack zu treffen, aber etwas an Dichte fehlt.Test vom 16.9.2010, Gebinde: Glasflasche

Pours pitch black with a small tan head. Smells strongly of coffee and oatmeal, also malty. Taste confirms the smell, very strong coffee flavor, oatmeal flavors make very a very smooth taste and finish. Medium bodied and very smooth, overall a great stout heavily centered around coffee.

A very rich full bodied Stout. The funny thing about it is that it would fit so perfectly with the breakfast. Smell and taste of lots of coffee and chocolate. But there is a nutty character and i detect something that is similar to oatmeal.
Pours black with a thick dark tan head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, oats and malts. Flavor roasted malts, chocolate, coffee and a hint of molasses. Medium bodied with a silky smooth finish.

Pours pitch black color with a thick caramel head.  Aroma is of coffee, big-time maple syrup, molasses, malt, and oats.  Nice palate, not too carbonated. Flavor has a nice chocolate coffee front, with some nuts, roasty malt, and soy. Leaves a maple syrup and coffee finish.  World class stuff here.

07/05 0.5 l bottle courtesy of ogivlado, thanks for sharing! It poured pitch blac body with bigger brown head. Nice and strong aroma of roasted malt, especially coffee, licorice and some citrus as well. Light coffee flavor, balanced with dark chocolate, some dried fruit, touched with citrus hops. Medium body, longer bittersweet finish, dominated mostly by coffee of course. Very nice one for sure, though expected a bit more.
Same bottle as pictured. Really interesting aroma with mostly coffee and smooth vanilla. Taste is similar. Body was a little thinner than expected. Very good.

Bottle 0,5l, pours pitch black with large fluffy light brown head...... for the nose is there coffee, chocolate some hops.... the flavor is sooooo nice.... coffee, espresso,hops....a little thin, body. the mouthfeel and the finish is light bitter hops.... very nice.....

Forgot that i had this one at a stout tasting sometime ago, but the impression it left on me still remains. Big, dark brooding beer. Full of character, full rich aromas, very complex with loads of roast and black malt. A big licorice hit in this too which to me suggests a good amount of a darker crystal malt or similar malt. the mouthfeel is quite unctuous and rich, very filling. the alcohol is held in check and leaves you wanting more.

Pours deep black with coffe notes that progress into a dense but easy drinking stout that gives hints of chocolate and a dose of coffee that runs to the finish.  The grains (oats) make it drink much smoother than I expected.
Pours black with a tan head. Aromas of dark roasted coffee and chocolate. Creamy coffee flavors.  Finishes a little thin like black coffee.  Overall an excellent beer.

Pure black with nice head. Smells of chocolate and coffe, some sweetnes similar to an imperial stout.
Tastes of coffe, coffe and coffe with some added cream. I think i need another bottle!

Draft @ Cask Pub & Kitchen, London on 27th November 2010. Black with pale brown foam head and smooth partial lacing. Moccha coffee aroma. Main taste is burnt coffee, very bitter chocolate, with late rich hoppy bitterness. Dry finish, light carbonation, leathery texture. Lasting bitter finish. Excellent.
Bottle from Alko Arkadia. Originally rated on 16.6.2009. Filling and tasty oatmeal stout.
Bottle, pours a nice dark black thick beer. smell was pretty good a bit of coffee, bit of coco, taste was a very smooth coffee taste. Greatly enjoyed this one
bottle, jet black pour with huge mocha head. flavours dominated by the roasty coffee malts. not much beyond that. good beer, just a little overrated.

Bottle.  Dark brown pour with mocha head.  Aromas of expresso, roasted malt, and muted chocolate.  The taste pretty much follows suit with a hint of anise and bitter hops.  The body is a little thin with a medium mouthfeel...
Very dark brown with big tan head. Aroma is chocolate and really nice coffee roastiness. Flavor is similar; dark chocolate and espresso, sweet and smooth. Delicious.

Bouteille de 500ml. Batch 540. BiÃ¨re noire avec une mousse brune, elle est visqueuse lors du versement. Le nez empeste les malts rÃ´tis et grillÃ©s. Il y a un amalgame de cafÃ©, chocolat. En bouche cette biÃ¨re de dÃ©jeuner est crÃ©meuse, ronde, douce, le cafÃ© est prÃ©sent. Elle est un peu sucrÃ©e.  Une douce amertume agrÃ©mente le tout. 9/10

(Batch 540)  The look :   Absolutely black and opaque with a strong and persistent brown head.  Very nice lacing.  The nose: Crazy smell of dark malts and coffee with a touch of milk chocolate.  Hops are there to.  The taste: Marvellous notes of coffee, roasted malts and bitter hops blended with good chocolate.  The mouthfeel: Body is full, obviously rounded by oats.  Carbonation is perfect, soft and silky.  Smooth and rich texture.  The finale: Long and roasted with a very nice kiss from the hops.  The appreciation : Just amazing!

50 cl bottle. #412, BBE 17.3.2011, brygget 17.3.2009
Heavily roasted aroma has coffee and liquorice. Flavour has lots of burnt coffee and very roasted malt. Also some dark chocolate and vanilla. Very good stout, especially for coffee lovers.

Pitch black with loads of amazing deep brown foam. Amazing looking and incredibly appealing looking. Nose is packed with coffee, chocolate, cacao and fudge. Full bodied, smooth with a nice creamy texture. Taste is dominated by coffee and dark malt. Just a tremendous beer.
Completely opaque and thick dark brown head.  Strong dark roasted coffee nose, mouthfilling coffee and dark bitter chocolate with a very long finish on a full body.  Terrific.
tap on 7/3/11 - pours a dark opaque brown with a khaki head. Aroma is of alcohol, floral, malt, and coffee. Taste has lingering bitterness, coffee and toast. Medium weight, creamy mouth feel.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2011 Date: July 3, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Beer Tasting, Bloomington, MN Appearance: Opaque dark with medium amount of head Aroma: Coffee/Chocolate Flavor: Consistent with aroma Other: Great beer, it was thick almost like I was eating it instead of drinking.
Bottle. Jet black pour with a smaller thick head. Aroma is smoke, bacon, coffee, and chocolate. Taste is similar to aroma. Great mouthfeel. Tremendous beer.

Bottle. Pours pitch black, thick, with a huge brown creamy head. Aroma of roasted malts, dark roasted coffee. Taste of deep roasted malts, nice bitter from the hops and roasted malts, some good dark liquorice. Lingering dark malty, moderate bitter/sweet, this is good stuff.
Pretty good stout. Opague black. Smells and taste like it should: coffee, roasty, chocolate and a bit hoppy. Pretty good.

Tasting with BuckeyeSammy and Scott from ChuckÂ’s. pours dark chocolate with mocha head. Roasted coffee beans, bitter cooking chocolate, bread and roasted oats on the nose. Fairly straightforward flavor, dry with all of the above expectations hitting your palate. good beer but not MikkellerÂ’s best out there.

Pours oily. Black. Lots of brown head, that is actually difficult to distinguish from the black beer at first. Strong nose of coffee, roasted, almost burnt malt, and a tad alcohol. A little bit of hoppy scent is also in there. Well balanced taste. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee. Chocolate or apple aroma, with a sweet taste. Full feel.

Bottle split with mcberko. Pours a solid black with a small caramel coloured head. Aroma of espresso/dark roast coffee, dark chocolate, oatmeal. Flavour of dark roasted coffee (predominantly), oatmeal, chocolate - milder than the aroma. Full bodied, dark, tasty!

Really just a perfect example of a coffee stout. A deep black color with a foaming tan head. The aroma is rich coffee but i still get some hops through the nose. So well balanced roasted taste. I could really see having this at breakfast

Black with  big, creamy, cappuccino head / Nose of roast coffee / Medium body, light acidity, chewy with good balance and finish / Simple but rich flavors of dark roast coffee and unsweetened chocolate, with notes of lemon and oats / Very good, but a little one dimensional.
Pitch black, opaque. Creamy, (light) brown head. You can really smell the centennial and cascade hops. Taste is a nice blend of hops and stout and coffee. Palate is good.

I love this beer.  Aroma is coffee and roasted malts.  Flavor is lightly sweet and very smooth with a great chocolate taste, and of course COFFEE.  If you dont like coffee beers then this is not for you but if you do this is very tasty and smooth and quite delicious.

16.7oz bottle poured into English pint for breakfast.  Seriously, itÂ’s 8:46am right now.  Pours a nearly pitch black with a luscious brown 1 finger head.  As the creamy head disappates, the aroma left behind is everything I could evey want from a stout.  Bold bittersweet chocolate, coffee, smoke, and dark fruits dominate.  Taste is just as bold as the smell, the bittersweet chocolate and coffee dominate the flavor as it slides across your palate, leaving a lingering smokiness, hop bitterness, and coffee aftertaste.  On the palate this beer is like a milkshake-- you can practically chew it.  The oats give this beer an uncommon viscosity as well as a super creamy texture.  Pair this texture with somewhat lively carbonation and you have a frothy, creamy beverage that will satisfy the breakfast needs of any beer geek!  Incredi-brew.  I can accept and support that this is the best-rated stout in the world.

Pours big, black, and has a huge dark tan head (be careful when you pour). Coffee dominates the nose, but youÂ’ll notice more layers once you take a sip. Oatmeal stout. Huge flavor, just the right amount of bitter, very well balanced between the coffee and oatmeal. ThereÂ’s even a dry, smokey, woody finish. Outstanding!

Keg at BrewDog Edinburgh. Inky deep brown, small mocha head. Rich nose of coffee, oatmeal and burnt toast. Taste is dry and bitter, but with just enough roasty malt to balance it out. More coffee, hint of oatmeal. Finish is long, bitter, burnt, leaves you longing for more. Amazing beer.

Nose of coffee covers milder aromas of caramel, dark fruit, chocolate and roasted malts.  Full bodied and smooth with a dry bitter coffee finish at the end.  Plenty of coffee and chocolate in the flavor with a nice roastiness to it.

Pours extremelly dark brown,almost black colour with medium,fast dissapearing brown head. Aromas of coffe, caramel, raisins, smoked figs , some hops,very complex. Taste is well balanced with coffe acsent. Finish is slightly dryish. Very complex and very good beer

The aroma is of malts and little bit of oatmeal while the appearance is jet black.  The flavor is very smooth and malty with a touch of coffee.  Have heard so many people review this and say its great and I cannot disagree with them.

Bottle. Thanks to Savvy1982!! Pours black with a nice mocha head. Aromas of chocolate,coffee,roasted oats, cereal and bitterness. Taste is chocolate and coffee at first. Some roastiness and more coffee. Full bodied with a long bitter finish. Awesome.

I have described other beers as "black", but this one is beyond black. This is like a black hole, without any Hawking radiation. Ok, thatÂ’s not quite true: when held up against a 300 W light bulb itÂ’s possible to discern a infinitesimally thin region close to the glass where the liquid is dark grey. When pouring the beer it seems very viscous, and out of this black lava a big, dense, creamy, brown head slowly emerges, itÂ’s almost a bit creepy to watch. The only thing that isnÂ’t absolutely perfect with the look of this beer is that the head gets rather small fairly quickly, and it doesnÂ’t create huge amounts of lacing. Smelling the beer reveals a delicious malty aroma with lots of roasted notes, chocolate and strong coffee. A promising hoppy scent is lurking in the background. The taste is initially light to medium sweet and light bitter followed by a moderate bitter finish and a very long bitter and roasted aftertaste. The flavours are roasted with chocolate, coffee, raisins, some alcohol and also some very nice hints of pine and grapefruit. Full body, oily texture, soft+ carbonation. A fantastic beer! 
[50 cl bottle, batch 580, from Vinmonopolet, Vika, Oslo]

On tap at Hopcat in tulip. Medium size tan head mean coffee and raosty aroma with some small sweet notes. Decent bitterness all the way through very roasty with great coffee flavors, very balanced malt sweetness and a hint of bittering hops. This beer overall is extremely balanced and has awesome coffee flavor.
Pours as pretty as can be. Great deep smokey flavor with some roasted coffee in the backround. Taste is also mainly smoke I donÂ’t get the coffee that I was expecting. A very good stout.

Just perfect.  The best coffee based beer, if not the best beer IÂ’ve ever tasted.  It took me enough time to finally try it but when I did about 2 months ago it was a special experience.  DidnÂ’t drink it with breakfast but easily could have.

Bottle (50cl) from Vinmonopolet (Oslo). Pitch black colour. Fingerthick brown head, quickly reducing to a thin film, no lacing. Complex aroma of coffee, chocolate, licorice, dried fruit, pine, wood, tar - nice balance between dryness and sweetness. Smooth, soft moutfeel. Taste is extremely well-balanced - dry, sweet and bitter (and a bit salty) in just the right proportions. A brew that is somewhat of a grower - I was not overly impressed initially, but the more I sniff and taste it, it gets better and better.

Head is initially large, brown, mostly lasting. 
Black body and chocolate and coffee aroma.
Taste is a bit bitter and sweet.
Creamy texture.
10/10 i mÃ¶rkhet. KrÃ¤migt milt rÃ¶kigt i doften. Fylligt rÃ¶kig i smaken, hÃ¤rligt rÃ¶kig i eftersmaken.
Black pour with beige head.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and coffee.  Flavor matches aroma with a little licorice and a bitter aftertaste.

Draft at CCB Nielsbohrium Release Party. Pours black with a medium tan head. Aroma is coffee, ash, chocolate, and licorice. Flavor is dark fruits, licorice, coffee, ash, chocolate, raisins, and leather. Full body with nice heat. Damn good.
Pours a black color with a medium tan head. Aroma is roasty malts, coffee, cocoa, and licorice. Taste is heavy roast. Ash, coffee. Vanilla. Palate is awesome. Heavy but balanced. Really good beer

Bottled 500ml. -Batch No. 471. Deep black coloured, medium to big sized brown head, strong roasty coffee nose. Roasted malt, coffee and dark chocolate but very smooth. Touch of tar in strong coffee finish. Complex and great beer.

Bottle courtesy of ogivlado who shared it with me and heavy, batch no. 471. Poured an almost pitch black body with a brown head. Fresh ground coffee tinged with lemon, very good stuff.  Light balanced roasty, slightly creamy coffeish soft, earthy. Lovely stuff, as good as I hoped it would be!

Shared 0.5l bottle. Pours a deep brown to black body with a thin creamy tanned head. Aroma is classic beer geek. Deep roasty flavors, mild dark chocolate and heavy on the coffee. Fantastic aromas. Full-bodied, medium carbonated and has a really nice creamy mouthfeeling. Flavors are nice roasted malts, good quality coffee, light licorice and itÂ’s ends with a warming and a near dry roasted feeling in the mouth with strong bitter coffee aftertaste. A simply fantastic stout.

500ml bottle poured into a pint glass.  The beer pours pitch black with brown head.  Notes of coffee, and roasted malt on the nose, with some bitter hops too.  The taste is coffee and roasted malt, with some light toffee notes.  The beer is not sweet and is well balanced.  Very good stout overall.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2013 2007 Vintage 66 cl. [emailÂ protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */: huge bottle by standards, black with tanned head that pretty quickly shrank down to all this nothing, very unusual beer, may have been partially due to the aging, bottle says good until 2008, roasted malt, milk chocolate, bitter coffee, oatmeal, burned toast, touch of smoke, especially in smell which is a touch lighter than the taste, wild non-eatable berries, grains, hint of spoiled cream, body was surprisingly lighter & less thick than I expected it to be /// Tried a 33 cl. bottle of the new version, way better than the previous one, much fuller, more bitterness but overall such a rich flavor // increased score from 4.1 to 4.6

Der Klassiker unter den Mikkeller Bieren. Nachdem ich bereits 3 spezielle Versionen des Bieres trinken durfte, komme ich endlich mal dazu, auch das Original zu testen. Pechschwarzes Aussehen, der Schaum ist mittelfest und dunkelbraun. Dunkler Malzgeruch mit kaffeartigen Hopfennoten. Im Antrunk zeigt sich das Bier genau so, wie man es sich bei Riechen vorstellt, tiefmalzig, gleichzeitig aber nicht unwichtig hopfig mit einer Kaffeenote, die hier noch keine groÃŸe Bedeutung hat. Er wird aber bereits im Mittelteil stÃ¤rker, der Hopfen wirkt ausgleichend. HintergrÃ¼ndig etwas bitter, zum Abgang hin stark bitter. Im Mittelteil dominiert kurz der Hopfen, eine leichte Alkoholnote erscheint. Sehr rÃ¶stmalzig, besonders im Abgang und Nachgeschmack ist dies das absolut dominierende Aroma. Dazu kommt eine dezente Bitterschokoladennote, die sich im Abgang etwas mehr zeigt. Granios ist das harmonische Zusammenspiel der Aromen und der Nachgeschmack, der genauso vollmundig wie das Bier selber ist. Besonders ab dem hinteren Mittelteil ein komplexes Stout mit vollmundigen sowie feinen Noten in viele Richtungen. Jawoll! 11/13/11/13/12/13

Deep black with a big brown head. Aroma of coffee, spice, chocolate and roasted malt. Taste is roasty with a touch of chocolate and a pronounced coffee flavor. The finish is long and a little bitter. Medium-full bodied and fluffy with mild carbonation. Good stuff

Finally had a shot at trying this fairly fresh.  Hints of roast, coffee, and dark chocolate on the nose.  Flavors run around the same bringing out a creamy blend of roasty coffee, dark chocolates dipped in milk chocolate, and a nice dark bittered finish that lingers strong.  Fine coffee stout right here!

50cL bottle. Pours a nice dark black brown. Smells of coffee (predominantly), a slight bit of salsa, and chocolate. Taste is initially of chocolate, coffee, and brown sugar. Then, after a while, lends itself slightly to a breakfast taste of salsa and a bit of egg before ending in coffee. Thick and smooth. Quite good.

16.9 oz bottle poured in a Guinness glass.
Dark black with a thick, dark, tan head that leaves a sheet of lace.
Aroma is coffee, chocolate, roasted grains, light molasses.
Creamy smooth mouth-feel. Flavors of coffee, bitter chocolate, oats and milk. Mild hoppy bitterness hits on the finish. Yum.

Pours pitch black with large dark-brown head. Aroma is dominated by roasted coffee with a very faint hint of hops. Taste is coffee, milk chocolate, vanilla, slightly sweet but ends on a bitter note courtesy of the hops. The mouthfeel is creamy and full with strong carbonation. Certainly easy to drink so I guess one actually could have one for breakfast. Good stout but lacks a certain something to make it stand out.

Bottle pours black with a beige head.  Aroma shows notes of dark chocolate, roast malt, coffee, and a big olÂ’ bowl of oatmeal.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of earth and light smoke.
Another challenging Mikkeller beer. Stiff, bitey and strong. We spilt a big bottle between three of us, kind of wish there wer six of us... Enjoyable, but hard to take in large doses.
Imported from Beerseek, no description given with original rating. Need to re-rate beer.
Bottle a black colored beer with a tiny beige head aroma roasted malts coffee spicy some fruits and hops flavor roasted malts coffee spicy laurel some fruits and some smoke and hops a balanced beer

Bottle. Pours black with dark brown hues against the light. A large head the color of mocha. Beautiful. Aroma is roastedness, coffee, slight hints of hops.  Later the hops disappear and are replaced with chocolate. Taste is a lot of coffee and roastedness. Hints of chocolate that get stronger later. Some hoppy bitterness near the end mixed with ashy roastedness. Palate is surprisingly light and carbonated.

500ml bottle, about a 14 months old so assuming the coffee will be faded. Pours a opaque black with a large creamy head that settles to a layer of velvet lacing. Roasted malts, cereal, coffee, bitterness from the hops - like the fact that its not sweet at all. Nice full bodied flavour, becomes quite bitter as it coats the mouth, get a bit of the alcohol, and some more coffee. Would prefer something with more upfront coffee but to be fair thatÂ’s more about the age then the beer. Overall a very nice stout - not necessarily worth a huge premium but still very tasty.

Pours an opaque black with a medium mocha head that dissipate but not entirely. Aroma is of slightly roasted grain malts, oatmeal, some coffee and chocolate scents with very subtle alcohol notes. Taste is mildly sweet throughout with a dry bitterness also present. Full bodied, slightly thick and fairly creamy on the palate, with soft carbonation and an abrupt finish. Overall an outstanding stout, the best stout I have ever had I believe.

Wonderful coffee nose.  Its Black!  The tan head that holds up and sticks to the sides of the glass the whole time.  A smokey expresso coffee ashey, balanced against the hops, not sweet.  Some harshness in the finish.  The palate is medium and a little flat.  This beer gets better as it comes up to room temp. and I like it more and more.

Bottle. Pours a pitch black beer with a chocolate head. The aroma is malt, roasted, coffee, licorice, ash and chocolate. The flavor is following the nose closely. The palate is sweetness and roasted. Overall a really good beer with a good balance and complexity.

Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast on musta olut. Sen vaahto on mokkaisen ruskea. Tuoksultaan olut on herkullisen kahvinen, paahtunut ja suklainen. Humaloinninkin voi aistia nenÃ¤llÃ¤. Se muistuttaa nenÃ¤ssÃ¤ lÃ¤hinnÃ¤ mÃ¤ntymetsÃ¤isiÃ¤ tuoksuja. Maku on kuivan kahvinen, katkerahko ja paahtunut. Ei mitenkÃ¤Ã¤n Ã¤lyttÃ¶mÃ¤n paksu, mutta ehkÃ¤ sellaista ei pidÃ¤ 7,5%:lta oluelta odottaakaan.

500ml bottle.  Pours super dark opaque brown with a chocolate brown head.  Aroma is dry and roasty with a bit of smoke.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied.  Tastes very dry and roasty.  Coffee, oats, smoke, bitter chocolate.  A solid beer but was expecting it to be just a bit better.

Reviewed from notes.

Poured into a snifter. The color is a deep, dark brown with a short light mocha head and a kiss of lacing on the side of the glass. IÂ’m watching college basketball, so I think that reference is only appropriate.

The nose is really nice with a strong odor of fresh-roasted coffee along with a bit of roasted malt. While the latter is there, the coffee is definitely on the center stage and is quite tasty. A bit one dimensional and I could use more depth, but the coffee definitely gets this up to a 4.0. Nice slightly bitter and roasted feel. A really nice coffee brew.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-14-2010

Bottle to snifter. Pour is black brown with a tight frothy tan head that dissipates to a thick collar. Aroma is coffee and roasted malt and some green pepper. Taste is burnt coffee and more roasted malt with some nuts and green pepper. Palate is full yet thin with a creamy tingle of carbonation and finishes dry.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2016 Bottle, september 11th 2015. Black body with a fine nut brown head. Aroma is roasty with chocolate, coffee, oatmeal, toast. Taste of roasted coffee, raisin, molasses, dry with a nice malt bitterness, smooth chocolate and coffee finish.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2011 Pitch black body brown head. Amazing sweet aroma of coffee, cereal, dark chocolate and more coffee. Smooth palate with almost no carbonation. Great sweet coffee flavour. Awsome. (10/5/10/4/19)


Pitch dark black body with a small brown head. Great aroma of coffee, dark chocolate and cereal. Full and smooth palate. Awsome sweet flavour of coffee and cereal, dry finish.

Bottle from Vinmonopolet. Pours dark, almost black, with a good creamy head and a full body. Aroma is roasted malts and coffee, with a hint of liquorice and some peat. Taste is very malty, with a lot of coffee and some smoke. ItÂ’s very heavy, but clean cut. Finish is quite dry, with notes of dark fruits sneaking up.

Pours dark brown, almost black, with a light brown head. Delicious coffee aroma with lots of roasted malt. Taste is more malts, a bit smoky, oats, more coffee. Very flavorful but still smooth, faint coffee bitterness. Quite delicious, very much looking forward to the bottle of brunch weasel I have stored away.

Bottle. Nearly black with a lighter tan head.  Roast, slight lactose, some sweetness, and nice coffee in the aroma.  Very coffee driven, and missing the sweetness in the aroma.  Bitter roasted malts, and a bit of a drier finish.  Rich, but not overly so and really digging this.  Only thing that keeps this from imperial in my mind (only considering the flavor) is the slightly thinner body.  Always a treat.
Pours totally black with a thick tan head. Aroma of alcohol and coffee. Rather heavy body and extremely smooth mouthfeel. Little to no booze on the palate. Big coffee on the finish.

Needless to day this beer also goes well after dinner while watching hockey.  I suspect it would go well in many occasions! dark roasty and oozing with coffee beans. Nice finger size head with good retention and exceptional lacing.

Bought a bomber of this beer at a local beer store, split it with my wife. Poured into standard pint glasses. Pours black, with an aggressive and thick brown head, seems to disappear after a few moments. Beer smells like a strong stout, hints of alcohol and roasted malt. Smells a little smokey. First flavor is of roasted malt. I am new to the breakfast stout genre of beer, but I do not detect a lot of coffee or oats. This may be my failing and not that of the brewery. All and all, a drinkable and fine stout.

Serving type: bottle

Aroma coffee, fine dark chocolate, grassiness, earthy, espresso roast, hazelnuts. Pour dark black with tan/coffee creamy head decent lace. Taste very deep coffee roast, almost a maple sweet burn, caramel, dark chocolate, slight herbal taste. MF rich and creamy full body with a nice fine carb. Great brew and really highlights the coffee/roasty aspects well done.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2011 30 May 2011, bottle. dark black, thin looking w/ fizzy brown head that fades fast. nose isnÂ’t quite coffee, it is more roasted malt w/ a faint wateriness. med body and fairly fizzy, slightly oily. great balance. huge coffee flavour but there is a big oatmeal or malt profile that keeps it from being a bitter coffee stout that is so common. there is a slight acidic burnt coffee finish. very nice!

(original rating 30 March 2011 - 8, 4, 7, 3, 16 = 3.8) looks like dirty engine oil when pouring and has a very thick fizzy head. smells strongly of alcohol (i would guess more than the 7.5%). iÂ’ve smelled beer that smells exactly the same, just canÂ’t place it. wow! med/thin body. very bitter. bitterness isnÂ’t first flavour but quickly dominates. flavour is heavily burnt/roasted malt. this is a good beer but there are others like it and it isnÂ’t great. lots and lots of coffee flavours. reading it was an oatmeal stout made me notice some cereal flavours.
Black/darkish brown. Aroma of coffee and some roasted malts. Flavour very much loaded with coffee, and dark chocolate. Some bitterness in the aftertaste.

Bottle from 12many.  IÂ’ve had this one a few times and have itÂ’s always a pleasure to drink.  A huge aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee.  Flavor is not as sweet as the aroma, but more dry, with lots of roast and coffee, and finishes bitter like a cup of black coffee.  Awesome stuff.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2011 The beer pours a dark black with a great dark tan head that rises about 3 finger and has decent retention falling to a thick soapy head with decent lacing. 

The aroma is medium in strength and at first all you get is coffee. As you dig a little deeper there is a little sweet chocolate. 

The taste is light, it starts a little sweet but then the rest start to finish is coffee. However, I love this coffee taste because its not overpowering, to strong, and its incredibly smooth to drink.

The feel is medium, decent viscosity but terrible lasting. Great drinkability.

Overall, IÂ’m very impressed. IÂ’m not a coffee stout fan at all, but this one is incredible. Its not to much coffee and very easy to drink.
Pours black with dark tan head.  Aroma of coffee, chocolate and burnt malts.  Taste is pretty much the same with some balancing hops thrown in as well. Nice

Aroma heavy in black coffee.  Looks dark and thick with a brown head that doesnÂ’t go anywhere.  Taste is bitter at first but quickly changes to dark and roasty.  The coffee and oats are.all there but the hops shine through.  Truly delicious.

0,5 l. bottle from HÃ¸keren, Copenhagen. Batch # 540. Very dark black colour, thick and oily looking with a thick brown head. Very dominant coffee aromas with some toasted malts. Coffee with grainy flavors -- especially the oat. Brown sugar sweetness with just a hint of cocoa. The flavours get really well together. Full bodied and creamy, with more carbonation that you would expect in a stout. Big and lasting untill tomorrow aftertaste of burnt toast, bitter coffee flavors linger a long time. Enjoyed with a full chocolate cake as a dessert. Just as coffee is perfect for dessert, this is even more perfect...

Tried this from my buddyÂ’s private selection. Thanks Steve! I have a bottle of Beer Geek Brunch Weasel, which IÂ’ve heard is better than this, but I wanted to try this so I could have something to base it off. Pours black with a thick, creamy beige head. Aroma is chocolate, earthy coffee, and a definite hoppy, citrusy aroma. Must be from the Cascade hops, because it smells like a double IPA. Flavor is much of the same: chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, and a slight citrusy hop bitterness in the finish. Mouthfeel is velvety smooth, which is to be expected from an oatmeal stout. Definitely worth the hype. IÂ’m excited to try Weasel now!!!

Hazy black with a large beige head. Aroma is chocolate, caramel, coffee, dark fruits, vanilla. Full body with low carbonation. In mouth, itÂ’s starts with a good chocolate and caramel taste, then is coffee for a long and enjoyable finish.

I came to this beer a sceptic. Can a beer really be that good? Have to say that drinking this is comparable to drinking a fine French Burgundy wine. Colour pours dark brown with an enticing chocolatey foamy head tinged with brown. Aromas are primarily chocolate malt with coffee and then a subtle citrous nose at the end. Flavour is beautiful refined and balanced. Mainly chocolate, coffee and like the nose, a bit of grapefruity hop zing at the end but very subtle. No bitterness, this is all smooth flavours perfectly balanced together. I guess the hype is for real.

500ml bottle.

It pours a tick, dark black. The head is tick, large and tan. It isnÂ’t as impressive as other Beer Geek Variations but it does work. Thick lacing rims the walls of the glass as the fluffy head slowly recedes.

The smell is roasty, a huge coffee note dominates. More sniffing introduces toffee, caramel, and chocolate.

The flavor is thick and roasty. Tons of roasted malt and coffee are in the flavor. There is surprisingly little malt to compete with the bitterness. There is a light bit of tartness and chocolate. It isnÂ’t as good as the variations that came out of it, but it is solid.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-10-2010 02:31:16
