UPDATED: APR 9, 2012 The most intese coffee stout I have ever had but that also kinda kills it cause its way to roasted. Either way a must try.

16.9oz bottle poured into a snifter. No freshness info. Okay so poured a little too fast and it foams up like crazy. Guess I was a little anxious. Pitch black in color and the head is frothy like root beer only a darker brown. Nice lacing. Delicate malt on the nose with rich coffee notes and hints of milk chocolate and alcohol. Rich and silky mouthfeel, like thick hot chocolate. Full bodied but not too syrupy. Carbonation is too low but probably because of how I poured it. Soft flavors on the palate. Everything is mildly blended together and comes together perfectly. Nothing overpowers so everything can be enjoyed. The malt has a kind of spicy quality on the palate that is different. Coffee and dark chocolate come to dominate and linger with a touch of honey in the finish. the finish is fairly clean and makes it super easy to drink. Definitely the best oatmeal stout I have had.

Pour is dark brown/black with a frothy tan head. Oatmeal stouts ; it has been quite a while. Excellent retention in this snifter. Chocolate and Coffee beans on the nose - there is a sharp coffee note, coupled with the oats on the tip of the tongue. The midpoint of this brew is very light, but creamy as well with the excellent head of the brew. The finish gives you that touch of sweetness from the chocolate. Fantastic!

Bottle; older style one - like in the picture.  Pour is pure black with a thin ring of tan head. Pretty imposing for a 7.5% beer.  Aroma is sweet roasted malt with hints of toffee, distant hop, light brown sugar, faint smoke, and milk chocolate.  Not much oxidation in the aroma. Flavor is rich roasted malt and coffee with hints of cholcolate, light smokey ash, faint dark fruit, with a clean dark-roast malt finish. Almost no oxidation to speak of which surprises me because I know this bottle in 3-5 years old and I have had very average luck aging Mikkeller stouts. Very tasty.

On tap at MaxÂ’s, Super dark color, huge dark copper tone tan head. Very nice lacing. Drank out of a tulip glass. 10.9% alcohol content was very potent. Chicory coffee flavors, Sweet, medium, smoky oat flavors. Loved this beer.

Pours pretty much jet black with a good sized tan head for a stout.  Lots of brown sediment is evident at the bottom of the glass.  A nice but not particularly strong nose of coffee and licorice.  A nice change of pace from all the Imperial Stouts I find myself drinking most often these days.    Coffee dominates the flavor, with a bit of leather on the tale end.  ThereÂ’s also a nice dose of crisp hops in the background that provides good balance.  My only complaint is that the mouthfeel is perhaps a bit light, but then this isnÂ’t an Imperial, after all.  A really nice beer that I expect to drink again---certainly the best offering from Mikkeller that IÂ’ve had so far.

Black with a big dark brown head. Aroma is hard roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate and hoppy - grapefruit and grass. Flavor is rather sweet and nicely bitter. Dry and roasted bitter finish. Full bodied. A brilliant stout that fully deserves itÂ’s current rating as number one among stouts. 080610

On tap @ Beer Temple. Black colored, opaque. Dense, beige head, but not much. Hard roast & mocha/coffee as aromaÂ’s. Bitter flavor, heavy roast. Lots of roast in the finish. Not really what I expected, and not very subtle.

Poured from bottle to a goblet. Dark brown/black. Poured with a thick smooth tan head. Light lacing on glass. Smells roasted and bitter and caramel with all sorts of subtle nuances I canÂ’t name. Coffee, dark chocolate, nut, roasty. Hints of spicy. Mineral notes. Long finish.

This is one fantastic looking beer! Pours a thick black with a great brown foamy head. Laces the glass well. Aroma is coffee, and roasted oat malts. Smooth and a nice balance of the bitter coffee flavors and some sweet chocolatey malt. Soft and creamy on the palate.  Just a great example of the style. Nothing is overpowering. Great, easy to drink beer.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2011 La Fin du Monde glass. Pure black. Giant, medium brown head, not going anywhere. Awesome. Aroma of bourbon, meat, coffee (predictably). Wow. An intimidating flavor experience. Syrupy, thick, challenging. So chewy. Clings to the palate, like it doesnÂ’t want to go away. Burnt finish that lingers forever. A lot going on here. Incredible. Eventually, a bit of tequila rolls onto the tongue. So sticky on the palate. This doesnÂ’t want to leave. Well deserving of its percentile. Need some time with this one, but it is outstanding.

Rating #999. 500ml bottle. Poured with a medium sized, thick & creamy, slowly disappearing light brown head with a slight reddy hue. A thin though heavy lacing and an opaque black/very dark brown body with a fine dark brown edging. The coffee is quite delicate but nicely bittersweet & creamy on the aroma accompanied by notes of chocolate, juicy dark (dried) fruits with a mild tang and some backing roastiness. On the tongue the coffee is a lot more prominent, following a slightly tangy dark fruit tone and roasted maltiness. Coffee, dark chocolate and roasted malts really meld together well & linger on the palate. Mildly warming on the throat initially, medium carbonation - quite dry in terms of mouthfeel & bitterness. Medium body and a lovely dark finish rounded off by a lightly tangy choccy aftertaste.

The beer in the glass is black as night, with dark brown, thick head. The smell is absolutely intoxicating. Strong roasted malt aromas, coupled with lots of coffee and chocolate and a hint of smoke. The BGB starts with a powerful malt body and a lot of coffee roasted aromas, which also contains lots of chocolate and toffee and a subtle, but absolutely perfect smoky taste. Also in the aftertaste, the smoke aroma is still there, besides the strong coffee and roasted malt aromas. At the center part, the smoky aroma disappears almost completely, but the strong malt body will holds the position completely!

UPDATED: APR 29, 2012 Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours a very deep brown-black with a thick, two finger tan head. Aromas of chocolate, roasted malts, loads of coffee. Flavours of coffee, slight vanilla, dark chocolate, roasted malts. Nice lingering bitter coffee finish. Amazing. Palate is sensational. This beer is phenomenal and is hard to beat

Aroma: burned / coffee. Deep black body with lots of hops and coffee.
Beer for breakfast i dont know is thats is a good ider.

Bottle, sampled in a Kuhnhenn tulip, 

has a black pour and provided a nice dark tan one to two finger head which receded a bit after a moment, I found a layer of sediment on the bottom of the bottle, 

there was a big roasted coffee aroma with some vanilla in the background, and a little roasted malt, 

and the flavor is predominantly coffee with a strong coffee bitterness, there was very little roast malt in this beer, 
this drink had a lasting bitterness after the finish, the bitterness lingers and lingers,  

the mouth feel is more on the thick side, 

a nice drink, this beer had more coffee than I prefer, if you love a lot of coffee in your beer, you will enjoy this drink.
The best coffee stout out there. When the brewery spends the effort in using a premium coffee for a premium stout they complement each other immensely. Very well done. One of my favorites.

Appearance:  black with deep ruby highlights; huge, creamy tan head that lasts forever; tons of rich lacing.  Aroma:  toasty oats, creamy coffee, bittersweet chocolate, licorice.  Taste:  dry roasted oats, coffee beans, espresso, hints of vanilla and cream, bittersweet chocolate, and resinous hops.  Finish:  medium-length, smoothly dry, a little coffee-laden acidity over dark chocolate.  Notes:  Sunday morning breakfast stout of the week.  Absolutely phenomenal.  Great combination of flavors.  Some sweet creaminess from the oatmeal aspect, with some dry, acidic bitter flavors melding perfectly from the coffee.

IÂ’ve had several bottles of this and always ended up trading them away, finally I will drink and review this elusive brew.

Pours a solid black with a huge tan head that takes forever to dissipate. Lots of carbonation at work here. Smells of chocolate and oatmeal and coffee. What would breakfast be without those right? A little milk chocolate and licorice in there as well. Taste is coffee and chocolate. Slight ash, a bit of alcohol with a lingering roast bitterness in the finish. Body is solid, mouthfeel is creamy smooth. Wow thatÂ’s a great stout, maybe I shouldnÂ’t have traded so many of these away. This oneÂ’s not to heavy on the coffee like a lot of breakfast stouts want to do these days. If it were a little less expensive IÂ’d drink more of these.

You can never go wrong with this beer. While it is not the best beer I have had, it has a decent price point and it is (almost) always good.

We have a breakfast beer festival every summer at Naboen pub in Trondheim, Norway. It is on this day, we empty their stock of Beer Geek Breakfast for breakfast at 13:00 in the morning.

Black in color with reddish hue and foamy tan head... Aroma is roasted malts, coffee.... Flavor is oats, rich roasted malts, oak, strong notes of coffee linger throughout and on the palate... Pretty solid stout, definitely could have this for breakfast, could replace my morning coffee....

Smells like roasted coffee. Pours pitch black with a solid tan head. Flavor is burnt coffee (in a good way) and really dark chocolate. Oats give the mouthfeel a nice effervescence. Nice bitterness, not overdone. Perfectly balanced stout.

Bottle. Dark, almost black with a thick espresso head that stays on for quite some time. The beer leaves nice lacings on glass. Aroma is raisins, liquorice, nuts and coffee. Taste is heavy on coffee malts and hints of caramel.. Feel is a bit oily and smooth. Finish has some hops and bitterness. I wouldnÂ’t suggest it for breakfast myself, but a substitute for coffe in the evening it sure is. Great stuff

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2011 Bottle @ home. Black appearance with a fluffy dark brown head. Deep chocolate malts and a dark roasty coffee aroma. Sweet but pretty bitter dark chocolate and dark coffee. Bitter coffee finish. Espresso aftertaste.

This beer poured jet black with a 1 inch head that hung around for a while.  The aroma is simple but effective amounts of chocolate, coffee, vanilla, and sweet malt.  The taste is chocolate malts, coffee, with hints of vanilla (imagine that).  With every sip i was wishing i had a plate of smoked meats to pair with it.  It is very smooth with a light carbonation.  Overall a very well rounded stout and I would leterally drink it with breakfast anytime ;)

Sampled on 1/29/2011. This stout pours an eclipse black color from a 50cl bottle. Small to medium sized tan foamy head. The aroma is chocolate, coffee and roasted malt. A medium to full bodied stout. The malts are chocolate, coffee and dark fruits with a hint of tobacco and vanilla. The hops are herbal and earthy. Nicely balanced. Good carbonation. Nice full chewy mouthfeel. Very smooth taste. A very nice beer to sit by the fire and sip. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

Came in a snifter with a head that settled to be light brown.  Smelled of a freshly brewed cup of coffee, sumatra style.  Creamy mouthfeel with tastes of roasted malt, coffee, and vanilla.  Had this several times while it was offered on tap.

Tulip glass was used and the  bottle poured a dark black. A smaller than expected head but was an interesting foam like beige head. Aroma of roasted coffee with notes of chocolate. Very smooth and had notes of roasted coffee/espresso flavor. Slit bitterness at the end, but a smooth creme like finish.

Bottle. 22 oz. Pours opaque chocolate black with a thick, tall, beige head. Aroma of espresso, coffee beans, chocolate, grapes, barley, roasted malts, pepper, scotch, and notes of cinnamon and tart. Extraordinarily smooth, thick, luxuriously silky body with a bold, robust mouthfeel; the coffee is very apparent. Finishes slowly with a lovely, toasty warming in the throat and belly. Overall, one of the best stouts I have ever had. Definitely try this brew.
Black pour with an off white head.  Aroma is coffee.  Taste is coffee, burnt wood and dark chocolate.  Mildly bitter finish.  Very good, but not as good as I expected.

Pour is black with a tan head. Nose is of licorice and chocolate, and almost hints at some alcohol presence. Taste is much different, incredibly roasty, bordering on the taste of a porter however the distinct coffee flavor is still there. Taste is not as alcoholic as the smell, and is rather smooth on the palate.

Deep brown, near black, pours slow like syrup resulting in a three finger, mocha head.  At first the lace coats the glass, then it eventually recedes.  Swirling leads to millions of uniform little bubbles that slide along the glass.  Some head remains throughout the beer.

Smell is deep barley sweetness, with a dark roast coffee center.  Hint of licorice and molasses.  

Taste is richly full.  Big coffee presence with chocolate and oat dryness.  Like the aroma there is a big malty, barley sweetness.  Rich, sweet, dry, roasty, with a smooth finish that is not overly dry like many roasty stouts are.  Rich, smooth, and complex.

So creamy.  Chewy mouthfeel.  Drinks slow both from its creamy thickness and the richness of flavor.  Delicious and wonderful.
500ml bottle, great tan frothy head, aroma of burnt coffee, sweetness, Quitw nice. A bit of burnt malt, a bit tart, the coffee is subdued, interesting... it grows on me as the pint warms. Nice.

Bottle kindly sent to my by Durhambeer. Pours black with a large khaki head leaving a bit of lace. The aroma is dark berries and coffee, along with some dark chocolate as it warms. Unfortunately these pleasantries are eclipsed by an over abundance of  vodka like booziness that does not mix well at all with the roasty tones of this beer. The flavor is better but that darned cheap vodka shows up again to mix up what would otherwise been a perfectly nice beer. Coffee dominates the flavor but this is not without some fruity hops and bits of molasses sweetness which works well with some berry like fruitiness. Man I really wish there wasnÂ’t such a clashing booziness here, IÂ’ll have to come back to this one... perhaps an off batch?

500 mL bottle from Grape & Gourmet.  Pours black with a rich cinnamon brown head.  Aroma of rich roasted coffee and dark chocolate.  Bitter coffee and bakers chocolate as well as rich smoke in the flavor.  Full bodied but the alcohol is barely detectable.  One of the best stouts IÂ’ve tried.

I glasset er den helt sort og kler det litt mystisk navnet. Skummet er tett og fint og ligger middels lenge. Lukten hinter om at navnet ikke er helt ufortjent. Den minner om varmt grovbrÃ¸d og kaffe. Den fyldige smaken bekrefter dette og fÃ¥r meg til Ã¥ mistenke at brÃ¸det er ristet rugbrÃ¸d. Ettersmaken er lang, passe bitter og behagelig og Â“faderÂ” sakte. Perfekt.

Kaffe Ã¸l nÃ¥r der er GODT!
RugbrÃ¸d, kaffe, chokolade, grape, grappa, trÃ¦, tÃ¸rv, sort, sÃ¸d, god bitter, kraftig, blÃ¸d.

New Beer Distributors, NY 500ml ($9.50): Finally, they dropped the price down below Whole Foods price of 9.99. In any case, it pours a very black color with a brown head. Aroma is what you would expect, but just a whole lot more of it. So you get roasted malts, along with smoky notes. Bunch of bitter chocolate and coffee. I the taste the hops become more apparent and provide an additional source of bitterness for the roasted malts and chocolate notes. The oatmeal does not really provide that smoothness that it provides for other oatmeal stouts, just because this is such an intense beer. Whole bunch of smoky dark chocolate, or maybe chocolaty dark smoke. I donÂ’t know how well this would go with breakfast (I had it with some scrambled eggs, just for the novelty value), but hey, that doesnÂ’t stop it from being a very flavorful beer, albeit not my favorite beer (still glad I tried this infamous brew though).

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2012 Beer Geek Breakfast pours a very deep dark black. The beer cascades a bit to develop a one finger tan head. I noticed the head looks a little lighter where it contacts the beer and slightly darker where it contacts the air on top. This reminds me of the crema in espresso. (Check the picture of the beer to the left and then click here to see some espresso I made recently).

Head retention was moderate and faded into a thin collar. Minimal lacing was left on the glass.

The smell is very appealing to a beer and coffee lover. You definitely smell some coffee but the dominating aroma is roasted malt. Other notes are of dark chocolate and perhaps a hint of licorice. This beer has been named appropriately.

First sip immediately reveals that the flavor profile of this brew is complex. Initially tastes of bitter dark chocolate which progresses to roasted malts and finishes with a definitive coffee aftertaste. I find that as this beer warms slightly the flavors really shine. I favor the coffee which comes out deliciously once the beer has sat a few minutes.

The beer is smooth and somewhat thick in the mouth with medium carbonation.
11th November 2007  Warning! Early amateur rating! Thich and rich stout, creamy. Coffee notes off set by some sweetness. Complex and rich. Very nice.
a nice chocolately, heavily coffee-toned porter that isnÂ’t too hot or tacky. a little bit of oaky, smokey flavours. quite good.

16.9 oz. bottle.  Dark opaque pour with a thick cascading brown head.  Rich roasted malt and coffee aroma.  incredibly smooth with a surprisingly not overwhelming flavor.  Exceptional flavor, balance and palate.  Mildly bitter aftertaste, similar to that of a cup of coffee.  Excellent beer.

A- Body is a deep, thick motor oil black hue. Pours with a 2-3 finger dark brown foamy head that eventually fades to a thick collar. Some lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Smell is very good. RIS-like with coffee stout qualities as well. Roasted malt is the the main character with a big background of dark bittersweet chocolate, anise, and licorice.

T- Flavor is complex and gets much better as it warms. Upfront is bitter dark chocolate and a hint of licorice but with a really big roasted malt background. The finish is mostly roasted malt with a hint of the initial flavors lingering in there. A moderate roasted malt bitterness lingers with a hint of dark chocolate wrapped in a warm alcohol blanket. 

M- Medium to high carbonation and a moderately thick and smooth body.

D- At first this brew just comes off as all coffee and roasted malt-but it really shines as it warms. One of the better coffee stouts out there as well as one of the originals-Happy to finally try this brew!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-10-2010 02:26:11

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2011 Black beer with brown smoothy but collapsing head.Dark chocolate,milk chocolate,espresso,mocha,tobacco,chocolate raisins,roasted and hoppy biterness,some flowers,olive paste.Great ballance.The body isn t as full as i thought but in the other hand this chocolate ballance makes this beer so drinkable.Yes i want one with my morning eggs.
Bottle. Pours black with a gigantic brown head. Flavor is coffee, chocolate, espresso, slightly briney. Full bodied, oily mouthfeel.

Very dark. No visible amber. Thick creamy two finger head. Espresso color and small bubbles.  Big roasted malt and coffee - predominantly. Then some bitter dark chocolate and maybe a little bit of malty sweetness in the back. Picking up a little hops. Overall itÂ’s pretty smooth and very balanced.  Medium-to-Full body.

Bottle 500ml
[Trade by Zoney] Pours black with a tan head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Taste is medium sweet and light bitter. Full body, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Pours black with a dark brown small head leaving nice lace. Aroma is dry, roasted, coffee, madeira, dark fruits, acidy and alcohol. Acidy velvety mouthfeel. Strong flavor of coffee and chocolate with slightly acidy fruity notes. Fruity acidy palate. Finishes with great tart and dry hoppy aftertaste.

Decided to try this one on a Christmas morning as a better alternative to the standard bloody mary/mimosa.  Coffee color with a thin, foamy mocha colored head.  Coffee, chocolate, and caramel in the nose.  Slight coffee bitterness in the palate followed by some smooth caramel, roasted malt and chocolate.
Smooth, dark and roasty. Sweet coffee flavors. Well balanced though. Hard to go wrong here. Not too fancy, just tasty.

UPDATED: FEB 26, 2011 Aroma is dark chocolate, coffee, roasty, biscuit, toffee, distant hop aroma. Appearance is dark dark brown with a very nice peanut butter brown thick head. Taste is chocolate and coffee forward, toffee. Roastiness comes in next. Sweet but not too sweet. Oats very present. Hops bitterness present but blends well with roasty bitterness. Hint of smoke. Palate is medium+ and smooth. Complex, in a way that brings all the normal Oatmeal Stout flavors together just right to style. A solid beer. Overpriced in my opinion though.
Batch 471. This look like stout. Smoky and malty smell. Bitter stout aroma, fairly smoky with cereal and roast. Really nice, but perhaps just a bit too dry to my taste.

pours a dark black you cant even see through smells has a great smell really cant characterize it other then coffee beans but very subtle cofee beans and first taste is a lot of coffee and a good beer very full flavored
UPDATED: DEC 24, 2010 NÃ¸gne Ã˜ version.  Deep dark chocolate brown color with a thick brown head.  Excellent blend of coffee, chocolate, and oats.  Smooth strong flavorful stout.

Bottle 50 cl. Poured pitch black color with huge tan head. Aroma is burnt coffee, dark chocolate and some faint herbal spices that kind of gives you the jÃ¤germeister vibe. Flavour is roasted coffee beans and dark chocolate. Nice slightly burnt coffee aftertaste.

Pours black with a thin tan head.  HUGE coffee aroma in this beer.  Taste of bitter coffee and smoke dominate throughout.  Literally slides across the tongue, to a bitter finish. Very good beer, would drink again.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2011 On tap at Cask & Kitchen Pimlico. It pours a very dark brown colour with foamy tan head. The nose is rich coffee, slight caramel, dark chocolate and smokey. The taste is smooth with a soft mouth-feel, bucket loads of coffee, dark chocolate, burnt sugar, nuts, vanilla, and oat biscuits. ItÂ’s very well balanced and very easy to drink. Not just for breakfast, but enjoyed at anytime of the day, any day of the week!
This is one excellent stout. has an almost oily palate, it is so good it curled my hair. And I am BALD

Pours with a dark brown almost black hue with a very light tan head. Slight hint of chocolate aroma with a rush of coffee.Creamy smooth slight chocolate coffee taste, nice dryness with a full fiish. Great beer, great competition for the Founders Breakfast Stout.
This is a very nice beer! Nice hints of chocolate and coffee. The taste got better and better after a while as it got closer to room temperature. Rich in taste and a beer IÂ’ll try again!

aroma is super roast-y with dark chocolate and coffee, dirt, dough, hay, smoke, and earthy hops.
pours an opaque dark brown with frothy brown head.
flavor is bitter in front and mildly sweet in the middle.
medium-heavy body, smooth and silky, with alcohol notes in front and long mild bitter coffee finish.

Very dark brown with a brown Â½Â” cap, beer looks so very thick and viscous. Aroma is deep dark coffee with hints of vanilla and alcohol On a swirle of my glass an odor of pear appeared. Smooth creamy taste with a massive coffee punchÂ…Â… I like it. The coffee wile horribly intense isnÂ’t has harsh or bitter as it is in some other coffee stouts. I can still taste the Vanilla, and my mind must be playing trick on me because I taste pear on some sips but that seems wrong. Hints of sour and earth fill the after taste, with a warm alcohol filling the stomach. Brew is turning more chocolaty as it warms and its yummy creaminess is coating my throat. This is an awesome brew I can see my self drinking this constantly  there is nothing not to love in this beer.
Pours inky dark, with a tan head. Smells rich and deep. Tastes of dark coffee, and perhaps anis and semi-sweet chocolate. A well balanced coffee-oatmeal stout. Smooth and drinkable. Thumbs up.

Like throwing Colombian coffee beans at a spinning airplane propeller, collecting the grinds, then throwing them into a batch of dutch baking chocolate and taking a flame thrower to the whole damned thing - and I say this as a good thing. If I could drink this for breakfast without seeming like a contemptuous alcoholic, I would be reading a newspaper with a heightened sense of happiness every single morning.

Bottle. Deep brown with a tan head. Aromas of coffee, chocolate and oats. Slightly thin and bubbly palate. Silky chocolate taste fades to bittersweet coffee aftertaste. This one seems to be the stout that all other stouts want to be.

Opaque black in color, with a mocha-colored head. Smells like coffee and malt. Chewy, thick, oatmeal flavors, some alcohol, and mild floral hops. Has a bitter coffee aftertaste with a rich roast malt backdrop.
Bottle.  A black color with a light brown head.  A rich chocolate and earthy aroma with a nice coffee layer.  Rich and delightful with a long coffee finish as it warms.

Served into an over sized wine glass

Bought it at Mikkeler bar from the dude on the right side 
http://www.youtube.com/watchv=gLlBJDhE8to&featur to put it out there)

Appereance: Jet black no light go thru, small steady head beige going brown, steady lace as well.

Smell: Sweet, Roasted coffee

Taste: Bitter roasted coffee, dark coffee, vanilla, almond, woody. Medium body, no carbonation, astringent like dark bitter chocolate, no alcohol flavor, faint hop backbone.

Overall: Amazing beer, delicious, wasnÂ’t heavy at all. I had a couple beer at Mikkelller that I didnÂ’t review but I really loved. Great "PHANTOM" brewery.

Serving type: bottle

Pours a black with a lasting brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, and a faint trace of pine hops. Flavor is strong roasted malts, chocolate, some coffee. Extremely smooth and thick, almost chewy. Easy to drink and the alcohol is well hidden. Enjoyed this alot.

Serving: 25 oz. bottle from Whole Foods Reston. 
Aroma: The nose is roasty with a bit of chocolate liqueur, a bit of flint, earth, and herbal hops. This brew smells outstanding. 
Appearance: It pours an almost pitch black with the slightest of ruby highlights and a large, dense, creamy, tan head.  To say this brew has head retention is an understatement.  The head lasts forever. 
Taste: Rich and roasty.  There is a deep bitterness from both the hops and the roasting.  There is a touch of underlying sweetness that brings dark caramel into play.  The coffee really comes through as well.  As the beer warms, a touch of raisin, soy, and smoke emerges. 
Palate: Very rich with a surprising amount of prickly carbonation leading to a very dry, burnt and bitter finish. 
Overall: If didnÂ’t know better, I would say this is an imperial stout.  This was a complex brew for sure, but the finish came across as a bit raw to me.
Nose of bitter, fresh hops, roasted coffee, some pine, feel is semi-creamy, carb is mediumheavy, taste is licorice, roasted malt, late weak alcohol and hops

Pours black with brown head that disappears in few minutes. I taste roasted something and chocolate but I cannot get into coffee taste. I like this beer very much however, its thick and with lots of flavors without being too heavy.
POurs dark and viscous with a tan head.  Smells of black coffee, otasy, hops.  Lightermouthfeel than I expected.  Hops and black coffee most prevalent.  Very good!

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2012 ***re-rate aug 26, 2012. On tap at Accent***
Good thing I wasnÂ’t here yesterday as I noticed that site cancer hoser was here spoiling the air of the venue with his poisonous presence. Ok - I gotta do a full 360 on my original rating - even though I pointed out that I need to rate again. This.  Is.  Awesome.  Ultra thick creamy oatmeal and chocolate is amazing. The faint fruit and coffee background is just a bonus in the smelly treat. The taste is stellar with a moderate yet stiff coffee that gives way on all fronts to bitter super dark milky chocolate - jay imagine using half the container of brown cow and then filling the last third of the glass with milk and then stirring the fuck out of it. Not saying it tastes like that but it just has that much more choco goodness. Stellar oatmeal. Thickest dark choco imaginable. The bite is a mix of bitterness and a mild spice (sort of), light candy fruit, dryness on the finish - dry roasty grain. Super thick and smooth. It does taste better if I donÂ’t put too much thought into it. The finish isnÂ’t the greatest but the early impressions are. Oh - and plenty of time between sips makes a huge difference as I find that this shot reeks havoc on my palate. Balls. Updated from 7473 14:3.5


Black. Chocolatey brown cap with great retention and better than average lacing. Big coffee aroma with chocolate that cowers behind the wake of coffee destruction. Some sort of hops, lemon, smells pretty good but nothing amazing. The coffee is quite nice. Not a lot of complexity. Taste: bitterness, tartness, then coffee and chocolate - more chocolate than in the aroma, burnt malts and not much more. Drying and bitter - kind of boring. Maybe IÂ’ll think differently after another bottle is cracked.

On tap at OÂ’BrienÂ’s after losing at Poker night at JasonÂ’s to a total donk.  This was the highlight of the night.  Nose is smooth chocolate and oaty malt.  Taste is smooth oats, cocoa, and light coffee.  Smoky bacon grows as the glass warms, but the smooth oats and warm chocolate remain in the front.  Smooth oat thickness leads to the finish.  Nice.

Pours dark and thick, almost black.  This beer has a substantial head made up of large bubbles.  This beer smalls of dark chocolate, coffee and sweet malt, and there are hints of dark fruit.  This beer is extremely smooth in the mouth, and the flavor is crisp rich coffee and bitter dark chocolate with cream.  This beer has pretty much one intense flavor that it does very well and is one of the best coffee stouts I have had.  However, there is a hint of an alcohol flavor in the back that detracts a bit from the overall experience.  Thie beer is definitely better than an iced coffee and is very easy to drink.

Pours a dark black color with a dark brown colored head.  Smells of many delicious things.  i smell almonds, oatmeal, vanilla, chocolate, molasses, caramel, and more chocolate!  Taste is magnificent.  At first, the taste is of chocolate.  Delicious delicious chocolate.  Next is some vanilla and maybe some nuts.  I finally taste coffee.  Finish is not overly bitter which i like in a stout.  A very good beer.  And I am drinking it close to breakfast time!  The mixture of all the flavors goes very well which results in a very good beer.

This is ridiculously good. Pours an opaque black, a dark coffee colored head. It drinks like an espresso with the roasted malt flavor going up into your sinuses. The palate is actually chewy, like a good bowl of roasted malt. Unbelievable.

Pours extreme dark with a profuse frothy brown foam that persists even after half glass. Fresh floral aroma, some malt...Medium bitterness, light sweetness and roasted strong coffee at the end of the taste, some chocolate too. Very round taste. Soft carbonation, full body, sublime bitter finish and after taste. Despite the look and the caracteristics is not so heavy. DidnÂ’t had it on breakfast but it was a very good stout. Recommended.

Bottle from "CsakajÃ³sÃ¶r"-store, Bp.
Pitch-black coloured stuff with a finger thick, dark brown coloured creamy head on its top.
Smell of chocolate and fruits.
Very nice and complex aroma of roasted malt (chocolate/coffee beans), flowers and dark/citrus fruits, the flavour is bitterchocolate liked, texture is thick and creamy.
The robust finish is coffee-bitter, citric and light alcoholy warming and remains long in a bitter aftertaste.
Overall very nice and memorable.

Bottle.  pours a dark black color with thin caramel colored head. aroma:huge roasted aroma with a nice fresh pot of coffee brew aroma, maple syrup, and some oatmeal with cinnamon sugar.  taste: it tastes like the most epic breakfast ever,  first some warm from booze, with some sweet spice, oatmeal, then from the roasted malts you get the coffee, and kind of some maple syrup pancake-ish flavoring.  totally wild brew
Black,creamy thick brown head.Big roasty dark malt nose,dark fruit notes.Chocolate malt fore,big roast espresso profile.Huge roast bitter end, slightly fatty. Medium alcohol heat

#1000. Settled on this gem because I just canÂ’t seem to get anything anyone wants to trade for. Anyway, jet black pour with brown head. Smell is coffee, roasted malts and a hint of soy. Taste is coffee, dark chocolate, hops and oatmeal. Very nice!

50Cl bottle from Alko. Poured pitch black with a light brown head, some lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, "swedish julmust", chocolate and coffee. Very smooth palate, with a medium body. Flavor is burned malt, coffee and hops. The finish is very dry with an espresso taste that stays in your mouth for some time.  Very drinkable and enjoyable.
Deep black color with average sized brown head that diminished quickly. Initially a taste of dark chocolate and coffee. Finishes with significant hops bitterness.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2011 Bottle:
Batch 412:
Very big brown foamy head.
Pours a black beer.
Smell: spices, fruit, hops, roasted malts, hint of alcohol and bit airy/gassy in the nose.
Taste is a fine well balanced mix of roasted malts, hints of coffee, spices, dark fruit and bitter/hops.
Slightly watery in the beginning but changes quick into a bitter full tasting spicy coffee, dark fruity and roasted malt stout.
Long aftertaste.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: [500ml bottle from Jim - cheers!] Black as you like, with the darkest brown head IÂ’ve ever seen on a beer - although oddly it noticeably lightened as I drank it.  Visibly thick, viscous and oily as you pour it.  Dominated by roasted malts that have one foot into the "burnt" camp.  ThereÂ’s some liquorice in there and a bit of marmite.  The coffee is in there, but disappointingly subtle.  Very smooth in the mouth (mouthfeel of milk chocolate, although not the taste), but also a little too sticky at times.  The burnt/roasted malt is still by far the biggest taste at the end (still maybe a little too harsh and burnt), and strangely, and unusually for me, I felt it desperately needed a huge hit of lemony hops or something (maybe more coffee?) to make it less one-dimensional.  ItÂ’s certainly not unpleasant, but I felt it fell far short of its reputation.
Bottle. Color black with medium brown head. Aroma coffee, dark chocolate, smoke, roasted malts. Taste coffee, chocolate, hop, fruit, bitter, roasted.Full body. Great beer

500ml bottle in an English pint.  Pours black with a thick, lingering tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, oats, chocolate, coffee.  Flavor very complex with all of those elements plus a little underlying hoppiness.  Not as thick as it could be, but an incredible beer.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2010 Pours black with a cappuccino- to brown colored head.Aroma is coffee beans, dark chocolate and cane sugar.Taste is heavy on the coffee, complex, rich, very well balanced, sweet tones of molasses and toffee, but with hops shining through to give balance, roasted notes and pumpernickel. Feels great in your mouth.One of the best stouts IÂ’ve had.

50cl bottle I bought a year ago.
Very dark.  Nice head.  Lovely complex tasty beer!

Amazing beer. Probably the tastiest beer i have had from mikkeller...and thatÂ’s saying something. Pour is deep opaque black with Finger or so of dark tan head. Aroma is tasty dark roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, alcohol and oatmeal. The taste is utterly sublime and I wish i had more of this beer. Delicious!

Oh dear god, this beer is awesome. It pours dark as youÂ’d expect, with a big foamy brown head that fizzles down. The aroma is unbelievable, it smells like a biscotti, i canÂ’t believe iÂ’m the only one here who commented on it, i smell this beer itÂ’s like being transported to a high end coffee shop, ontop of that there is of course the coffee, a bit of chocolate and roasted malts, with light notes of banana. The flavour Starts with notes of coffee, which give way to semi sweet notes of chocolate, mabye a light touch of banana, ends with a little more chocolate, coffee, and anise. This beer is friggin amazing. Best stout I think iÂ’ve ever had.

660 ml bottle @ Gastropub Nordic. Rated @ 4.2.2009.
A pitch black colour with a big creamy brown head. Burned malts, roasted coffee and caramel notes on the nose. The flavour is pine needles, roasted malts, coffee and of course hops. Medium/full bodied, oily texture and soft carbonation. Dry and hoppy finish. Truly a nice stout.

Black beer with a light brown lasting head. Aroma of burned malts, chocolate , coffee and fruit. LotÂ’s of coffee in the mouth. When the beer warms up a bit the fruitiness is more noticeble with banana and pineapple. Hoppy aroma with chocolate, coffee and pineapple.

Poured black with a thick tan head. Smells like toasted malt, chocolate and coffee. I would of sworn there was cinnamon in this as itÂ’s a very dominant flavor. Medium carbonation, Alcohol slightly evident. Taste even better as it warms. This is smooth, sweet, and very drinkable.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2011 Draught. Black with a small tan head. Aroma: coffee liqueur, licorice, rubber, some cream. Taste: coffee and some grounds, roasted malt, rubber, a light acidity, grapefruit/citrus, licorice, medium bitter. Fruity and bitter finish. Very smooth with light carbonation. This is the third time IÂ’ve had this, and the draught beats the bottles IÂ’ve had earlier.

500ml brown bottle. Black pour, opaque, thick dark brown head that is long lasting. Roasted coffee nose with dark chocolate. Flavour is bitter and very roasty, lots of strong black coffee. Long bitter finish. Coffee aftertaste, some cocoa notes, fairly dry. Medium body and very smooth mouthfeel. 7.5% abv gets hidden well, drinks like a lesser strength stout. Essential for coffee stout fans.

Pours jet black.  I let it warm quite a bit after I removed it from the fridge and it provided a nice, big, tan, head that seems to lace well.  Nose is bitter chocolate, coffee, roast, and some malt.  Not reallly too fruity-very clean, at least way cleaner than expected.  Taste is full of roast, coffee, wood, nuts, bitterness, and no dectable hop flavor.  Not too dry or sour in the finish, just bitter.  Full, creamy, slick mouthfeel with the correct carbonation.  This is a wonderful bitter, chocolate, coffee, stout well suited to the American taste.  Nice.

I had to try this one because of the high rating but must face that I am just not a stout guy... ItÂ’s black and thick with creamy beige head, strong coffee aroma, a nearly burnt malt taste.  Lots of complex flavor but in a range that I just donÂ’t appreciate. Probably a great stout to those who drink stout, but I just didnÂ’t like it although I wanted to...
Bottle pours a nice, thick head that thins out slowly.  Aroma is predominantly coffee.  Flavor is coffee bitterness, some hops.  Damn, this beerÂ’s good!

Excellent appearance with a big think brown head. Coffee aroma (obviously). Nice weight on the palate and just the right amount of carbonation. My wife says it has a floral taste. I can taste the oats. There is definitely a sweet aftertaste. This beer would be perfect with the Irish breakfast wrap at KellyÂ’s Corner Tavern in Neptune.

Poured into a Belgian tulip glass from a 1 pint 9 oz bottle. Very dark black and opaque, thick and oily looking with a thick brown head. Very much coffee aromas with some toasted malts. Coffee with some grainy flavors -- especially the oat. Some brown sugar sweetness with just a hint of cocoa. The flavors gel really well together. Full bodied and creamy, with a bit more carbonation that you would expect in a stout. Big aftertaste of burnt toast, bitter coffee flavors linger a long time. I donÂ’t know about having this for breakfast as the name and label implies, but it makes a great end of the night sipping beer or a fine beer to have with a chocolate desert. IÂ’m not typically keen on coffee flavors, but the coffee in this is quite mellow and not overpowering bringing out additional flavors.
This seems like itÂ’s supposed to be smoky but itÂ’s not. It kind reminds me of some dark chocolate sÂ’mores. Delicious as hell

(22oz bomber) jet black pour, deep tan oily bubbles, great coating on the glass. Nose of fresh coffee beans, bakers chocolate, fudge, and very mild smoke. Taste of oats, fudge, coffee, light cream and smoke, rich chocolate malt. Viscous medium body, nice and well carbonated, very smooth and linger of slightly bitter chocolate and cream.

IÂ’ve been anticipating opening this one for months. Pours like an imperial stout - totally impenetrable black with a medium-brown head. Loans of coffee on the nose with a little burnt caramel. Sharp and slightly acidic coffee flavour, complemented with chocolate malts and maybe a hint of seaweed astringency. Smooth mouthfeel and a dry finish. Expensive for what it is, but IÂ’m glad I tried it.

Rich dark brown/black color; Heavy creamy body; Aroma of toasted smoky malt, coffee, & chocolate; Flavor of roasted malt, espresso, bittersweet chocolate, nuts, oats, and some hops; Finish is slightly bitter; Very nicely balanced & complex; Overall, well done - excellent stout.

Pours dark black with a small brown head. The roasted coffee aromaÂ’s are very present and dominate the aroma together with roasted malts and tobacco. Taste is again coffee that adds some (light) sourness to the beer and lots of roasted flavours. Would have liked a bit more body, but very drinkable and warming with some hops in the finish.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2011 Creamy and full-bodied texture is absolutely wonderful.  Nose is solid, coffee dominant but also some slight char.  Taste is surprisingly dry, with some roast characteristics and a nice coffee bean acidity on the finish.  Just a nicely balanced, highly drinkable stout.  Worth a shot, although pretty damn expensive for what you get.  The texture is on point, but I wanted stronger flavors.
Pours pitch black with a dark brown head and a slight ruby tint. Nose is full of coffee, oats, and toasty sweet malts. Loads of coffee in the taste and a wonderful bittersweet finish.

Bottle.  Pours opaque black with a big tan head.  Nose is roasty malts, caramel, chocolate, and a big hit of dark coffee.  Flavor and mouth feel are interesting on this one.  Combines the full body and dark roastiness of an impy with the smoothness of an oatmeal stout.  Taste is just slightly sweet with dark roasty malts, oats, caramel, dark chocolate, and lots of coffee.  Finishes long with a slight bitterness and big coffee flavor.  An interesting, well crafted, and supremely enjoyable stout.
UPDATED: NOV 13, 2010 Lovely dark, with an explotion of flavour. Thanks denmark :) Almost an imperial stout :)

Draft.. Jet black pour , thin beige head , no lacing . Aroma of coffee , bitter chocolate and roasted malt.  Flavor is a nice balance of dark roasted malt and hop bitterness , with the smoothness and creaminess of the oats . Full flavored but medium bodied . Long lingering coffee bitterness in the finish .

Bottle from Csakajosor.hu. Poured pitch black with a strong brown lacing head. Roasted, smoked aroma with caramel, coffee, dark chocolate and plenty of hops. Dense body with low carbonation with a dry, bitter finish. Coffee and ash in the aftertaste. The gourmet coffee shows no mercy to keep you awake...but overall this is an outstanding beer.

0,5 l bottle, CsakajÃ³sÃ¶r
Poured black like rock-oil with a stable, creamy brown head that melt down slowly to a fantastic lacing one. Peat and smokey, mild tarty aroma with roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate and cocoa-beans, nice lurking hops. This character rules the flavor too with in well roundeed chocolate-roasted character. Coffe and molasses, but dry smoked peat tastes spicied with hops. Ash and fine tart aftertaste. Really good one!

22 oz bottle from PrincetonÂ’s.  Deep black pour with a fluffy, crater filled head.  Aromas of roasted coffee and more of the same in the flavor.  Coffee dominates this intense, rich beer and thatÂ’s a good thing.

Bottle at natifest 2010.  Had before, but have not rated.  Aroma is strong with coffee and roasted malts.  Notes dark chocolate, vanilla, and molasses stand out.  Palate is surprisingly smooth.  The coffee is in charge of the flavor.  I prefered the weasle, but this is still damn good.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2011 Bottle. Poured black with a thick dark brown head that dissipated slowly but never completely. Aroma was full of roasted malts with a relatively strong coffee note as well. Roasted malts shine in the beginning of the flavor and the meld with the growing coffee note.

Bottle into snifter. Pours jet black with small tan head. Aroma is strong, mostly of roasted coffee beans. Mouthfeel is smooth with moderate carbo. Flavor is also of strong roasted coffee with a slightness of hops. Very delicious beer.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2010 On tap. Pours black with a small brown, lasting head leaving beautiful lacings when it finally starts to reduce. Medium roasty aroma with coffee, very dark chocolate, a smoky hint and a nice dark fruitiness giving it a smooth edge. Some makes themselves known, but this is mostly about the dark malts.

When I had it bottled I thought of it as a bit more raw, but equally good.

A Coffee stout that raises the bar for me. Great taste of Chocolate, Coffee, smoke but not to bitter. I like to enjoy this beer by itself, but can imagine it also would be great with deserts or dishes that can be complemented with this great beer instead of coffee..

Enjoy!

500 ml bottle.  Pours a pitch black with a 1/2" light brown head leaving very light lacing on the glass.  Smells of chocolate and coffee with a bit of hops and a hint of alcohol.  Taste is a bit of chocolate and roasted nut malt with the coffee coming through on the finish.  Medium bodied.  Great beer.

(16.9oz bottle).  Pours black with a caramel colored head.  Aroma of coffee but also some herbs?  Taste is sweet and bitter.  Full bodied and creamy.  Finish is bitter.  This is a sweeter stout so I appreciate that, but there is also some dryness and bitterness that is balanced.  It think this is a very nice beer.
Dark thick and viscous. Burnt amber colored head. Huge roasted oats and coffee nose. FÂ’n amazing.

[Tap] Pours an opaque black color with a lasting dense head. Heavy chocolate, molasses and dark malt in the nose. Taste is heavily roasted. Coffee beans, dark chocolate, hints of smoke, earth, creamer and oats in the taste. One thing I appreciated about this beer was how smooth and drinkable it was. No harsh alcoholic finish or abrasiveness that often accompanies a heavy stout. Excellent balance and a thick, chewy palate. Thoroughly enjoyable and well crafted.

50 cl bottle, pours pitch black with a decent creamy head, aroma is roasted malt combined with coffee and a hint of hops, taste is roasted malt and coffee nicely balanced with a solid hoppy bitterness, fairly dry overall, but a very enjoyable beer that has a nice long lingering finish.

Poured black with a thick brown head.  Great aroma of chocolate malts, oatmeal, and coffee.  Taste is full bodied and flavorful with coffee and chocolate malts.  Slightly sweet and creamy at first with some vanilla and cherries.  Transitions into a slightly bitter oatmeal finish.  Balance is perfect, and no alcohol is present.  An amazing stout!

Pours out a motor oil black with only the very most edge showing a dark walnut brown.  The head is thick and creamy.  When it lowers it leaves behind a tan lacing, which lasts for most of the drink.  The nose is all bitter coffee and earthy hops, chocolate, liquorice and a cola or cherry like presence.  There is also a wooded or dusty vanilla quality reminiscent of a barrel aged beer - this is impressive.  As it warms the flavours open up.  I can find that particular Mikkeller soy sauce note in this - which is so present in Black and Black Hole.  And now the hops tune up to become astringent.  One would be forgiven for thinking this had a much higher ABV than its 7.5%, not due to any heat but because the flavours are so dominating.  The finish is bitter and tapering with just a little malt sweetness creeping in.  A well made and enjoyable stout.  I popped the cap at 10.12AM.  Beer for breakfast: what a good idea.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2014 Pours black with a brown head. Aroma of coffee, dark chocolate, smoked malts, dark dried fruits.
Taste also has Coffee, dark chocolate, smoked malts and the dark dried fruits. There is also a burnt feel to it. A very nice kinda dry end with a bit of bitterness! <333
Tap at the Sunset Grill outside of Boston. Coffee, cream, and chocolate dominate. Huge flavor that is sweet, bitter, and a bit sour as well. A huge, interesting brew.

Pours pitch black with a dark tan creamy lasting head.
Nose shows masses of dark chocolate and creamy truffles with soft coffee as well. Not to much plain roasted character. Reminds me of coffee chocolate liqueurs. Later on a syrupy sweetness shows through, like brandied plums (if anyone actually does brandy their plums...). Very nice!
Roasted character seems to have been reserved for the taste, thereÂ’s definitely loads of it here along with well-roasted coffee beans. Pretty full on, as is the finish with its big roasted bitterness.
Creamy carbonation but a little too high for me. Very thick body.

My 600th rating! Bottle. Pours a deep black with a large brown head that lingers. Rich, smooth aroma, of dark chocolate, coffee, oatmeal, malt, toast, brown sugar, licorice. Taste is complex, of coffee beans, roasted malt, bitter chocolate, oatmeal, and a hint of anise and brown sugar. Lingering bitter toasty malt. This beer makes me happy.
$9.99 from Wine Warehouse, Charlottesville. Pours black with a large brown head. Smells of sweet chocolate malts... caramel too? Tastes of Dark chocolates... lots and lots of dark chocolates.

Pours black with a thick beige head. Looks amazing. Aroma of very strong bold coffee. Tastes great. Very well integrated hops give this beer an excellent complexity. Lots of coffee and roasted malt flavours with a touch of molasses sweetness make this a fantastic beer. The finish is very dry. This is a fantastic stout great stout flavour perfectly balanced with the hops, Dry sweet rich and bold. This is an amazing stout!!!!!

Yummm, this is what a stout should be. Pitch black with a nice tan brown head that permeates the air with chocolate, coffee, toffee, and oatmeal aromas. A light medium body of the beer really surprised me and is the only reason why it is not rated higher, but the Beer Geek Breakfast Stout makes up for its lacking depth by offering a wide range of flavors to the palate. Hints of dark chocolate are chased by spicy smokiness and oats and creamy cocoa coffee. So glad I finally found this beer, now if it was just a bit heavier...

Bottle (some age on this one, not sure. a year or more). Aroma of coffee and booze. Alright, thatÂ’s what I smell like most mornings, too. I get your angle. Black with no head. Coffee in the flavor, but then what? a weird void of dry nothingness, and then acidic chocolate. What just happened? Some numbing effect in the middle of the tongue that makes me think that this is supposed to be some high concept zen experience masquerading as a beer. Okay, if thatÂ’s the point that I get it. I respect you, Mikkeler, for being so expressive of the existentialist dilemma we face when trying to reconcile a lifestyle that pursues luxury while remaining rooted in an essentially rustic peasant food. Now you can start making decent beer that isnÂ’t a marketing gimmick. Eh?

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours a deep black with medium brown head.  Descent lacing, nice carbonation, and aroma is oatmeal.  Taste is coffee, burnt malt, and finishes hoppy and  a little dry.  Body is thick and chewy.  Let this warm up a bit, a little harsh when cold, but improves as it warms up.  Too much coffee for me, but still pretty good.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2011 Sampled on tap at SIB, pours jet black with a tan head. Aroma of oatmeal, roasted malts and coffee. Flavour is a supremely complex and amazingly smooth oats, roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. An amazing one here.

Vilken tjock, svart olja som kommer ut flaskan. Och som det skummar.
En stoooor smutsig skumtopp som ligger lÃ¤Ã¤Ã¤Ã¤nge Â– det lovar gott!

Det doftar rÃ¶k (ek?) och choklad, fast den har inte sÃ¥ komplex doft som t.ex hos Imperial Stouten til NÃ˜.

Men smaken en smÃ¥tt fantastisk med stora brÃ¤nda toner av choklad och kaffe (med en liten Ã¶vervikt av den fÃ¶rsta). En god kÃ¤nsla i munnen, och en eftersmak  av lite lakrits och peppar som sitter lÃ¤nge. VÃ¤tskans konsistens nÃ¤r man fÃ¥r den i munnen Ã¤r dock inte lite tjock som man skulle kunde tro nÃ¤r man hÃ¤ller den i glaset. Den Ã¤r faktisk fÃ¶rvÃ¥nansvÃ¤rt lÃ¤tt. Absolut en Ã¶l som nÃ¤stan hamnar i topp tillsammans med NÃ˜s Imperial Stout eller HoppinÂ’s B.O.R.I.S, men inte helt.

Pours black, tan head. Big coffee and hop aroma, combining to be kind of musty. In a good way.
Flavour is almost like a black coffee, just big coffee flavours going throughout everything.
ItÂ’s good and stuff.

Nice aroma. Chocolatey, coffee - rather typical imperial stout aroma. Some clove. Lots of alcohol. Really nice aroma. 
Dry on the palate. Lots of hops and a yummy bready yeast. Robust chocolate malts. Beautiful.

Black pour with a dark tan head. Aromas of dark roasted malt, coffee and some plummy fruit. Near medium body with heavy, creamy carbonation. Strong bitter coffee, almost coffee grounds like, and smooth malt. Finish is coffee and burnt bitter, but itÂ’s very nicely done.
A wonderful rich coffee and chocolate flavour. Smoky with a rich full mouthfeel. A wonderful beer.
From bottle.  Pours a syrupy, jet black.  If there was a coffee soda, this would be it.  A very good combination of beer and coffee.
From a bottle,Black in color,smelled and taste like coffee,brown head,oatmeal notes too.This was  damn good beer.

50 bottle. Pours black with a big brown head. Aroma is chocolately and sweet with lots of coffee, cream, sweet/roasty malts. Taste is similar, with also oak notes.  The body is full with medium carbonation.

50cl bottle. Pours a total black color with medium brown head. Very good lacing foam, mostly lasting too. Aroma is disappointing: way too simple with coffee, wood, alcohol and roasted notes notes. Taste is way better, but still too woody-roasted for me. Alcohol is well hidden and almost not perceivable. Palate is full, but not as thick and chewy as other top stouts. Overall, way too simple for my expectations.

500 ml. bottle. Pours a thick lasting mocha head, with some lacing, over a hazy, loaded with particles, brownish black (SRM 35) body.....nose is heavy with coffee, chocolate, light toffee/caramel, a tiny touch of pine and citrus......taste is rich with roasted coffee tones, bit of malt sweetness, molasses, brown sugar, finishing with a light lingering bitterness......mouth feel is thick and creamy, carbonation adds to the effect. This is a very nicely balanced Stout. The coffee fits in well and does not dominate overly much the way it can in so many using it as an ingredient. The very heavy sediment is the only major detraction. BJCP 7/2/16/5/8

UPDATED: JUN 20, 2010 What a surprise this was to see at my local bottle shop.  $8.99 for a bomber.  Poured as black as it gets with a rather large coffee colored head that took a bit to fade.  Aroma was lots of coffee, some malty sweetness and some hops fading from the background.  Taste is fresh coffee, it finished with a lingering bitterness and a touch of sweetness.  Super balanced.  It seems as though anything these dudes at Mikkeller touch turns to gold.  Cannot wait to try some of their other offerings.

Bottle from earth.  drank this one for lunch just to see if it could be done.  Tasty beer put together real well.  Reminded me of the first time I tried to forge my parentÂ’s signature on a shitty report card - nervous at first but became second-nature once I considered the alternative.

Bottle 66cl from 2006. Black pour with a medium-sized, nice brown head with good lacing. A very beautiful beer. The aroma is a nicely rounded blend of subtle roast, a tiny bit of smoke, liquorice, pretty intense and delicious coffee, vanilla and berries, and it has a sort of buttery sweetness to it, that just finishes the whole thing off nicely. The taste is dominated by the gourmet coffee and has further notes of subtly roasted malts, chocolate, dark fruits, vanilla, blueberry and liquorice. The finish has a nice, round and pleasantly bitter roast/hop-combination. Beautifully rounded and almost velvety soft. Long duration, low carbonation, oily texture. One of my favourite beers!

22 oz. bottle.  Pours black, with a hint of brown, and a rich tan head. Aroma has loads of coffee and dark chocolate, very nice nose on this beer.  Very rich and complex, just enough carbonation. A lot of chocolate in the long finish, complemented with the hops, this is one of the nicest finishing beers IÂ’ve had.  I have nothing bad to say about this beer.

Bottle. Had this one quite a few times before, but never got around to rate it. This time around i had it for breakfast, with a full english breakfast, turned out to be a fantastic pairing, especially with the Danish Backbacon! It pours almost pitch black with some brownish notes, in the bottom of the glass. the head is brown and is quite frothy. Aromas are of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, some sweetness and also hops. Flavor is quite alot of coffee, with a decent amount of roasted and burnt malts. It is also fairly chocolatey, with some sweetness from the oats. There is also some nice hop bitterness. The body is medium to full, with a nice creamy mouthfeel, even though it is just slightly watery. Overall an excellent Oatmeal Stout brewed with coffee, deffinetley one of the best beers from Mikkeller!

at Savvy1982Â’s tasting, which wasnÂ’t at breakfast - Smells of coffee grounds and hops. Good head on pour, dark, nice lacing. There is a nice coffee flavour, with alcohol. Dark and smokey. Nice and foamy on the tounge, coffee flavour really comes on. Quite strong coffee flavour, but itÂ’s very nice. hops arenÂ’t too strong.

Coffee, licorice, a zing of hops. real thick in the mouth, oily smooth. Opaque darkest brown with long lasting, dakr tan head. A slight sour taste harmonizing with the hops and roast malt, root beer, alcohol-- how all these dark flavors dance around together. mildly sour test with alcohol warming.

On tap at Stone.  Black in the glass with minimal head and slight carbonation.  Wonderful roasted malt, coffee, expresso, and chocolate aroma.  Taste mirrors the aroma.  The beer is well balanced and extremely drinkable.  Stout of the highest quality.

500 ml bottle courtesy of shawnm213- thanks again, Shawn!  Pours a super dark opaque brown, basically black, with a small brown head.  Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate, smoked hickory, smoked meats, earthy hops, vegetal notes, and alcohol.  Flavor of coffee (and a lot of it), roasted malts, alcohol, hickory smoked meat, wheat, molasses, oats, metallic notes, grass, and overripe pit fruits.  Full-bodied, with mild carbonation and a roasty, bitter mouthfeel.  Lingering earthy, bitter aftertaste.  A lot of roast and smoke.  Awesome beer.

Beautiful blackish brown body.  Aromas of heavy chocolate, oats and big coffee.  The flavor is heaviest in the choclate department, but the oatmeal and coffee are no slouches either. Great job on this beer Mikkeller.
Pours syrupy and has a thick texture and black colour. Strong coffee flavours. IÂ’d drink it for my breakfast, lunch or dinner!

This rich, mouth-coating coffee stout feels distracted by piny American hops, but is otherwise quite satisfying.

Pitch black hue; billowy, brown head. Espresso, dark rum, and RoloÂ’s (caramel + chocolate) aromas are equally present. Medium-high sweetness, medium-low acidity, medium bitterness. Resinous aroma/flavor later clashes with the sweet and roasted components. Creamy texture, medium-full body, light alcohol, effervescent carbonation. 50 cl bottle, bottled on 17.03.2009.
Superb ingredients. black and thick with huge brown foamy head. Delicious coffee and hops with chocolate. Not stunning but very good.

500ml Bottle at Plan B, Copenhagen 09/05/2010
Fruit and hop aromas. Small beige head. Black smooth on the palate strong in alcohol hoppy and fruity with a little bitterness in a coffee roast finish.

Pours black with a healthy tan head.  Surprisingly laid back in aroma and flavor (especially considering the added coffee).  Orange comes out in this one, and some mild chocolaty malts (I should note, I was tasting this with World Wide Stout and Goose Island: of the three, this was the best).  Very impressive flavor profile

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2013 Aged about six months.  Not super complex but it is super outstanding.  Starting with the pour, jet black with one of the thick dark heads, decent retention too.  Swiss chocolate and coffee and the nose, touch of dark fruit.  Palate rocks.  Silky, creamy, dark fruit, beautiful balance, a bit charred, some hoppiness and a nice dry and clean finish.  

Aged another 3 years for the 2nd bottle.  Still pretty good.  Was dry, not silky, plenty of warmth, cocoa, dark chocolate.  Coffee subdued.  Clean.  Roasted body.  Would probably rate it a bit lower but it held up nice.

The bottle looks absolutely great and the beer in the glass is simply amazing. Starts complex malty without being too much, creamy-malty, wonderful coffee notes that get stronger in the end. Light chocolate notes. Finish very well balanced, very drinkable. An absolutely amazing beer!

Nose is mostly coffee and black malts with hints of chocolate, light roast, and  dust. Pours black with a huge rocky brown head. Mostly coffee and roast in the flavors with softer notes of chocolate, light smoke, earth, and dust. Easy drinking with sharp coffee/roast finish. Lively small bubbled carbonation. Dry mouthfeel. To me this was good, but not as good as the score indicates.

Bottle, bought 18 months ago and liberated from itÂ’s hiding place under the stairs. Pours black with a frothy tan head which gradually receeds. Coffee, smoke, wood, raisins and toffee aromas. Excellent nose. Dark roast coffee, licorice, caramel, dark chocolate and vanilla flavours. Excellent carbonation. Dry, smoky finish. Very tasty.

On tap at RattleÂ’nÂ’Hum.  Fully smoked grain aroma - complex, with a touch of esters.  Lots of toasty, smoky, campfire coffee flavor.  A beautifull balanced stout, that is not sugary, or aggressively hopped, or too lite.  Excellent.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2010 Finally. IÂ’ve had this many times, but never got around to actually rate it. Pours a pitch black, oily body with a medium, but dense caramel head. Nose is licorice and espresso, with hints of leather. Taste is burnt toast and coffee, with some malty licorice coming in mid-palate. Very drinkable, and the lightness of the body is relieving in the face of the imperial stout-like taste. Some oat tones in between the coffee and leather. One might say that this is, simply put, a very drinkable imperial stout. Solid craft beer.

Pours a great jet black color with a dark brown creamy head.The aroma was of mocca and a little vanilla.The flavor is dominated by coffee with a small hop bite.Goes down down smooth and a little bitter aftertaste that grows as you drink.Overall a well deserved reputation.

Mmmmmm ahhhhhhh back to the good stuff. Mikkeller, I bow down. Great classic beer actually. Poured with a large light brown thick creamy foamy frothy head that lasts and lots of lace. Color is opaque brown black. Aroma is malt roast cocoa dark ripe fruits yeast and a bit of coffee. FlavorÂ’s like aroma and better. Very well balanced. Excellent creamy smooth body and carbonation. Superb finish that is like flavor and ends up chocolate malty with a suggestion of alcohol. Fabulous beer. Very easy drinking although more sipping than quaffing.

This is a great example of a coffee oatmeal stout. I wish it was priced a little more reasonable - well if it was priced half as much as it is I would still say that. Pours a jet black with a tan head. Very big coffee aroma, mouthfeel great from the oats. I could drink a few of these on a cold winter night and not think twice. If I were a millionaire. DonÂ’t know if I could justify drinking them for breakfast though. Well I guess I could, work might disagree.

Wow!  I really believe that this is the blackest beer I have ever seen!   I held it up to a very intense halogen lamp and could see no perceptible light coming through it.  Only a deep garnet red at the bottom edge of the glass where itÂ’s very thin.  The nose is a deep roasted, almost estery coffee aroma with almost a little burned rubber in the background (good, not bad).  The head is a billowy, long lasting light brown covering over the opaque fluid below.  First sip is dark chocolate, slight roasted bitter/sour, dark roasted coffee mid-palate and espresso around the sides.  Not nearly as overpowering as I thought it would be given the color and aroma.  Slight vegetal after taste that compliments the roasty, chocolate goodness up front.   This is an excellent coffee stout that keeps getting better with every sip!

From the bottle.  Pours a deep black with a few finger coffee colored head, that slowly recedes.  Smells of bitter coffee and toasty and roasty malts.  The taste is more of burnt coffee / popcorn than any other flavor.   A hit of booze sneaks through.  Great creamy mouthfeel.  Overall a good beer, but the coffee has just been roasted a little too long

UPDATED: APR 20, 2017 [5/10] 500ml bottle. Black. Thick , quivering dome of crema head. Quite a few tiny bubbles. Gentle, enticing mocha and roasted malt aroma with some vanilla, porridge and dark berries.Oily verging on creamy mouthfeel with quite German sweetness and a hint of metal before roast and coffee bitterness kick in and linger. The main flavours are good and well balanced. The complex notes mesh well with the main flavours - almost like harmonics. And the beer is not overwhelming: it retains a sense of space as if listening to music in a room rather than through headphones. [8 4 9 5 18 =4.4][12/12] Pours a little gloopily but ends up looking the same. As before, except the metallic tinge is absent and citrus flavours - which are just slightly intrusive - are more obvious. Super balance, fairly powerful but easily manages to be inviting. [4/17] Can. US product. Black, tan head laces well. Lots of oats, moderate roast, coffee doesnÂ’t have a lot of "top". Very porridgish. Bitterness is firm, but hop aromatics onÂ’t do a whole lot. OK, a rerate where the score comes down a bit. But this is still a great and harmonious beer.

Bottle 50cl. A deep black stout with a brown head ! Smell is low but roasted like. A creamy ale with huge black patent malt aroma, but less roasted barley aroma therefore not too pungent just bitter at the finish. Notes of licorice and dry prune, nice cofee smell aftertaste.

Poured deep black with a thick tan head. Light coffe aroma with some roasted malt. flavor is nicely balance with coffee notes with lingering bready malt. good cofee finish. perfectly bitter with some stickiness. very very tasty.

500ml bottle courtesy of @weeheavysd and @bikesandbeers.  Poured into 4oz beer tasters.  Giant head that thins out with time, with some legs.  Intense coffee and grain aroma.  Thick and syrupy mouth feel.  A little sweet up front, reasonably bitter in the back of the throat, definitely intense coffee!!

Pours black with a nice caramel colored head that quickly fades, although it leaves behind some pretty nice lacing. The smell is of coffee. Almost no malt or hop aroma whatsoever. The taste is also very strong on the coffee but includes hints of chocolate, roasted barley, and a little tinge of alcohol. This is far and above better than any other normal stout that IÂ’ve had.

Really a very good stout.  Pours a dark brown, with the slightest hint of light able to penetrate the edges of the beer, with an immense head of medium brown.  Nose is quite nice, well balanced between coffee and chocolate notes, and a stronger alcohol note than might be expected from a 7.5% beer.  Flavors are nice, though perhaps too dominated by the coffee.  Not quite so well balanced and delicious as the nose would indicate.  As the beer warms, the coffee is overtaken by roast flavors and the bitterness of the beer picks up a bit.  Overall, a very good brew.

22oz bottle from La Cave Ã  Bulles in Paris 
Appearance: Thick black with a nice dark tan head that doesnÂ’t dissipate, some lacing 
Aroma:  Dark malts, vanilla, smoke and chocolate 
Taste: Silky smooth and full mouthfeel. Roasted malts, chocolate and coffee 
Wow! This beer is named correctly, I feel like IÂ’ve eaten a big breakfast full of malts, oats, coffee and chocolate for desert. Well balanced and very tasty.
Actually drank this beer for breakfast. Beautifully crafted blend of oatmeal and coffee. Some chocolate and cognac in the nose. Rated 8/6/08

Bottle.

A - Deep, dark black, even on the edges. Large, thick, creamy, sticky sandy brown head. Very good retention with a thick, creamy layer of lacing left.

S - Rich malt aroma with espresso beans being dominant, they smell perfectly roasted. Also present is a good amount of dark chocolate and toasted oats along with some caramel and a hint of vanilla. Somewhere in between a strong coffee stout aroma and a regular stout.

T - At first, there was more bitterness and roasted flavors than I picked up in the nose. Strong roasted coffee and malt along with a load of roasted oat flavors up front along with some dark chocolate. Mid sip, some earthy and slight citrus hop flavors come out. However, there is still a large roasted presence. After it warms up and opens up for a little while, the flavors mesh a bit more. The strong roasted bitterness blends and becomes a bit more mellow. Oat, coffee, and chocolate mix with some caramel, lactose, and hints of vanilla. Coffee is definitely prominent but not dominant.

M - Slightly above medium body with moderate carbonation. Smooth, creamy and rich mouthfeel.

D - Quite a drinkable beer, especially after it warms and opens up a bit. Quite smooth and balanced. The coffee flavor is definitely there and present, but it is as strong and dominant as other coffee forward beers.

Notes: Batch No. 412 (Brewed on 17/03/09). Nice breakfasty beer. Coffee and oats are there and upfront but not dominant. Coffee mixes roasted bitter and sweet lactose well and oats make a smooth, slightly chewy enjoyable beer. Really nice when it opens up and becomes a bit more smooth and balanced. Not the best beer IÂ’ve had, but a good solid beer.

Pours a jet black color with a chocolate brown colored thick foam head.  Has an aroma of chocolate with a hint of coffee.  Has a subtle sweetness to it, with a dry bitter finish.  Notes of chocolate and coffee.  The coffee taste lingers a bit too long on the finish for me.  And I do not drink coffee so...  Decent.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2010 Update 2010-05-08: Doing a new tasting, this time batch #464, brewed 2009-10-26. Wow! Is it me, or the beer? This is a quite different experience! This one is a lot more easy/soft, with no stingy rubber madness! Nose is still mainly coffee and chocolate. Aroma is mainly of coffee, caramel, malt, with some tobacco and slightly fruity edges. Earthy undertones, hints of nuts. A long, pleasantly bitter finish. A very welcome surprise!

Batch #357, brewed 2008-04-24, tasted 2010-04-30.

It poured a black brew, blacker than an extra black black hole on a moonless night! Light just doesnÂ’t pass through it - even holding a lighter on one side of the glass didnÂ’t help. Head was half a cm, brown and disappeared quickly.

Smell: Very nice, somewhat fresh actually, dominated by chocolate malt and coffee. Pretty much what IÂ’d imagined.

Then thereÂ’s the taste and aroma. Which was quite something else than IÂ’d expected! The first sips felt like eating a whole sea urchin dipped in liquid rubber (!) - and I thought "what? is there something wrong with my bottle?" - but then I paired it with some dark chocolate (great pairing), and read some reviews here to see if other people described a stingy, heavy bitterness - which many did. Which again leads me to believe itÂ’s supposed to taste like this. Now, after some more sips and a little more chocolate to balance out my mouth, IÂ’m starting to enjoy it, though IÂ’m still uncertain about it. The bitterness is just a bit overwhelming for me. Apart from that, the aroma is mainly coffee and rubber. Yeah, rubber. Like eating bicycle tires and having a cup of coffee at the same time. IÂ’m having trouble with this one, to be honest.

IÂ’m liking the palate though, which is full and thick and creamy. Carbonation is to me quite spot on - not too much and not too little. The long finish is bitter.

If this beer was a movie it would be a well-made(-but-not-my-taste) film noir, called "The long, bitter finish". 

ItÂ’s definitely a complex, impressive brew nonetheless, but perhaps not my style. Well, I still have two more bottles, so IÂ’m gonna give it another shot later. Maybe itÂ’s actually good for breakfast? Bacon, eggs, good cheese and this beer sounds like an interesting experiment!

Pours inky dark, brownish black with cascading sparkling brown, creamy tan 2inch head. Smell is toasted malty flavors, creamy dark chocolate. The taste on this one is very smooth. It reminds me of drinking a smooth, creamy cup of iced coffee. Very enjoyable to start the day with 22oz of this one!

I love strong coffee and I love this beer. Nice and hoppy and bitter.  Smokey and drinkable. It coats your tongue and the aftertaste lasts forever. With so many great stouts out there.  I would not buy again because of the high price.

Pours darkest brown with lots of cloudy brown sediment collecting at the bottom of the glass and topped with a creamy, dark tan head from a bottle bought at Whole Foods: Meaty aroma of bitter, whole roasted coffee beans, fresh black coffee, burnt caramel malts, dark cocoa, and hoppy bitters. Flavor of finely carbonated coffee, more powerful than coffee itself. Other notable flavors include sharp wheat, molasses, oats, bittersweet dark chocolate, tough smoked vegetarian jerky, hints of orange, grilled asparagus, and prickly grass. Really dissectible. Really really delicious. Drinkability: Aggressively bitter throughout. Lacks sweetness in a bold, unapologetic way. Pairing: Roast turkey with lots of herb seasoned skin, and a side of grilled asparagus. Rebuy: Yea. #430 on 26042010, DG.

50cl bottle cellared 2years. 

Poured a dead black ale in the tulip with a massive mocha colored meringue cap....lasts the drink and laces well. 

Aroma is pungent roast with coffee tones but there is a layered cereal complexity under this giving a grainy sweetness under some hop spice bouquet.

- rich rounded mouth feel big bodied. 

Big body and malts meet the palate in the profile front side, then almost instantly coffee-hop light astringenscy flood the palate, seconds later the oats show with some nutty flavor a bit of cereal complexity...like oatmeal and raisins with espresso poured over it.....finish is long and wet with puckering bittering from hops and coffee.

 Damn fine coffee stout. Not as good as PÃ©chÃ© Mortel, but close. I suspect this cellared sample had some coffee and hop brightness subdued but the rounded mellow center were worth the wait.

Bottle at GÃ¶teborg Beerfestival 2010-04-23, GÃ¶teborg 
roasted malt, espresso coffey x 3

great pour, black with a delayed brown head thats very controllable, good lacing, foams nicely on a swirl. great aroma to hold its own with any coffee beer, lots of roast, lots of layers. the taste is great, nice stout with some good really dark coffee. the mouth feel is nice and creamy, but i took off 1 for an overtly overly bitter aftertaste, way overroastedness shows up here, and reminds me of a starbucks flop.
Aroma of fresh roasted coffee, licorice and chocolate. Appearance is black with scant tan head. Flavor matches the nose. Palate is bubbly and lively. Good, but overrated.
Good but not overly great. Pours a really nice dark brown. Feels a bit thin, and never kicks in any outstanding flavor. Roasted and sweet, with a bitter finish.

dark cloaked, full body with great lacing and tightly grouped tiny bubbles build to a decent manilla head.  Poured from bottle chilled quickly in the freezer, beer just below room temp, coffee and toast balance the malt and the perfect amount of alcohol can be felt on the roof of the mouth.

Bottle says brewed at Nogne .... Opaque black pour tan head..... aroma of roasted coffee, chocolate and oats ..... full thick bodied taste of oats, roasted dark coffee and a slight hint of sweet caramel/chocolate which i tasted more as I got to the bottom of the bottle  ..... not much sweetness though its pretty much a dark roasted stout with a light bitter hop finish .... Definitely a complex feel ... it did go well with breakfast

Pours black as oil with slight tan head. Freashly ground espresso dominates the nose, with some caramel and a tiny hint of those floral yankee hops, smoke and vanilla. On the palate itÂ’s all coffee at first, but the hops do come through as well as a whack of caramel/roasted malt. Good bitterness. Very mouth-filling with a lovely velvety texture. Not as sweet as I thought it would be. Slightly astringent finish. One of my all-time favourites!

500ml Bottle -  Black with a chocolatey brown/tan head.  Enticing aroma with chocolate, coffee, hops and roasted malt. Roasted taste with coffee, chocolate, roasted malt and hops, Nicely balanced and whilst the flavours are strong, no aspect is overwhelming and itÂ’s very enjoyable.

Note: There is a distinct possibility that the batch I had was contaminated. Thus i will re-rate when I get access to a new bottle, whenever that may be (trade anyone?). Anyway, poured a dark, dark brown with no head and a ton of sediment. Looked like tannic acid stained water with a lot of sediment runoff. Almost no aroma to speak of, just a hint of coffee. Flavor was of ... well... there wasnÂ’t a whole lot of flavor besides some burnt malt and an unpleasant aftertaste that just lingered and lingered. Was very disappointed, as I enjoy oatmeal stouts. But I do believe I may have ran into a bad batch.

Bottle from De Molen. Pours a pitch black beer with a good brownish head. Impressive aroma with hints of chocolate, coffee and hops. Taste is great. Alot of coffee kicks in, burned malts, with a hoppy finish. Great beer!
