This beer has a sensational aroma. Grounded espresso coffee beans hits you with a lot of power. I am getting coffee; chocolate, roasted malts, nuts, vanilla and oak. This beer is excellent. Batch no 412 bought from the PRE-ZBF 2010 shop. 17th March 2009 on the label. Awesome stuff. This is an exceptional stout. Loving this. Cheers. Alcohol is remarkably well hidden and drinkability is good. Pallet is a little too nutty on the texture but itÂ’s still a knock out.

bottle-over a year old!  beer poured black as oil with a nice beige head-foamy and sudsy.  great nose-molassas, lite spice (cinnamon), coca, char, anise, and lots of burnt notes.  The coffee beans come through, but i think alof of that dropped out in the nose.  flavors show all of the above with a lingering note of coffee beans and a touch of vanilla.  lots of char and roast with a touch of dark chocolate.  long as hell roasty finish-i mean it went for minutes!  pretty awesome!  Palate is about as perfect as your going to get-round, oily, nice mouthfeal with perfect carbonation.  One monster stout for sure that packs alot of flavor for not being high alcohol.  I have had this fresh and it was very hoppy fresh, which is one thing i really like about the beer when fresh-gives it that green note.  A wonderful stout that i will definately seek out again (which is rare for me these days with stouts!).

Deep oily black pour, large creamy brown head. Aroma of coffee, liquorice, hops. Very floral and fruity hops. Flavour is full of coffee, quite bitter and sweet at the same time. Awesome. Lingers on for ever.
Awesome.
Excellent.  Smooth creamy palate from the oats, contrasted with a sharp roasted bitter bite from the coffee.  Hints of chocolate.  Really excellent all around.

Nose is pleasant, chocolate malt/oats/ light heat.  Minor hop fruitiness and caramel. The centennial really hangs around.  Flavour is all coffee to start. Very full in the mouth. Little buttery on the back of the tongue and slightly astringent/ tannis on the finish.  I think it lacked some sweetness, but very enjoyable

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2013  thin creamy beige head. not much lacing.  espresso nose. caramel and coffee taste.. soft carbonation, with that terrific grimstad water mouthfeel. no sign of the 7.5ABV. bitter coffee dominates flavor but at the same time so soft and delicious.great coffee stout.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2011 bottle i had was off 2007
creamy dark brown head , pitch black beercolour
smell was mild coffee not as hard as i tought when i saw the colour of this beer , almost sorta french kinda coffee smell, but when i walsed the beer in the glass i had a smell of white aspargus
taste was kinda interesting coffee taste was subtle , also had a watery flavour and hints of orange blossom water , the beer was pretty bitter tough , but very good beer overall and just the taste i always like !!

had it again last wednesday 15/06/2011, and the taste was still as marvelous as i noted above , remarcable at this age is that the beer is still as hopy/bitter in flavour as it was before !!! amazingly good aging  !!!

Pours dark brown, with 2 fingers of airy brown head. Aroma is wonderful with dark roast coffee, burnt malt and chocolate. Carbonation is high, I think too high for the style. Flavor starts with bitter malt, and finishes with smooth coffee. Enjoyable.
Tap at Blind Tiger - milky, creamy and oats. chocolate, coffee and molasses. I expected more roast in this one, but great beer nonetheless. Finishes with some vegetal sharpness and a bit tart.

Beer Geek Breakfast Stout
Pours black with a thin creamy head. Mild lacing on the glass and decent retention. Color has an almost rusty look to it. Aroma is slightly metallic with coffee and molasses. Flavor is bready and coffee and a nice bitter finish. Fairly smooth drink, but slightly underwhelming. Very good though

Tasted 2010-03-27. Pours black with light brown head. Very powerfull stout. Especially considering the relatively low (?) ABV. ItÂ’s a very balanced mixture of your roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate, vanilla etc.
500ml bottle from a private order.  Pours black, with some worriesome looking chucks as the bottle drains.  Aroma of coffee and chocolate is lovely.  Big flavour, almost chewy, and a pleasant finish.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2010 Bottle pours thick black with huge tan head.  Taste chocolate and roasted coffee with minimal alcohol.  Slight hoppy finish.  I like it but not quite to the level others apparently do.

Tap at the Blind Tiger. Definitely deserving of all the praise. Pitch black, motor oil pour with a big beige head. Nose of burnt malts, coffee, chocolate. Flavor is huge and dynamic. A full, roasted malt backdrop, rife with expresso and milk chocolate. Full bodied and rich with medium carbonation. A joy to drink. Long and lingering coffee and cocoa aftertaste. Brilliant.

Big dark and rich but with crispness - noticeable oatmeal and coffee flavour balanced by three layers of bitterness - coffee, roasted malt/barley and hops. As good as it gets - the breakfast of champions!!!

A jet black pour with a decent brown head that unfortunately doesnÂ’t last too long. The aroma is an almost sweet black liquorice chocolate and dark fruit smell, really fantastic. The flavor is burnt toast, coffee, etc, all the roast malt notes. It finishes a little weak, could be a bit more heavily hopped in my opinion, and the mouthfeel isnÂ’t quite as chewy as a big stout could be. All in all, a great beer.

Had on tap with breakfast at the Library Alehouse.  pitch black in color. aroma is muted.  really lingers at the back of the mouth and the roof of the mouth.  coffee notes dominate with some chocolate .  bit sparkly too.

Rated a bottle on 2/2/10.  Full tan head, black as pitch, beautiful.   Sweet chocolatey nose, no hint of alcohol.  Faint aroma of lightly roasted coffee.  Tastes good, the sweetness of a cream stout balanced with roasted (but not charred) coffee.  Slight bitterness in the finish, just enough to balance the sweetness in the flavor. Not too thin, quite nice.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2010 Bottle, 50 cl from Ã˜lkonsortiet
Pours opaque black with a nice and creamy brown head.
The has a lot of coffee, a hint of liquorice and you also get a bit of hoppiness. The taste has coffee, coffee and coffe along with a slight hoppiness and a hint of caramel. A very toasted taste.
A long aftertaste with the coffee sticking all over your mouth, and itÂ’s actually rather refreshing.
Another really nice brew from Mikkeller. (8-5-8-4-16)
Re-rate: Bottle from 2006: Aroma is just delicious with a lot of delicious chocolate, dark fruits, blueberries, sweetness and a nice coffee occuring in the end with a nice hop profile. Velvety smooth aroma. The taste is much dominated by the coffee, very bitter espresso-coffee, some fruitiness, but not as outspoken as in the aroma. Taste is a little less complex than the aroma.Tastes just amazing. Just stunning. (9-5-8-4-17)

bottle thanks to Drowland.  Pours pitch black tall dark brown head.  Strong milk chocolate and roasted barley with a touch of coffee in the nose.  Flavor is strong cocoa nib and coffee lingering in the finish.  Very nice.

Tap at NajaÂ’s. Thick black pour with a thick dark tan head. Huge coffee, tobacco and dark roasted grain aroma. Thick chewy chocolate, roasted grain, tobacco, oats and coffee dominate the taste. Thick complex and tasty. Awesome.

500 ml bottle.  Pours a true pitch black with giant head of mocha foam.  Aroma of dark roasted malts, roasted oats, coffee, and milk chocolate.  Tastes of bitter coffee and espresso, oats, and the American hops make a nice appearance.  Incredibly creamy and smooth mouthfeel with lingering (coffee) bitterness in the finish.  This is statistically far and away the highest rated stout on RateBeer.  It did not disappoint.  (1110, 256)
Delicious . . . lots of espresso, malt and a very thick beer. Perhaps a little bit of chocolate.

Pours black as night with a dark brown head that gets lighter as it settles. Espresso, dark chocolate, toffee, wood and vanilla in the nose. Light impression of sweetness goes dry and fairly bitter. Lasting espresso-bitter aftertaste. Stunningly light and creamy mouthfeel... almost fluffy.

500ml bottle into snifter. Pours black with a finger and a half of dense, creamy light brown foam. Aroma is sweet milk and dark chocolate and lots of espresso. Flavor is roasted malts, bitter coffee, with a touch of sourness. Dry and lingering bitter finish. Mouthfeel is medium full and creamy, with soft carbonation. Wonderful aroma but, IÂ’m not a coffee drinker, so the flavor pushes the limits of my ability to enjoy this one.

Bottle from Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam. Black pour with a muddy brown head.  Banging nose that  just draws you right in, oodles of roasty coffee and dark chocolate. You just know this is gonna be shit hot before your lips touch the glass. Cracking silky mouthfeel. Straight up the best coffee flavour IÂ’ve tasted in a beer, with more choc, malts and lovely hoppage. Sweetish towards the finish which had some bitterness. Wish I had this readily available as a go to beer. Need to move to Denmark I suppose.

Bottle poured into glass. Great aroma of roasted mocha and coffee. Deep dark pour that laced the glass nicely. Flavor is huge, bitter chocolate yet smooth. Immensely tasty and wonderful sipping Stout.

A fantastic smell who reminds me of "Struise Black Albert" roasted coffee, earthy notes and wood. It is astringent. The beginning is smooth but thereÂ’s a harsh and inappropriate bitterness in the finish that ruins everything. The bitterness covers everuthing and prevents other flavors to speak. What a pity

50cl bottle.   Black with a lasting and amazingly thick and dense brown head. The aroma has a really inviting toasted oat and creamy malt thing going on.   Also reminds me of honey on biscuits with some coffee on the side.   Nice stuff so far.   The flavor is pretty acidic and a touch chalky, with a little coffee and rich toasty malt.   The roast is a creamy background layer for the most part, and the finish is bitter and acidic.   Medium-full body with perhaps too much carbonation, but a nice tight feel to it.   Dry in the finish with alcohol showing but not to overt.   Good at parts, but oddly lacking in overall balance and drinkability.   Nice stuff overall, but not quite what I expected.

On draft at Ginger Man. DidnÂ’t like this one as much as expected, based on ratings. Would be interested to try again to see if I just got a random bad glass. Aroma and flavor strong of roasted malts and coffee, but also a really strange fruitiness that almost verged on sour, which seemed pretty out of place in the beer. There was also a lingering mustiness on the finish that was not so appealing. An interesting beer, no doubt, but not entirely successful, at least not the sample I had.

big dark brown head with a nice mocha dark brown colored body, nose is lots and lots of coffee, chocolate, roasted malts, some smoke and raisin. flavor is again big time coffee, semi sweet choc, smoke again. smooth mouth coating brew nice stuff
Bottiglia. Profumo meraviglioso di caffÃ¨ tostato, intensissimo e persistente come la schiuma a dir poco spettacolare. Aroma che riempie e che soddisfa le papille gustative come poche altre birre.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2015 Bottle at home. Very dark brown, a bit red. Oily head, donÂ’t hold long, a little browny.. Fruit-roasted-chocolate, cofffee, espresso.Feels a bit like oil. Very smooth. Roasted coffee, dark fruits, a lots of coffee in the taste, caramel. Bitter aftertaste . The hops are more in front as expected.

On tap at Local Option. Foamy head to it before it disappears completely. Dark fruitness followed by hops then finishing with a strong coffee finish. Long after taste of roast malts and bitter coffee. Solid over all but it will not blow you away like the ratings say. FounderÂ’s Breakfast stout still better and for way less money.

Thick dark tan head that lasts and lasts. Smells like a dark rich espresso with roasty malts. Heaps of coffee flavour, rich and bitter with plenty of body. Wildly expensive here in Australia; quite possibly the single best beer IÂ’ve ever had from a bottle.

On draft at CaponeÂ’s.  Pour is a moonless midnight with a very little amount of mocha head.  Nose is extreme coffee, toasted malt, oats, light chocolate, and sour cherries.  The body on this is quite thin, considering the complexity, but not surprising because of the oats.  I detect everything in that I got from the nose, but the sour cherries were a brief flash at the beginning before making the vanishing act.  The brew comes off creamy, and then lingers with a bitter espresso finish.  This is quite tasty, but I believe the Founders Breakfast Stout offers more for less $$$.

Bottle from private order with R&R Toronto. Very dark, almost black with a huge tan head. Lots of roasted coffee tones. Taste is dry, espresso with a hint of chocolate. Medium to full body with a very long and dry finish. Very nice!

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2010 Pours pitch black and thick, tar-like. The head is huge and frothy but fast diminishing. Some creamy, dark beige lace remains. The aroma is very intensive. Lots of roasted maltiness and fresh crushed coffee beans, chocolate and dark fruitiness. Plentiful with slightly herbal and resiny hops. Powerfull but very soft roastedness. The flavor is bitter, roasted and heavily malty. Finishes slightly burnt, chalky and ashy. Some milgk sugary souress. The palate is full bodied, roasted and sticky in the finish.

Location: 500 ml bottle from NormÂ’s, 3/3/10 


Aroma: Tons of coffee on the nose, some chocolate, vanilla, thereÂ’s smokiness there too

Appearance: This beer pours an opaque brown-black color with a somewhat thin, creamy brown head that leaves some drippy lace on the glass

Flavor: The taste is lots of roasted and burnt malts, some creamy coffee/chocolate, and earthy hop bitterness gives a nice balance to the burnt toast malt flavors

Palate: ItÂ’s not as full as expected, say medium bodied, with a nice mouthfeel, it has a nice, not overly heavy, drinkability/feel to it that works pretty well, its pretty smooth, creamy, chewy, and has soft to average carbonation

Overall Impression: 
This is a really good brew.  One of the better stouts IÂ’ve even had, it has a wonderful complexity to it.  Drinks so nicely, it is somehow not the full bodied brew I was expecting, but manages to be just full enough.  I can see why this one gets so much hype, IÂ’d been holding onto it for a while, but today is a good day, so IÂ’ll celebrate with this incredible beer.  Awesome stuff.
On tap at Capones.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Taste has a light sweetness but nothing overpowering.  Could have this for breakfast everyday.

Bottled.  Poured dark with a moderate yet disappearing head. Taste was strong coffee and chocolate, but taste was surprisingly light, not overly sweet or rich,  and ABV way camouflaged.  A fantastic coffee stout.
big bottle a black pour brown head A big sweet chocolate flavor up front and a nice not ovepowering coffee finish. thick and oily. Awesome beer

Pours a dark black, almost oily in appearance with a tan head.  Aroma is of roasted malts and chocolate.  Taste is bittersweet, more sweetness at the start.  Thick mouthfeel that finishes very light on the tongue.

0,5 l bottle. Dark beer with fine brown head. Coffee and malt aroma, a burned malt or coffe odour also detected. A liquorice taste, not sweet at all. Hops grow on the taste buds as you drink.  The beer is a bit thick as moutfeel. Nice.

Bottle to snifter.  Pours black, with a decent head. Aroma of chocolate and coffee .  Full body and complex flavors going on, but I get a burnt taste as well.  Solid beer, but too highly rated IMO comapred to others.

The aroma of smoke and coffee is supportive of its name. The deep dar chestnut brown color has a decent lacy foamy head. The flavors of smoke and crisp coffee are overpowering but still delicious on the palate.

Rich, chocolate color with a (too-)persistent tan foamy head. Roasted malt, coffee, chocolate aroma. First sip grabs your attention, but no single overwhelming flavor - combination of chocolate, coffee, smoke, but well blended. Nicely bitter ending. Full and creamy, but a little over-carbonated for me. Solid, not spectacular, overall.

You can hear all roasted malt and a lot of coffe...
The bitter itÂ’s delicated when you taste it , but after 1 minute itÂ’s like you drink a coffe without sugar .. :-)
The color itÂ’s simply perfect ... ALL DARK...!!!
The foam itÂ’s compact and brow like cappuccino!!
Good breakfast...I need croassant...

500 ml bottle. Pitch black, with a medium-sized beige head. Rich aroma of dark chocolate, roasted malts and coffee. The flavour is roasted, a little burned, with plenty of coffee, somedark chocolate and liquorice, and a dry bitter chocolaty finish. Full-bodied- slick and smooth.

Pours a rich coffee black with a med. tan/beige head. Immediately opens up with a wonderful aroma, lots of espresso and black coffee scents, some sweetness and chocolate. Also, a little smokey. Taste is similar, very rich, oatey, chocolate, espresso, licorice, some smoke/roast flavors as well. Super rich without being overwhelming or syrupy. Amazing. May be one of my favorite stouts. If Mikkeler set out to bottle breakfast in beer form, they did it perfectly.

500 mL bottle from Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, served in a snifter. Pours a deep black with a creamy brown head with good retention and good lacing. Aroma is sweet, with notes of molasses and roasted malts. Expresso is also prominent. Notes of dark chocolate, charcoal and a touch of smoke. Flavour is sweet molasses up front; roasted espresso develops through the middle, leading to a long bitter hop finish. Full-bodied, creamy texture with soft carbonation. Overall, an excellent coffee stout. I didnÂ’t have it for breakfast, but thatÂ’s not a bad suggestion! 2010-02-21

Bottle from drowland via Cavie.  Dark black pour with a great looking brown head.  Aroma is roasted coffee beans and baking cocoa.  More dry cocoa taste with coffee, caramel, and roasted flavors.  Great thick finish.

IÂ’m not sure about the other Mikkeller beers, but this one is not overrated in the least bit! A really fantastic bier, beautiful and rich in every aspect. Pours into goblet a dark motor oil black with a finger sized brown head. Aroma is instantly coffee, heavily roasted malts, burnt toast and dirt. Down the hatch! Taste grabs a hold me immediately. It actually made my brain stop thinking for almost 10 seconds. I was just caught in the moment, in the beautiful full, chewy chocolate coffee mouthfeel. The flavour was so incredibly well balanced, it was almost sinful. It wasnÂ’t big and boozy and roasted, it was very subtle, smooth and delicate. An absolute treat. Thanks Malt House for bringing this gem in!

A: A 500 ml bottle poured into a snifter. The pour is a velvety black with an initially abundant mocha colored foam. The head leaves a bit of lacing.

S: A rather tame nose. Mild aromas of roasted malt, coffee, and chocolate.

T: The primary flavor is the roasted malt. The coffee is not quite as intense as I expected, but certainly present. A nice bitterness on the finish.

M: A smooth, creamy, full bodied feel on the tongue. The carbonation is fairly low, and helps to contribute to this silky feel.

D: The booze is not really present at all, which is good for an imperial stout, but not surprising since itÂ’s only 7.5%. Good flavors, if not a bit underwhelming.

A nice effort from Mikkeller, but not quite as good as I was expecting. I would enjoy this one again, however.

500mL bottle.  Pours an opaque dark chocolate brown with a fine, persistent brown head.  Aromas of molasses, chocolate, pine and citrus, with the coffee taking a back seat, and some faint smoke, roasted malt and raisin in the mix.  The coffee comes forward in the flavour, high bitterness from the coffee and hops.  Medium bodied, average carbonation, quite creamy, slight astringency on the palate with a lingering bitter finish.  

Goes well over vanilla ice cream.
UPDATED: MAY 16, 2013 33cl (recently brewed at Br. Lervig), Danish brew, with coffee, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex dry Stout, yet easy to drink, balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew

#1700! Bottle with huge thanks to drowland. Beer so black I canÂ’t see through it with a gorgeous tan head. Heavy roasted smell. Some black peppery smell with sweet creamy coffee. Lovely aroma of French Vanilla press. Slick mouthfeel. Dark roast flavor. Bitter coffee flavor. Dry finish that finishes pretty bitter. Sharp flavors carry through to the end. Very good. Very.
Bottle from Cavie.  Color is BLACK.  Thick creamy head that lasts forever.  Dry finish....almost powdery? Still good though.

Bomber enjoyed after my brother was admitted to the U of I! I had this beer a while ago so this is coming from memory. The beer pours a dark brown color with a huge tan head that takes a while to die down. The aroma is very roasty with a lot of coffee notes, some bitter chocolate, and some sweet malts. The taste is very pleasing with a lot of coffee flavor, possibly some burnt wood, and a sweet hint that reminded me of vanilla. This finishes very smooth and makes you want more. If you are a coffee lover or just love a great stout, do yourself a favor and give this one a try! I am looking forward to trying the Brunch Weasel at some point...

Outstanding! Beautiful near black pour, opaque even held up to the light, smooth tan head. Subtle nose- roasty malt with just a hint of coffee. Thin (for a stout) and slightly oily in the mouth. Flavor dry, terrifically balanced dark roast and the coffee is not at all astringent, but smooth and creamy and reinforcing the low dark notes of roast malts.

bottle - Almost black beer with a long lasting off-white brownish head. Aroma has some coffee and caramel. Faint hops notes. Flavour is not too malty, more dry. Very nice coffee! Medium bitterness. Full body with an oily texture.

[bottle from bierkompass.de]
Roasty aroma with tons of vanilla and oak, notes of raisins and chocolate. Opaque black under a lasting, light brown foam. In the flavour there is tons of coffee that was not obvious in the nose. Not quite black coffee, like just enough milk in it so that it is dark brown. With the coffee is a nice bitter oak accent together with vanilla. Dry with gentle bitter chocolate near the end. Balance is towards dry but still very pleasant. Medium body, moderate carbonation, hazlenut vanilla bitter finish.

Bottle.  Fantastic dark brown pour with a thick brown head.  Aroma of coffee and roasted malt.  Great medium bodied taste with plenty of carbonation.  Taste of roasted malt, oats and coffee.  Lasting dry finish.
pitch black with thin tan head. aroma is bursting with dark roast coffee. drinks with bitter dark roast coffee and thick burnt malts. alcohol on the finish with more coffee.
Bottle: Thick and heavy, pitch black with a huge dark brown head. Smokey, slightly bitter. Food Pairing: Chocolate Cake with chocolate mousse filling.
Pours black with a thick tan head.  Aroma is coffee, oatmeal and alcohol.  Tast is strong coffee with a sweet oatmeal finish and slight alcohol aftertaste.  Great beer.

Bottle. Black with a small brown head. Nose is major league coffee and roastiness, with the oatmeal in the background. Taste is overtly coffee, with a hint of cacao. Alcohol is well hidden. Body is medium, smooth and silky.
Bitter and dry but very easy to drink. Well done.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Bottle. Chocolate, caffee, vanilla and bread in aroma. Very dark brown colour with brown head. Bitter flavour of coffee, hops and grapefruit nicely mixed with oats. Slight touch of smoke.

Bottle, 500 mL.  To be honest, I thought this was gonna be a bit overrated, but I was wrong.  Pitch black pour with a nice frothy coffee-colored head.  Smell is oatmeal and coffee....a heavy dose of both.  Smoke and roast malts in the flavor, very strong.  Oatmeal and coffee in the taste too, maybe even some sweetness in the back...toffee?  No idea, but I greatly enjoyed this

Bottled 50cl. It pours a pitch black beer with a beautiful beige head. Absolutely mindblowingly fantastic! The wonderful hop profile is extremely well integrated in the coffee and malt components. Perfect balance. Spicy, salty and complex. Almonds sneaking in throughout. Flowery. I usually donÂ’t like oxidized hop characteristics in my beer- but here they add a new dimension which really adds to my appreciation of this already very complex stout. Distinct coffeish finish. Wonderful.
Bottle 50 cl. Black with a nice dark brown head. Aroma; coffee, dark fruits and dark choccolate. Flavor; Strong coffee taste with some sence of dark fruits. Chocolateaftertaste

Pours deep dark black with a creamy brown head.Very smooth yet full bodied.You can taste an array of flavors from toast coffee to milk chocolate.This is a superb beer.IÂ’m not even a coffee drinker and this is one of my faves.Must try!!

(bottle) pours a pitch black colour with a dense, creamy dark brown head. wonderful aroma of of dark toasted malts and chocolate fudge, marshmallow, brown sugar, char and some surprisingly fruity notes of lychee. flavour is all of the above, roasted malts being dominant, with some light hints of coffee and herbal hops. medium body and carbonation with a pronounced roasted-bitter finish.

Large bottle from Village Beer Merchant in Buffalo. I knew I couldnÂ’t pass up the opportunity to get this beer, even at close to $15 a bottle. Pours an ink black opaque body with a really nice thick, long lasting brownish head. Good lacing in my big snifter glass. Aroma is sweet milk chocolate malts, light roasted coffee, berries, caramel and some booze. Flavor is a great balance of sweet caramel and bitter roasted coffee. A bit cloying. Super smooth lightly carbonated mouthfeel. Bittersweet long lasting finish. Great beer IÂ’m surely gonna try again.

Thanks 17thfloor for buying me this beer on tap at Local Option in Chicago. Pours deep black with a small creamy tan head that lingered throughout. Aroma is nicely blended with cocoa, coffee beans and black coffee, nice roasted lightly burnt malts. Flavors are perfectly balanced with the same soft dark coffee character, chocolate, coffee beans, very very oaty, almost cookie amounts of oats which made this seem even more dessert oriented. Very rich creamy body, lightly sticky and a soft carbonation. Really tasty beer, thanks Gerrit!

Nice coffee, malt and a little hop in the aroma.

Good coffee taste, a little sweet like chocolate, little bitterness.

 Smooth. Thick. Velvet.

 Nice. A must for the birthday brunch.



Purchased at Ã˜rsted Ã˜lbar, tap.

birra scura con un bellissimo cappello color marroncino di schiuma molto compatta!
non molto amara ma decisamente delicata soprattutto nella sua persistensa al palato e allÂ’olfatto.
buonissima tostatura,abbastanza luppolata con punte di vaniglia,buonissimo lÂ’odore di caffÃ¨, e particolarisssimo il gusto di cioccolato fondente, che lascia in bocca.
veramente un ottimo prodotto,grazie Mikkeller!!!!
I have to put this in my top 10. A load of flavors and incredibly smooth and easy to drink. Very well balanced, good for breakfast, lunch or dinner. Even good as a snack at bedtime.

Pours pitch black with a big, building, sticky, brown head that lasts. The nose has a beautiful dark malt character: deep fruits, coffee, dark chocolate. In the mouth, it leads with smooth chocolate, followed by roasty coffee and more deep fruits. Bitter chocolate and a bready, cereal character on the swallow. Chocolate seems to be dominant and coffee is present throughout though I was expecting a bigger coffee profile. The mouthfeel is smooth all the way through. This one did go well with my breakfast, though it sort of clashed with the hot sauce I put on my eggs...

scura buona schiuma piuttosto fine buona persitenza naso tostato caffe leggero tabacco luppolo agruamto un tocco di vaniglia in bocca corpo medio discrete tostaure caffe un po di alcolico scaldante non molto amara retrogusto di caffe

Finally got a chance to try this amazing brew. 1 pint, 9 oz bottle poured into a snifter. Squid-ink black, impenetrable, with a huge, dark brown, pillowy head. Nose is out of this world, with nearly burnt coffee and fine espresso, dark and milk chocolats, black cigar tobacco, with slight plum, hazelnut, and cereal notes. Taste is even more amazing: nearly all coffee (yet not overpoweringly so), with dark chocolate, dark wheat bread, and a wavering wisp of smoked meat. The oatmeal keeps the mouthfeel velvety and smooth. Finishes well, but lingers on the palate, and the breath, forever. Absolutely astounding.

Bottle 0,5 l (bbe 2011). Pitch black with a thick light brown head. Nose has coffee, bitter chocolate, espresso, maltiness, roastiness. All the same in the flavor. Pretty thick mouthfeel with very fine carb. Beautiful.

Beer Geek Breakfast pours ink black with a massive fluffy brown head.  Complex aroma of vanilla, chocolate, pipe tobacco, and dare I say, marij*ana?  Nothing wrong with that in my book.  The beer has an incredible mouthfeel and a wonderful palate of oats and coffee beans.
I hesitate to make rash proclamations about a beer until IÂ’ve had it at least twice on different occasions, but now that IÂ’ve tasted this one twice, I think it to be the best stout, and one of the best beers IÂ’ve ever had.  Wow.

Wow, is this stuff good. Pours a deep black with nice thick creamy head that lasts. The coffee is very noticeable in both the aroma and the flavor. Other flavors include some chocolate, some spice, some peppers, roasted grain. This is one of the best stouts IÂ’ve drunk. Very smooth drinking.

Rating #202.  Good times.  Pours a very inviting, deep, rich black with a solid tan head, lacing nicely on the surface of the glass.  Aromas are richly of anise, dark fruits, leather, and coffee.  Taste is very dry, with a complex series of movements in the palate.  Starts with leather, works to somewhat stale coffee, then moves into a simple earthy finish.  IÂ’m not sure I buy all the hype, but this is a very solid beer.  I like stouts, but I think this beer is an example of why I prefer the imperial stout... just  a little too little going on here.

Bottle. Split with Vinny. Pours opaque chocolate black with a thick, tall, beige head. Aroma of espresso, coffee beans, chocolate, grapes, barley, roasted malts, pepper, scotch, and notes of cinnamon and tart. Extraordinarily smooth, thick, luxuriously silky body with a bold, robust mouthfeel; the coffee is very apparent. Finishes slowly with a lovely, toasty warming in the throat and belly. Overall, one of the best stouts I have ever had. Definitely try this brew.

Pours dark brown to black with a huge dark tan head. Aroma is big time coffee with some hops as well. DidnÂ’t expect to find them in this beer. The flavor is lots of coffee, but also some hop flavor and bitterness. The taste starts with coffee, then moves to citrusy hop flavor and bitterness and then finishes with more coffee. The hops somewhat diminish as the beer warms. Medium thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Oatmeal adds to the creamy mouthfeel.

Sample at BeerandBlues2 blind stout tasting 9/22/09-Pours black with a nice tan head. Aroma of coffee and roasted malt. Taste of roasted malt, chocolate, and smoke. This is an outstanding full bodied brew.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2010 Bottle split with Tony DiUlio @ Pub Italia in Ottawa, Ontario.   The pour on this sucker was absolutely brutal.. uberly thick black pour.  A good stout but not as extreme as IÂ’d hoped... especially for this sick rating.  Founders Breakfast Stout is better.

16.9 oz. bottle.  Pours midnight black (absolutely no light passes through this) topped with a thick dark brown head.  The head slowly collapses to leave wisps of lacing on the glass.  Aromas of dark roasted bitter coffee, latte (lactose), alcohol, brown sugar cane, toast, and a touch of hops.  Taste is bitter and sour, like strong espresso, with sweet roasted malt flooding in at the finish to round things out.  Warming, medium body, somewhat creamy, with low carbonation; if this were a little bit thicker, it could be awesome.  Lingering coffee aftertaste, with milky creaminess becoming more pronounced as it warms.  Really good, and IÂ’m glad I tried it, but pretty expensive.

Rating 1400. Bottle from De Molen shop. Black colour, generous tan head. Aroma has roasted malts and coffee. Flavour of roasted malts, oats, bitter roasted coffee and chocololate. Oily texture. Very nice.
Birra pazzesca!! potrei benissimo inzupparci il cornetto la mattina... Ã¨ un capucino cioccolatoso caldo e avvolgente eheheh
Holy coffee! Thick black pour with cappuccino colored head. Coffee and chocolate in the nose. Noticeable coffee and oat flavor with chocolate malts. Nice stout, great way to start the day!

Very dark brown, coffee looking beer with a medium, longlasting, brown head; aroma of roasted barley, coffee, liquorice, chocolate; full bodied, mouthfeel is very thick; flavor is everything you hope for a perfect breakfast - coffee, toast, cereal, poridge - with dry, coffeelike finish. Liked it, but didnÂ´t fall in love with it - maybe the time of the day was wrong (yeah, I admit: I didnÂ´t dare to drink it as/with breakfast) and just half liter of this beer was quite an hefty serving.

IÂ’m a beer geek and proud of it. Yes. Yes, I am. Mikkeller understands this. Why else would they have an exquisitely divine oatmeal coffee stout named, aptly so, Beer Geek Breakfast. I also find it a bit ironic that IÂ’ve had their Beer Geek Brunch with Weasel before I had their Beer Geek Breakfast, the stout that started it all.


Black, thick, rich, and viscous, she pours velveteen and black as pitch. Equally thick, rich and smooth is her head which is a gorgeous espresso crema, lingering long and soft from the first to last quaff. Stretching her fingers up the sides of my glass, her nose gently envelops me. Just as her appearance promised, thick, rich, and smooth. There is a subtle creaminess which permeates her nose which oozes rich European chocolates, oatmeal, and freshly drawn espresso. I have the oatmeal to thank for her smoothness and creaminess which I just know will be even more evident when I finally sup on her liquid bounty. But before I do, there is more of her nose to tease and tantalize. Black licorice, plums, raisins, burnt wood, and rich black earth culminates in burnt black chocolate, espresso crema, and toasted oats. Divine. I could smell her nose all day, but then I would be denying myself the beauteous brew below. Eyes closed, our lips meetÂ…and the heavens open unto me. A shiver courses from the tip of my toe to the top of my head, tracing ecstasy every single step of the way. Beervana is surely made of this, the rivers running black with Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast while soft cappuccino clouds float by upon a breeze of chocolate esters and dark fruits. I forgo any reservations I might have had and draw deep for each subsequent quaff. Her body is melted chocolates and cream with a sprinkling of vanilla bean and licorice root, leaving nary a surface of my mouth untouched. The finish dries, lingering long with brittle chocolates, charred wood, burnt sugars, and a touch more espresso crema. Dried raisins and prunes decorate the middle of her palate and, as her body warms, the oats are toasted to dark brown proportions, a touch of char along their edges for good measure. Every single ounce of her palate melts together in precision and, for me, quaffing ecstasy. There are few beers I could quaff every day and not get tired of, and the Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast is one of those. Each mouth-filling quaff is liquid bliss: toast, oats, charred wood, black earth, dark fruits, licorice, espresso, vanilla, cream, and melted chocolate. I refuse to let this moment end, and eyes closed, I relive each moment that my empty glass no longer allows me to do.


Mikkeller, you have stolen my heart and I donÂ’t think I want it back. At least, not unless it comes with a complimentary bottle of Beer Geek Breakfast. DonÂ’t believe me? Sup on one yourself, and rediscover heavenÂ’s nectar.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2010 Pours with a huge head. Very fresh nose with yeasty notes, dark chocolate, toffee and coffee. Great mouthfeel with freshly baked bread notes, vanilla, black cherry fruit and a hint of coffee on the finish. 

I didnÂ’t think this one was excellent the first time mainly because I treated it like a high alcohol, low carbonation imperial stout. Chill to 45 degrees and pour with moderate head into a frosted glass and this one improves considerably. If served too warm, the carbonation overwhelms any real flavor. Great beer to introduce friends to big coffee-flavored stouts without slamming them with the high gravity stuff. 

Since this has an ABV of 7.5%, I consider the price pretty outrageous. Costs about as much as a pint at the Ritz Carlton.

Bottle. The aroma is malty, dark smell of coffee and bitter chocolate, very nice. The large creamy brown head has a long duration, the body is black. The taste of chocolate and coffee, roasted malt, quite astringent. The body is creamy and dry, medium strong without much carbonation. A great beer.

My first Mikkeller beer, and I was impressed.  Bottle from the Party Source in Newport, KY.  This is one of the most impressive looking beers that IÂ’ve seen.  The pour is opaque, oily black with with a clinging, chunky dark tan head that lingered throughout the whole beer.  The aroma was surprisingly mild with hints of roasted malts.  The flavor was a complex medley of deep roasted malts and dark roasted coffee.  This oatmeal stout had the body and complexity of an imperial but the drinkability of an oatmeal.  Creamy, oily and dry in the finish, this is a superb beer.

Almost black beer with big and espresso-like, brown head. Aroma is strongly roasted, coffee, some liquirice and sugar, slightly sour: overally inspirating and complex. Flavour is full of roasted malts and roastiness is even stronger in the end, coffee, some liquirice and light hop flavours. Quite easy to drink, soft and quite high carbonation but it is nicely smooth. This beer based on strong roasted coffee, but still smooth and there are interesting nuancees.

500ml bottle.  Pours thick black with a large dense brown head that with excellent retention.  Walls of lacing.  Aroma is predominately gourmet coffee beans and dark chocolate.  Flavor opens up with coffee and chocolate, and is followed by some dark fruits.  Somewhat bitter and acidic finish.  Medium to high carbonation, but the oats help balance the mouthfeel with some creaminess.  I love me a coffee stout, and this is one of the best IÂ’ve had.

Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast is an opaque black beer with a dark muscovado colored head that gets blotchy and has outstanding retention and lacing.  It smells roasty, like coffee, ashy and almost... salty.  ItÂ’s full bodied and lively.  ItÂ’s smooth and the finish is slightly metallic.  It tastes roasty and smokey, with a lot of coffee.  I swear it tastes a little salty.  It has a long, charred finish.  This is a pretty serious beer.

1 pt .9 fl oz bottle. Aroma is toasted malt, black coffee. Pours as black as can be with a nice head, beautiful lacework. Tastes like a perfect coffee stout. Nice creamy mouthfeel, medium carbonation. Finishes bitter, leaving my mouth tasting like a used coffee pot. ThatÂ’s a good thing.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2010 Bottle. Black with beautiful chocolate brown head that will not go away. The aroma is truly wonderful - lots of sweet roasted chocolate, strong coffee, rich caramel and oatmeal. Taste is initially sweet though is quickly replaced with a mild bitterness of burnt chocolate. Palate has lots of carbonation (somewhat unexpected) and overall is smooth. What an unbelievable stout!

Pours black with a beautiful beige head which leaves an attractive lacing. Nose is full of strong black coffee,dark chocolat an roasted malts.
On the palate creamy toffee notes and bitter hop, dark dried fruits, some bayleaves liquorice. Finish is dry. Lovely stout.

Aroma of dark roasted wood and coffee.  Appearance is jet black with a dark tan head.  Tastes like bitter chocolate, coffee, and the dust from a chocolate malt grinding session.  Smooth and rich with a very nice mouthfeel.  Certainly well crafted!

Pours espresso black with a thin tan halo of head. 
Nose is heavy on coffee, not too acidic on the nose, fairly roasty. 
Taste is thinner than the beer geek brunch, less chewy, less obvious oat character, slight hop bitterness, slight acidic coffee bitterness, flavors arent as rich as expected, but none over shadow the others. nice coffee, roasted malt, oat, and floral hop flavors all play quite well together.

Bottle. Heavy malt notes of dark bread, dark chocolate and strong coffee, moderate resin for the hops, light leather for the yeast, with background notes of raisin, charcoal, toffee and alcohol. Head is average size, creamy/frothy, light brown with fair lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is black. Flavor starts moderately to heavily sweet and lightly acidic, then finishes lightly sweet and acidic, moderately bitter and a touch salty. Palate is medium to full, creamy with a soft carbonation and a lightly astringent and dry finish. This has to be the fullest and richest Stout IÂ’ve had to date. Excellent in every respect.

50cl Bottle from De Molen. Pitch black, big beige brown head. Great aroma of sweet chocolate, rich coffee and hops. Flavour is light sweet, chocolate, coffee, roasted/burnt malts, light tar notes, firm citrussy hoppy bitter finish. Smooth mouthfeel, medium to fullbodied. Lovely stuff, also for lunch and dinner.

Poured a dark chocolate brown with an initally thick khaki head which settled down to a thin layer of foam. Strong aromas of coffee and licorice. Super creamy and medium bodied. Bitter cocoa and coffee flavors. Somewhat dry finish. Overall a quality stout.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Bottle shared with portableparty tonight.  Dark black pour, little carbonation and a solid bitter coffee and chocolate aroma.  Flavor was also vanilla, coffee and very dry bitter chocolate and some hops on the finish.  Definitely a great beer, but I really liked BGB Weasel much more.

Pours black with chunks and a thick brown head. Intense aroma of coffee, cacao, some dark fruits and roasted malt. Very dark dry rich taste that is slightly creamy and bitter. Long dry bitter finish. A really well made beer.

This was one of the best stouts I have ever had, the toasted malts and coffee, just enough hops to balance it out. jet black with a tan head that stays forever, great bitter taste and just enough sweet aftertaste to keep you coming back.
sweet, smoky, coffee aroma. flavor is complex; roasted malts, oats, coffee light smoke. the overall composition really transcends the individual parts. awesome

Like all the Danish highly rated brews, aroma is very enjoyable but much more subtle when compared to American versions, dark chocolate, roasted malts,fresh coffee bean, flavor is mix of bakers chocolate, coffee ,finishes with a bitterness that seems more malt a nd coffee bean derived then hops,as usual,the texture is as smooth as silk. Always an enjoyable experience, but it has to be the first beer of the day to appreciate all the nuances

Bottle. Thanks to Hogtownharry. Pitch black pour with thin brown head. Rich moka aromas. Thick dark chocolate taste, even the mouthfeel is like dark chocolate a little oily with a nice bitter finale. Very, very well done.

Bomber into a snifter.  Pours solid black with a thick and tight brown head.  The aroma is complex malts with a touch of sour stout.  The flavor is quite complex.  There is a bit of dark fruit and sour cherries that is followed immediately by roasted malts, coffee, and a dash of vanilla.  This has opened my eyes on stouts... This isnÂ’t a stout - this is a light imperial stout!

Obsidian black pour with a flimy tan head.  Aroma is light flakey oat with a dark bitter chocolate roast and some coffee ground.  Dry, Ashy roasty bitterness..Flavor is ashy coffee with dark burnt sugars and a lovely bitter roast.   Enjoyed for breakfast on Thanksgiving day, as it should be.  Simply lovely

@ a tasting, pours black opaque with a huge dark moka color head that leaves a nice lacing, aroma of coffee, chocolate, nuts, cherry liquor, smoke and notes of cream, flavor of chimney smoke, sausage, dark chocolate, coffee and some cherry liquor, long cappuccino & tobacco aftertaste, sticky and full bodied. Great stuff

I do not know where this bottle came from but it was dropped off to me at my store. Pours black with thick, huge dark chocolate head. Aroma of fresh coffee, strong dark roast, chocolate, as well as a dark roast bitter. Flavor is dry, just pure, clean dark roast & coffee, baking chocolate with a sharp dark roast and coffee bitter. Mouth feel is smooth, creamy, has a medium-heavy body with low-medium carbonation. Overall, damned good beer, has some character....

500 ml. Very deep brown color, full brown head. Appealing roasted malt flavor with hints of smoke, oak, vanilla and coffee. Smooth dark chocolate flavor with notes of coffee and hops. Full body, medium carbonation. This is a very nice brew indeed.

Jet black pour, small tan head that laces up nicely on the glass. Aroma holds large amounts of oat, dry roasted malt, chocolate, espresso, caramel, and a light touch of smoke. Flavor is excellent; great way to start the day. Full and rich notes of chocolate, coffee, oat, and roast. Some subtle hop character also comes through, particularly some light citrus from the Cascades. Palate is full bodied, with a nice combination of the sweet chocolate and dry roast creating a complex and enticing mouthfeel. Absolutely top tier stout, worthy of its score; another great brew from Mikkeller.

Drank for breakfast on Thanksgiving morning. Obsidian pour with a one finger brownish tan head. Aroma is flaked oak, dark roast coffee, milk chocolate, dark chocolate, molasses, caramel, and  charred roasted barley. Flavor is a heavenly concoction of roasted espresso,  oat sugar, peat, bitter chocolate, hints of dark fruit, and a beautifully balancing hop bitterness. Palate is rich, thick, full, creamy, and velvety with medium caressing effervescence and a chalky roast oriented finish. A delicious Thanksgiving breakfast...
All one could home for in an oatmeal stout!  Outstanding flavors of coffee, excellent balance of everything else.  Aroma is tame but enjoyable, great beer!

I canÂ’t remember a better looking beer in the glass. Pours very dark brown/black with a with a very thick, fine brown head. Spectacular. The aroma is almost as good with dark chocolate, fresh ground coffee, and ash. Right up my alley. The flavor doesnÂ’t disappoint either, but somehow doesnÂ’t quite match the previous categories. ItÂ’s very roasted and dry with flavors of oats, coffee, dark chocolate, and ash. ThereÂ’s some pretty intense hops in there buried under all the roast. Frothy mouthfeel and an extreme ashy finish. Overall, one of my new favorites.

From the bottle, this poured deep chocolate brown with plenty of sticky brown foam in no hurry to disappear, light lacing. Plenty of oats and chocolate in the aroma, a little dank and just a bit of booze; sharp coffee high notes come out as it warms. ItÂ’s just the best mocha IÂ’ve ever tasted. ItÂ’s got just a bit of hop tanginess in the back, intense dark chocolate bitterness with sweetness that stands up well. ItÂ’s thick, a bit oily as it coats the palate. The carbonation is soft but adequate; well balanced flavor and feel. Proof that God loves me :)

Bottle from Crown#6. Pours midnight black with 1 finger tan head. Nose is sugar cookie, molasses, chocolate malt smoothness. Taste is much more coffee than the nose, with roasted malt and brown sugar. More molasses and some dark fruits come through. Very excellent beer.

At a tasting, many thanks Zvikar, small brownish head, almost completly opaque dark brown, aromas of cocoa, lightly roasted coffee, and hay, flavours of strong roasted, wet dirt and a hint of hay and the oats felt in the back. Understated, balanced and not to bold, extremely enjoyable.

Bottle from Ã–lbutikken.

I have been enjoying my bottle for almost 3 hours now. It is full of aroma and flavours without exesive alcohol.

Pours black/brown. Nose is fresh coffee, smoke, dark chocolate, roasted malts, floral hops. Flavor is fresh coffee bean, cocoa powder, earthy hops, vanilla, roasted grain, harsh bitter malt and some coconut.
Bottle: espresso, black coffee, heavily roasted malt, heering cherry liquer, oatmeal, good cirtusy hoppy bitterness, wet wood, creamy and full mouthfill, great beer, thanks zvika.

Bottle. Pours a deep black color with a lingering medium foamy head. Flavor is gourmet coffee, chocolate and roasted malts, oats. Medium bodied and slightly creamy. Finish is just the right blend of hops.  Well done, this could fit in alongside a nice plate of bacon and eggs. Beer, not just for dinner anymore!

Pours a very dark, opaque chocolate, espresso brown with a very thick tan-colored head. Aroma is very malty and a sugary espresso/chocolate notes with undertones reminiscent of vanilla bean. Flavor is very espresso-like/full city coffee roast. The flavor is so pure nutty coffee. The coffee flavor is so pure and rich that chocolate doesnÂ’t even really mask the flavors. It is a very pure coffee flavor. Body is creamy yet light with a medium amount of carbonation. Fabuloius.

Bottle at Olutravintola Kukko, Kemi, Finland. Very dark brown beer with the most beautiful reddish brown head Iâ€™ve seen. Aroma has roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Flavor has the same with a bittery end. Nicely bodied stout.
Bottle @ the HotD dock sale...  Poured black with a huge, light, brown head.  Roasted nose of sweet malts.  Coffee flavors, charred smoked malts.  Overall low bitterness and alcohol heat.

500ml bottle. Wanted something special for number 500 and boy did I get it. Pours a thick dark tar colour with an amazing choclate head of crisp dense foam. Aromas of chocolate and coffee beans invites you in and teases you. Strong thick flavours of dark chocoalte that hits every part of the mouth and leaves a flavour burst in the mouth.

Opaque, black, with a larger brown head that leaves behind a sticky lacing.  Aroma contains notes of oat, coffee, and chocolate.  Flavor consists of roasted coffee, dark chocolate, with a little bit of bite from the hops and the coffee in the finish.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2011 Deep black with a tan head.  Nose is abundant with coffee and chocolate malt, but has a slight funk that doesnÂ’t quite mesh.  Flavor is coffee overdose, but is not quite as rich as the nose would suggest.    Admittedly, I am picky when it comes to Â’coffeeÂ’ stouts.  Maybe I am being harsh on this as it looks like others enjoy this quite a bit.  I was expecting it to be a bit more rounded and rich in order to balance out the bitter coffee essence.  IÂ’ll have to give it another go in the future.

This very dark beer pours a pitch black with a nice tan head which also leaves behind a nice and sticky lacing. Aroma has roasted malts and coffee. Upon first tasting there is certainly a strong floral hop profile in addition to the chocolate, coffee and the roasted barley. On the aftertaste there is also a lingering taste of dark chocolate which has a slight sweetness to it, though the bitterness overall is more prevalent.  For a standard stout, this is very very delicious and complex. There are plenty of other great coffee tasting stouts out there but this one has more than just coffee going for it. Highly recommended.

The nose was weaker than expected.  Malty, cereal, oats, roasted coffee, dark chocolate, ash.  Much less roasty and much less sweet than expected.  Beautiful jet black beer, tan head.  The flavor is very nice, roasted coffee, dark chocolate, slightly burnt.  The finish has a slight hop bittering, piney, but is bittered from the roasted coffee as well.  Beautiful thick oliy mouthfeel.  Great beer, not as great as I expected.  I thought I was crazy when I first noticed a slight pilsner-like quality on the nose, until I read the label.  The oats come through on this to give a oatmeal aroma and thick mouthfeel.  At $12-14 per bottle, I wonÂ’t indulge in this very often.

I must say, this is a sexxxy looking beer.  I dont usually like black gals, but the darkness of this beer, all the way to the deep dark brown head, made me feel all tingly inside.  Those was full of milk chocolate, salted nuts, coffee, and roasted malt.  Flavors are on the dry side...powdered cocoa, espresso, with american hop bite in the finish.  Finishes without much lingering...so, its not much a lingerer..lingererer.  This is too dry for me...i need sweetness to allow the chocolate malts to linger..this is too quick, too dry, to crisp in the finish for me to get all mushy about it.

Pitch black with a beautiful brown head that settles rather quickly into a thin layer of lacings on top of the liquid.

Plenty of coffee, coffee beans and roasted malts in the nose. Chocolate, faint notes of dark fruits and some alcohol.

The taste is full of wonderful coffee flavors - espresso and freshly ground coffee beans. Big malty backbone with a strong roasted character. Plenty of chocolate, some fruity notes, minimal hint of soy sauce, licorice. The finish is fairy bitter with more notes of coffee, some wood and alcohol. The hops are restrained throughout the experience.

Full body with a very smooth texture. Low levels of carbonation.

This is a great coffee stout with a rich coffee profile. Highly recommended.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)

Black appearance with a thick brown creamy head.  Aroma: Leather, Black berries, coffee, dark chocolat, alcohol, soya and jerky.  Flavor: Black forest cake, minerals, coffee, burnt malt and dark chocolat.  Palate: Full body, soft carbonation, oily with a dry finish.

Pours very dark brown with a large nicely laced brown head that slowly diminished. Aroma of dark chocolate, oats, hints of roasted coffee and low profile hop notes. The flavour is rich dark chocolate, oats, milk and roasted coffee. Medium bodied with a smooth and bitter mouthfeel. Finishes with chocolate malt and a slight dryness that lingers. A great stout thatÂ’s nicely balanced and very easy to drink - a mini me version of the Impy. Very nice. Bottle shared in celebration of my 27th year in existence. 01112009.
Very good breakfast stout.  The Coffee overwhelms other flavors but there are still hints chocolate and smoke.  It is little less thick than other stouts.

Pours black with a thick light brown head that has great retention and very nice looking lace. Take it easy when you pour this one, the head builds fast! Aroma is coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malt, more coffee, and a touch of sweetness from the 7.5% ABV.  Flavor profile consists of coffee, bitter dark chocolate, and light smoke.  Very complex.  Medium-full body with moderate-low carbonation and very low alcohol warmth.  A great beer overall!

500 ml bottle at Pikkulintu. Pours black with a tan head. Coffee, dark chocolate and roasted malt in the aroma. Some smoke in the taste along with the afore-mentioned coffee and chocolate. A burnt finish. Superb beer compared to its price.

25 oz. bottle- pours deep black with a thick tan head, be careful when you pour this, lots of carbonation in this and can cause there to be too much foam. The aroma is great, coffee, alcohol and dark chocolate, the flavor is the same, with coffee being the dominant flavor. I think this is the best beer IÂ’ve ever had, Totally awesome.

Pours pretty dark, near black; medium creamy tan head. Aroma - oatmeal, coffee bean oil, licorice. Flavor - lots of roast, medium bitterness. Very creamy texture, added body / caloric value from the extra alcohol. A super stout. About as strong as a stout could be while still being enjoyable. Very very good, though still beat out by Aphrodisiaque in my book.

50 cL bottle at Stone.  Black pour with 1 finger mahogany head.  Roasty aroma of nuts, coffee, and campfire. Very smooth mouthfeel with burnt tones of coffee, chocolate, and smoke.  Way too drinkable.  I finished 2 bottles back to back.
(bottle). Black color. Large tan head. Strong roasted coffee aroma and flavor. Avg duration. Smooth finish. Slick texture. Soft carbonation. Good lacing.

Bottle bought in Oslo.

Gorgeous black color with a fabulous brown foam.

Coffee and chocolate both in aroma and flavor. A little smoky tones and above all much chocolate in taste. Chocolate Milk! Really good! Surprisingly easy to drink, who knows, maybe it really is a perfect beer for breakfast? The alcohol did not feel at all. Long, long finish! Very pleasant beer.

Bottle, thanks again to my inlaws! Pours a dense viscous near-black with a slow-to-rise brown head of fine bubbles. This looks like an impy! Initially the aroma is very perfumey and floral, but as it warms and settles the roastiness rolls out. Like many coffee beers, this has high vegetal overtones, but the perfuminess never completely leaves, giving this beer a very intriguing aroma. Velvety smooth mouthfeel with lots of coffee roast and a bit of char and chocolate. Very bitter roasty finish. Again, the floral quality adds this really intriguing dimension to a beautifully crafted stout. Outstanding for being more than just a coffee stout!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Pours jet black with a very thick, long lasting dark brown head.  Thick coffee and roast aroma.  Rich malt flavor - bitter coffee finish.  Medium-full mouthfeel with medium carbonation.  Excellent balance between the malt sweetness and the bitterness of the coffee.

First of all this is the nectar of the gods. A black beer with a nice dense bubbly head that leaves a long lasting layer of foam. The aroma is so nice of coffee roastiness. The taste is roasted barley, black coffee, & a bitter burnt taste, with no taste of alcohol. The mouthfeel is so creamy smooth & was also slightly chewy like you could have it for breakfast. People say drinkability but I say enjoyability & this is at the top of the enjoyability chart. In my opinion this is possibly the best beer IÂ’ve had & the closest to a perfect 5.

Pours a dark brownihs black moter oil like with a nice brown head.  aroma is of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, oatmeal, and some hops. flavor is of nutty-roasted malts, coffee, oatmeal, alchool, anbd some bitter hops in the background.  as a nice creamy mouthfeel and a bitter finnish from the hops.  overall. a excellent stout.

Pours a deep dark brown, almost black.
 beautiful tan brown head. roast flavour, coffee, nutty, ver super smooth on the palate. smooth bitterness. unreal beer so bloody nice

From the bottle, courtesy of Secret Santa, pours black like motor oil with a thick brown foamy head.  Coffee beans and roasted malts are the aroma, with a taste of coffee, alcohol, dark roasted beans, and a bitter aftertaste to complement the smoothness during taste.  Thanks Santa!

Exceptional appearance with enormous meringue-like dark brown head, opaque black body, and gobs of lace as the beer goes down.

Nose is roasty with some hop character in the background.

Roasty flavors dominate the palate as well, with hops again making a presence, and there is a coffee character that is hard to miss.

Medium bodied and goes down with a dry roasty aftertaste that is quite good.

500mL and 22oz bottles - LiquorMax.net and GomerÂ’s LeeÂ’s Summit.  this review will be in general about the multiple times drinking it.  aroma is mainly coffee, which subsides over time aging.  carbonation appears to get better with age- smaller, more coca-cola-ish in the early stages.  thicker and longer lasting with age.  flavor is dominated by coffee when young but the oatmeal still comes through.  also a nice nuttiness.  great young, but give this one a year or more and the magic really happens.  the flavors meld, hops balance out, it gets creamier, sweeter (with more chocolate) and smoother.  wonderful.  a solid, solid stout when young, but it really comes into its own with age.

22oz.  Black body topped with a medium-small brown head with creamy sheets of lace, fully lasting.  Aroma of coffee, oats, roasted grains, smoke, bakerÂ’s chocolate.  Mouth is full and creamy with a dry finish.  Flavor is rich, dark, and well-roasted coffee with a backdrop of oats, molasses, "coffee cherry" notes, campfire smoke, chocolate finish.  Excellently crafted, delicious, rich, and wonderful.
IÂ’ve found my holy grail of stouts. This is the one. Has an incredible aroma of chocolate, coffee and malts. Explodes with flavor that has a perfect balance of everything a stout should be.

pours very, very handsom dark brown head, strong and fluffy, gives off strong aroma of coffie with milk, chocolate and grain. Taste - coffie just kicks you into whatever you are sitting on. It has this sweet aftertaste fo chocolate. One dimentional but who cares. It rocks And alc note like someone added some vintage liquor. Just a dessert. A littel heavy, but not too much, neither bitter, not too smoked, not too sweet, not too strong
Brown, beige lasting head. Pleasant coffee aroma. More coffee in the flavour. Licorice? Acidious? Lingering on to a roasted, dry bitter finish. Overwelming/powerfull stout.

A nose of tobacco, coffee and vanilla. Taste contains the same flavors plus an earthy note. Finish is roasted and has a little acidity. Palate is pleasantly oily, but a bit thin. This is a good stout, but its hardly worth the high rating. Maybe the effect of peoples affection towards its bigger brother and Mikkeller in general?

Aroma of coffe, tobaco and sweet toffe. Apperance is dark black with medium brown head. Flavor is bitter with clear taste of well rosted coffe. Palate is very oily and nice, maybe a bit thin. Overall a very good coffe stout.
Poured very thick, dark black with a brown head, very rich roasty coffee and chocolate taste with a slight bitter finish, my first stout and the best one so far.

This is a really nice imperial stout, but, once again, IÂ’m apparently a complete wimp when it comes to coffee stouts. The drinkability score is purely a reflection of my bodyÂ’s annoying tendency to react strongly to the blending of alcohol and caffeine. At any rate, this beer pours dark and thick with a lasting mocha head. The aroma is a bit ashy and oddly mild compared to the flavor. The flavor is rich and full with big roasted malt, chocolate and coffee notes. ThereÂ’s also a clear hop bitterness in the finish. The coffee flavor is not artificial like some coffee stouts but dark, complex and rich. The feel is smooth despite the bitter rich flavors. I just wish that my body didnÂ’t freak out so much when I drink coffee stouts. ItÂ’s very odd because IÂ’m a regular coffee drinker and a regular beer drinker, but alas, here we are.

Bottle. Been wanting to try this for a while. Pours jet black, even held up to the light, with a big brown head that lasts for quite a while and leaves a lot of lacing. On the nose coffee and dark chocolate really stand out, but the notes of vanilla, roasted malt and cocoa are also very prominent, in addition to a little woodiness. In terms of flavour, the aroma says a lot of it, but the roasted grains are more at the forefront and there is an even stronger cocoa, or maybe mocha, presence. Smooth, creamy and very full bodied, this is a stout worth seeking out. The hype was just about spot on!

Birthday beer purchased at the Davis Food Co-Op.  This aroma has a nice amount of burnt roastiness with some coffee hints, but not overly coffee-like.  There is an underlying sweet chocolate aroma present, which is nice.  Subtle hints of anise are also present.  Has a nice opaque dark brown/black body with a large, brown frothy head that leaves some really nice lacing.  Very attractive.  Roasty chocolate flavors dominate early, before it has a bit of an astringent acidity in the middle.  Finishes with the coffee flavors, which is nice.  A pretty flavorful brew, but the strange astringency in the middle hurts this beerÂ’s score.

Been looking forward to this one for awhile.  I always seem to be let down when I really look forward to something.  

Pours a deep black with a nice head.  It looks sexy, maybe the hype is rightÂ…  So it begins.  The aroma was disappointing to say the least.  It was overpowered by a metallic hop.  Not at all what I was expecting from a big coffee stout.  You had to really get in there to get the coffee and chocolate.  Taste was WAY better than the smell.  There is  toasted oats, coffee, bitter dark chocolate, and hints of white chocolate.  Seems more like a chocolate stout than a coffee, until the finish.  There is a good bitter coffee finish.  Rounds out a rather complex beer.  Over all still a bit disappointing, but only because of the hype.  It is better than good, but not fantastic.

Wow, oh my goodness. Best breakfast I have ever had. This is something else. Very rich smell and tastes similar to Kona coffee. I am a stout guy and a coffee guy. This stuff takes the cake! I only wish I would have bought more. At least I can get it one mile away. =)

Rich aroma is like a fine roast coffee with a firm chocolate undertone and a hint of yeast. It pours a deep, opaque sable with a very thick cinnamon tan head that sticks around for a while. Flavor is more like fine mocha coffee than beer, but has hints of malt and yeast and a nutty touch so you know it is indeed brew. Flavor is oily smooth yet edgy, quite tingly and fizzy, leaving a smoky coffee finish that has an undertone of unsweetened chocolate.

Pours deep dark black with a hint of brown around the rim, huge fluffy tan coloured head. Nose has a heap of dark roasted malt, but not appearing astringent as some coffee beers do. The malt is perfectly rounded, some sweetness, some honeycomb, a touch of smoke & of course the coffee. Palate has surprisingly lively carbonation, not over the top but a touch more than i expected. Much like the nose, the malt is so well rounded. Has a bit of everything with the coffee standing out, but not overpowering. Finishes with rich coffee notes, but in no way astringent. Lively carbonation dries it up a touch as well. Hops are there, but play second fiddle to  the well controlled coffee notes. Awesome beer! Clearly alot of thought has gone into the malt selection and it has paid off, cant wait to try the weasel!!

I have been wanting to try this beer since I first spotted it on the shelf and I finally plunked down the $14 to try a bomber. The pour is a not surprising inky-black with a dark brown head that reminds me of BellÂ’s Expedition it is so dark. The smell is heavy roasted coffee with oats lurking at the edges. The smell is really good if you like coffee. The taste seems to be more oat than coffee with some bitterness like dark chocolate at the end and then the coffee coming back to slap you in the face! The mouthfeel is neither too thin nor too syrupy, just right and the alcohol is well masked by the flavors of the beer. In my opinion this beats FounderÂ’s Breakfast Stout by a hair or two. This was worth the price of admission but only for one viewing. If you are a coffee-beer fan then you should probably seek this one out.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-28-2007 14:58:29
Aroma is of dark chocolates and coffee.  Flavor is a bit more coffee with chocolate and more subtle sugars followed by a bourbon finish.  Nice beer

16.9 ounce bottle in Sam Adams glass.  Black with thick dense light brown head and lace.  Bready chocolate and roasted coffee aroma.  Mildly smokey chocolate and subtle roasted coffee with some dark fruit and just the right touch of green hop flavor in the clean medium bitter finish.  Awesome thick rich creamy mouthfeel. Incredible richness and balance.  One of the best beers. A true work of art.

Delicious. Served cold from bottle. Jet black. Reddish head. Aroma of coffee. Flavor is coffee and cream, very smooth and quite drinkable. Just a really good stout, easy to consume and tasty. Highly recommended.

Beautiful pour: black with a thick, airy, slowly fading reddish mocha head. Aroma of coffee, plum, licorice, and some dark chocolate. Slightly acetic character in the nose.  Feels wonderfully smooth as I sip. Flavor has loads of coffee with notes of malt, licorice, and bourbon. Nice and velvety. ThereÂ’s a slightly hoppy finish with some milk chocolate syrup and tons of roasted malt goodness. I said Â“MmmmmmmÂ” after the first sip, and I stand by that.
Very good. Black. super drinkable and satisfying.   Smooth and creamy. Dangerous as you could start at breakfast and just keep going, if you can afford it.

22-AUG-2009, Bottle @Henriks.
Dark brown, high brown head.
Chocolate, coffee, all sorts of roasted aromas.
Very creamy, nice carbonation, quite bitter from the hops, but not too much. Actually nothing is too much, and all is there. Alcohol is almost undetectable, everything is in perfect balance, Wow this is truly a great beer.
Have tried it several times, but still not in the morning. Maybe that should be next goal?

Mondial 2009, Montreal.  Black, with a thick brown head, with a large amount of sediment.  Lots of espresso and dark chocolate in both the aroma and flavour.  Not too sweet.  A bitter, roasty finish.  Alcohol is completely hidden.  Very full, smooth and creamy  body.  A well constructed beer.

ust perfect in the appearance department. Incredibly thick and sticky head that changes color as it gets closer to the liquid. The liquid is used motor oil black and seems to pour pretty thick. This is the nicest looking pour IÂ’ve seen without a nitro widget.

Smells of oatmeal mash, meaning I have a thick mouthfeel to look foward to, but I digress. Coffee, roasted malts, light chocolate. Very good.

Taste is also the winner, exactly what I expected for a coffee oatmeal impy. With that said, IÂ’m guessing this one falls a little below the radar because similar drinks can be had a bit cheaper.

Mouth is thick, but not quite as thick as I had expected, and the drink is medium in carbonation.

With some other Coffee Oatmeal Imperials around here in easy supply, I donÂ’t think that IÂ’d go out of my way to trade for this one, but it is a damn good drink.

Complex nose with good stuff and bad stuff. The bad: feet and bandaids. The good: dark chocolate, must, mud, and sweet cream. At any rate, it is very distinctive. Black pour with a thick firm brown head, some lacing. Dry flavor of coffee, old wood, cream of tartar, and bark. Grass and parsley finish. Lives up to the hype. I like it with chocolate truffles or doughnuts, preferably boston creme.

Colore nero, Schiuma abbondante,marrone e cremosa. Aroma di malto tostato, sentori fruttati ecaffÃ¨. Buona struttura di malto, non troppo spesso, con una buona combinazione di malto tostato, liquirizia e caffÃ¨,tutti gli elementi conferiscono un grande equilibrio. Forte il finale, lungo, con malto tostato e un pÃ² di liquirizia.

Appearance: Pours a midnight brown with a sturdy ring of khaki colored foam on top. The beer almost looks creamy or frothy. Aroma: A nice, freshly prepared cup of coffee. Taste: Acidic, medium roasted coffee and roasty malts. Some chocolate sweetness goes in between the coffee bitterness. Mouthfeel: A silky smooth texture. Overall: The best coffee stout I have had to date. Really impressive, and gets better once it hits room temperature.

Pours black, gigantic  brown head, excellent lace. Nose of coffee, molasses, citrus/hop?. Taste is initially sour, turns sweet, then hits with a strong coffee flavor, finishes hoppy with slight bitterness. I also get some soy sauce stuck on my tongue after a sip, very complex stuff going on in this beer. Absolutely a treat, the balance is incredible with this many flavors going on.

0.5 l bottle from Alko. Pitch black with thick tan head. The aromas of coffee, salty licorice,  citrusy-mentholy hops and warming alcohol. Thick strongly coffeish bittersweet flavor with salty licorice and piney hops.  Initially thick, sweet and creamy palate which soon turns into dry, burnt, slightly astringent charcoal finish.  Very uncompromising with strong coffeish and hoppy flavor and burnt finish.  Slightly too overpowering for me but still pleasant to drink. If this wasnÂ’t first beer of the day, I might have given more points.
Has a great aroma of chocolate and roasted barley.  Taste is of coffee and more roasted barley.  Not as much coffee and oatmeal as I might have expected, more like a really strong stout.

Deep, lush brown in color with a lasting head and a beautiful look in the glass.  Aromas of chocolate nibs, chocolate cake, dry roast coffee.  Rich malty flavors of peat, coffee, oats, and an espresso finish.  The emphasis on malts is so well-balanced it nearly overshadows the hops in the beer.  The slight pine complements the long finish of the beer and it really all comes together at the end.

Bitter black coffee with a little hazelnut. The Oatmeal really smooths it out and lets it slide silkity in your mouth. Fantastic beear, made better as it warms. Really dark body with a really dark head, large bubbles. RockinÂ’ good stuff, kid. Bottle from Knightly Spiritss in Orlando.

Appearance:  Pours a midnight brown with a sturdy ring of khaki colored foam on top. The beer almost looks creamy or frothy.

Aroma:  A nice, freshly prepared cup of coffee.

Taste:  Acidic, medium roasted coffee and roasty malts.  Some chocolate sweetness goes in between the coffee bitterness.

Mouthfeel: A silky smooth texture.

Overall:  The best coffee stout I have had to date.  Really impressive, and gets better once it hits room temperature.

The Norwegians have perfected the stout, and this is further proof.  The appearance is a very dark, oil black color totally opaque, with a well developed fully frothy brownish tan fluffy chocolate milk head that slowly subsides, into a thin 1/4 inch tan slice of foam, like all good head it comes to and, no pun intended, but with this head your close to spent by then.  Flavors range from a black coffee, hazlenut coffee, to tobacco, ultra dark roasty oak.  What it has in flavor it lacks in aroma, there remains a very earthy quality, with a somewhat present dark roasty barley malt alcohol aroma, as it warms to a more appropriate temperature the tobacco notes really become enhanced.  For such a flavorful beer the finish is utterly smooth, almost no char left in the palate, just a slight tinge of roasty bitter, as the beer warms to ideal temperature itÂ’s tannins take on a more pronounced bitter flavor and finish.  As a side note, this beer is an excellent partner to a black and mild, or other chocolate dominant cigar.  Of course the better the cigar, the more intoxicating the experience.

500mL bottle: appearance is pitch black with brown head, aroma is of roasted malt chocolate and hints of coffee, flavor  has lots of chocolate and roasted malt but isnÂ’t the top notch stout I was looking for. Want the best get speedway this just doesnÂ’t cut it for me.
Pours like two stroke oil, coating the glass, clinging to it.  DidnÂ’t have much of a head.  Chocolate and smoke nose.  Palate was a roasted bonanza.  Outstanding and worth seeking out.

Bottle. Black, massive medium brown head, chunky sticky lacing. Aroma is complex, loads of coffee, herbal hops, dark fruits, chocolate, roasted notes, hints of smoke and nuts. Flavour is full, loads of coffee, some nuts, roasted, almost burnt malts, some ashiness, and a solid bitter espresso and citric hop finish. Body is nice and full, smooth carb. Good brew.

Opaque black pour with immense and substantial cocoa head. Gold brown edge highlights. Very present aromas of fig, cola, coffee and alcohol. Taste rich roasty malts and alefruit, very nice roasty/red-winey coffee showing some cocoa and nutty overtones. Great bitter citric hops and coffee finish, displays a little alcohol. Go, Mikkel. The palate and cocoa notes improve with some gentle cooling.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2011 1)Bottle from Briskeby Vinmonopolet, Oslo. Inky pitch with a well behaved, filthy yellow collar going the distance. Nose marmite on charred wholemeal ,coffee grounds, grapefruit juice and husky malt. Slick and creamy, no prickling b/c fizz and acidity like the last beer (Dark Force), fine savoury espresso and cocoa ashiness; Twiglets, bitter nutty malt, grapefruit hop and charred barley linger. Good but not great, and a bit one dimensional. 747415= 3.7. 
2) Pint at The Penguin, batch 471. Black like oil with a solid, grey-tan bloom of head settling down like Guinness. Aroma of blackcurrant, plastic, cinder toffee and high cocoa dark chocolate. Fat and viscous with a Lindt 80%, burnt toast, burnt pistachio, grapefruit and ashtray Friij milkshake mouthfeel approaching perfection.The hop and carbon bitterness is immense, but streaked with blackberry, apple and blackcurrant like a true stout. Just hugely drinkable and terrifyingly easy to drink by the pint- again, like a true stout. Some alcohol numbness on the lips, but none elsewhere. Not really getting any gourmet coffee, but then I wouldnÂ’t know what it tastes like. Bags of ash and very dark chocolate. Incinerated nut husk, blackcurant and dark chocolate ice cream, dead leaf burps. Deeply impressive- upgraded to 848416.

12/25/2008:  I drank this bottle of Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast for BREAKFAST on Christmas day...  Aroma:  Coffee and cream, roasted malts, semi-sweet and dark chocolates.  Appearance:  Extremely dark brown and opaque with a sparkly, frothy brown-coloed head.  Flavor:  Smooth roasted coffee liquour, light cream; roasted espresso finish with accompanying bitterness; milky, lactose-like and oatmeal aftertaste.  Palate:  Medium-ful, smooth.  Overall:  Good, but not worth the $11.99+tax/bottle!
1 pt. 6.3 fl. oz. bottle (7.5% Alc./Vol.) from Dilly Deli in Mariemont, Ohio.  Rating #936 for this beer.

Deep dark black/red.  Nose; perfectly roasted coffee beans, toasted oats, chocolate, burnt wood, very strong, i wish they made cologne like this!  Taste was similar to the nose, oh so malty!,  nice balance, id rather drink this in the morning instead of coffee, wish i could afford it.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2014 smells of roasted malts and a touch of coffee and cocoa, with a nice hop presence usually reserved for imperial stouts.  looks/pours like an imperial too!  taste is pretty intense, more coffee, smooth oat flavor and a touch of bittering hops in the dry finish.  smooth body too from the loads of oats.  great beer, if a bit pricey.  For me Espresso Yeti is king of the voffee stouts, but this is quite good.
Bottle pours black with a nice beige head. Aroma is coffee, sweet and roasty malt, and chocolate. Flavor is coffee, a bit of smoke, roast malt, and a good bit of bitterness. Smooth and easy to drink.

Bottle from Parti-Pak Liquors (Indianapolis, IN). Pours a dark brown to black with massive tan head that settles slowly. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of chocolate, smoke, wood, brown sugar, molasses, caramel. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of roasted malt, chocolate, brown sugar, molasses, coffee. Silky smooth mouthfeel with a roasted malt finish.
