Black beer with a coffee coloured head.  The aroma is malty and the flavour is dark, malty, vinous and not that dry.  Overall a reasonable dark beer that is quite malty.

Poured a really dark black with a pretty tan head...really perfect looking. Great aroma that smells like my garage after I have been roasting coffee. Lots of coffee up front, really nice but finishes a bit astringent and bitter. I would have liked a bit more sweet cream flavor with the oats, but still a nice beer.

22.3 oz bottle - Rating #1000!  IÂ’ve been digging the stouts lately, so it seemed fitting to grab such a well regarded stout for the thousandth rating.  It pours black with a big dark tan head.  The aroma is of dark roast malt and plenty of coffee.  The roast malt and coffee are well balanced in the flavor.  Let it warm for awhile and enjoy the full bodied darkly roasted experience.  ItÂ’s also got moderately strong hops that are even more apparent in the finish.  This is not a sweet stout.  I wouldnÂ’t call it a terribly complex beer, but it sets out to be a coffee stout and it does that extremely well.  Delicious!  Now to celebrate with a bottle of Westvleteren 12!
Brown pour with tan head.   Huge coffee aroma with chocolate sidenotes. Flavor was very espresso like with some solid chocolate, minor hops and of course malt thrown into the mix.    very solid beer.

Courtesy dsnowden. Black, black/brown edges. 3cm of chocolate milk shake head. Looks great. Flavor and aroma of roasty and grainy malt, roasted coffee, bittersweet dark chocolate, milk chocolate, and subtle resinous hops. Medium/full body, balanced carbonation. Rich yet easy to drink. Really would be an excellent breakfast beer. Top notch stout.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2008 Black body with an initially medium tan head.  Aroma is very roasted, fresh citrusy hops and pastry dough.  Main flavours are the usual three amigos: roastiness, chocolate and coffee beans.  The chocolate flavour is not like black bitter chocolate, it is more like rich chocolate cake with a sweet chocolate cream.  The high roastiness level (may be a bit too roasted) detracts the attention away from the rich and smooth chocolate.  The roasted coffee beans flavour are there but not as upfront as with many breakfast stouts.  A very pleasant astringency lighten up the experience.  This generously hopped beer develops some kind of green apples flavour/astringency in the finish that makes a bottle go down even more quickly.  Full but silk body with soft carbonation.  Certainly one my favourite Â“littleÂ” stouts ever (8% and less).  Feels like a 5%.  And yes, IÂ’ve been a beer geek on at least one occasion.

Bottle from Brawleys. I had to buy this in another state Â’cause all the dudes in this GA hoarded all of it.  Nice stout.  IÂ’m getting ready for the time of year when these go perfectly.  Smooth and slightly sweet.  All the elements play well here.  Oat malt gives some body.  Coffee aromas and slight bitter coffee flavor.  Some bittersweet chocolate notes in there too.  Creamy texture.  Big brown head.

Bottle, from SamÂ’s Blue Light. 9/3/07. Real good aroma, sweet & roasty, Oat, coffee, milk, cocoa, banana. Blackish brown color, good cocoa beige head that slowly faded to a small cover. Bittersweet flavor, Coffee, baking chocolate, little dairy, little viney. Thick body, creamy mouthfeel, dry finish with a bitter streak. Very good stout. Enjoyed every drop,  Flavor was great the whole way through. Body might of thinned a bit as it warmed.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: A very dark beer that has a great aroma with a bit of mocha and oatmeal. Very smooth going down. velvety finish. good to the palate

Nearly black color with thin ring of chocolate colored foam that coats the glass. Fresh roasted coffee aroma with faint hints of cocoa powder and dark fruits. Roasted barley and coffee flavors hit the tongue followed by subtle notes of chocolate covered cherries. A slight smokiness is apparent before a dry bitter roasty finish. A well crafted stout for sure, but not one of the worldÂ’s best IMHO.

Bottle:  Pours a intense black color with a small tan head.  Very little lacing.  Nose is rich with coffee, roast, mocha, and hints of oats.  The taste is a creamy blend of roast, coffee, chocolate, and light bitters.  The coffee compliments the brew well rather than overpowering it.

Bottle placed into my brand new, shiny beer graile.  IÂ’m pretty excited about it and decided to break it in in style.  Pour is really thick and blackish brown with a short-lived brown head that, with time dies down to a thin film on the surface with a few bubbles rising above the etched area on the bottom.  Aromas are strongly charcoal-ish with lots of peat and espresso.  Maybe there is a bit of an anise seed tilt to it, too.  Mouthfeel is silky and exquisit.  The smokey charcoal flavor leads the charge, but is quickly supported by some espresso, dark chocolate and peat... and I think that IÂ’m picking up some of that anise in the background.  Very smooth and I could probably drink several bombers of it before I realized what a bad idea that was.  For a plain Jane stout, this is fantastic... I must say that, while at first I was a little disappointed (expecting some sort of trumpet blast or other sort of epiphany/divine experience and not finding it) this really grew on me as I worked my way through the bottle... take your time, enjoy it and let it air and warm.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 22oz bottle from FlorianÂ’s. Pitch-black completely opaque body with a good inch of light brown head. The first completely opaque beer IÂ’ve ever had. Smells like burnt malt and good coffee. Tastes like burnt and roasted malts, as well as oatmeal with a generous dose of coffee as well. No real hop or alcohol presence here. This stout is thick - you could cut this with a knife and fork. Probably the thickest feeling carbonated beer IÂ’ve ever encountered. Definitely a sipper due to the big taste and mouthfeel, but one sip definitely invites another like few beers do. I am unbelievably impressed with this beer. I cannot say enough good things about it; it exemplifies everything I love about stouts - and about beer in general.  A new favorite!  I could drink this morning, noon, and night.  IÂ’ll be buying many several more in the coming weeks!

Black beer with a dark brown head. Coffee, roast,chocolate aroma with the coffee getting stronger. Coffee flavor with a bit of chocolate and late astringency. LIngering coffee, licorice. Fuller bodied. Nice complexity. Too much coffee for my tastes, but still a very good beer

On bottle. The appearence is a very dark color and af large thick and creamy head. Light bitter taste and a full body, very creamy texture. A good taste of chocolate and coffee. The finish is a delicate mild taste of the chocolatemalt.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2008 Bottle: Pours a beautiful opaque black with an extremely dark brown, thick, head with good retention. Has an enormously rich aroma. Deeply kilned malts, rich chocolates, espresso/mocha, freshly ground coffee beans, licorice, tobacco and even more. Very creamy, velvety mouth feel with nice, subtle, mild carbonation. Tons is anise and licorice with everything else you could want in a Stout. Espresso, tiramisu, licorice, dark chocolate truffle, a boozy quality, burnt flavors and so much else. The finish has a ton of dryness to balance out the ridiculous body. An exceptional Stout that should be classified as an Imperial.

Pour: Deep oily black. Head: thin, fizzy/creamy, dark brown. Aroma: coffee, roasty, malt, soy sauce, alcohol, burnt malt. Flavor: coffee, roasty, bitter, soy sauce, alcohol, malty, burnt. Palate: thick bodied, lively. Finish: warm, roaty, coffee.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2007 Holy crap. The color is black, oily. Darker than any "stout" IÂ’ve ever seen. Thick creamy brown head. The aroma was sweet, dark sugar, molasses, rich roased chocolate, coffee, an earthy burnt wood, and alcohol. The flavor was rich rich rich, coffee, burnt wood, bakers chocolate, alcohol, warming impyish quality, very malty, waxy hoppy aftertaste. The palate is complex, it has a warming quality from the alcohol and yet the brew has a smooth cool feel in your mouth. One of the most complex and satisfying beers IÂ’ve ever had.

Bomber. Pours black black with a rocky head thatÂ’s very brown... dark all around. The aroma reminds me of oatmeal, with a strong cappuccino character and little whiffs of vanilla and licorice. The flavor is smooth coffee almost immediately. There is also some sweet chocolate and noticeable oats. The middle has some vanilla and nut tones, but still a bunch of coffee and oats. The coffee isnÂ’t overwhelming, but it does stick around. Licorice emerges in the finish after a while, and even a little bit of hoppiness. Great stuff. I want another.

22 oz. bottle - To say this beer is midnight black would be like calling a Model T white.  This beer is DARK even for a stout.  There is a tremendous cocoa colored head that lasts forever.  Flavor- If you pay attention, you can actually discern the coffee from the oatmeal flavors.  This beer is is loaded with flavors.  Very good.

22 oz Bomber-Poured jet black w/a slight tan head. WOW, thats all I can say about this one. Intense coffee aroma & flavor, like drinking an espresso w/a kick. Has some traces of chocolate & roasted almonds as well, but the coffee is prodominant. Rich mouthfeel w/a finish of roasted malt which does balance it out well. Long full finish, great after dinner beer, very enjoyable.

Bottle via The_Epeeist, thanks Chris!   Pours oily black color with a dense tan colored head.   Aroma is coffee, chocolate, roast, toffee.   Flavor is again roast, chocolate, nice blast of coffee but definitely kept in check.   Palate is full bodied, medium to mildly carbonated, finishes dry and bitter.   This is one bad ass brew.   The coffee is not overpowering, just adds to the depth of the beer.

Tried at Lost Abbey Brunch with awaisanen and cquiroga. Tan thick head with microbubbles.  Pitch black color.  Great appearance.  Nicer end of roasty, chocolatey taste, with no sourness (that I donÂ’t like in roasty beers).  Medium body, which was thinner than I was expecting.  Leans a bit toward dry.  Pretty drinkable and best with a meal.

8/11/07. Bomber 2007 vintage. Deep dark brown. A black strap molasses aroma with some coffee. Very pleasant smooth mouthfeel. Nice bitterness balanced by the oatmeal sweetness. The coffee is not overwhelming at first but intrudes on the flavor as the beer warms and becomes too prominant.

Oily black with potent brown head.  Deep chocolate aromas as well as coffee, vanilla, burnt nuts and pine.  This is a very robust brew, smoked, woody flavors persist and provide an oaty quality and good body for the beer.  For some reason I figured this brew would be more complex, but it does have some intriguing layered flavors and aromas and a simple, but powerful and fulfilling structure.  While I didnÂ’t have this one for breakfast, it does seem like a good idea.

Pours black as night with no light escaping from it.The head was khaki that dissapated quickly that laced up on the sides of the glass nice.A sweet coffee aroma.Coffee and oatmeal with a backside of sweetness to it.The finish was sticking to the back of my throat.
UPDATED: OCT 4, 2007 66 cl bottle. Black. Lovely brown head. Coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, hops. Dry finish. A wonderful beer.

Wow, an instant fave. Espresso like appearance with a nice tan head. Oatmeal, malt, baking chocolate and of course coffee in the flavour, all balanced to perfection. Great mouthfeel, well, good all round actually. Extremely easy to drink and very moreish. I could literaly drink this for breakfast, prolly plenty of vitamins and iron in there anyway, lol.

Bottle from Bierkoning. Syrupy dark, black really, liquid. Heavy toasty dark aroma. Really nice coffee and chocolate flavours. I feel bad for drinking this in the evening, tastes like it would be especially delicious in the morning. Creamy and luscious. Thank you.

Bottle purchased at Ocean Wine and Spirits. Pours a near perfect looking jet black with a huge dense brown head. Fantastic aroma of espresso, coffee grinds, chocolate, tobacco and oats. Flavor, although by far fantastic, doensÂ’t seem to have all the levels that the aroma did. Full creamy mouthfeel with light carbonation. This is one great beer.
This is surely a bomb in your mouth. Although it is named a breakfast beer I wonÂ’t recommend that. It is an explosion of taste and you wonÂ’t be able to taste anything else for the rest of the day!

UPDATED: APR 11, 2009 Gorgeous brew--black and perfect body. Excellent flavor profile that is exceptional, and near-perfect in its simplicity. No spikes, no wackiness. Just a pure, simple array of malt and hop in perfect balance. Great touch of pleasant asphalt in aroma. The coffee is so subtle as to be undetectable, and does not interfere with the well-crafted and finely honed recipe. Tastes better with every sip leaving me with the frustrating feeling that I canÂ’t have more. Nice burnt finish. Really a great beer.

Very thick, oily, dark-brown beer.  ThereÂ’s only a few tan bubbles around the sides of the glass.  Nice espresso-filled aroma. Hearty, rich with roasted malts and vanilla.  IÂ’m impressed with the creaminess of the beer overall. It does seem to be a great breakfast beer. Nice, lactose-sweetness. Pretty darn good.

Okay, so IÂ’m a bit late to the party with this one - thatÂ’s cool - at least I finally showed up - now where the bitches at? - this beer pours a thick, inky black, with a rather small ring of brown foam - decent, but fairly stereotypical aroma for a coffee stout (a nice balance of sweet cream, strong espresso and some burnt character) - nothing stand out enough to make me able to pick this one out of a line-up, but enticing none-the-less - medium-bodied brew, with limited carbonation enhancing a creamy mouthfeel - the flavor is much thinner than I expected - the beer tries to strike a balance between some oat/sweet stout character and a strong espresso bitterness, but the biterness winds up winning out, bringing with it some leathery and tobacco notes - luckly for the beer, I tend to like these things - the beer thins out a bit near the end, allowing some alcohol to become apparent - a good coffee stout, but not quite in the same league as Peche Mortel or Founders Breakfast.

Pours a one finger brown head that fades slowly leaving some lace.  Totally black color.  Light carbonation and heavy bodied.  Coffee/molasses nose.  Flavor is a balance of coffee and molasses, hints of sweetness. Smooth. Bakers chocolate aftertaste. Great to try but pricey at $14.00 for a 22.3oz?? (659ml) bottle from TullyÂ’s Beer and Wine Wells, ME.

(660 ml bottle from <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/maine/boothbay/ target=blank>1828 Vintage House) Lots of coffee...Looks thick and black coming out of bottle. Sits very dark brown with some brown highlights along edges. Four fingers of stout, creamy tan head. Aroma is of fresh coffee and bittersweet chocolate. Mouthfeel smooth and full, although not silky. Lightly oily. Pretty nice sturdy lacing. Flavor is pretty much coffee, plain and simple. Strong but not overboard. More sweet than bitter. Hints of grassiness here and there. Liked that this is only mildly bitter. High bitterness would probably be too much with the strong coffee. Good beer but was hoping for something really exceptional.

Coffee, tan-head, purple darkness, Coffee chocolate roasted &  burnt. "CHARLIE MURPHY! WhatÂ’s happening, partner! DARKNESS, Everyone, DARKNESS! Hey everybody, darkness is spreading! ...You DARKNESS, you BLACK - late night - EVIL MOTHAFUCKAS - BLACK MAGIC, DARKNESS! YOU RAW... DARKNESS... YOU... DELIRIOUS... MOTHAFUCKAS."
A powerful stout, with big flavors of creamy chocolate, grains, and maybe some subtle vinous tones? Not as good as the Founders Breakfast Stout, but in the same league.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2012 
Date: February 15, 2006
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting
Appearance: black, thin brown head
Aroma: sweet milk aroma with lots of roasted malt
Body: creamy body
Flavor: lots of roasted flavor, slightly sweet, coffee comes through strong in the end

Date: July 15, 2006
Source: tasting
picking up coffee in the aroma, 

Date: December 01, 2006
Mode: draft
Source: tasting
more chocolate in the aroma and flavor, drier, long bitter finsh from the roasted malts and coffee, 

Date: August 07, 2007
Mode: bottle
Source: roadtrip
Appearance: black, creamy brown head, drippy lace
Aroma: strong dark chocolate aroma with lots of roasted coffee that gets a bit ashy
Body: big creamy oatmeal body
Flavor: rich chocolate and coffee flavor, the richness of the chocolate balances the roasted coffee, constraned bitter finish considering all of the roasted

Date: January 15, 2012
Mode: draft
Source: the porter
Appearance: black, fine tan head, drippy lace
Aroma: coffee and dark chocolate aroma, warmth brings sweetness that pulls out a sweeter milk chocolate
Flavor: rich roasted and dark chocolate flavor, lots of roasted coffee, bitter from the roasted malt and beans, bitterness is abusive but in a good way that you become to love, bitterness gives way to a touch of sweetness as it warms allowing a milky chocolate character to emerge

Date: February 22, 2012
Mode: bottle
Source: cellar stock
Vintage: 2009
high carbonation, rich chocolate coffee, has mellowed out a lot, 

Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 9/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 4.1/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *** /4
Dark black with a small dark brown head. Also has thick brown lacing.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Flavor is smokey, with roasted malts, coffee and chocolate

Bomber from Uber.

IÂ’ve wanted to try this one for a long time. Pours a deep inky black with a relatively short-lived crema head that leaves behind intense lacing. The aroma is intense: roasty chocolate malts laced with blackberry juice and coffee icing. Heavy oat-stout flavors lead off the flavor profile, tasty but not too sweet, a slight lacto-sourness, hints of berry leading to a wonderful roundness of both flavor and palate through the middle before yielding to what one expects to be a imperial-stout hop close but instead offers a balanced bitterness driven entirely by the coffee, leaving one with the feeling that one has just down an espresso (from a roast that is dark but not at all burnt)  and is savoring the oils that linger on the tongue; baking chocolate and again hints of oat peek through in places and add interest to the finish.

The mouthfeel is excellent throughout. As smooth as can be, creamy but not heavy or oily, absolutely no alcohol presence on the tongue (though there is a hint in the aroma). Beautiful. 

Overall an excellent beer.

Bought this bottle from State Line a few weeks ago and opening it today in honor of Michael JacksonÂ’s passing.  Sticky-sweet coffee stout aroma with a huge, room-filling level of roast.  Chocolate and cocoa.  Soul-sucking, black hole black pour, as opaquely black as imaginable with a dark brown, fluffy head that richly reaches its way up the sides of the glass and offers a truly beautiful meniscus.  Taste of darkly roasted gourmet coffee with occasional flashes of chocolate and cocoa powder; very dry (water-sucking, quickly dehydrating) with a nearly unbelievably true-to-life espresso aftertaste - should I have served this in a tiny cup and consumed it with raised pinky?  Slightly burned with a touch of lactose, though I may be mistaking the latter for the oats.  Bitterness here is understated and tactful, with very faint hop prickling toward the back.  Great balance!  As for feel, one of the few beers to truly earn the term "velvety", as this is luscious and swirling smoothness in fullish-medium form.  ItÂ’s not reaching to say the oatmeal adds a lot here - in both sultry smoothness and the occasional oaten note.  Alcohol here is so well integrated as to not be noticed, and therein lies the paradox; this big boy features all the robustness and flavor of a well-made imperial stout but without the potentially catastrophic hangover effects.  Classy yet decadent - it just blows the competition away!
A well- balanced stout.  The coffee is not too overpowering. The chocolate aspect of the flavor (chocolate malt?) compliments the coffee.  This would be great with a rich and decadent chocolate cake!
22 oz- Pours like motor oil. Nice long lasting,lacing tan head. Scents of chocolate malts and coffee with tastes of the same. Very smooth with tastes that linger. Good choice Jimmack.

Post-Mondial Tasting.

Roast coffee aroma,  black with a small toffee head. Big taste of coffee, some cocoa notes. Medium bodied,bitter. Really fine.

Pours a dark, almost black brown. When served in a pint glass, it gave me a 2cm head which qiuckly dissipated. The aroma is of coffe laced with a bit of alcohol. 
The flavor is chocolaty with a lot of coffee notes. a bit of hops. low carbonation. 
A very good stout although not my favorite style (stouts)

22 oz bottle.  Pours an extremely dark and opaque black-brown with a dark brown head that quickly recedes to a thin film that laces the glass some.

The aroma is chocolate malts, oatmeal, lactose, dark fruits and vinous alcohol.

The flavor is chocolate with some slightly tart and sour fruits (seem a little out of place) leading to a roasted grainy and acidic coffee and tar finish that is quite bitter.  The mouthfeel is medium to full bodied, a little low on carbonation, but extremely velvety - one of the first things I noticed as I sipped it.

Overall, a fun well-made beer.  IÂ’d prefer less hops and more coffee though (never thought IÂ’d say that!).  I really want to love this, but it is just shy of an awesome beer...still very good though (albeit expensive).

Pours a dark dark brown to black with a decent light brown to tan head, diminishing.  The nose is basic coffee stout.  ThereÂ’s a full bodiedness to this beer that goes beyond weak as shit coffee stout, but this lacks the umph of a coffee imperial stout.  Rond sweetness, but still that acrid coffee sweetness like in SchlaflyÂ’s Coffee Stout is still there.  Otherwise, the profile has more in common with FounderÂ’s Breakfast Stout.    Thick on the palate without too much carbonation and decent viscosity.  The nose predicts the flavors well.  Too much of that coffee flavor that disagrees with me.  The oats give a soft sweetness, that I think should be slightly amped up.  Not that this is too harsh with sweetness.  The coffee roast comes on strong in a surprisingly dry clean finish.  Not bad, but slightly below my high expectations.
Huge espresso and dark chocolate nose and taste. Very velvety smooth on the palate. Has bold and intense flavors and aroma. I need to try one with pancakes in the morning (followed by a nap).
Roasty smoky thick aroma. This is a beautiful looking beer. Very smooth, and doesnÂ’t seem strong at all. A great grainy finish with lots of oatmeal.

650 ml bottle mail order from liquidsolutions.  Black with a fizzy brown head.  Strong chocolate, cherry, and coffee aroma.  Bright velvetty palate.  Bitter dark chocolate, espresso, and smokey taste with some citrus notes to the finish.  Very good.

Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast
22 oz bomber
Moderate pour in a snifter.
Unknown brewing, snacked on 08/07

Poured black with a large frothy mostly lasting dark mocha head.

Smelt of strong premium roast coffee, rich burnt malt, dark chocolate.  

Taste was upfront strong sweet dark chocolate malt, and strong bitter coffee and burnt malt followed by more of the same, with a stronger coffee aroma and  a slight dry yeastiness on a long lingering coffee finish.

Palate was medium to full bodied, rich and creamy, lively carbonated and strongly astringent.

Overall, this beer is great aromatherapy, and the flavors are pure bliss.  It seemed a bit heavy to drink on a hot August night, though. Heavy coffee stouts being my favorite style, its hard for me not to like it, but without being biased I still think this is a very well done brew.

Pours dark tar like black beauty.  Nose an astonishing mix of grainy hops and chocolate malt.  How did they do that?  Tight bubbles, that dissipate pretty quickly.  Lovely palate rolling around the tongue.  Lingering finish.  Nice work.

22 oz. bottle.  First off, these guys have some fantastic graphic designers doing their labels.  As for the beer, it begins with a pitch-black pour with a thick and creamy chestnut brown head on top.  Aroma of dark chocolate, rich and roasty coffee beans, creamy vanilla and some resiny hops.  Goes down velvety smooth with a full body.  Starts with light caramel and dark chocolate and finishes bitter and dry with some roasty/toasty coffee and graininess.  A little smoke and wood in there at the end too.  Impressive.

Bottle, GBBF 07.  Black with a beige foam.  Aromas are earthy rich coffee and dark chocolate malts.  Malty and fairly sweet.  Some smokiness.  Flavours are rich weetabix and chocolate malts with strong coffee.  Dry and bitter on the finish.  A powerful beer.

Sampled at a STL gathering.  Pours close to black with a dark tan head.  The aroma is creamy with milk, dark bitter chocolate, coffee and roasted malt.  Medium body that is a bit thinner than expected with minor sharp carbonation.  The flavor starts with lots of coffee, dark chocolate and charred malt.  The finish is highly bitter with coffee, char, cocoa, char and wood.  A very good beer, but doesnÂ’t seem to blow me away like it does a lot of others.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2011 Bottles (says 6/07) from eaglefan538 & pantanap; Nose of chocolate, roasty coffee, and light vanilla and caramel; Opaque black with a thick, glass-lacing cinnamon-tan head; flavor of bitter chocolate,oatmeal, with some peppery spiciness thrown in; thick, juicy body with a finish of mild hop bitterness. 8/15/07 9/5/9/5/18 4.6 Bottle shared by Enniskillen Brewed 9/13/10. Nose is roasty, smoky coffee, with a background hint of chocolate. Black with a big cinnamon tan head that laces lightly. Flavor is smoky with coffee but the smoke dominates. 8/5/8/4/16 4.1 8/10/11

Supposedly an Oatmeal Stout (according to the label), yet ridiculously bitter. The roast coffee flavour would be overwhelming, if not for the overhopping. I hate wasting beer so I drank it all, but I was very tempted to pour it away. Really, really unpleasant. Why do so many love it?

22 oz bottle from MrBendo and Beertopia in Omaha.  Pour looks like motor oil - all black with a nice dark khaki head and a touch of layering.  Aroma is initially roasted espresso then gives way to roasted barley and a nice amount of hops.  Taste is big on the coffee, though it is nicely blended into a nice full bodied stout.  Good hop bitterness at the end.  This was really well made, yet something just didnÂ’t entirely do it for me.  Maybe I just donÂ’t like coffee stouts as much as others?

Pours a deep blackwith a brown head. Aroma and taste expand as this one warms up. Chocolate, coffee, and slight carmel. Mouthfeel is a little light, but good. Taste of coffee, oats, slight smoke and vanila. Finish is bitter sweet, almostlike dark chocolate with bitter coffee.Very good.

22oz bottle Â– and an expensive one at that.  To keep the tradition I decided to drink this for breakfast.  Pours very dark black with a bubbly, foamy, dark brown head that sticks around for awhile.  Nice, thick lace left down the entire glass.  Aroma is surprisingly mild but very appetizing.  Chocolate and coffee predominate.  Nice roastiness.  This is a really, really nice aroma, I just wish it were a little bit stronger.  Thankfully as this warms up it improves.  Around room temperature this baby smells real nice.  Taste is rich, chewy, semi-bitter coffee with a long chocolate aftertaste.  Nice, smooth flavor.  The body is a bit thin for my liking, however, and it is the biggest flaw of this beer.  Overall this is a very nice stout; certainly one of the best IÂ’ve had.  The price is not justified in my opinion.  Still, IÂ’m happy I got to try this.

22oz bottle shared, Pitch black motor oil pour which i love, goes nicely into a big brown chocolate milk head, taste is very sweet and leaves sugary sensation on my lips, each sip makes me want more, this is like a smoother FBS. and quite good indeed.

Bottle purchased at Liquor Max in Loveland.  Pours opaque with a small, dark brown, creamy head, somewhat diminishing, fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (coffee, chocolate, toasted grain), heavy hops (perfume, grass), average yeast (leather) with notes of light alcohol, raisins, smoke and vanilla.  Full bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation and a bitter finish.  Long duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and bitterness; dark roasted coffee, dark and slightly bitter chocolate, wood and smoke flavors.

This fine Stout pours a glossy near-black color with a thick and rocky light brown head that has good retention. Nice big patches of lacing on the glass. Big roasty aroma of coffee, oats, and chocolate malt. Rich, smooth body with a character somewhere between an Oatmeal Stout and an Imperial Stout. Flavors of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and hops are all present. All in all the beer manages the smooth texture and flavor of an Oatmeal Stout while toying with the robust body of an Imperial. The finish is moderately bitter coffee and hops balanced but malt and chocolate. Overall this is an excellent Stout.

The flavors of an imperial stout, but the alcohol and dryness of a stout. Black body with big-bubbled, tan head. Rich aroma of roasted malts, coffee and dark chocolate. The flavor is lightly sweet and moderately bitter. Very dry finish along with a coffee bitterness. Medium body and slightly watery texture. Velvety mouthfeel. Excellent.

The best no impy stout i have ever drank.  Pours out like burnt motor oil with a nice brown head.  aroma has alot of coffee and malt to it.  Flavor is very much the same.  Very thick.  Oh i would love to drink this bad boy for breakfast.

Actually tastes like crappy acidic coffee.  Some creamy oatmeal smoothness in there, but otherwise itÂ’s harsh and bitter.  I donÂ’t mind the bitterness, but the acidity is too much.  Somewhat watery as well.  Smooth palate disappears quite fast and gets thin.  Vanilla flavor is there as well.  Flavorful, but just doesnÂ’t blow me away at all.

Thanks to my Secret Santa, July 2007: Pours oil can black with a healthy mocha head that slowly fades.  The aroma is deep and rich - lots of dark chocolate, cocoa, vanilla bean, mocha, roasted malt and earth.  The oats create a full and chewy mouthfeel, the perfect vehicle for the rich body.  The body is loaded with bitter chocolate, caramel and espresso.  A slight atringency from the coffee is the only real flaw I can see.  Good, good stuff.

I actually saved it to have it with breakfast. Jet black in the glass with a nice tan head. Roasted aroma with some sweetness involved. Tasted just about how it reads on the bottle. Very smooth. Finish leaves only a hint of malt with coffee. Went great with eggs and sausage. $18.50 for the bottle here in Philly.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2008 Poured deathly, oily black with deep tan head.  The aroma on this was a complete shock.  Roasted malt and chocolate aroma obviously, but a distinct pine hop aroma that compliments the other aromas and adds a complexity.  The aroma really makes the mouth water.  Flavor was what you might expect, chocolate, cherries, malt, expresso, nuts.  Finish is really smooth, extremely drinkable, with only a lasting coffee bitterness and a little chalky in the mouth.  Some of the recent ratings suggest that maybe this beer is slipping in the top 50, or that maybe they overpaid for this bomber, I canÂ’t say either.  This beer was worth every penny I paid and lived up to all of my expectations.  This is a stout loverÂ’s stout.  I highly recommend.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2008 Sampled in a blind tasting among Mikkeller Beer Geek Breakfast, Alaskan Stout, DickÂ’s Lava Rock Porter, and Coors Light.  hah, well this was the clear winner of the night, right behind Coors Light. This was the darkest of the ales with a distinct ebony color and a dark tan head. The lacing is clingy and viscous. Man, this stuff smells great. This is easily the most robust of the four, packed full of rich chocolate, a notably fresh Latin American coffee scent, oatmeal, toasted almonds, and grill smoke. This has a dense mouthfeel with distinct, defined toasted oats, ash, rich milk chocolate, fresh java, and a delightfully tastefully syrupy finish. This is not very aggressive, just rich, balanced, bold, robust, and savory. I love it.


[June 22, 2008]

Bottle. Pours black with some faint reds somewhere in the body and an everlasting very dark tan head. The aroma sports tons of well defined dark roasted coffee, but thatÂ’s not all. Excellent tones of dark chocolate, ash, oatmeal, and milky sweetness are found. This is hearty and enjoyable. Though it is over-the-top in the coffee department, that flavor is well rounded with an almost sweet, roasty character. Not one dimensional by any means, Beer Geek Breakfast wows my palate with hints of toffee, chocolate, oatmeal, and a powdered milk finish.

Pours a thick, black, and soupy  w/ a full, semi creamy froth. Superb hangtime reducing to a satin canopy  w/ full sticky lacing.  Aromas of sweet roasted coffee bean and dense chocolate malts. Full nectar w/ creamy residual effers. Nice! A big roast component is balanced by a mild sweetness then promptly bittered. Strongly flavored w/  bitter cocoa, roasted coffee bean, leather, and molases. Other nuances of dried rose petal, cherry skins, herbs. The cocoa is so strong it just coats the palate w/ a thick blanket. Then Robo  Hop comes  round with itÂ’s machine guns blazing reducing the cocoa to a mere afterthought. Robo Hop leaves an asprin aftermath to cleans the palate like they used fire back in the dark ages for purification. The finish is long and bittered perfectly for a good balance. A very rich brew, more like a meal. It deserves all the attention coming itÂ’s way. Highly recommended.

I was really excited to find this and more surprised that it was only $16.  Probably shouldnÂ’t have cosumed it under the conditions that i did but you only live once.  poured into a blue solo cup and maybe 60 degrees.  super thick pour with a dark brown head.  big coffee and chocolate aroma.  flavor was uber sweet and rich.  kind of syrupy and stingy.  honestly, a little bit let down.  and iÂ’m surprised itÂ’s only 7.5%.  not worth $16.

poured into a tulip.  well this was exciting, what a good drink.  pours a black glug with mild caramel head.  aroma of malts and mild coffee.  creamy palate, such and inviting creamy consistency lending itself to the casual coffee presence and milky finish.  milky subtle smoothness to the coffee, very good.  mild carbonation on the front, coffee offers a balance that makes the finish complete...

very thick syrupy black pour with a medium sized very dark brown head.  sweet milk chocolate, coffee aroma.  flavors of dark chocolate, milk chocolate, coffee, little hints of hops and maple syrup.  full bodied of course.  perfect amount of carbonation.  awesome.  send more mikkellerÂ’s to atlanta!

The next one of these I have will certainly be for breakfast.  Sexy cold coffee  nose and chocolate ganache.  Tan foam hints at a creamy and rich mouthfeel.  This beer manages a very sexy performance and has one of the coolest textures IÂ’ve ever experienced from a stout.  Reminds me a lot of FounderÂ’s.  Beyond reproach, the only gripe is the price.  CanÂ’t wait for my next day off.

Wow, what a nice dark chocolate head to accompany a stout. The head is very thick and creamy looking. The beer is BLACK in color, and looks very thick when you pour it. Great chocolate and coffee aroma. Smells great because you can really smell the roasted coffee beans. One of the creamiest beers I have ever tried. This beer is just so smooth. The flavors are chocolate and coffee. this beer has a great sweet taste in the before taste. There is a sweet flavor in this beer, but I wouldnÂ’t call it an oatmeal sweet flavor. The oatmeal part of the name I believe infers a sweet flavor more than it does say that hey this beer will taste like oatmeal. A nice finishing spice and bitterness. A well crafted beer.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2007 bottle- jet black, tannish head that disapates, but never quite disappears. Always acts as a coating over the beer. Moutfeel is very creamy, typical of oatmeal stouts. espresso flavor, roasted malt. sweet astringent flavor in the finish along with some bittering hops. Breakfast? maybe, but I would prefer this in the evening.

Black as night, dense dark tan head with good retention, espresso nose. Espresso, bittersweet chocolate, slight boozy notes, mild bitterness, coffee finish. Sensational silky mouthfeel. Excellent for morning, noon or night.

This pours out like dark brown motor oil and has a hefty chocolate colored head.  The aroma is heavy on the coffee side with detctable amounts of roasted oats and a little bit of cocoa.  Pretty smooth drinking, the flavor being a skillful blending that closely reflects the nose.  A very mild nutty bitterness is also introduced.  All in all, this makes for a very fine breakfast.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Lakeview Liquors, Chicago, IL<font size=-1>

Bottle from DocLock in the mystery swap.  Thanks Jeff!  Pours a dark brown bordering on black with a nice, sudsy, light brown head. Aroma is predominantly coffee, with a little bit of oat and cocoa hinted upon. Flavor is similar to nose, but the coffee is much less pronounced than I expected.  Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy, but the bold coffee and/or chocolate flavors seem to have faded.  I have been told this is much better with a year or two of age and I plan on testing that theory.

pours black with moderate brown that retains pretty well.  aroma is strong coffee with some cocoa and nice smooth oatmeal.  the bouquet of ester.  taste is a nice coffee with fairly oat and chocolate follow-through (also bring some sour cherry in there).  finish is surprisingly astringent with some hop bitterness consider how smooth the nose, taste and mouthfeel is.   good but not quite deserving the rating.

This beer is stupid black with a perfectly formed tan head. Plenty of lacing. The aroma is a blast of coffee. The taste is tons more coffee. This is a huge coffee flavored beer. Still, being a 7.5% stout instead of a 10% impy stout makes this sucker plenty easy to drink. Killer stuff.

bottle aquired via trade with AllAboutStout...pours black with small, ochre head..aroma of roasted coffee, dark, bitter chocolate, and a massive molasses backbone..this gives rise to a heavily roasted body of bitter chocolate, coffee, nuts, and a touch of lactose...hugely bitter, becoming sweeter as the beer warms to room temp...perfect, creamy mouthfeel...wow, this stuff was good!!!!

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2007 Pours like motor oil.  How is this only 7.5 percent?  A nice caramel head slowly dissipates into the beer.  The aroma is not huge, but a very respectable coffee mellifluence.  The taste is at first one dimensional, but as the beer warms up the layers unfold and leave a profoundly thick and oily beer with varying levels of coffee and hop bitterness and a roundness that is only equaled in the worldÂ’s best beers.  This is one awesome beer.  Finally, as the beer is completely drunk the hop bitterness and slight citrus linger on the palate and mix with the residual coffee sourness for ages- and it makes me wish I had another one of these beers to drink.  Outstanding beer, but a little thin in the finish.

22 oz bottle from west lakeview.  Pitch black with small brown head.  Aroma is big coffee, chocolate and alc.  Flavor of coffee, dark chocolate, alc, burnt roasted malt, and dough.  Creamy, full body.  Overall a very tasty brew and an excelent example of a coffee stout but in my opinion not top fifty material.

So I actually drank this for breakfast on the weekend.  Large dark an head with a very dark brown body.  Beautiful beer.  Nose of nutty malt, coffee, coffee, coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, smoke and a hint of dark fruit.  Flavors of dark roasted coffee, sweet chocolate, oats, and hints of smoke and dark fruit.  Mouthfeel is smooth with a medium body.  Damn good beer, but way to expensive.

Bottle shared with Ross and Daniel. Thanks guys. This thing looked amazing in the glass, big, dark, down and dirty black color with a deep brown head. Smell is all coffee and sweet chocolate and in a nice one to sniff. Taste is very smooth. The smoothness of the palate was the first thing I noticed then coffee and sweet chocolate come next. I was expecting this to be more "roasted" in taste but it was not so. I suppose this is why this smooth drinkinÂ’ stout can be consumed for breakfast. Man, this stuff was good.

Bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Charcoal black body, medium to thick ochre head. Deep, complex aroma of coffee, rich roasted malts, chocolate, molasses, smoke, and hints of dried dark fruit. Vinous. The flavor wasnÂ’t quite as impressive, but was excellent nonetheless, with plenty of bitter coffee beans backed by slightly sweet burnt brown sugars, licorice, and roasted malts. Bitter, somewhat astringent finish. The touch of fruity sweetness beneath the bitter roast and coffee is a big plus. Very good beer.

Bottle from Brandon.  Thanks.  Pours out a dark brown color with a thick tan head on it.  Smell is full of coffee and oatmeal, some chocolate, but not as bold as Olfabrikken (sp?) porter.  Rich and some nice roasted malt smells.  Taste is smooth and rich, bold, and very much like a pot full of black coffee.  It is not as pronounced as founders breakfast stout is, but damn, this is a very good beer.  I hope to see alot more of their beers hit the states.

Bottle. Black color with a small beige head. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Full roasted body with notes of roasted malt and coffee. Light chocolate sweetness on the palate, light dry. Really nice.
Looks like espresso and smells like a good cappuccino. Perfectly balanced and rich.
lang holdbar eftersmag - mildt af kaffe. mÃ¸rkebrun farve med holdbar skum.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2008 22oz bottle. pours pitch black with creamy dark-tan head. nose has lots of coffee and dark chocolate, very roasty, and oats. flavor seems lacking, some coffee roast and chocolate but not robust enough. i keep wanting this to be an imperial stout even though itÂ’s still 7.5%abv itÂ’s not big enough. itÂ’s drinkable, light, and just a flavorful coffee stout. the body seems oddly thin and palate short, a stale coffee note in the finish. i wouldnÂ’t mind drinking a few pints of this at the pub but I donÂ’t find it something special or top 50 worthy. i can see why this has been slipping in the top 50. the beer does look beautiful, could use some piney hops for a touch of bitterness. the head has a great wealth of dark shades and beige, gray, tan, and chocolate shades. really cool looking. now iÂ’m glad chicago is gettting mikkeller now but about $13 bomber for a coffee stout is outragous.3.7. 

7/15/08, 22oz bottle. aged 1 year. thanks to holdenn for sharing! what a beautiful looking stout, i mean the head is so creamy and dark it is crazy looking. very ten fidy esque. aroma is loaded with coffee and roast. flavor is less coffee notes but strong roast and chocolate. if this was canned and in a 6 pack i would drink it all the time. great brew. I think this time I wasnâ€™t concerned with the hype as I was in the first rate (grant it that was when this was first released in the US) so I was able to really appreciate this beer for what it is, a great coffee stout. 4.0.

Bottle. A dense espresso head over a near black, opaque body. Sweet licorice and dark coffee in the aroma. Scents of earthy hops. Very flavor-full; Roasted/burnt malts, dark coffe and dark chocolate, with a hoppy bite and an underlying gentle sweetness. Full body. Soft and smooth in the mouth. Lingering bitter and coffee-ish end. Very nice.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2008 visually this the most stuning beer iÂ’ve ever seen.  Thick and dark this lovely beer yieldÂ’ed around 3 fingers of thick frothy head that slowly gave way to about one finger. Excellent lacing!  Nice oatmeal stout with a nice blast of expresso and chocolate.  Cant wait to drink this again, maybe at brunch!!!

Dark, almost black pour with a big, but fading tan head.  Aroma is chocolately and sweet with lots of coffee, cream, sweet/roasty malts.  Taste is a wonderful helping of good coffees, chocolate, and tasty malts.  A bit of cream and various sweet flavors detectable.  Tasty stuff.
Opaque, with a mocha head.  Heavy coffee, chocolate fudge, espresso, caramel, espresso, and butterscotch.  Taste is coffee, milk chocolate, very roasty.  Nice mouthfeel.

Deep black pour with a thin tan head. Nice coffee aroma. Nice flavor, with strong coffee notes and a hint of roasted malt. Alcohol is masked. Personally, I like the Nogne Imperial Stout better, but this is still pretty good. I can tell why they call this "Beer Geek Breakfast." Glad to have tried it.
Reminds me of Deschuttes Abyss. Pleasing sourness followed by a sweet, smooth and lush coffee and licorice malt. An American stout made in Denmark.

Pours a black color with a dark brown head.  Nice balanced aroma with the coffee not being too over powering with roasted malts, chocolate, sweet malts, and just a hint of hoppiness.  Flavor starts off with plenty of coffee, roasted malts, and chocolate.  Sweet malts and oat dominate the middle flavor and finishes with a decent bitterness from the hops.  A pretty delicious stout.

22 oz. brown bomber bottle. No freshness date seen. Poured out a deep chocolate brown color, with a volumous mocha colored head. Aromas are of chocolate, coffee, burnt sugars. Medium body, thick & chewy mouthfeel. Flavors are of coffee beans, roasted malts, slight notes of vanilla also. Finished dry & somewhat chalky.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2011 Beuatiful pour!  Black color with a fairly full, dark tan, firm, and creamy head;  head is somewhat lasting leaving nice, tight lace.  Nose is somewhat simple but perfectly balanced between dark chocolate notes, nicely roasted coffee beans, and a cedar hop bitterness.  Other hints of smoke and burnt caramel.  Flavors are similar; nice roasted bitterness of a fine coffee, balancing moderately bitter cedar hops, with only hints of dark chocolate and burnt caramels.  Palate is nice; velvety smooth, soft, medium full, and flows off the tongue with a silky , dry touch.  Finishes somewhat quickly leaving silky with a touch of dryness, coffee bitterness, and woody cedar notes that linger.  Lacks the complexities of an imp but probably the most drinkable dark beer IÂ’v ever had.  ItÂ’s too bad I couldnÂ’t drink this everyday for breakfast!  A very balanced beer with excellent roasted coffee notes and bitter cedar hop notes.  Finally available here in CO and it was worth the wait.
Choclate hop aroma, pitch black in colour with thick toffee coloured head. Big hop flavour, hint of chochlate and coffee.

Bomber thanks to xnoxhatex.  Pours dark brown with a thin filmy head.  Coffee yep thatÂ’s coffee in the nose.  A little chocolate and earthniess.  Burnt coffee charred flavors.  Lightly creamy and bitter roast.  Finishes with dry coffee beans.  Its good.  Basically a creamy cup of cold coffee.

22.3 oz bottle.  Enjoyed for breakfast while watching the climb of the Galibier.  Dark chocolate brown yields a small head but leaves a pretty crema ring and a thin haze.  Looks rich, smells rich.  Dates, coffee, concord grapes and mild woodiness.  Milky body with coffee and dark fruits.  Melts away with a bit of citric carb fizz and ends with dry bitter greens.  Elegance becomes aggressive.  Crazy good.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2007 Purchased a bomber during my visit to Oliver Twist - June Â’07.  What a beer!  Amplified coffee aroma on the nose of this pitch black beer with beige-brown edges/head.  Flavor was dominated by dark chocolate, oatmeal, and COFFEE.  And even though IÂ’m not the biggest fan of intense coffee, it seemed to work perfectly here.  Super easy to drink - and the mouthfeel was very smooth. - I mean smooth smooth.  Finish is moderately sweet with a touch of bitterness and roasted malts, lingering with hops, chocolate, and coffee.  This thing is straight up delicious.  MMMMMMMMMM, breakfast!

The bomber bottle filled a big glass with a thick, black, opaque liquid topped with a creamy brown head and there was still half of it left in the bomber. It was strong flavored, strong malt, strong coffee with a feather light hop hit. My mouth was coated and my eyes closed in ecstasy as I swallowed. It was very smooth, the head held high and the lacing coated the glass.  A lip smacking delight.

Bomber, with yet another HUGE THANKS to the man - john_adam2002!  Pours a syrupy dark black, super dark brown head that dissipates down to a whispy covering, good lacing.  Aroma is dominated by coffee/espresso as youÂ’d expect, but also plenty of diversity behind that - milk chocolate, vanilla, oats, molasses and a hint of dark fruits.  Taste does the same; a big hit of coffee/espresso up front, but some hoppiness in the back.  What seems a bit separate and distinct blends nicely as it warms.  Palate is creamy and slick, average carbonation, with a medium mouthfeel and long but dry finish with some bittersweetness.  This one lives to the hype quite well!

Thanks to Zathrus13 for doing the case split. Pours out black with a moderate foamy off-white head. Aroma is of coffee, roasted malt and slight hop. Creamy mouthfeel, slightly thinner than IÂ’d expect, but nothing to negatively impact the beer. Very complex flavor, chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, slight dark fruit with a dry finish. Very solid beer.
Black and strong. Lots of flavour especially, coffee and chocolate and a worderful burned finish. It has a moderate hoppy balance. I would characterise this beer to have a medium to full body,

From a bottle, thanks iowaherkeye. The body was very black with a light brown colored head. The aroma was soybeans with some milk chocolate. There was also coffee and sweet vanilla. The taste was quality coffee with some dark chocolate. There were also some prunes. This was relatively subtle for an Imperial stout. While well made, nothing about it stood out to me.

Bomber. Beautiful appearance. Beer is opaque very dark brown/black with a largish, light brown, creamy/frothy head. Diminishes slowly and mostly lasts. Affectionate lace curtain draping.

First impression clangs with pine, creamy malts and strong acidic coffee. Malty with heavy notes of roasted grain, creamy oatmeal, dark chocolate milk, coffee, light note of vaguely fruity molasses; Hoppy with heavy notes of herbal resin; Yeasty with a moderate note of damp. crawly basement; Moderate note of dark French Roasted coffee.

The flavor is moderately sweet, moderately/heavily bitter, lightly acidic with a long, moderately sweet, lightly acidic, light/moderately bitter finish. Generic coffee in the retronasal return.

The body is full, the texture is watery/velvety and the carbonation is soft/lively. Swank on the palate.

IÂ’ve been looking forward to this meeting, and I want to be blown away, but, honestly, IÂ’m not. For me, itÂ’s terroir-driven subtleties that make a great coffee-infused stout. Here, those subtleties feel masked by high-alpha hop and over-generous roast. Nothing wrong here at all, in fact there are few quite good things happening. But a phenomenon? Eh...

Big brown choco colored head, retention is good with a bit of stringy lace hanging around. Black like only black can be, very dark. Large roasty nose, chocolatey, berryish and of course the coffee aromas. Body is almost big, nicely creamy, a touch chalky with a good astringency. Almost dry, roasty malt flavors, cocoa, bittersweet chocolates, coffee grains are laid back. There,s some hops going on just not sure what, piney almost. Large and lucious roast and coffee flavors, chocolate, all well put together.  My wife stops in as i,m rating this and trys it and says WOW , it,s like an iced coffe flavor, hmmm, OK i ,ll go with that though i,ve never had an iced coffe. Damn what am i missing?? Damn near dry, roasty, fruity finish. Pretty well luxurious i,d say. Big props to jasonmech77 for this bomber, thanks bro! Props to the boys at Mikkeller also, well done!!

Bottle courtesy of bu11zeye.  Black as a cup of coffee and tastes like pure. roasted, almost burnt coffee.  Overpowering.  Too much so IMHO.  I like my stouts w/ more subtle flavors.  This is definitely not subtle.

SOLID beer for sure. Poured a black some light on the edges, solid lacing throughout.  Aroma was of perfectly roasted coffee, some vanilla.  Flavor was a blend of coffee and oats some vanilla Mouthfeel, wow perfectly smooth silky.

Pours dark brown with a tan head that initially starts off brown.  Smells of roasted malt, coffee, bitter chcocolate, hints of anise and dark pepper.  Taste is very roasty and unbalanced.  The hints suggested by the nose are overpowered by the intense burnt coffee flavor.  Not my thing.

A syrupy black pour, producing a sludge of rich brown foam.  Nose of charred, sweet venison, cured salami, and milk chocolate.  A whiff of cedar and pine on the back end.  This sprucy bitterness leads the flavor.  Lemon tartness, a hint of port barrel and a dryness that almost reaches latex levels make for an intriguing, elegant series of accents on this syrupy mocha canvas.  Finshes with a long, slow pulse of tangy brisket, then giving way to dry earth.  Full and rich, but lively.  Definitely a very adult stout.  Thanks Phil!

Pours a deep motor oil black with a medium deep  creamy brownish tan head that laced. Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, nuts, vanilla, cream, oatmeal and just a nice coffee based complex malty aroma.  Flavor of rich coffee, roasted malts, some nuts, creamy with hints of vanilla.

22oz bottle.  Aroma:  Rich roasted malt with a strong oatmeal note.  Coffee comes through strong, but doesnÂ’t dominate.  Chocolate, light smoke, and a subtle spiciness.  Alcohol is noticeable, but not hot or unpleasant.  Appearance:  Black in color and opaque.  Dark tan head was huge and creamy with great retention.  Fantastic lacing.  Flavor:  Lots of roasted malt.  Coffee flavor is intense.  Notes of smoke, cocoa, oatmeal.  Strong roasted malt bitterness followed by a very dry finish.  Palate:  Full bodied and creamy.  Moderate carbonation.  Light alcohol warmth in back of mouth.  Overall:  I though Speedway Stout had alot of coffee!  This is one great beer.

Deep multilayered with blackened tones. Laced out immensely and the head was a jumping off-white. Big chocolaty oatmeal coffee mix in the nose, taste, and finish. A very complex and interesting beer. Somewhat viscous and not as cloying as I thought it would be.  Very well balances. and scrumptious.  Quite pricey, but unquestionably worth a taste!

I canÂ’t imagine a stout being more complex than this.  Pours a deep, dark black from the 22 oz. bomber.  The dark tan head cascades beautifully down the sides of the English Pint.  The lacing is a half inch higher than the head.   The smell is chocolate, oatmeal, caramel and roasted nuts.  What a beautiful complex beer, the mouthfeel is perfectly thick and coating.  Excellent stout.

rich aroma of bitter chocolate and coffee there is even a bit of must in there. Very creamy and thick In the mouth. Not much initially but there is a a big blast of flavor soon after the first sip. There is a lot of bitter coffee and some chocolate. Some bittering hops in there as well. Lots of stuff going on in here making for an overall tasty beer.

Bottle from Belmont Station.  Pours oily black, no opacity, and a really tall dark brown head.  Aroma is roasted malt, sweet coffee, but a little weak.  Initial flavor is great, lots of roasted coffee, bitter chocolate, but a very dry bitter taste toward the end.  Very drinkable though, and strong for a non-impy.

(bottle from jb175,thanks man!)pours a thick black body with a nice full and creamy chocolaty head.as the thick head sits it leaves thick sticky looking webbing on the glass.the aroma is a little light but it blends up oatmeal,coffee,chocolate,and roasted malts.the flavor is damn never perfect.i pick up roasted coffee beans,oatmeal,chocolate,smoke,chocolate malts,and the only thing i didnt like about the brew,a small sour lactose finish.other than that this beer is simply divine!

Pours a very dark brown with a small head.  Smell is roasted coffee, and then some more coffee.  Taste is definitely all coffee.  ThereÂ’s some roasted bitterness that comes through as well.  The mouthfeel is a bit thin.  After itÂ’s sat for awhile, the chocolate tends to come out a little more, and it tends to get a little more creamy.  An easy drinker that IÂ’m glad that I found.

Pours black, chocolate brown colored slow developing head, nice lacing. The aroma was roasted dry coffee, not much else, quite simple. No fruits, no dried fruits. Flavor was bitter coffee, oatmeal very noticeable, smoothing out the body, silky and grainy, and adding a fullness that was just enjoyable. The flavor was like a coffee-ed version of St. Ambroise Stout, really enjoyable, far from a sweet coffee stout, wonderful.

#250 for me. Bottle: This one pours like motor oil, with a dark brown head. Smell is of coffee and roasted malt. Taste is definitely roasty and has a nice coffee taste. Maybe I like my coffee a little more bitter, but I did not feel this would go down as well as I hoped with breakfast. That being said, this a fantastic beer to sit around and warm up with. SMooth and creamy.

Bottle: Pours black with a huge head, giant creamy brown head threatens to foam out over the glass, less bubbly than creamy. Aroma is of toasty carmel and coffee notes. Flavor is slightly sweet and malty and very warm and toasty oat and coffee. The coffee is subtly used like in Speedway stout. Not as roasty and burnt as i would have expected. Balanced roastyness with nice creaminess, goes down easy.

22 oz bottle from trade with Boutip.  Thanks Phil! Pours a thick pitch black color with a big dark brown head. Aroma of coffee, milk chocolate and roasted malt. The beer is incredably balanced and complex with all of the different flavors.  The taste is intially sweet and smooth and then finishes dry with a lasting hop bitterness.

Wow! Bottle from Goldtwins, danish release, best by (I think -- "Tappet den Holdbar til") 9/2007. This is fantastic. I didnÂ’t realize this was a normal stout -- not imperial -- going into it, but this is the antithesis of American brewing -- which I also didnÂ’t expect. Super-dry and extremely elegant, coffee flavors are perfectly meshed with an utterly unbitter roast and creamy tapioca. Brash and boastful, a buttery thick brown head sits upon a black body, bursting with the burliest coffee aroma. Blah blah blah, the BÂ’s are getting out of hand. This beer kicks ass.

First thing thank you Ron for somehow obtaining this beer that just hit the U.S. less than a month ago. I brushed my teeth and took a shower before opening this to be in perfect form to indulge on what I expect to be one of the best beers IÂ’ve had yet. Complete black pour like a black hole suckin the lifeforce out of anything in itÂ’s path, big finger thick dark brown head that fades to a small brown head and stays. Aroma of coffee, chocolate, mollassess, and oats when swirled. Now to finally taste..... A shot of espresso to the face, itÂ’s so freakin roasty itÂ’s like it was brewed 30 seconds ago. The espresso is there and it dominates but not to the point of being harsh or bitter itÂ’s very smooth. More roasted coffee, it takes coffee to a whole nother level, you get a shot of espresso, freshly brewed coffee, it taste like coffee beans were in the secondary, it just has coffee in every way imaginable. Very smooth and creamy with a higher level of carbonation that tingles my tongue with coffee goodness, medium mouthfeel and very cloying leaving me licking my entire mouth. I canÂ’t stop sipping this beer. The other flavors are really being pushed aside by the coffee which is a little dissapointing but then again they made this to be a coffee beer for breakfast, chocolate sits in the background and the oats leave a grainy taste. A little on the sweet side as it warms with a touch of sugary chocolate coming through. I think I will take a brief intermission and allow this to warm..... IÂ’m liking how the chocolate is coming out more, milk chocolate all the way because of the slight sweetness and silky smoothness. Damn this beer is smooth. The coffee is still dominating I know itÂ’s suppose to be this way but I do wish itÂ’d be a little more than just one-dimensional. I think the caffeine is hitting me, thereÂ’s more oomph in this than the FolgerÂ’s I had this morning thatÂ’s for sure. Overall itÂ’s coffee all the way, with light notes of chocolate and a slight sugary sweetness as well, but basically this is alcoholic coffee. As it warms even further a big charcoal smokiness comes through as well blending with the coffee like a madman. I liked it a lot but I have to say itÂ’s not one of "the" best IÂ’ve ever had. But it is what it is a breakfast beer true to itÂ’s word.

Bottle from Dilly Deli. Poured reddish black color with an average creamy brown head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Solid roasted coffee and chocolate malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Heavy roasted balanced flavor with a heavy chocolate  bittersweet finish of long duration. This is a standout beer.
SIB. Oh yeah, this was everything I hoped it would be. Lots of coffee and chocolate in the aroma...coffee is just a bit bitter, but very nice. Smooth finish. I want more.

[Taster Â– Seattle International Beerfest]
Dark Black in color with no head.  Deep coffee, toffee and chocolate aromas.  The Dark malts and fresh flavors where awesome.  This was a totally fun beer to drink.  I will recommend this for any beer geek to try.  Love the start to the finish what a great beer.  AWESOME

The aroma starts with a hint of coffee, chocolate, and roasted malts.  This pours a thick black, with a dark tan head that reminds me of the crema from an espresso.  The head quickly fades, but makes its presence known by the thick lacing on the glass.    The flavor has notes of coffee, bitter chocolate, and a touch of smoke.  Much lighter mouthfeel then I was expecting, it does win for getting the sensation of coffee oils coating the mouth.  I am looking forward to seeing if I can snag some bottles for cellaring to see how it holds up.

Black as treacle on a moonless night.  Pours like blood, and bubbles slow like boiling oil or releasing balloons in a storm.  Burned chocolate seeps forth filling the atmosphere.   The flavor is striking malt with bitter hops- complex and strong.  An exceptional stout which lives up to itÂ’s reputation as more of a meal than a drink.  If you donÂ’t have access to this beer try eating a bar of pure dark bitter cocoa and washing it down with strong black coffee and a shot of liquor.

22oz. Bottle:  Moderately sweet aroma.  Smells of coffee, roasting, smoke, malts, cream and chocolate.  Poured dark black in color with a medium to large, rocky, dark brown head that lasted throughout.  Great lacing.  Opaque.  Flavor is medium sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of chocolate, coffee, cream, and roasting.  Medium to full body.  Smooth, viscous texture.  Soft carbonation.  Long, dryish, coffee finish.  Overall, a very good, smooth, stout.

Love the bitterness, mostly from the coffee, inherent in this beer. Melds deliciously well with the oatmeal stout underneath, which provides hints of milky sweetness. Aroma is grainy, and mostly coffee. Love the dark brown head against the beer and the way it pockmarks, and the body is supple, but not thick. Very nice. From The Man.
user_location: ÅÃ³dÅ¼, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Courtesy dsnowden.  Thanks again Dan!  Pours pitch night black with a big foamy light brown head.  Looks awesome.  Smells of big coffee and roast with the chocolate on its heels.  Very inviting smelling.  Coffee seems to be the dominating smell and flavor here.  Big coffee in the taste as well, but noticeably turns into chocolate in the finish and the aftertaste.  Leaves a nice oily coat on the palate.  very warming beer.  Excellent!

Pours dark chocolate brown with a soft than head that fades away. Very bitter coffee flavor throughout, bakers chocolate, very roasty. Palate wasnÂ’t that heavy, lighter with a tingly carbonation. A nice stout, but to expensive, more then a bottle of Speedway stout here.

What a beer for rating #100.  Pours an ebony, midnight black.  Head is, and I am quoting SoLan "pure chocolate" milkshake".  Aroma is very telling, grains, coffee, bittersweet chocolate, slight sweet aroma.  Flavor is explosively powerful and long lasting.  Blast of grainy goodness along with some rich coffee flavors that seem to last for an eternity.  This is an awesome beer.

Thanks to WeeHeavySD for bringing this, among many other fine ales, to the compound to celebrate my exit from the womb 37 years ago.  Pours black as the night is long.  Smells like a rich, delicious mocha and tastes smooth as silk with subtle coffee notes.  This is one of those stouts that you can drink in duration because itÂ’s so perfectly balanced.
Pours black with nice size brown head. Aroma was of strong coffee and roasted malt. Most of the flavor was coffee with hints of chocolate throughout. Very nice and smoothe.

22oz bottle via trade with my pal Ughamash, thanks Jason.  Beer 1 of Bartzilla birthday bash of course shared with Bart.  Aroma is amazing with oatmeal and roasty hops.  The pour is super pretty with a black base and a huge retaining head of dark brown.  The taste is super malty with roasty sweetness.  This is a really supremely fantastic brew with lots of drinkability and so much flavor damn, nice stout, good work Mikkeller and damn good name.
On bottle at culminator. A smell of real coffee. And first tast is a very strong cop of coffee. But i liked the beer

22oz bottle.  Nearly opaque brown-red with a medium sized dark brown head.  Roast malt, dark alefruit, coffee bean, and a vegetal hop character in the aroma.  Heavy, smoky roastiness up front, followed by slightly tart alefruit.  Coffebean bitterness peers through in the finish, with residual roast malt, verging on acrid.  Mouthfeel is medium heavy, rather smooth.

Imported bomber. Near black pour with a large head. Aroma of coffee, oatmeal and chocolate with plenty of bitter, grass-like hops. Medium to heavy body. Smooth and rich texture. First taste of Mikkellers, and it was wonderful.
[Bottle from Tom] Pitch black with a tan head.  Lots of coffee, some milk chocolate, fruity, figs. Full bodied, fruity upfront, a little fruity tartness, coffee, dry, lingering coffee finish.

22 oz bottle, thanks Wayne for sharing...:)....Pours a rich brown, looks like coffee with a dark brown sugar colored head...smells orgasmic!...on a deep inhale, coffee beans rich and deep, licorice and prunes seep into the nostrils, I allow it...it smells sweet, I want to taste it...palate creamy and hearty all at the same time, aroma is more powerful than flavor, its good but a bit unbalanced in the malt department...a lot of coffee showing through, and a bitter finish thats blended with baking chocolate and unsweetened cocoa

Bottle from CaponeÂ’s of the 22 ounce variety.  The pour was onyx with 2-fingers of dark brown head; one of the brownest heads IÂ’ve witnessed.  The aroma was huge chocoff, dark patent malt, molasses.  The palate is hefty, complex, and rich, providing flavors of roasty patent malt, fine espresso coffee, rich chocolate, and molasses.  This one is very smooth, well balanced, and you want to chug it after a few sips.  This one deserves all the accolades it has received.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2007 22 oz bottle purchased at Liquor Outlet. Pours black with a nice compact and large light brown/tan head into my Tripel Karmeliet chalice.  Aroma of this beer is great, chocolate, coffee, light notes of roasted barley.  Taste is even better with alot of roasted malts, caramel, and the coffee really seems to hit the beer in the finish where the flavor lingers nicely and is moderately bitter for the style.  Body is silky and smooth as I expected, roast is more bitter than astringent. excellent, glad this finally hit NJ, even if it is almost 13 for a 22 oz bottle.

Finally they have BGB at my local NJ beer store.  Pours jet black, coffee aromas wafting up from the glass.
Black patent and coffee come through strong at first sip, finishes on the dry side.  Second sip and get more of the dark roast coffee flavors.  A bit of a harsh bite, would expect it to mellow a little with time and improve.

Holds a good head on a black beer. Strong but not overpowering chocolate coffee aroma. Have to pull to get the full scent out. Flavour is strong coffee. Full body and palate. Very dry. My taste buds seem to stop at coffee.

900th rating!  Bottle. Pours a jet black body with nice head. Aroma is of bitter coffee, roasted malt, chocolate. Flavor is very bitter, big coffe taste, hoppy, big robust flavors. Very dry! Sugary. This is a good beer, but too dry a mouthfeel - felt like it was stripping flavor from my tongue. Good taste but seemed to be missing something that should make it the beer that it is rated as, it falls a little short of greatness.
Pours black, with a brown head. Aroma is coffee, hops, roasted malt, chocolate, and some oats. Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, hops, and dark fruit.

[Bottle, shared by Marsiblursi with Guerde and me (thanks again guys!)] Very dark brown to black appearance, coffee aroma, thick mouthfeel. Hops came through a little strong with the first taste, but overall a pretty nice balance between them and the roast. Another good beer.

Bottl sampled from Capones with the Mad Indian. Dark pour with a dark large cola colored head. Aroma of Coffee, roast, earthy hops, and slight chocolate. The flavor is prodominately coffee & roast, earthy hops and slight chocolate can also be detected. Great brew, maybe a little to much coffee for me.

Sampled at Capones on Allagash night with Stegosaurus. this bottle was set aside for us. Black pour with roasted malt aroma. BIG COFFEE PRESENCE IN TASTE. NOT BLENDED WELL BUT A REAL GOOD OVER ALL BEER. I enjoyed it.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2008 [bottle] Thick, black colour. Large, creamy head. Aroma is liquorice, roasted malt, smoke, tobacco and hops. Smooth and balanced on the palate. Flavour brings roasted coffee and chocolate. Finish is long and bitter. Great beer but IÂ’d rather sip on it in the evening than in the morning.

550th rating.  Pours an oily pitch black with a thick brown head.  Aroma is of roasted malts,  oatd, bitter coffee beans and dark chocolate.  Taste is dominated by roasted malts and bitter chocolate.  Lacks sweetness.  Very good, but lacking that punch that would make it great.

Bottle - Pours pitch black with a burlap colored head.  Aroma is dominated by roasted malt, coffee and chocolate.  Flavor is roasted malts, dark chocolates and strong coffee but none of these are bitter or overbearing.  Finishes with a light earthy hop note.  Excellent mouthfeel with a smooth texture that does not become too syrupy as the beer warms.  Overall a fantastically balanced beer considering all of the flavors and abv.

Black with millk chocolate head. Strong aroma of deep roasted malt, dark chocolate,coffee, and oats. Very good looking beer,oily texture and smooth creamy mouthful. The taste was the same as the aroma with nice bitter hop/coffee finish. Impressive stuff.
Robe noire surmontÃ©e dÂ’une mousse brune qui sÂ’estompe. ArÃ´mes de cafÃ© et de houblon amÃ©risant. Saveurs de cafÃ©, de fumÃ©, dÂ’avoines, de caramel et de houblon amÃ©risant.

A really nice looking stout and the first impression is aggresive. All the way roasted bitterness and after comes the great flavor of a real good coffee. Altough that i have some difficulties with the bitter side of this beer i like it.

Aroma:good coffe aroma,rosted aroma...
Appearance:dark,with a huge brown head...
Flavor:coffe,rosted malt,cocoa

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2010 Courtesy of BBB63, DL Â’06. Oily black body, tan head, growing legs. Huge coffee up front, followed by licorice, faint bitter cocoa, and tons of roastiness. Flavor on par with aroma, bitter cocoa/roastiness even bigger, hop character shows up in the finish, helps to cleanse a little. Slight warming. Just not my thing.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2010 Bottle (Helsinki Beer Festival 2007, Helsinki)
Thick oily coffee/espresso aroma, and a real punch of dry dark roasts. Fill your whole mouth to appreciate the full taste. Very good, but a little unsophisticated in its extremeness. (6-5-7-4-13=3.5)
Rerate: (7-4-8-4-16=3.9)
Keg (Pikkulintu, Helsinki, Winter beers 2009)
Lovely coffee aroma. Simple but rich palate - very roasty. Frighteningly drinkable. Soft palate. Stale coffee - and thatÂ’s so good! nomnomnom. I was supposed to be ticking, but I had 3 pints of this instead! yumyumyum!

(Bottle)  Pours a black body with a medium tan head.  Aroma of sourness (reminiscent of a Belgian-style stout), pine, roastiness, and some cocoa.  Flavor of hops and chocolate (similar to a FFF Black Sun) with some roasted malt and coffee in the finish.  Soft, smooth mouthfeel.

UPDATED: NOV 4, 2007 Bottle thanks to enjoyit, gareths ipa tasting. Aroma of rich chocolate coffee, roasted barley and sweetness. Taste is similar but super balanced, the chocolate coffee is amazing just stupendious. The best stout in the world by 4 miles. RERATE: Alright still but nothing like as good as before.

Rich deep ruby black colour with a large smooth creamy head. Oh i could smell this beer all day!!! Rich aroma of fruity plums, port, figs, dates and rich roasted dark malt and dark chocolate. VERY COMPLEX! Tate is similar with pronouncd choclate and roasted malt character with bangs of expresso. Delicous. DonÂ’t know if i cu handle this at breakfast but definetly a Pleasure to drink

My 1700th rating! Bottle (660 ml) courtesy of Viper666. IÂ’m pretty excited, IÂ’ve been looking forward to trying this for a while now. Pours an impenetrable black, lots of bubbles stuck to the side of the glass, with a large long lasting foamy brown head -- looks great! Wonderful aroma of roast coffee, roasted malt, bitter chocolate, smoke, oats, pepper and a nice amount of grassy hops -- so much going on here and it smells great. Big chocolaty flavour with lots of coffee, roasted malt, hops, some smoke, oatmeal and a big roasty bitter finish -- so flavourful and easy to drink, goes down smooth. AlcoholÂ’s well hidden. Medium to full bodied, creamy/oily mouthfeel. Man, what more can I see about this awesome beer? ItÂ’s simply fantastic. I will also add how ecstatic I am that I will be receiving more of them soon. I look forward to trying more Mikkeler beers.

Bottle (650ml).  Via trade with Vipert666 - thanks again, J-F!.  Essentially opaque oily brown-black, red around the edges, huge lasting foamy-creamy brown head, even lovely drapes of tan lace left behind.  Aroma - wow! - is this Three Floyds? - incredible balance of full-on pungent hops, lactic deep roast malt, coffee, chocolate, cereal grain richness in the background, dry and even a little herbal as it warms - if this tastes as good as it smells, weÂ’re talking new top 25 for me!  The taste is very good - bakerÂ’s chocolate, strong coffee, dry herbal hops, less lactose character, pretty solid deep roast bitterness by the end, moderate alcohol.  Silky, decently full but not thick body, almost oily, not sticky at all, feels great on the tongue, lasting but not coating, light astringency, more acidity than you initially think, with a smooth, long lingering finish - perhaps a little bit weak in the finish.  Solidly in the middle between stout and imperial stout, would do credit to either - this is an incredible beer, I would keep this on hand always if I could.

Sweet aroma, with coffee, chocolate, nuts and hops all in a harmonious balance. Strong flavour dominated by burnt chocolate, and roasty characters, doesnÂ’t quite live up to the aroma. Excellent mouthfeel and finish. A real class act.

(Draught at Ã–lbaren, Copenhagen, 17 May 2007) Pitch black colour with lasting brown head. Roasted, creamy nose with chocolate and coffee, lots of both, but mingling well together. Roasted taste with dark bitter chocolate, coffee, chocolate pudding, hints of cream, roasted oatmeal and ... more chocolate. Balanced bitterness, some sweetness. Rather full body, velvety mouthfeel. Loads of taste but in such harmony that it just sits at the back of the tongue, lingering. Superb balance. Absolutely lovely beer.
Bottle at home. Black, black, black and even blacker. Thick dark head. Roasted taste of coffee, cream, chocolate. Well-balanced and overall great.
Opaque, darkest head iÂ’ve ever seen. Coffee dominates aroma, some malts, hops, liquorice. Soft flavour, obviously bitter, hops shine through, dry. Could use a bit more creamy texture.

Bottle: Poured a deep black color stout with a huge dark brown foamy head with some really good retention and some lacing. Aroma of dry coffee is well mix with some light roasted malt note. Taste is a nicer mix between some dry coffee and some nice lightly sweet roasted malt. Body has a great creamy texture which really fits with the style. I also found that this beer had some great carbonation with no alcohol being discernable. I have to admit that this beer was well brewed with some great balance between coffee and malt with a nice texture.

Aroma of very pure coffee beans, some licorice, some hops. Slick, black coloured with a chocolate brown head. Taste is sweet, moderate bitter, coffee malty, quite creamy. Nice balanced and quite smooth. Good stuff.

Pitch black color, with a creamy tan-colored head, leaving laces, nice yeasty,roasted malt, and a mild smoky nose, with a smoked peaish malt accent, with some smooth oatmeal mochaish and vanilla notes, a dark bitter chocolatey and good roasted coffee bean bitterness aroma follows through on a full-bodied palate with a chocolatey, toasted malt character, with some roasted coffee bean flavours, a smooth oatmeal espresso mouthfeel, gaving a nice bitter chocolatey accent, with a flowery hop bitterness, leading towards a roasty malt, dark chocolate, dry hoppiness finish.

Bouteille de 660 ml obtenue via Importations PrivÃ©es BiÃ¨ropholie. ArÃ´me: Odeur de chocolat et de cafÃ© torrÃ©fiÃ©. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. PrÃ©sence dÂ’un mince col mousseux et dÂ’une fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: GoÃ»t de cafÃ© et de chocolat avec une pointe dÂ’houblons. Longue durÃ©e de lÂ’arriÃ¨re goÃ»t. Palette: Le corps est plein avec une texture lÃ©gÃ¨rement crÃ©meuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. PrÃ©sence de cafÃ© en arriÃ¨re goÃ»t. (Rating #1043)

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2007 A Mes rate: 
Draught at Ã˜lfestival 2007. This will always have a special place in my heart due to the night we ended up behind the bar at  Ã˜lfestival 2007 pouring our own. I have no idea how much of it we drank but I know it was a serious amount. What a way for Sim to learn how to pour beer serving up this wonderful stuff.
