Rest assured we were very very drunk but who wasnÂ’t that night? Anyway the beer... Not much I can say that hasnÂ’t been said already so I will be brief. Roasty coffee with bags of dark chocolate. Sublime malts. Absolutely exotic mouthfeel. Great balance considering the heavy coffee, wonderfully full bodied and equally well rounded. Shit the bed itÂ’s amazing stuff. Have to say a huge thanks for letting us stay guys and for such a special experience. Sim said she felt like she was at DennyÂ’s throwing back free refills of coffee...

Tap @ Brewpub Kopenhagen. Dark black color, medium off-white head. Aroma of roasted malt, hop, coffee, licorice, some caramel. Not the chocolaty sweetness, but more dry and bitter with a very nice balance in hop bitterness and coffee and licorice. Full creamy mouthfeel.
Very dark, almost black with a huge tan head. Lots of roasted coffe tones. Taste is dry, espresso with a hint of chocolate. Medium to full body with avery long and dry finish. Very nice !
UPDATED: MAR 8, 2008 The most malt astringent stout I have had in years. Nose of cocoa, and ground espresso beans. grainy and astringent palate. horribly overroasted finish that outlives its welcome.

Big thanks to thewolf for this brew.  Pitch black thick poor with a huge foamy brown head.  Aromas of mesquite, fresh ground coffee beans, burnt toast, roasted malts... reminds me also of a nice camp fire smell.  Very nice smooth lactose (creamy) feel.  Full bodied nicely carbonated with a nice dry longlasting bitter aftertaste.. Roasted oats, molasses, coffee completes the flavors... The head didnt last to long though and the lacing was very low.

In bottle at Norrebro Bryghus in Copenhagen.  Opaque jet black with a thick dense tan head.  Aroma of coffee, slight berry fruit, light toffee, and some milky sweetness.  Roasted bitterness, coffee, and easy-going grain astringency with a low fermentation profile which leaves the palate clean and dry.

Sampled March 2007
This is a very dark brew, it is quite opaque and is quite black as it sits in my glass.  It is topped by a billowing, easily three-finger thick, light chocolate brown colored head.  Ah, the aroma is so nicely roasted; smelling of chocolate, espresso, lightly roasted coffee, a touch of burnt grain husks.  It has this underlying, but always evident, decadent dark malt note that makes it smell like a lightly sweet, dense, dark dessert; perhaps a dessert that is a mix of chocolate and coffee, but there is an unmistakable, complex malty sweetness here in the aroma as well.  This just smells so decadent.  Up front the aroma smells quite burnt & perhaps a touch sharp, but it quickly picks up a richness that is just so compelling; this is certainly a beer that I can easily spend a few minutes sampling just the aroma.

The first sip hits my tongue, at first it seems a bit lighter in the body than I was expecting.  A roast acidity seems to lighten the effect of this brew, but then the malt kicks in and this brew becomes quite chewy and rich, just like the aroma promised.  It starts out with roasted coffee & barley malt notes, then picks up notes of chocolate and darkened malt sugars.  It finishes with a lingering sweet notes reminiscent of sweet dark chocolate and a touch of espresso acidity.  As my palate gets used to this brew it seems to lose a bit of that initial richness, perhaps the burnt acidity becomes a bit too acrid for the other competing flavors to compete with.  It is still quite tasty, though I might recommend not drinking this on an empty stomach, the acidity seems to be causing me some, though extremely mild, stomach discomfort.

While the flavor is quite nice, I think that the aroma is better; it is richer and fuller, with a better complexity to it.  If the complete beer lived up to the initial aroma this beer would be just about perfect.  The mouthfeel of this seemed to fizzle a bit after the first couple of sips.  Ultimately this is a great beer, it is just that after the first couple of sips this promised to be a stunning beauty of beer; or perhaps better said is started out so decadent and rich, but then took on a lighter tone.  As most beer geeks know, it is better to have the lighter less powerful beers first in a session and move oneÂ’s way up to the more powerful brews; not the other way around like this brew seems to do.  As it is though, it is still a great beer, one which I would be happy to have easy access to.

Bottle. Pitch black with long lasting head. Palate is thick, thick and then thick. Espresso aroma with lots of hops. What a great combi. Also roasted malts here. Flavor is more Espresso, Chocolate and heavy bitterness from the hops. My kind of stout! Good work guys.
UPDATED: SEP 28, 2009 Bottle. Black with nice brown head. Lots of coffee and chocolate aroma and flavour. Nice coffee finish. Great beer.
(50 cl. Bottle) Very black with a fine darkish head. Aroma and flavor of chocolate and coffee. Very smooth and nicley light carbonated. A very good stout.

SEX in a GLASS!!!!!!   I love this beer!   I love coffee, I love great Stout and this is the bollox!     Sorry to be so crass on the rate, but hell I canÂ’t be bothered with smells like, tastes like - Nice one guys!    FANTASTIC BEER!!!!! Between you and Struise and RR,  props!

Bottle. Black color with a dark brown great head. Roasted tar aroma, lots of tar, viol, licorice, dry hops, rather smoked and with notes of chocolate and cream. Hoppy tar flavor, cocoa, chocolate, smoke, ash, salty and with a really bitter hoppy finish. Also some slat and tar in the finish.

Bottle, via trade with janka at GABF. Split this bottle with my cousin after dinner on Easter. Pours like motor oil, with a moderate brown head. Big aroma of coffee and chocolate. Roasted malt, cocoa powder, caramel and chocolate flavors at first, giving way to a long lasting hop finish.  delicious.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2007 Bottle shared by gears81, thanks Jake. Pours a near pitch black with a thin tan head. Aroma is huge, driven by roasted coffee and not overly bitter dark chocolate. Flavor is very rich, nutty, and roasted/burnt, but still very good. The flavor is very bright, but not to the point of being harsh. This is a very nice brew, and much more balanced when compared to some of the other "coffee stouts" on the market.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2008 Jet black beer with a creamy brown head.
The aroma is freshly ground coffe, citrusy hops and notes of caramel and fruits from the yeast. The flavour is cold coffe (meant in the most positive way...) loads of burned- and caramalt and hops. It all blends into a perfect smooth taste with a nice and slightly dry bitter end. The oats are not very apperant.
Thick and creamy and about the most un-metroxexual way to start your day!

Added 15/03 2008: New batch: Seems a little lighter on the palate and a bit more easy drinkable. Also a little more hoppy. Still a fantastic beer!
UPDATED: DEC 22, 2009 (66 cl.). Black colour with thick mocca-coloured head. Coffee, oat, dark chocolate aroma. Roasted malt, coffee and very bitter hoppy taste. Feels very smooth and creamy.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2007 First rating(66 cl bottle, thanks Marsiblursi) Pitch black color, brown head. Huge hoppy, burnt malt, coffee, chocolate and fruity scent. Bitter hoppy, burnt malt and chocolate taste. Long burnt malt aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel, huge bitterness.8/5/8/4/17=4.2Second rating(Bottle at a Mikkeller beer tasting held at Brewpub KÃ¶penhamn)Black color, brown head. Lots of coffe scent and taste. Nice big bitterness. Smooth mouthfeel.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2008 Bottle (65 cl) thanks Marsiblursi. Black colour with light brown head. Burnt, roasted and complex malt aroma, with notes of coffee and green pepper. Very smooth and silky mouthfeel. Well balanced, both mellow and bitter, with a long finish.

Bottle at Per & Gurli.
Black with a brown head. Aroma heavy malty (chocolate, coffee, roasted) and hoppy. Moderate/heavy sweet and bitter. Medium body, creamy, soft carbonated.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2007 Again, many thanks to Maria for this outstanding beer. Aroma of gentle caramel and coffee, maybe a french roast. Head pours a medium/dark creamy that stacks upon gentle pouring (hence the oats).  Color is dark....so dark that Darth Vader himself may choose that this beer become the official sponsor of the Dark Side.  A fair amount of bottle conditioning.  MMMMM....first taste is caramel chocolate cofferificness!  A nice lingering finish after a shorter body. A fine brew to relax with after clearing 18" of snow off the driveway St. Patricks day morning.  Get it if you can and horde it.

Thanks Maria! After so many imperial stouts it is nice to have just a....umm...non-imperial. Aroma of coffee. Pour was a thin black with a tannish red head that dissipated quickly. Taste was a mix of roasted malt with coffee and some smokiness in the after taste. A nice change of pace from where IÂ’ve been lately
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 20.5 oz bottle.  Pours a pitch black with a half-finger mahogany head.  The aroma is of roasted coffee and chocolate.  The flavor is WEIRD! - there is creamy roasted coffee followed by very bitter hops, then chocolate and molasses.  Smooth, sweet and suprisingly thin. Very good.

66 cL bottle. Pours completely black with a huge creamy head, almost looks like chocolate cream. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee. I have to admit that the aroma is weak compared to the taste that follows - my oh my. creamy mouthfeel. Taste is very complex yet in perfect balance. First and foremost: IÂ’m so happy not to encounter yet another helltauer beer :). There is coffee and bitter hops together with tart bitterness of the chocolate that is providing a differentiated bitterness through a sip.  Starts hop bitter, then coffee followed by chocolate and ending in a characteristic coffee bitterness blended with hops. Chocolate and oatmeal also provide a sweetness and softness throughout. Aroma hops (cascade and centinnial) gives the beer a slight touch of freshness without at any time stealing the picture from this full coffee, chocolate and oatmeal breakfast.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2008 Bottle 0,66l. Thanks to Rune for sharing this one. Pitch black. A small tanned head. A rich, spicy aroma. An flavor that expands in your mouth. Very rich in taste. Roasted malts dominates after a while. Well balanced - and an aftertaste that lasts. KI=5

Last time I visited Copenhagen I got hold of a 660ml bottle at Barley Wine. The bottle was brought back to TromsÃ¸ and shared with some good friends at a drinking session. Pours a black-as- coal body under a lasting, beige foamy head leaving great lacing on the glass. Rich hoppy aroma supported by black malty hints. Lots of dark chocolate malts in a complex roasty taste than also includes dark berries, ending up with a rich and lingering aftertaste of coffee. Perfect balanced. Moderate to full mouthfeel (23.02.2007).

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2009 Saved over from annual trade with Madsberg. An excellent stout with coffee aroma. Dark and roasty with giant head that is soapy. Then there is some lace. High perceptable alcohol there and chocolate and chocolate malt. Creamy taste.Oatmeal, A tad smoke. Perfect coffee and unbelievable overall balance.

<proppen>
Dark brown/black with a huge creamy brown head. Sleightly smoked aroma along with hobs and coffee. Extremly malty roasted bitterness in the flavor leads to a very dry finish. Very powerfull brew that doesnt allow you to taste anything else for a few minutes. Make sure you have someone to share with if you break open a big bottle

Bottle at a beer gathering in BirkerÃ¸d. Nice deep dark brown colour with darkish brown creamy long lasting head leaving a very good lacing. Strong aroma of coffee, chocolate and good roasted malts. Flavour of well roasted malts, good chocolate, bitter dark chocolate, smoky. Long bitter, roasty coffee finish.

(sample at the DÃ¼sseldorf RB gathering) Black as tar coloured with a dark brown foamy head. Roast-malty aroma with strong notes of coffee and dark chocolate. Roast-bitter flavour, medium to full bodied with a pleasant, smooth carbonation. Strong roast-malty aroma with the impression of coffee-beans, but unfortunately not much more; dry, moderately bitter, roast-malty finish with loads of coffee notes. Very interesting and highly quaffable but also not that complex brew.

Bottle from Olbutikken. Opague, dark brown head. Licorice and pineapple in the aroma. Licorice in the malty sweet flavor. Full bodied. Pleasant roast character. Coffee, pineapple and cacao. Abundant with flavors and aromas and not without character and complexity.

From a 22oz Bottle.  Opaque, murky black chocolate pour with a creamy layer of quickly dissipating lightly roasted tan head.  Loads of silky roasted coffee in the aroma that blends eloquently with shavings of dry bakerÂ’s chocolate and toasted walnuts.  Great name, I want my morning cup of coffee to smell like this.  Nice aromatic balance between the chocolate, roast coffee, nutty, and caramel tones.  Each layer is carefully layered to prevent any single aspect from becoming too dominant.  Medium bodied, well carbonated mouthfeel.  Lots of dry chocolate and medium roast coffee initially invade my welcoming palate.  Some interesting coconut husk characters seem to be working a bit of a lighter, softer dimension onto the palate without giving up any of the bitter roast character.  A bit of toasted hazelnut lingers on the palate in the final smack along with more coffee beans.  I like how the edginess of the roast flavors is kept in check on the palate by the softness of the subtle toasted oatmeal in the mouthfeel.  Thanks, Jake!

Bomber courtesy after4ever. Thanks again! Pours black with an orange-brown head. Coffee and chocolate nose, with more in the taste, but the finish arrives too soon and seems too dry, if thatÂ’s possible. There is a burnt toast, espresso, sour, salty quality builds on the tongue as I finish my glass.

gahl06, bottled. thick black with a persistent beige head. hugely burnt aroma, traces of whipped cream and dried apricots. all sorts of burnt flavours - bitter chocolate, espresso doppio, bbq marinade. some pleasant lactic sourness and deeply bitter finish that i could taste for days

Bomber, courtesy Maria--thank you! IÂ’ve been aching to try this beer for quite a while. Big dark black pour with a thick, creamy, moussy, light tan head. Enormous coffee aroma--seriously overpowering. We served it with dessert tonight and it still seems pretty crazy. Bold attack, with a medium-high body and intense coffee flavors. Puckery astringent dry finish after the onrush of coffee flavor. This is an interesting beer, but let it never be said that Americans have cornered the market on insanely bulked-up flavors. This oneÂ’s a great one for standing out from a crowd of coffee-rich stouts, but it strikes me as a little too far around the bend to really be drinkable in a pleasurable way--more of a curiosity.
Sligthly intimidating roasted coffee aroma, but very satisfying aftertaste. Solid stout with a not too sweet taste experiece.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2007 Bottle from Ã–lbutikken in Copenhagen. Pours a thick, inky black with rich chocolate head. Aroma of roasted malt and expresso coffee, which is really what this wonderful stout is all about. Lots of expresso coffe bean in the flavour, which leaves an extremely bitter, burnt smoke and dry, dusty aftertaste. Not as sweet and gentle as, say, the Oak Aged Yeti, but a more menacing stout that tastes like one of those tiny cups of explosive coffee you get in an Italian cafe - with 7.5% of alcohol cleverly and quietly slipped in to it.

Thanks Santa!
Dark brownish black pour with a frothy brown head; turning into a creamy tan ring.
Roasty oatmeal stout aroma with possibly slight hops.
Nice full flavored roasty coffee, brown sugared oatmeal, 80% omanhene chocolate (made with cocoa liquor),. Full and thick with flavor. Great drink. Similar to the Founders Breakfast Stout, but a bit more "real" and fuller to me.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2007 Bottle: Pitch black body with coffebrown head. Aromas initially dominated by hopps but then roasted malts take over, but still this note of hopps lies beneath, which may be the reason why a person like me, who normally donÂ´t like stouts can find a lot of interesting stuff in this beer.

Taste dominated by roasted malts with vague hints of hopps. And after a while the coffee becomes noteable. good and long finish. 

A very complex beer, but for breakfast ? 

By my opinion 66 cl is too much. The finish gets too dominating and after a while tasting gets impossible. I donÂ´t find it harmonic, a little too much of everything and not so well balanced.

A good beer, but not the best danish.

Bottle: Pours with a pitch blak body and a huge creamy, brown head - medium lasting. Nose of roasted malt, chocolate and espresso coffee. Flavour is with malt, black coffee, oatmeal and liquorice. Oily texture. Full bodied. The finish is bitter and again with roasted malt. A complex and very drinkable brew.

Bottle (at the Duesseldorf Gathering): Black coloured with a tanned head, like a freshly prepared Espresso; coffee, roasted malt and espresso in the nose; dry bitter flavour, light to medium bodied, soft MF; lingering coffeeish-bitter finish. Good, well prepared stuff.........

Thin head but beautiful.  Thanks to JohnC for bringing this by the PP Strong Ale Fest in December.  (Just now getting around to rating).  Some strong coffee and chocolate flavors with lots of roasted malts and some walnutty flavors.  Very good and would love to have this again.
Bottle DÃ¼sseldorf gathering. Black pour, brown fluffy head, coffee, chocolate malts, some roastedness,Sweetness on the lips,  bitterness on the finish, Very good.

Bottle at the DÃ¼sseldorf Gathering.  Muddy, amber body.  Creamy, light brown head.  Pours quite sirupy.  Aroma of coffee, liquor, chocolate (strong malts).  Lightly bitter, lightly bitter flavour.  Quite dry.  Ok balance, but not very very complex.

Dusseldorf Gathering, Bottled. Grassy and moccha aroma. Black color, brown fine head, good lace. It starts like youÂ’re chewing on coffee beans, roasted and bitter but gets sweet half way. ItÂ’s all there, everything you were expecting. Very good but not really exceptional. Finishes a little dry. Thank you Papsoe!
Tried this one two times during the same evening from two different bottle and there were some deviation, slightly dissapointed due to high expectation, but still very nice.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2007 I had waited a long time to get this beer, and finally I found it. After a few days of resting, I simply could not wait any longer, I just had to open it. ItÂ’s a pitch black beer with a huge, light brown head and the aroma is simply wonderful, IÂ’m in love! I get notes of bitter chocolate and coffe, and the sensation is so very balanced, that I even before I taste it know, that IÂ’m not going to share this one with anyone.... The flavour - Mamma mia.... I think this must be the best stout I ever sank my greedy teeth into, itÂ’s thick and lovely - ready to be eaten with its notes of porridge and coffee with a hint of chocolate. The coffee flavour is simply wonderful and the oats gives a smooth and soft counterweight, and the balance is unique. The finish is marvellous and very long, and the bitterness develops in an exciting way. I can only say:Â Mikkeller RULES, they make great beers, and this one is phenomenal...!!! It is a more than worthy beer for my personal rating # 1600.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2007 I was expecting to be blown away by this, and while it was interesting and very drinkable, it wasnÂ’t mind-boggling in complexity or creativity of brewing. What did stand out, instead, was ease of drinkability, a Mikkeller strong suit. Poured dark black with a substantial and compacted dark tan cap. Soft aroma of brewing coffee, light chocolate, even lighter raspberries and oatmeal. Palate is soft and medium bodied. More coffee and chocolate bitterness in the initial taste. Very easy to drink, surprising how quaffable and light this goes down. Very complex, quite tasty, but nothing stands out besides the drinkability. I donÂ’t desire any particular beer have a huge flavor, but this had a clear lack of focus.

Bottle. Not stored. In a year or so I rerate a stored version. I like this beer. It has a lot of everything. Lots of dark flavours, superior bitterness and this layer upon layer of complexity. A true brew for the geeks, and others who like their stout complex and heavy. This is Nanobrew at its finest.

Bottle. Black with a good brown-grey creamy head. Great aroma with some alcohol, lots of coffee and quite a bit of chocolate-like sweetness. Extremely full mouthfeel. Low carbonated. Quite dry with lots of coffee - actually quite bitter as well.
Bottle. Hoppy aroma with some coffee. Black colour, brown head. Nice flavour, the coffee is distinct, but not overdone. Quite bitter. Soft, creamy mouthfeel.

Beautiful pitchblack colour with a lightbrown head that is medium high and only dissapears slowly. A powerful and incredibly lovely aroma of oatmeal, liquorice, coffee, chocolate. Furthermore is the aroma hops very obvious for a stout. The flavor is very malty by chocolate and liquorice and has a lot of real coffee-flavor. The beer becomes more sour towards the aftertaste that has nice touches of smoke, coffee and enormous amounts of bitter hops. It is a little thinner than I expected, and is very dry. Maybe it  could  have used a little more sweetness. However, this is an exceptional beer, without a doubt.

Shared by sliffy at CT4. Aroma of coffee  and chocolate. Very rich and a little burning in the nosrils. Flavor was a little bitter most likely from the coffee. Had a very nice oily palate but the body seemed a little thin.

(Bottled) Very dark brown color with a medium, tight and beige head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee with milk, and chocolate. Strongly roasted, malty, ashy and dry flavor with quite high bitterness and hints of smoky tar. Long, lingering, dry and ashy, very bitter aftertaste. No alcohol present in this baby. Medium-bodied, dry and bitter palate with smooth carbonation. A tasty porter with a delicious coffee aroma (IÂ’m not a coffee lover, thus only 8 points) and all, but maybe a bit too ashy flavor. Smoother and nicer in room temp - or maybe even higher! For breakfast ... why not - if youÂ’re taking a bus to work ;)

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2008 Black with a lasting brown head. Intense roast aroma with some coffee and chocolate, some fruitiness, possibly from the hops. Big, big roast flavour with underlying coffee, hop flavour a good dose of bitterness.

Shared by sliffy at CT4, thanks! Black pour with a tan head that turns to a film. Aroma of cofee, hazlenut, and some dark chocolate. The flavor held elements of dark chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, and a bit of raspberry. Oily and smooth with a bitter/clean finish. Pretty damn good stout...I really liked how a lot of it was kinda of delicate without being thin or watery...some nice subtle flavors and aroma.

Shared by Sliffy at the C-bus tasting #4.  Coffee dominates the aroma, which flows from a black body with a nice brown head on top.  Medium mouthfeel for an impy.  Strong coffee flavor with a slight bitter chocolate taste in the finish--I thought this beer might blow me away, but it just didnÂ’t live up to the hype in my opinion.  A good impy stout, but not one of the great ones out there.
Thick black beer. Very powerfull aroma of coffee and chocolate and long bitter finish. My high expectations were not fully met.

THANKS ANDERS37.  Bottle.  Poured pitch black, motor oil like pour.  2 finger sized dark tan head.  Aroma of roasted coffee and oats, very nice.  Flavor of nicely balanced roasted coffee, chocolate up front, and a nice oaty, oaky tones in the back.  A nice sweetness in the finish.  Dry roasty finish. Medium bodied. Long lasting aftertaste.  good carbonation present.  I definaltely enjoyed this.  By far one of the best beers I have had in a long while!

Black colored, medium sized beige head. Aroma is roasted, smoky and oaky as in some barrel aged stouts, chocolate, vinous tones and  strong coffee there also. Medium to full bodied. Flavor is even roastier with coffee and licorice, aftertaste has strong and obvious dryness and lasting roastiness with some caramel.

Big thanks to sliffy for sharing this one.Aroma is of chocolate and coffee.Pours black with a tan head.Has a coffee flavor at first then a nice bit of bitter chocolate.Mouthfeel is thick and oily with a solid chocolate finish.

Pour is midnight black with a medium tannish head. Aroma was a bit ash-like for me with notes of burnt charcoal/ashes, coffee, vanilla and tootsie rolls. I had a hard time getting past the nose of ashes, which was the most pronounced for me. Flavors were bakerÂ’s chocolate, coffee, with a moderate kick of hops and malts. I wanted to love this beer, but overall IÂ’d say it was above average. Drinkable, but not spectacular.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2008 Hop and coffee aroma. Brown/tan head with decent lace over dark motor oil body. Acidity reminiscent of a good, strong espresso and hops that feel slightly citrusy. Great balance, great hopping, brilliant!

July 8th 2008:
Another re-rate of an old favourite where I lower the rating... where will it end? Of course, this is still a smashing beer but not quite as good as I remembered it. Used to be 9-5-9-5-18 but is now 8-5-8-2-17 for a bloody decent score of 4.2.
Bottle at Horsens beerfestival. Black colour with a light brown head. Aroma is hop, roasted, coffee. Flavour is hop, roasted, coffee, fruit.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2013 again, the word here is power! This has everything, espresso, moccha, tiny hint of caramel, smoke, cocoa. The list is endless. Incredibly warming and you can feel the massive coffee in this. Breakfast of champions maybe? :) Magnificent long dry finish with the aftertaste of the best espresso a man can ask for. yes!!!!

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2010 Bottled at Horsens Beerfestival. Jet black with a small, dense, brown head. Chocolate, mocha, roased/burnt malt, coffee and lots of citrusy and piney hops in the aroma. The flavor is much the same delight, but feels a bit more pronounced. Fullbodied, with a long coffee-bitter and burnt finish. A balanced, yet hoppy beer. A bit too much for breakfast maybe, but delightful. Rating: 8-4-8-5-17-4.2. 061028Bottle. ThereÂ’s some brownish notes in this black beer. The head is tan and of moderate size, leaving lacings. ThereÂ’s loads of freshly brewed black coffee on the nose, roasted and chocolatey, and with a lovely hoppyness giving some citrus and pine cones. The flavor is sweet with an underlying roasted bitterness. Black coffee, smooth heavily roasted coffee beans, dark chocolate and a fine citrusy, piney hop impact that leads my thoughts to a newly opened bag of hops. No molasses or dark sugars, no dried fruits. Still, itÂ’s damn fantastic with all itÂ’s complexity in a simple way. Can I write that? I mean, simple and complex in the same sentence. It might be a bit thin on the palate, but itÂ’s damn smooth, quite dry and it slides down dangerously easy. And as it warms up a bit, everything is lifted up to an even higher level. ThereÂ’s some alcohol too, all the way from the nose Â’til after the last swallow, but itÂ’s just there to compliment the beer, it adds to the complexity and is just pleasant, almost relaxing. Nothing like the boozy alcohol found in strong euro-lagers, just a smooth, sneaking touch of warmth that suits this dark, rainy day very well. And the finish, it just donÂ’t disappear. The coffee and dark chocolate just lasts and last, I had to drink some water to get rid of it. Well, I didnÂ’t want that, so I had another sip and quit drinking the water. Oh, what a lovely beer, IÂ’ll definitely have one with breakfast this weekend. I donÂ’t drink coffee, except when Mikkeller and other brewers put it in their beers, so a bacon, toast, marmalade, butter, milk and BGB breakfast will probably kickstart the day in wonderful way. I might even make some scrambled eggs and have some smoked salmon with it. IÂ’m hungry already! The last ten or twenty or so BGBÂ’s IÂ’ve had has sort of disappointed, probably due to the wonderfullness of itÂ’s bigger brother Beer Geek Brunch Weasel. This BGB was the best IÂ’ve ever had, it stood out even though it was drank after two lovely porters at the same ABV level. The combo of dry, roasted malts and coffee and hops did it for me. Damn, IÂ’m glad I didnÂ’t just bring one bottle home. Cheers! 101005

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2007 Pours thick jet black with a creamy brown head, brilliant lace and retention. Aroma is very strong, of freshly ground coffee, caramel, fuggles hops and cocoa. As I sipped through the head, there seemed to be small chunks of coffee coming through, interesting but not all that nice... probably my biggest problem with the beer. Otherwise, it has a thick creamy feel in the mouth... Flavours of coffee, chicory, earthy hops, vegemite... its also very bitter from the hops, coffee and malts. The finish is long and bitter, roasty and warming. Great balance, amazing beer. In recent bottles IÂ’ve bought, the roastiness and hops seems flatter, and not as enjoyable. IÂ’d have to say that I enjoy it as fresh as possible too.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2006 Thick black with fine brown head. Smooth & filling texture. Powerfull roasted malty aroma. Coffee. Easy smoke, chocolate and liquiorice. Great bitter lasting finish. Good bite! Mikkeller, the best in Denmark right now!
Bottle at Horsens Ã¸lfestival. Black colour with a nice mostly lasting brownish head. Complex aroma and taste of coffee, licorice and spices. Great beer.
Dark brown color with fine beige head. A fine balanced flavor with liquorice and burnt malt. Bitter aftertaste.

Pours a jet black color with a ring of light brown lace. Excellent and complex aroma of coacoa, coffee, roasted malt and citrusy hops.  Lightly sweet flavor balanced by light bitterness. Charcoal, mocha, ash and vanilla. Full-bodied and milky with soft carbonation. Finishes dry, burnt and softly bitter.
Bottle. Almost no head. Black colour. Moderate malty and very hoppy aroma. Powerfull licorice/coffee flavor. Not too much coffee as I had feared. Creamy palate.
Bottle. Nice head with good duration. Color is dark brown. Aroma is coffee and chocolate. Taste is coffee and chocolate with some bitterness.

Bottle. Dark, dark brown. Roasted coffee beans, mocha and a light smokeyness in aroma with some piney / rasiny hops. Cold black coffee and pine flavour with some smoke and hints of liquorice. Extremely roasted and very dry. Big body.

Bottle.


A fantastic beer which deserves to be served at special occasions. Not so smooth as the draft version, but IÂ’m just a newcomer

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2007 Bottle (mini caffeine beer tasting).

Head is initially large, frothy, brown, mostly lasting.
Body is opaque black (flashlight tested).

Aroma is lightly to moderately malty (roasted grain, chocolate, coffee), moderately hoppy (grapefruit, resin), with a note of chalk.

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, creamy texture, soft/lively carbonation.

Second try and still not that enjoyable; overly hoppy nose (seems more American than European) and the malt-and-coffee character is surprisingly not very compelling.  Quite acidic. Awesome appearance and a very good mouthfeel, but thatÂ’s about it.

Bottle. Happy birthday to me! Pours pitch black with the darkest head IÂ’ve ever seen Â– absolutely amazing. Aroma is a great blend of Â‘pineyÂ’ hops and roasted malts with coffee notes. The best attempt of this in a dark beer that IÂ’ve tried. Flavour is somewhat sourish at first, but soothens down as it warms. Roasted and hoppy notes. Ends on a lingering bitter licorice finish with a dryish touch Â– great! Fullbodied and with a smooth palate. The best stout IÂ’ve tried. Go Mikkeller! 23-10-06.

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2007 (Bottle) Pours dark, dark brown. Roasted coffee beans, mocha and a light smokeyness in aroma with some citrusy hops up front, pine and rasin is secondary . Cold black coffee, citrus and pine flavour with some smoke and hints of liquorice. Extremely roasted and very dry. A bit salty and some cocoa. Big body. Second try. Pours black. Very roasted and burned aroma with a lot of hoppy  tones ,grapefruit citrus, pine and resin. Coffee also up front. Undertones of tar, pepper, dark chocolate and crisp bread. Burned coffee flavour with a very bitter and dry citrusy grapefruity finish. A lot of hops with piney, grapefruity and resiny tones. Thick mouthfeel and a pretty full body.

This beer deserves the rating itÂ´s getting.This stout is almost perfect in everyway.Heavy body,rich creamy head,very flavoursome,long aftertaste 
and itÂ´s very filling.One of the best stouts i have ever tasted!
UPDATED: OCT 21, 2006 Pitch black with thick brown rocky head. Loads of roasted coffee, chocolate, nuts and hops. Full body and long finish. Great beer!!

Pour is black with brownish highlights and a bubbled tan head...explosive beer...overly carbonated...smell is rich with fruit and cocoa...turns to foam in the mouth it is so effervescent...seemingly more fruity than roasty...?...good...
Draft at plan b, Copenhagen. Full, rich stout, you can almost eat this with a fork. Chocolate head, coffee aroma with a splendid bitterness. Amazing...

bottle from christiansa. black body with a thick tan head that remains throughout in the form of a thin blanket over the beer. aroma is coffee, chocolate, and a touch of red grapes. taste is slightly acidic coffee and wet melting chocolate, some graham cracker notes and a nice roasty finish.  a bit metallic with a weird fruitiness about midtaste, but that fades after a bit(donÂ’t know if it was just my palate getting used to this, or what). something in this reminds me of a cigar. great complex lingering flavors that are a pleasure.  a well balanced brew that works well.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2007 pre-GABF party Â’06: Deep and dark brown. Rich chocolate and coffee throughout -- nice. Zingy hops seemed to balance well. Bitterness built in the finish. RERATE: Motor oil blackness; creamy, lasting, tan head. Milkshake-like texture. Rich chocolate and roasty coffee notes throughout. Bitterness (grass, pine) was balancing. Warm and soothing alcohol. Dark chocolate cocoa nibs in the aftertaste. Tasty beer.

UPDATED: OCT 23, 2006 Bottle: Deep red to black colour, nice creamy head.
Aroma of salt,coffee,dark chocolate, burned beens.
Flavor is coffee,malts and dark chocolate in a fatastic nice balnce.. Dry choclate coffee finish. Full body, long finish. Werry nice!!!

[Bottled
Black colour, brown head. Dry coffee dominates, the chocolate tones add to a good aroma profile. Dry mouthfeel - good balance of hops and malts, and when warmed up - cocoa, tobacco, licorice and a touch of smokiness.

Aroma of burnt coffee, bitter chocolate and licqourice. Stunning in the glass: almost black body with big lasting brown head.
Taste is that of coffee (again) roasted malts and a hefty dose of hops on the side.
CanÂ’t wait to start a day off with one of these and a full english breakfast.
Superb.

Bottle shared with Walt. Opaque body with a thick foamy head. Bottle was a gusher. Smells like cold pressed coffee with a touch of chocolate. Taste-smooth coffee, fig, tootsie rolls, medium bitter, light tannins, and wood. The coffee and sweet dark fruit flavors play off of each other very well, but something about this that I canÂ’t put my finger on is justÂ…not right.

RBSG 2006 - DC Grand Tasting Lineup
Dark murky black, tan head, light lacing. Nose of mosquito spray and coffee, vegetal with a weird thyme note. Milk thistle, dandelions. The flavor is rich and strong with lots and lots of coffee, dark chocolate. Lots of roast. Finishes smooth and roasty. Good. Thanks Jens!

Bottle 66cl at HeleneÂ’s - shared with Helene and Mette. Pitch black - brown head. Coffee + Coffee - --> This is the best... !!! Roasted, burned, high lovely hopped, light smoked, very smooth, very complex. This is Blaxploitation.

Bottled. Sampled at Marsiblursis residence, Stockholm. Black colour, wonderful brown foam. Coffee, NescafÃ©, and chocolate in aroma. Nice. Big presence of iced coffee in flavour, with a toast touch, toast beans. Very dry mouthfeel. Burnt tone. Extremely good balance of hop bitterness and maltiness. Once warmed up, it developed a furhter dryness from cocoa, tobacco, salty licorice and smokiness These components were all bound well together.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2006 This beer properly has the greatest foam that I have ever seen on a beer. The color was dark; well no it was pitch black. The aroma was also nice and complex. There are notes of liquorish in the aftertaste. Have anoter bottel just wating to be sampled to see if I missed anything.

660 ml bottle thanks to janka and friends.  Very dark with awesome cramy brown head.  Aromas of rich coffee, Dark chocolate.  More coffee in the flavor too.  Like rich black coffee.  The hop bitterness in the end is very pleasant as well.  Very very tasty beer.
Pours black as pitch with a small brownish head. Rich and roasted - coffee, coffee and more coffee. So so good.

Deep black in colour with a rich and creamy long lasting tan coloured head, great lacing.  The aroma is of coffee, oatmeal, cream, sugar, dark chocolate, intense roast.  The flavour is again intensely roasty, lots of cream, chocolate and coffee, light molasses and oatmeal.  Bitter mouthfeel, medium body, medium carbonation.  Finishes long, slightly warming, roasty and bitter.  No noticable alcohol.  A fantastic beer all-round.
<font size=-2>500ml bottle obtained in an in-person trade with <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?U target=blank>henrikb, thanks Henrik.  Best before December 2006.</font>

Bottle. This lively beer pours a deep pitch color with a very large, firm, brown head. Long lasting. Full roasty aroma, well balanced stout elements of the roasted malt and the roasted coffee. Light sweetness creeps in along with a touch of smoke. Full flavored, a lot going on but each element seems to have its own space. Nice melding of the smokiness, coffee, roasted malt, and a touch of oat sweetness. Smooth medium to full body, light warming comes in. Delicious. Thanks Jeff!

Bottle. Pours a deep black body with an airey large mocha head. The aroma is fantastic - maple sugar, pungent coffee, faint smoke, and bitter chocolate. <!-- i -->Really<!-- /i -->, really nice. Roast chocolate is a big component in the flavour among some burnt maple sugar. 
A nearly perfect transformation between the aroma and flavour...everything is well represented and nicely integrated. Silky smooth with bitter cocoa and rich roast coffee substance. Slowly warming alcohol.

Thanks for sharing this sublime stuff, radiomgb.

RBSG Â’06.  Very dark beer with an active big brown head.  Dark sugar and tar in the nose.  Lots of charcol, ash, molassess, and bitter chocolate.  Smooth oatmeal mouthfeel.  Very drinkable for its size.  A beer to be sought out.
UPDATED: OCT 6, 2006 This is better than sex!! Aroma of coffee and chcolate, and a beatiful taste of licorice and coffee. my favoite beer atm!

An exellent beer! ItÂ’s hard to find it in the shops but IÂ’ll keep looking. ItÂ’s worth the effort!
Nice appearance. Thick rich body. Creamy. Bitter chokolate taste. And much more.....

RBSG DC 2006: Opaque deep brown body with a small tan colored head.  The aroma is molasses, roasted malt, chocolate, burnt apples, dry bakers chocolate.  Taste is prunes, sweet molasses, sugar cane, and dark roasted barley.

Bottle. Pours black with a big brown head. Aroma is coffee, chocolate Dark roasted malts, sweet malts. Taste is sweet, roasted, coffee and chocolate. Velvet fullbodied mouthfeel and a long sweet roasted aftertaste

black body & super tall dense foamy sienna brown head.  aroma of chocolate mochachino.  mouthfeel is smooth, yet high carbonation.  flavor is very dry coffee malt, as deep roasted as you can get without being burnt.  chocolate malts are in the background compared to the coffee flavor, but bittersweet like baking chocolate or high cacao bars.  this is a deep roasted coffee/dark chocolate loverÂ’s beer.  went very well with an authentic italian pastry from north NJ.  thanks a million, Madsberg for this in trade!

Sampled at RBSG 2006- Grand Tasting. Pours dark brown with a multi-colored head of cream and dark brown. Very tingly mouthfeel. Coffee flavors are pronounced. The foam and lacing just lingers beautifully in the glass. You should drink this stuff out of a coffee cup.  Yum.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2010 RBSG 06. Pitch black with tan head, lasting cover. The aroma is heavy roast, burnt, chocolate and coffee. The flavor with burnt, roasted acidity, coffee, and dark bitter chocolate. Medium body, bitter end.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2009 RBSG 2006, Grand Tasting. Pours dark black with a beige head. Nose of vibrant green hops and chocolate. Flavor has notes of roasted malt, caramel, chocolate, earth and a pleasant burnt bitter back end taste. Medium bodied with a smooth texture and moderate carbonation. Quite good. RERATE- from a bottle IÂ’ve had for over a year. Awesome, smooth bold dark chocolate with subtle coffee flavor. Keep wanting more of this. A mix between Stout and Imperial Stout - very drinkable.

Sampled during RBSG 2006.
I got to rate this side by side with the Great Lakes Bourbon Barrel Stout and this was my favorite.
Thanks to Ungstrup for bringing another winner!
Pours black with a light tan head that hangs forever.
Rich aroma of coffee, dark chocolate, and roasted malts.
Well balanced flavor that combines the aromas with a nice dry finish from the roast malts.

Bottle by trade courtesy of Humleimporten... many thanks, Jacob.  Poured tar black with a large, mostly diminishing brown creamy head.  Big aromas everywhere.  Dominating are heavy dark roast coffee, various chocolates, warming to subtle dark fruits and some sweet and burning sugar smells.  Tastes of bottom-of-the-pot coffee, burnt driftwood, and dry cocoa.  A long salty, tangy, bitter finish like youÂ’ve finished too many cups of coffee at an all night diner while your carÂ’s in the shop waiting for a new fuel pump Â’cause they donÂ’t stock imports in Kansas.  Big, full, strong body with thick creaminess and milky smoothness.  Solid carbonation.  Alcohol is lightly detecable in the finish.  Knowing IÂ’ll probably never get a chance to have this beer again, I try to take things slow, but in spite of its robust nature, this beer is too dangerously easy to drink quickly.  IÂ’m entirely satisfied with this beer.  Thanks again, Jacob.

(RBSG06, 50cl bottle) Big brown head atop an opaque black body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, coffee, chocolate, roast.  Taste is medium sweet, coffee, some burnt.  Creamy medium body.  I guess not being a coffee drinker shows up in my ratings of these "breakfast" stouts, as I also gave below average ratings for Founders (though not as far below as I do here).

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2012 Dark as can be, head is rich copper brown, even pumpkin colored it seems.  High carbonation, rich toffee, amaretto and coffee nose, sweet, rich, excellent all around.  Flavor is sweet, more pale and mundane than the nose, but still ric, full of caramel, butter-toffee, creamy coffee and chocolate flavors.  Texture is good, slick when the carbonation is leveled out a little bit.  Thanks to Jens for bringing this one to the summer gathering.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2007 Bottle at RBSG Â’06. Black in color with a rich tan head. Aroma was mild coffee, dark roasted malts and milk chocolate. Flavor was more intense than the aroma. The coffee really came on, along with sweet roasted malts and finishing with a rich chocolate finish. I had this a few weeks ago at a Heavyweight open house and wasnÂ’t overly impressed. I can only guess that it lost something in the shipping over to the states because this one from Ungstrup was beautiful.
RBSG06:  What the hell.  Another awesome little stout.  Thick, black, rich and tastly.  Maybe a touch too sweet, but otherwise amazing

Thanks to sk8viking for this brew.
Holy MedisterpÃ¸lse!! This was a gusher...
Once past that, it poured black with a long lasting, dark brown head. The head. The aroma was very nice, roasty, chocolatey. The flavor started out silky smoth with lots of chocolate and roastiness. finishes great. Thanks

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2009 Bottle courtesy of RealityDeviant on 05/21/2009. Dark black body with a medium creamy brown head. Roast, chocolate, light vanilla and caramel flavor with a dry floral hop background. Medium full body with moderately low carbonation. 8/5/8/4/16 - 4.1

Jul 17, 2006: Sampled at RBSG06. Dark black body with a huge creamy head. Chocolate and roasted malt aroma. Sweet chocolate and roasted malt flavor, very smooth. 9/5/9/4/18 - 4.5

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2006 Many thanks to Ungstrup for this one, RBSG 06.  One of the standout beers on a long night of standout beers.  Beautiful head texture; large bubbles with strong retention.  Looks like an event.  Dark chocolate, roasted malts on the nose.  Bitter chocolate in a layered mouthfeel.  Coffee.  Nice carbonation on the tongue.  Long finish.  9/5/9/5/18 ...  Rerate, courtesy of sk8viking.  Thanks, Rene!  Slightly hotter than I remember; still the best coffee stout IÂ’ve ever had.  9/5/9/4/17.

Pitch black with a really nice creamy tan head. The aroma is tinged with that peculiar oat aroma and of course coffee and chocolate. The flavor is sweet up front with a coffe like bitterness developing late. Mdium full palate. A pretty fine beer. Thanks to Ungstrup for providing this at the RBSG 2006.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2009 Beer #14 RBSG 06.  Black with a deep tan head.  Great deep chocolate aroma.  Flavor is quite grainy, almost like roasted barley husk.  Touch of coffee on the finish as well. Nice, and actually sort of different from anything IÂ’ve had before in a way.   Never thought I would get to try this.  6/28/09 - rerate of full bottle.  Everything matches my initial notes, except that there is a bit more pine hope character present on the finish.  This might just be reflective of a fresher bottle.  Still good stuff, and glad to be able to find it locally now.

loads of coffee in the nose, a bit of chocolate, and some heavy roast malts. great sweet flavor, excellently smooth flavor.  lots of chocolate.  this could easily be a meal, as its thick viscous body and oily black color create an amazing beer experience

Bottle. Pours a black colour with a longlasting tan head. Roasted malty aroma with hints of coffee and chocolate. Flavor is roasted malty with nice hints of coffee and chocolate. Very roasted aftertaste with some bitterness. A nice one.

Black as pitch.  Big brown head.  Massive roast & dark malt aroma with light imperial stout notes of dark fruit and alcohol.  Massive body.  Neither chewy nor oily nor creamy nor tart...I think the word Â’solidÂ’ best describes the body.  ItÂ’s built like a brick shithouse.    The flavours start with an interplay between sweet & dark chocolate malts and insistent espresso roast.  There is a solid hoppy base for this intense, if simple, palate.  The finish is big with lingering roast, pungent alcohol and burnt fruitcake.  As it warms, it gets rather oaty (though not as fatty as most big oatmeal beers) and gains in milk chocolate character, which helps temper the intensity of the bitterness.  Well-made, rather interesting brew, especially considering the cliched concept.

Mocha, dark chocolate mousse aroma.  Looks more imperial than plain stout with its no head.  Flavor is per aroma and a little smoky.  Palate is smooth, full enough to be chewy, and mellow.  No jet fuel, a very smooth, nice stout, light sweetness, vinuousness.  It sounds like I had a rather different beer than clark previous to me got, mine was rich but not extreme flavorful and lacked carbonation.  Strange.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2006 October 2005 bottle from Engelsmann shared with SuIIy May 2006Bountiful, dark olivine-tinged coal-black body supports a ash-rubbed dark sienna brown head.  Nearly immovable and fills the sides of the glass with sticky lace.  Plenty of sediment lies undisturbed at the bottom of the bottle.The nose is packed with rich, sweet toffee-like malt notes that mix with a strong milk chocolate (also sweet) before becoming lightly fruity (almost a roasted barley vinousness) and finally dried out by coffee (black, rich, french roast-like coffee notes).  Sweet, creamy, vanilla-like sugars seem to crowd the very beginning of the aroma and the transition from start to finish is very abrupt and shocking to my nose.  With extended warming and breathing, I get a trace of alcohol in the nose, on the very end, mixed in with the bitter black notes and roast.Sweet chocolate, tempered lightly by poigant roasted notes (dried figs, coffee beans, salty toffee) builds up quickly, and through the middle the creamy sweet caramel, chocolate and vanilla-cream sugars really hang on the palate.  But everything is blown away by the massively bitter, acidic and darkly malted finish, laden with both hop acids and black coffee notes.The carbonation was a touch too loose, or perhaps I just drank it too warm?  Odd because itÂ’s naturally carbonated and formed a wonderful head (maybe more an influence from the oats?).  But residual sugars seemed to create a heaviness on the mouth, nearly syrupy with, perhaps, an oat-like gelatinousness? (though not cloying).  I love an unfiltered texture and a thick, rich body, but things just seemed a little too loose for all of the rich flavors.  I also was a little turned off by how powerful and forceful the flavors were.  It moves from very sweet to very bitter quickly.  Quite extreme, too much so for me, but certainly a well-made beer.  IÂ’d love to try another bottle (and hopefully will soon).
pitch black color. roasted malt and lots of coffee. full body very smooth. bitter complex and exellent.

Jet black color with a dark brown head. Dark malts and light coffee along with hints of light fruit covered in dark chocolate.  Full but not cloying or sticky as you might expect. Full mocha flavors, with a touch more dark roasted coffee. Mild acidity form the hops as well as dark malt and coffee. A light return to malt in the finish, but the coffee comes back in the linger. Thanks Tom for sharing.
Coffee and bitter chocolate aromas dominate this brew. Slight sweetness balanced by lovely bitter malty tones. This is a lovely beer.

Thanks for sharing Chris (Cquiroga).  A thick brown head sits atop the black body of this brew with a good amount of lacing hugging the glass.  The brew is slightly sweet, malty and roasty with a nice underlying coffee note.  Full bodied, smooth and a touch warming.  What a great stout.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2017 (Blind rating at sk8vikingÂ’s.) Pours black with a big foamy brown head. Sweet with some dryness / bitterness. Aromas of burnt malts and some coffee. Quite high carbonation. Crispy dry finish.

Bottled. Pitch black colour with huge brown head. Aroma is roasted malts and coffee with hints of dark chocolate. Flavour is roasted, coffeeish and toffee. Also some fruits and berries are noteable, though so weak I canÂ’t specify them. Great brew, where the aftertaste stays very roasted malt and long. Very wellbalanced, and stoutish indeed! Thanks to TBone_ who got it from Papsoe and shared it with me!

[Bottled] (BB 12/2006).
Opaque black, HUGE brown cloudy head. Dark chocolaty and roasted nose. Full-bodied. Hoppy, cold coffee, very roasted. Long bitter and roasted aftertast and very hoppy too. Extreme coffee stout ... for breakfast.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2006 Courtesy of Papsoe

Aroma is big with quality roasted coffee and roasted malts. Hints of darker fruits and even a tinge of blueberry are also present. After this a lighter wave of dark chocolate follows. Quite a range of aromas here. Excellent smell that is made unique by that mild fruit/blueberry accent. Body is very slightly brown tinted black and the head is a full three fingers thick, creamy and bubbly, mocha affair that is quite lasting. Fore is tart and acidic then strongly bitter with a blast of coffee. That fruity sweetness from the aroma appears in the middle, but it is more sugar sweet than blueberry/fruit sweet. The coffee notes dominate and while this has a certain smoothness it doesnÂ’t immediately strike me as an oatmeal beer. The finish is a blast of dark chocolate and VERY bitter strong dark cofffee. I donÂ’t want to say it is a let down because it is a fine beer, but the overall package wasnÂ’t as sublime as I anticipated.

Pitch black. Massive, thick, creamy tan head. Extremely roasted, sweet and chocolatey in aroma with some notes of coffee. Flavour is very roasted too, coffee, dark chocolate and some dark fruits. Dry mouthfeel. Full bodied, with a lingering bitterness in finish.

Thx to Bierkonig. Poors a pitch black beer with a huge dark brown head. The aroma is complex, sweet and notes of dark chocolate, coffeel. The flavour is sweet but balanced with a roasted maltyness, dark chocolate and coffee. The aftertaste is sweet with notes of coffee and alcohol. PERFECT BEER!

22oz bottle shared by ClarkVV on 5/26/06. Pours a very dark brown color with a big thick foamy tan head. Head slowly receedes to a few fingers worth. Nose is sweet malt and chocolate, some very nice dry notes are mixed in as well, like dry bakers chocolate? Palate is big and full with a nice oil slickness to it and a nice harshness to the finish. The nose now has a bit of mintiness to it.  Flavor is nice and dry, with some good hints of chocolate and some mint or other dry herb notes, light chocolate. A very nice earthy hop presence is felt as well. This flavor really sticks to your mouth and makes itself known. It is there for a while.

Thanks a lot to JensenTaster and BierkÃ¶nig for providing this in in shared will to us ;-) Nice opaque color with a fuzzy medium brown head. Intense chocolate nose also some charcoal. Intense Charcoal taste - that lasts long. Very intense roasted coffee beans and almond traces. The taste digs itself into the roof of the mouth and the tongue and builts up. Awesome Brew!!

Bottle. Courtesy of Mikkel & Jeppe Â– thx guys! Finally, after several requests from Mikkel, IÂ’ve pulled myself together to enter Beer Geek among some of the other Mikkeller beers in my ratings (more will follow). IÂ’ve rated this beer twice in my little black book Â– first rating was the last rating in a long line of ratings in one evening and IÂ’m still not sure as to what I wroteÂ…I ended up describing the palate as Â“smooth-smoothÂ”. Guess thatÂ’s Â“velvetÂ” in wino-language? Second time I rated this resulted in a more readable handwriting: This beer is pitch black! In VendelbomÃ¥l (dialect in the northern part of Jutland) it would be Â“swÃ¥ttÂ”. Head was like whipped chocolate Â– brown and delicious! Aroma of licorice, hops and treats! Yup, I was drivelling in pure expectation, knowing already what was in store for me. Taste is hoppy as Heaven, licorice as Paradise and palate is velvet as The Garden of Eden! This is the combined nectar of hopheads AND malt winos! If Mikkel and Christian shaved, IÂ’d kiss them!!! (let that be a reminder to you NOT to shave for the festival, unless you want to get intimate with a big, Beer Geek loving bum!) By the way: who in their right mind would drink anything else but beer for breakfast?

Big bitter-sweet chocolate nose - nice! Opaque motor-oil-brown, huge spongy rocky head. Pours thick. Roasted malt, coffee tastes, some tobacco, dry oaky end. lingering espresso bitter. Aggressive, but under control. Pushes the limits (hence the name?). Maybe too roasted at times, but not one dimensional. Excellent.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2011 Acquired in a trade with BierKonig. Thanks Jeppe! Bottle. Black body. Tall rigid brown head packed with medium sized bubbles and dense micro bubbles. Nose is rich coffee (espresso), licorice, hops, dark, bittersweet chocolate, and roasted malt. Taste is exquisite! Full, rich coffee flavors, strong roasty malts, burnt chocolate chip cookies, dark chocolate, slightly burnt oatmeal, light molasses and a touch of hops. Body i oily and has a full mouthfeel. Dense thick carbonation. Finishes with more coffee, roasted malts, and dark chocolate. Breakfast indeed! This is the breakfast of champions! Previously - 10, 4, 10, 5, 19
****RE-RATE****   Bottle. Black pour with a tall, fluffy brown head. Aroma is strong roasted malt, black, oily coffee beans, burnt oatmeal and light licorice. Taste is also strong roasted malt, burnt caramel, burnt oatmeal, dark chocolate, dark coffee and light licorice. Body is medium with a soft bubbly carbonation. Ends with more roasted malt, oatmeal, burnt caramel, dark chocolate and big coffee notes.

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2013 2013-03-21, bb Dec 2006, 7 years old, 10-5-9-4-18=46Probably the first commercial batch!Ink black color with generous brown head, persistent. Infinite roastiness, with wonderful coffee aroma, pungent, with waves of roasted macadamia, vanilla cream, tobacco. Good body structure, with smooth mouthfeel; excellent flavor of roasted malt, dark chocolate, tobacco, talk; correct bitterness, leading into a balanced and coffeish final, also drier now.No signs of age, lovely black pearl.2008-05-25, bottle 2 years old, 8-5-8-3-15=39Black color, with a creamy head.It has a very nice aroma of caramel and roasted malt, fresh. The body is thinner than I remembered, with strong roasted malt flavor and coffee, this getting maybe too strong at the end, for me; and liquorice. The black coffee aftertaste remains long in the mouth, which I donÂ’t exactly like too much (but with the attenuation, when drinking it with food, it gets much better).2006-05-04, fresh bottle, 8-5-8-4-16=41Black color; brown creamy head. Aroma of roasted malt, also some fruitiness on and off, light coffee. Good malty structure, not too thick, with a good combination of roasted malt, liquorice and coffee; all the elements are mixed well together. Strong final, long, with mostly roasted malt and some liquorice. Thanks Mikkel (and Jeppe) for storing this bottle for me.

Much thanks to BBB63 for sharing this one: Black pour with a dark tan head. Oats and coffe in the aroma. Flavor is loaded with coffee and roasted malts, some chocolate comes through as well. Very nice beer.

Bottle provided by Mads Berg and shared with the crew at the Hampton Inn Friday night tasting: Nearly opaque with reddish highlights topped by a small frothy tan head and some lace. The aroma has coffee (duh), oats (duh), roasted and burnt malt, grassy hops, clove, white pepper, non-aromatic pipe tobacco, and hint of prune.  The taste starts with a balance of smoky and mocha malt with a hoppy bitterness. Undertones of walnut, oatmeal, and pine as well. The finish has a lot of coffee but it seems in check all told. The feel is lively and sharp, a tad thin for the oats added, some mineral component as well.  Darn good, really balanced till the finish and enjoyable. If the palate was a bit thicker, it would a 4+ beer for me.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2007 Bottle:  Another rarity courtesy of BBB63 at the Hampton Inn Tasting (Friday).  Also received a bottle from Secret Santa (July 07).  Aroma has lots of black licorice, chocolate, and the slightest hints of vanilla.  It pours black with a moderate brown head that lasts a minute or so.  The flavor starts with a quick dose of black licorice that is instantly followed by moderate chocolate and very faint vanilla.  The finish has moderate amounts of black coffee with some bitter burnt notes.  The mouthfeel is slick and slightly oily.

Dense black, thick creamy dark tan head.  No doubt this would be prefect for breakfast.  Rich nose of cocoa and toasted vanilla beans, soft espresso roast coffee, and hints of berry.  Flavor jumps out with Starbucks type espresso (burnt), more cocoa, touches of caramel and toast.  This gets a nice semi-bitter hop finish that keeps that crazy malt bill well in check.  Full bodied, super-soft carbonation, ultra creamy, bitter-sweet finish.  Best oatmeal stout I ever tried.  Straight up fantastic...

Deep, opaque void with an enormous, persistent cocoa-colored head.  What an aromatic nose: cocoa, coffee, caramel, maple, piney hops, burnt grains, oily nuts, ash and probably a little molasses.  The body is thick and creamy, chuck full of soft, velvety carbonation.  The flavor doesnÂ’t seem huge due to the fact I usually drink Imperial Stouts when drinking stout, but itÂ’s got plenty of flavor and has tons of balance.  The roasted malts and burnt coffee are wonderful with the piney hops and moderately sweet residual sugars.  The piney hop kick at the end adds some bitterness, but not quite enough to handle the intense sweetness.  This is a hell of a beer and just as good, if not better, than the Founders offering of the same ilk.

Muddy reddish-brown body with a fading, oily brown head. Aroma is oaty with characters of plums, dark chocolate, rich caramel, mild coffee, and vanilla bean. Medium sweet malts, light acidity and some bitter roast. A great hop profile compliments this nicely. Big-time flavor, but substantially starchy in both taste and feel. A nice stout all-around. Thanks to hopdog and egajdzis for sharing.

500 mL bottle, via Sk8viking.  Pitch black pour, not unlike heavily used motor oil, with an incredible two finger mass of creamy brown head.  Good amount of sediment noted in bottle.  Aroma of roasted and burnt malt, espresso, light alcohol, caramel, and some chocolate.  Very dry roasted and burnt malt up front leading to and espresso and bitter finish.  Very soft and well rounded.  Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied and oily in texture with moderate fine bubbled carbonation.  Very good all around, only drawback that I noted was that as the beer reached room temp the alcohol flavor really came out a bit too much.

Bottle via trade with BierKonig - Thanks Jeppe! Consumed to celebrate my birthday - Pours very black with a healthy mocha head.  Aromas of chocolate, coffee, and some notes of dark fruit.  Flavor has alot of those same notes.  Big roasted malts, coffee, some chocolate.  Some definite earthy and smoky notes as well.  Palate is smooth and not overly carbonated.  Good mouthfeel.  Big roasty finish as well.  A very drinkable stout

Bottle.  Dark black pour...big brownish head accompanies.  Whew...nice choco-coffee aroma.  Flavor is big roasted malt, light sweetness, but not as much as anticipated.  Medium bodied and pretty slick.  More bitter than sweet, but I like the balance.  Very tasty....I wouldnÂ’t mind being called a beer geek if I could have this available all time!  Thanks Rene!!

Dark brown body w/ a reddish hue.  Sweet chocolate syrup and oatmeal in the aroma w/ a good coffee roast in the background.  Big roasty flavor wiht strong oatmeal oil and dark chocolate.  Meidum mouthfeel.  Great flavor - big stout elements.  A bigger mouthfeel would bring everything together more.

Huge thanks to erica nd steve for sharing this great beer.  Pours a deep dark brown, not as dark as most stouts of this abv.  Nice lasting tan head.  Slight tart earthy coffee aroma, lots of roasted barley and some chocolate malt.  Flavor is loaded with dark roasted malts, and nice deep crystal malts, toffee, chocolate, and slight smoke.  Very smooth mouthfeel and great lasting finish.  Very clean overall.

Dark black coloured stout, thick creamy brown head and intens coffee aroma. Smel is very rich, tons of coffee, cacao, tar, roasted malts and hops are jumping into your face. Taste is also very rich but this intens tasting stout stays unbelivable elegant. Taste is very clean. It is rich and light at the same time. Its wanting you to drink of it all the time. Coffee, cacao; tar, flowers and hops are all there at the richt spot. This is "BLACK GOLD". At CarloÂ’s Mikkeller tasting.

Much thanks to egajdzis & hopdog for this...
Appears a black color with a small brown hue and a small tan head that sticks around. Nice scattered lacing is left around the glass.
Smell is of cocoa, roasted barley, cream, coffee, caramel, and vanilla. Very American smelling stout...perhaps itÂ’s the hops?
Taste is of the same aromas with a nice roastiness to it.
Mouthfeel is roasty, mildly thin, with a coffee like bitterness lingering around.

Bottle acquired in joint trade. Poured a pitch black color with a large sized brown head. It just doesnÂ’t get any blacker than this. Aromas of coffee grounds, chocolate, smoky/ashy, caramel and cherries. Tastes of roast, chocolate, coffee (lighter than the aromas), vanilla and caramel. Smooth body that was way too easy to drink. Delicious.

Bottle. Tasting session with omhper and ante. Thanks Jeppe, for the bottle!Odd toasted hop-coffee (yes) aroma with some toffee thrown in. Medium roasted mild coffe (Blue Mountain?) and dark expensive chocolate taste. Hops are also present and gives a fruity accent. Powerful, full bodied and complex brew. Some licorice towards the end. Soft mouthfeel. Yes, I must be a beer geek!

Bottled.  Very black, brown head. Concentrated coffee aroma. Dryish, soft and rounded. The mouthfeel and relatice dryness makes it very drinkable despites itÂ’s near full body. Very roasty, dark chocolate is evident and there are notes of tobacco. Most dryish very roasty beers gets a metallic edge, but this has non of that. Instead it finishes with lots of espresso-like lare bitterness. Very well made. Justifies itÂ’s high rating.

Poured an opaque black color with a medium sized tan head, that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, smoke, vanilla beans, and dried fruits.  Taste of vanilla, smoke, light sweet malts, and a long roasted finish.  Soft and creamy mouthfeel.

Black, firm brown head. Loads of roasted coffee, cocoa, nuts and minty hops. Strong coffee flavour, notes of vanilla, nuts and hops. Full creamy mouthfeel. Long nutty aftertaste with roasted coffee and hops. Great beer and great name.

Thanks Tom, for bringing and sharing this one! Great pine and chocolate aroma with tons of roasted coffee.   Black with a bit of dark brown around the edges and a light tan head.  Sweet chocolate flavor with coffe (a light roast) and some oatmeal in the finish.   Creamy texture, nice body for a stout. A really good stout.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2006 HUGE thanks to CaptainCougar for sharing this one with us. Who does that? TOM DOES THAT! We are talking pitch black, medium brown head. The aroma strikes you, like a bowl of oatmeal covered in hersheys syrup, only instead of hersheys, GOOD chocolate! A fine brew... IÂ’d like a little more punch to it. Sure theres oatmeal and coffee, and its well blended, but to be honest, the ratings and hype made me expect something huge. This was well balanced and well brewed. Kudos.

Glorious stuff. ThereÂ’s not too much better than a well made stout IMHO. If all days started with this for breakfast then I sure as hell wouldnÂ’t get much done all day. Lots of the usual coffee in the aroma, the essential in all great breakfasts, along with some burnt grain. Good flavour with some lovely deep bitterness and a touch of salt. IÂ’d love to give this a run as the first or second of a session, rather than number 22. Cheers to Duff for lugging this down under.

Bottle, extra special thanks to CaptainCougar!  Poured a very deep, opaque brown with a well-retained cap of caramel head.  Nose was everything a guy can hope for in a sweet stout!... sweet milk chocolate, freshly mulled oats, and a saliva-inducing coffee blend.  Flavors were of fresh, medium roast coffee (hints of sour citrus from the blend, perhaps?), milk chocolate, and flaked oats.  Exceptionally smooth body with a low level of bitterness surrounding the tongue and pleasant citrus highlights.  Finish was long and elegant, full of coffee, oats, and chocolate.  Wow!

Opaque and pouring to a moderate viscosity, with a tan hair wisp head and some bubbly, beady lace.  Dark roasted aroma reveals some alcohol within.  Espresso drips onto a dark chocolate tort graced with black currant.  Bitter aromatic edge imparting the breakfast quotient of its namesake is unmistakable.  Full, bitter and breakfast flavor force leaves little to be desired.  Lick the coffee grinds off the countertop, Joel.  Vibrant dark chocolate and a double concoction of a super-charged tiramisu.  Heavy force on the palate produces enough love to be considered a morning romance and get me out the door in the morning with an endless smile across my face.  Burnt oatmeal and broiled milk chocolate, left together and untended for two minutes too long, and thereÂ’s no shying away from the flame.  Very tasty take leaves us with damnable, double dark chocolate and greasy mouthfuls of espresso.  ItÂ’d be all too easy to forget the food pyramid if I could start every day like this.  Lord, bless CaptainCougar for sharing this with us!

The aroma is coffee, oatmeal, delicately balanced.  The beer pours to a very dark brown body.  The flavor is very good.  Coffee, chocolate, oatmeal.  Really well made and balanced.  The palate is medium-full bodied, chewy, silken.  GREAT.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2010 RATING # 1000 thanks to Tom for sharing.
Jet black pour w/ a thick tan head and some great lacing.  Aroma is simply delicious!  Hugely roasted, coffee & chocolate notes sweet w/ a tiny hint of hop.  Full palate coats well and nicely creamy.  Flavor is roast grains and malt nice touches of coffee & chocolate a dry touch of bitterness.  This is some damn good stuff.

ReRate on tap: has become way to bitter and 1 dimensional w/ a weaker pal.  No longer a great beer.  From 10-5-8-4-17 to:
9-5-6-3-13

50 cl bottle. Served in NÃ¸rrebro Bryghus ale glass. Black w/ limited tan head. The aroma is impressively roasted, coffeeish, chocolatey and made seriously impressive by an assertive citrus hop presence. Stunning. The flavor is extremely coffeeish, powerfully bitter, well-hopped, chocolatey, very complex, and yet perfectly harmonic. Long, long, bitter finish. Very smooth, pleasant mouthfeel. Good drinkability. A truly impressive stout.

Pours a jet black color with a ring of light brown lace. Excellent and complex aroma of coacoa, coffee, roasted malt and citrusy hops. Again the words excellent and complex have to be used to describe the flavor, coacoa, coffee, chocolate, roasted malt and citrusy hops work well to provide a blend I wouldnÂ’t mind having every morning for the rest of my life, the flavor finishes bitter. The body is full with an adequate dry texture and moderate carbonation. This is probably the best stout (not imperial) that I ever had, itÂ’s so rich and complex.

Amped-up oatmeal offers aromas of thick chocolate and coffee with a huge orange-citrus and resiny pine hop profile and some light hints of alcohol.  Opaque dark brown body is topped by a low, fine bubbled, tan head that recedes to a lasting cover.  Everpresent chocolate, coffee and orange flavours blend wonderfully in the build-up towards a very assertive bitterness.  Full bodied mouthfeel never feels heavy.  Rich, thick, luxurious texture with moderate carbonation.  Each new sip leaves me wanting more.  I wish that I had the luxury of sipping on a bottle or two of this for an evening.  Bottle sampled with beerbuzzmontreal, Goldorak, MartinT, muzzlehatch, Olivier_MTL, Rastacouere and Siroy.

(Rateings # 800) 50 cl bottle. Yeast at the bottom. Pitch black colour with a nice brown head. Aroma of smooth roastedness, coffee, liquorice and some alcohol. Great tastefull flavour with smooth roastedness, coffee, chocolate and ends up with a nice warm feeling from the alcohol. Some bitter noteable and very tasty endeed. Very good to breakfast.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009 (Bottle 50 cl) Pours completely black and opaque with a thick, creamy and very goodloking light brown head. Burned aroma with hints of coffee. Very soft and smooth mouthfeel. The body is - surprisingly - not very full, actually the beer is scaringly easy to drink. Very distinct accents of burned malts and a somewhat burned edge. Lightly burned bitterness. I believe the brewers could easily turn up the coffee presence. 170306

Bottle... Pitch black ale with a large, creamy, tan head. Excellent retention. The aroma is of chocolate, espresso and  caramel... everything deeply roasted and rich. Lightly sweet flavor balanced by light bitterness. Charcoal, mocha, ash and vanilla. Full-bodied and milky with soft carbonation. Finishes dry, burnt and softly bitter. Thanks go out to JensenTaster for sending the bottle from across the pond!

Very black beer, creamy deep beige foam. Nose is all coffee, nuts, burned apple pie, black malts, honey, the beer has a good balans beween burned bitters and herbal bitters of hops. Taste is very present. Again loads of coffee, burned malts, black caramel, some mint and fresh herbs. This is a medium boddied stout with an outstanding drikabelity. It is not heavey and the balans is one and all harmony. Indeed a stout to die for. Thanks Carlo !

Black opaque beer with good, creamy dark beige-brown head. First impression is stale coffee, but followed immediately by warm, rich malts. Vaguely sweetish and cigarette ashes. Extremely roasted taste with mounting background bitterness. Smokey, tobacco, coffee. Gets burnt-emptier, like a dry stout, but never becoming thin. Every new sip has a short glimpse of these warming malts, both nasal and retronasal. Very slick, medium body but not watery texture. My first impression was the morning coffee cup of a chain smoker - but after a few sips the welcoming warmth stays. I just would rather not have this for breakfast, if you know what I mean...

Thanks to CaptainCougar for sharing this.  Dense opaqe black pur with a small head.  Roasty bitter chocolate aroma, with lots of bitter coffee.  A fair amount of chocolate malty flavors, and coffee is present but not overwhelming.  Fairly smooth body, and warming.  Very nice beer.

Sampled at the "letÂ’s piss off Clark" tasting, thanks to Siroy for supplying this rarity
Absolute darkness, with a near-perfect mocha head.  Call me mister bleak, but I just love the look of a good stout.
A very bold mixture of coffee and hops that dance along my nostril cavities, each taking the lead for a while then leaving the other in charge to do his thing.  Coffee smelled freshly torrefied with no acrid features, yet the hops were youthfull and green, sometimes piney, sometimes more citrucy with orange notes, and it works.
Malt profile is rich, roasted with plenty of dark high-cocoa content chocolate, and again the hops really make their presence known without messing things up.  I wouldnÂ’t have thought this mix would work, but then again I know tons of people who go for the one-two punch of a tall glass of OJ with an expresso chaser in the morning.  Kudos to the brewer who had the balls to give this a shot, make it turn out great, and name it with a friendly wink to his niche clientele.

Very intens warm black color with an outstanding Beige-brown creamy froth. Nose is rich, exeptionnally well balanced, chocolaty, has tons of softly torrified brasilian coffee beans, hints of tar and salty Dutch drop. There even is a touch of dried fruits, PX, Malaga wine and blackend candi sugar on top of a crÃ¨me brullÃ©e. Now the taste. This is what i call a stout ! It has it all. Not the blackest, the highest in alcohol or the most powerfull of stouts, Bud IMO the best, most elegant and most complex one i ever had. Taste is soft, smooth, very long and perfectly balanced. When you say chocolat, it has impressions of the best of chocolats. When you say coffee, it is the best fresh torrified coffee you can fiend. The mouthfeel is sliky, very vanilla like, has a fine round body, of burned malts, honey, burned breadcrust and sugar bud also has a complex bitterness of hops and wild spring flowers. I never had a boost of powerfull aromaÂ’s like this before. The beauty of it is that the composition and the balance is perfect. A MASTERPIECE signed by Mikkel and Kristian. I want it in my museum !!!

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2006 [ Bottled ; chilled ; BB Dec 06 ]

A fully lasting small frothy brown head that tops up a almost opaque black body. Moderate lacing. No particules. No bubbles. Aroma presents malt being heavy burnt coffee/chocolate.. while hops are very high citrusy for the style, it hit me ... Yeast character is light dough. Also, there are faint evocations of vanilla . Initial flavor is heavily bitter chocolate/coffee grain.. while development presents an array of subtilities.. raisin/figs/dates/wood... Finish is long..  Full body... creamy texture... Soft carbonation... Wondeful oatmeal stout and another superb product form this brewery. Thanks Papsoe!

500 ml bottle, Montreal Sourheads gathering on February 26 2006.  Thick, full black body with a dark lasting somewhat foamy head....gobs and gobs of woody, resinous hops are the first thing the nose essays, dark chocolaty-espresso malts are also present and just a touch of Burgundy....the tongue is instantly assaulted by vastly bitter chocolate, part of a harsh burnt-coffee-malt complexity that lingers through to the finish....but sweet, milky lighter cocoa tastes arrive after midpalate, taming the roaring cowboy coffee that is boiling away at the back of the throat...smooth, creamy, even milky mouthfeel belies the rich bitterness, doesnÂ’t ever tame it but makes it oh-so-palatable....touches of raisin and light wine deepen the mystery, the beauty.  No disappointment, this.

Thanks to CaptainCougar for sharing another treat.  Poured a very dark brown to black color with a small brown head.  Pleasant roasted aroma.  sweet coffee and a good amount of chocolate fill the nose.  The flavor starts out with chocolate and then moves on to a roasted sweet malt. Black coffee bitterness is located on the finish.  Mildly warming with a medium body.

Pours a rich opaque with dark brown edges and a frothy, nicely-lacing light brown head.  Aroma of mildly sweet milk chocolate and coffee with some light roast.  Body starts with a light caramel sweetness, some dark fruity notes and a lingering light coffee presence.  Nicely balanced and very drinkable.  IÂ’m guessing itÂ’s smooth body comes from the large amount of oats.  A nice coffee stout.  Thanks sk8viking!
Pours a pure balck with a creamy head. Big aroma, with the imperial stout old fruit and coffee. A bit of alcohol underneath. Very mild astringency. good.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2014 Any first impressions?
-A fine cloth of foam lingers atop the near opaque darkness.
-Citrusy hops coexist in grateful harmony with the roasted coffee beans, married by a high chocolate priestess.
-Coffee beans and 90% dark chocolate blend admirably well.
-Dry roastiness reigns supreme in the Â’07 version.
-The relatively low carbonation suits the silky body perfectly, making it very drinkable while showcasing its wealth.

What if you dig deeper?
-Resinous, wooden hop bitterness subtly surfaces, adding complexity and diversity to this already unique creation.
-Raisins and vanilla dwell within the coffee.
-This isnÂ’t just another coffee stout, but rather a creative twist on oatmeal stouts, and a beautifully crafted one at that.
-Another stellar performance from a brewery I would definitely encourage often if I had the opportunity of sampling them more easily.
-The Â’07 might be a little thinner than the Â’06?
